However, new and interesting attempts have been made for developing methods for including also the anaerobic rumen fungi in the rumen microbiome analysis [<xref rid="B50-jof-07-00207" ref-type="bibr">50</xref>]. Based on the results of the current study, showing rumen fungi to be top ranking among all fungal species analyzed we hypothesize that the rumen fungi play a role as Key Stone species, playing a more prominent functional role than the ratio of fungal biomass and fungal DNA constitute as compared to bacterial biomass and DNA present in the rumen (fungi estimated to be between 8 and 12% of rumen microbiome) [<xref rid="B51-jof-07-00207" ref-type="bibr">51</xref>]. Thus far, none of the enzymes from rumen fungi or rumen bacteria have been industrially exploited. One reason being their anaerobic adaptation contrasting the predominantly aerobic industrial processing, another, that the complexity of the cellulosome structure is difficult to take advantage of in industrial fermentations and biorefinery processing. Most promising could be to use rumen fungi in a probiotic manner or possibly more advanced by combining it with special feed components (substrate oligoes and/or selected enzymes) to strengthen feed conversion and digestion at the same time as methane emission is reduced.</p>
        <p>Recent studies have investigated different biomass degrading capacity among closely related species [<xref rid="B52-jof-07-00207" ref-type="bibr">52</xref>]. The results of the current study open for studying the variation among species, belonging to the same genus in both biomass-degrading capacity and function specificity diversity. More specifically, to elucidate this issue we analyzed comparatively the high number of species by ranking separately all species of the following five genera, <italic>Aspergillus</italic> (103), <italic>Penicillium</italic> (48), <italic>Fusarium</italic> (180), <italic>Colletotrichum</italic> (34). The preliminary conclusion from this is that variation among species within one genus apparently follows two different patterns. <italic>Aspergillus</italic>, <italic>Fusarium</italic> and <italic>Penicillium</italic> all have some species which have a very rich enzyme portfolio, in both total capacity and function diversity, ranked among the top 100. However, these genera also have species ranked in the middle part and even in the lower part of the total list of 1932 species. This result coincides with [<xref rid="B14-jof-07-00207" ref-type="bibr">14</xref>], where an enzyme profile relatedness analysis was made (by binary intergeneric comparison of &#x201C;Function;Family&#x201D; observations), dividing <italic>Aspergillus</italic> and <italic>Penicillium</italic> into sections. These sections were shown to be held together by the observations they shared to have as well as by the observations they shared not having. In contrast to this stands the ranking pattern of species of <italic>Colletotricum</italic>. This genus exhibits a pattern where the sequenced species are ranked rather close to each other, within a narrower part of the ranking list. Similar pattern is seen for species of <italic>Diaporthe</italic>, where in all seven species are included in this study, of which as much as four are placed among the top10 in biomass degrading capacity. Thus, the genus <italic>Diaporthe</italic> as such appears to be a real hotspot in enzyme biomass degrading capacity (see <xref rid="jof-07-00207-t001" ref-type="table">Table 1</xref> and <xref ref-type="app" rid="app1-jof-07-00207">Table S1</xref>).</p>
        <p>The term Redundancy Multiplication Score, RMS, is here introduced as a quantitative measure for characterizing different evolutionary trends in optimizing biomass degrading capacity (see <xref rid="jof-07-00207-t004" ref-type="table">Table 4</xref>): Highest RMS was found among anaerobic fungi and in the exceptional Basidiomycete, <italic>M. citricolor</italic>. The lowest RMS was found in species of the ascomycetous genera <italic>Colletotricum, Diaporthe</italic>, and <italic>Coniochaeta</italic>; notably, equally low RMS found for species of these three genera, both among enzymes active on the highly complex pectin substrate as well as on the much simpler cellulose. A preliminary conclusion is that RMS is primarily varying between fungal genera; and exceptionally high RMS is found in anaerobic fungi.</p>
      </sec>
      <sec id="sec4dot2-jof-07-00207">
        <title>4.2. Applied Perspectives</title>
        <p>Improved use of the global biological resources is urgently needed. We currently lose as much as approximately 35% as food waste [<xref rid="B53-jof-07-00207" ref-type="bibr">53</xref>] and estimated 15% more by not upgrading the food and non-food processing side-streams to their full potential [<xref rid="B5-jof-07-00207" ref-type="bibr">5</xref>]. Hereby all in all loosing, about half of all food and feed produced. This is a scary fact but most importantly, it provides a perspective of hope for improved food security by upgrading what was hitherto wasted; and it accentuates the need for new research in fungal carbohydrate active enzymes. Biotechnology, including use of enzymes to accomplish a range of conversions, is an integral part of accelerating the transition to a more circular economy, including improved use of the biological resources through increased resource circularity and production of bio-based substitutes for fossil-based materials and chemicals [<xref rid="B54-jof-07-00207" ref-type="bibr">54</xref>]. Plant biomass, bio- and agro-industrial waste streams, and even aquatic biomass and certain synthetic materials (e.g., plastic) must be utilized and/or recycled more efficiently to support the development of a sustainable bioeconomy. The target aim is increased &#x201C;biologization&#x201D; of the economy to help transform waste and materials into new products with defined, desirable properties [<xref rid="B55-jof-07-00207" ref-type="bibr">55</xref>]. Conscientious development of a sustainable bioeconomy provides an opportunity to decouple increased resource consumption from economic growth. Since the complexity and diversity of different biological substrates is reciprocated by the plethora of enzymes evolved to convert and degrade them, the diversity of enzymes is poised to help transform waste and materials into new products with defined, desirable properties. The new method presented in the present report for identifying the species, richest in biomass digestive enzymes can open for a wide spectrum of new inventions and new applications. A summary overview can be achieved by not distinguishing the specific ranking 1&#x2013;10, but simply including all species with Top10 scorings on more than one substrate. Based on this principle the following Hotspot species overview is achieved (see <xref rid="jof-07-00207-t005" ref-type="table">Table 5</xref>).</p>
        <p>As shown in <xref rid="jof-07-00207-t005" ref-type="table">Table 5</xref>, <italic>P. roridum</italic> has amazing industrial enzyme potential, excelling on all four substrates; if it was not for its toxicity profile. Would a knock-out or block of the mycotoxin synthesis pathways be a feasible, regulatory-acceptable strategy to pursue? Would this strategy be workable also for, e.g., <italic>Colletotricum</italic>?</p>
        <p>In a broader perspective the results presented in the present study hint at a major avenue of new research for identification of novel fungal enzymes, function specificity diversity and degrading capacity hotspots: The data (i) provide an expanded basis for identifying new candidates for non-GMO production hosts for new types of biomass degrading enzyme blends, optimized by nature. The findings presented clearly outline that species for non-GMO enzyme blend production organisms should be chosen, depending on which primary cell wall components that are the main targets for biomass upgrading. (ii) help identifying candidate species for new whole-cell biocatalyst systems, suitable for biorefinery processing. (iii) provide a new foundation for identifying candidates suitable as new production host systems for recombinant production of mono-component enzymes and enzyme blends: blends inspired by linkage analysis, learning from Nature, how to optimize enzyme blends for specific types of biomass, see, e.g., <italic>M. citricolor</italic>, exceptional strong in pectin and lignin degradation but also efficient in cellulose and hemicellulose (symptoms in <xref ref-type="fig" rid="jof-07-00207-f001">Figure 1</xref>). (iv) contribute to improved, evidence-based and intelligent strategies for understanding for discovery of new and improved enzymes and enzyme blends for efficient and value adding biomass conversion.</p>
        <p>Increased understanding of the fungal CAZyme portfolio provides insight into the role of biomass degrading enzymes for fungi of different lifeforms, eco-physiological specializations and taxonomic affiliation; exemplified by the spectrum of iconic species identified as enzyme hotspots. The result of this study can therefore be used as basis for studying evolution of the fungal digestive enzyme system and for improving the understanding of possible co-evolution of enzymes and metabolite profiles in fungi and directly for providing a new conceptual understanding of the role of fungi in biomass conversion and carbon-recycling. Additionally, for finding new hotspots of biologically active secondary metabolites, e.g., for drug discovery. Analogously, whether there is any possible connection between fungal CAZyme profiles and mycotoxin production calls for further study. Experience from antimicrobial metabolite discovery (unpublished), revealed that fungi with a strong capacity for plant cell wall degradation is a hotspot also for finding antimicrobial metabolites. Studies next in line for learning from Nature is to further compare enzymes originating from different species and to look deeper into the different enzyme systems (e.g., different CAZyme profiles) employed by fungi to degrade biomass. Specifically, such additional work involves analyzing the LPMO profiles and elucidating the composition of the sets of &#x201C;Function;Family&#x201D; observations of the species here revealed to be global hotspots; and obviously to make a similar &#x201C;Function;Family&#x201D; observation-based analysis, for identifying bacterial hotspots with regard to enzyme function specificity diversity and overall degrading capacity.</p>
      </sec>
    </sec>
  </body>

      <ref id="B10-jof-07-00207">
        <label>10.</label>
        <element-citation publication-type="journal">
          <person-group person-group-type="author">
            <name>
              <surname>Jones</surname>
              <given-names>D.R.</given-names>
            </name>
            <name>
              <surname>Thomas</surname>
              <given-names>D.</given-names>
            </name>
            <name>
              <surname>Alger</surname>
              <given-names>N.</given-names>
            </name>
            <name>
              <surname>Ghavidel</surname>
              <given-names>A.</given-names>
            </name>
            <name>
              <surname>Douglas</surname>
              <given-names>I.G.</given-names>
            </name>

              <surname>Wade</surname>

  <floats-group>
    <fig id="jof-07-00207-f001" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <label>Figure 1</label>
      <caption>
        <p>Flow diagram describing the steps from downloading the full fungal genomes from NCBI and prediction of genomic proteins using AUGUSTUS. The carbohydrate-active enzymes were assigned a CAZy family and molecular function prediction via CUPP (see text). The predicted Function;Family observations were then assigned to their respective target substrates. The * indication added as fourht number in some EC numbers (molecular function numbers) indicate that no full EC number is available in the CAZy database. A similar molecular function (same EC number) from two different CAZy families are considered as two different observations by combining the EC number and the CAZy family into a combined string.</p>
      </caption>
      <graphic xlink:href="jof-07-00207-g001"/>
    </fig>
    <fig id="jof-07-00207-f002" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <label>Figure 2</label>
      <caption>
        <p>Attack of American Coffee Spot, by <italic>Mycena citricolor.</italic> (<bold>a</bold>) on coffee leaves, leading to total degradation of attacked areas, forming conspicuous holes in the leaves. (<bold>b</bold>) Minute fruiting bodies (caps) of <italic>M. citricolor</italic> invading coffee berries. The berry is strongly affected by the fungal infection, causing brown necrotic tissue. The entire infected area is sunken in, flattening the shape of the infected coffee fruit. In short, the figure hints the effect of a plant pathogen with a powerful, pectinolytic as well as ligninolytic secretome of biomass degrading enzymes. Photos: Andrew Dominick. University of Wisconsin-La Crosse and Direcction General de Sanidad Vegetal, Sagarpa (Secretaria de Agricultura Ganaderia Desarrollo Rural Pesca y Alimentacion), Mexico.</p>
      </caption>
      <graphic xlink:href="jof-07-00207-g002"/>
    </fig>
    <fig id="jof-07-00207-f003" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <label>Figure 3</label>
      <caption>
        <p>Pie chart representation of representation (in number of species) of fungal phyla in the upper most part of the list of Total biomass-degrading capacity: (<bold>a</bold>): 1&#x2013;500, (<bold>b</bold>): 500&#x2013;1000 and (<bold>c</bold>): 1000&#x2013;1932. Ascomycota species dominates from 1&#x2013;1000; Basidiomycota grow from 22 to 86 to 335 from upper part to lower part of the ranking list. All 8 fungal phyla are represented in the second half of the ranked listing of in all 1932 species, although some are in such low numbers that values are not visible in the charts, so numbers have been added with the phylum name. Sequencing projects are still biased towards over-representation of Ascomycota and under-representation of especially Chytridiomycota, and Blastocladiomycota.</p>
      </caption>
      <graphic xlink:href="jof-07-00207-g003"/>
    </fig>
    <table-wrap id="jof-07-00207-t001" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <object-id pub-id-type="pii">jof-07-00207-t001_Table 1</object-id>
      <label>Table 1</label>
      <caption>
        <p>Listing of the ten top-ranked species with regard to biomass degrading capacity, (all observations included), specifying the number of &#x201C;Function;Family&#x201D; observations. The table includes ranking according to &#x201C;Total&#x201D; (A), followed by ranking according to enzyme observations with affinity for each of the target substrates, Cellulose (B), Xylan (C), Pectin (D) and Lignin (E). The total list of observations for the analyzed 1932 genomes is given in <xref ref-type="app" rid="app1-jof-07-00207">Table S1</xref>.</p>
      </caption>

    <table-wrap id="jof-07-00207-t002" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <object-id pub-id-type="pii">jof-07-00207-t002_Table 2</object-id>
      <label>Table 2</label>
      <caption>
        <p>Listing of the ten top-ranked species with regard to enzyme function specificity diversity (including only unique observations), specifying the number of &#x201C;Function;Family&#x201D; observations. The table includes ranking according to &#x201C;Total&#x201D; (A), followed by ranking according to enzyme observations with affinity for each of the target substrates, Cellulose (B), Xylan (C), Pectin (D) and lignin (E). (*) indicates more species with same number of observations. The total list of observations for the analyzed 1932 genomes is given in <xref ref-type="app" rid="app1-jof-07-00207">Table S1</xref>.</p>
      </caption>
      <table frame="hsides" rules="groups">
        <thead>
          <tr>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-top:solid thin;border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">A Ranked: Total </th>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-top:solid thin;border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Taxonomy</th>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-top:solid thin;border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">
</th>
            <th colspan="5" align="center" valign="middle" style="border-top:solid thin;border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1">Target Substrate of Encoded CAZymes</th>
          </tr>
          <tr>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Species</th>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Class</th>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Phylum</th>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Cellulose</th>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Pectin</th>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Xylan</th>

    <table-wrap id="jof-07-00207-t004" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <object-id pub-id-type="pii">jof-07-00207-t004_Table 4</object-id>
      <label>Table 4</label>
      <caption>
        <p>Left column is names of top scoring sets of species with total-ranked observations (including redundant observations); the scores are given in second column. The third column from the left is the number of unique &#x201C;Function;Family&#x201D; observations of the same sets of degrading capacity Top ranking species. The right-hand column is the ratio, Redundant over Unique observations, named as Redundancy Multiplication Score. * marks the species/substrate with the strongest (&gt;8) Redundancy Multiplication factor; &#xA4; marks the species with the lowest (&lt;3) Redundancy Multiplication Score.</p>
      </caption>

      <title-group>
        <article-title>Water-Transmitted Fungi Are Involved in Degradation of Concrete Drinking Water Storage Tanks</article-title>
      </title-group>
      <contrib-group>
        <contrib contrib-type="author">

          <license-p>Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.         </license>
      </permissions>
      <abstract>
        <p>Global warming, globalization, industrialization, and the rapidly growing population at present increasingly affect the production of safe drinking water. In combination with sustainable bio-based or recycled materials, used for water distribution systems, these factors promote emerging pathogens, including fungi. They can proliferate in oligotrophic water systems, affect the disinfection process, degrade building materials, and cause diseases in humans. In this study, we explored fungal-based degradation of modern concrete water storage tanks and the presence of fungi in chlorinated drinking water at the entrance and exit of the tanks. The degradation potential of isolated 52 fungal strains and their growth at different oligotrophic conditions was tested in vitro. Forty percent of strains grew at extremely oligotrophic conditions, and 50% classified as aerophilic. Two-thirds of tested strains produced acids, with <italic>Penicillium</italic> strains as the best producers. Only 29.7% of the strains were able to grow at 37 &#xB0;C, and none of them was isolated from drinking water at consumers&#x2019; taps. Although not yet part of the guidelines for building materials in contact with drinking water, fungi should be taken into consideration in case of visible degradation. Their number of consumers&#x2019; endpoints should be checked to exclude possible health risks for consumers.</p>
      </abstract>
      <kwd-group>
        <kwd>degradation</kwd>
        <kwd>chlorination</kwd>
        <kwd>drinking water</kwd>
        <kwd>environmental factors</kwd>
        <kwd>fungal contaminants</kwd>
        <kwd>growth of fungi</kwd>
        <kwd>materials in contact with drinking water</kwd>
        <kwd>water storage tanks</kwd>
      </kwd-group>
    </article-meta>
  </front>
  <body>
    <sec sec-type="intro" id="sec1-microorganisms-09-00160">
      <title>1. Introduction</title>
      <p>During the 19th and 20th centuries, humanity was driven by modern technical development and rapid urbanization. Since water is essential for life and its presence was regularly needed also for industrial development, most urban centres evolved next to the main water sources. This led to water pollution and caused many disease outbreaks [<xref rid="B1-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">1</xref>]. Increasing knowledge in the fields of medicine, microbiology and chemistry established the connection between the presence of pathogens in water with diseases and implemented water cleaning procedures and the necessity for water quality monitoring [<xref rid="B2-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">2</xref>]. These procedures prevented many deaths and contributed to a prolonged life span. Nowadays human population faces different threats. The world is quickly changing due to global warming [<xref rid="B3-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">3</xref>], increasing globalisation, industrialisation, and growing population. Care for enough safe drinking water remains one of humanity&#x2019;s most important global goals [<xref rid="B4-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">4</xref>].</p>
      <p>The current legislation includes the monitoring of many microbes, particularly the causative agents of gastrointestinal illnesses, however, listed global changes also promote the growth of other microorganisms, recognized as emerging pathogens, but not yet included in drinking water regulations [<xref rid="B5-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">5</xref>,<xref rid="B6-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">6</xref>]. Among them, the members of the fungal kingdom stepped into the forefront [<xref rid="B7-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">7</xref>].</p>
      <p>The presence of fungi in water has been known for a long time. Usually, the fungi have been connected to changes in taste, color, and odor of water [<xref rid="B4-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">4</xref>,<xref rid="B8-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">8</xref>,<xref rid="B9-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">9</xref>], but lately, they have become increasingly recognized as emerging opportunistic pathogens, raising health concerns [<xref rid="B4-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">4</xref>]. Mixed fungal bacterial biofilms often cause problems in industries, depending on the water sources used [<xref rid="B8-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">8</xref>]. Nevertheless, there is still no uniform legislation on the building materials used in safe drinking water production. These choices depend on the country&#x2019;s authorities and industrial financial budget [<xref rid="B10-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">10</xref>,<xref rid="B11-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">11</xref>]. Another aspect is the sustainable use of water and energy, that in combination with bio-based or recycled materials, often promotes the growth of sturdy fungal biofilms [<xref rid="B12-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">12</xref>,<xref rid="B13-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">13</xref>]. The World Health Organisation (WHO) reported and associated with contamination of wet materials species <italic>Aspergillus flavus, A. versicolor, Cladosporium cladosporioides, C. herbarum, C. sphaerospermum, Mucor circinelloides</italic> and <italic>Rhizopus oryzae</italic> [<xref rid="B14-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">14</xref>]. Moreover, species of the genera <italic>Acremonium, Alternaria, Candida, Debaryomyces, Fusarium, Kluyveromyces, Meyerozyma</italic>, <italic>Rhodotorula, Penicillium, Stachybotrys</italic> and <italic>Trichoderma</italic> were reported as biodegraders of materials used for water transport [<xref rid="B15-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">15</xref>,<xref rid="B16-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">16</xref>]. The most commonly isolated fungi on the damp walls covered with plaster, wallpaper, and gypsum were <italic>Acremonium</italic> spp., <italic>Penicillium chrysogenum</italic>, <italic>Stachybotrys</italic> spp., <italic>Ulocladium</italic> spp., and <italic>Phoma</italic> spp. On the contrary, concrete coatings were more likely colonized by the fungi <italic>Sporothrix</italic> spp., <italic>Chaetomium</italic> spp., and <italic>Penicillium</italic> spp. In addition, <italic>Aspergillus fumigatus, A. melleus, A. niger, A. ochraceus, Chaetomium</italic> spp., <italic>Mucor racemosus</italic>, and <italic>M. spinosus</italic> [<xref rid="B15-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">15</xref>] are often present on the concrete, final layers and adhesives (cork, linoleum and glue). The ubiquitary present fungal genus, regardless of the type of damaged material, was <italic>Penicillium</italic> [<xref rid="B15-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">15</xref>]. Plastic materials, silicone, and rubber are colonized by <italic>Candida</italic> spp., <italic>Cystobasidium sloofiae, Magnusiomyces capitatus, Meyerozyma guilliermondii, Naganishia</italic> spp., <italic>Rhodotorula mucilaginosa</italic>, and melanized black yeasts <italic>Phialophora</italic> spp. and <italic>Rhinocladiella similis</italic> [<xref rid="B4-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">4</xref>]. Biodegradation and deterioration of these materials are due to fungal production of organic acids [<xref rid="B17-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">17</xref>,<xref rid="B18-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">18</xref>], precipitation of minerals, leaching, and after extended periods of fungal growth also mechanical degradation (e.g., scaling, peeling, cracking) of the material [<xref rid="B19-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">19</xref>]. These changes do not only cause water leakage and expenses due to clogging; they also negatively affect chlorination, taste, color, and odor of water [<xref rid="B8-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">8</xref>]. </p>
      <p>The aim of the present study was to determine the presence, abundance, and diversity of fungi in chlorinated water entering 1.5 years old concrete water storage tanks already showing degradation, seen as local scaling and discoloration. We isolated and identified fungi actively involved in the colonization and degradation of ceilings in these tanks. Additionally, we followed the possible transmission of these fungi in the water distribution system, to the tap water end, in order to assess their potential effect on consumers&#x2019; health. </p>
    </sec>
    <sec id="sec2-microorganisms-09-00160">
      <title>2. Materials and Methods</title>
      <sec id="sec2dot1-microorganisms-09-00160">
        <title>2.1. Sampling of Drinking Water and Materials in Contact with Drinking Water, and Cultivation of Fungal Strains</title>
        <p>Samples of 1.5 L of water were taken from 8 sampling points (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="microorganisms-09-00160-f001">Figure 1</xref>) in sterile containers as described by the standard SIST ISO 5667-5:2007. Samples were transported to the laboratory and processed immediately. Physico-chemical parameters of water samples were measured as required in Drinking Water Directive (98/83/EC) [<xref rid="B5-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">5</xref>] at Komunala Novo mesto d.o.o., Slovenia, by trained personnel. Parameters included temperatures of water and air, concentrations of disinfectant, electric conductivity, pH, color, smell, taste, turbidity, and visible presence of sediment. </p>
        <p>For analysis of fungal presence, aliquots of 100 mL were filtered through 0.45 mm membrane filters (Merck, Millipore, Darmstadt, Germany). Filters were placed on solid media Dichloran Rose Bengal Agar (DRBC; Oxoid Ltd., Oslo, Norway) and Malt Extract Agar with the addition of chloramphenicol (MEA+Ch) to prevent bacterial growth. After visible growth of fungi, colonies on 10 aliquots of 100 mL were counted and colony-forming units per liter (CFU/L) were calculated. </p>
        <p>Samples from concrete and metal materials in contact with drinking water were taken from water storage tanks in Lutr&#x161;ko selo and Gorenja vas (both Novo mesto, Slovenia) by rubbing 1 cm<sup>2</sup> of area with sterile cotton swabs (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="microorganisms-09-00160-f001">Figure 1</xref>), soaked in sterile saline solution. Swab samples were inoculated in duplicates by rubbing the whole area of the DRBC and MEA+Ch media.</p>
        <p>All plates were incubated at 25 &#xB0;C and 37 &#xB0;C for 5 to 7 days. After visible growth of fungi, colonies were counted and colony-forming units (CFU/L and CFU/cm<sup>2</sup>) were calculated. All morphologically different strains were transferred to fresh Malt Extract Agar (MEA) plates and later permanently stored in the Ex Culture Collection of the Infrastructural Centre Mycosmo, MRIC UL, Slovenia (<uri xlink:href="http://www.ex-genebank.com/">http://www.ex-genebank.com/</uri>), at the Department of Biology, Biotechnical Faculty, University of Ljubljana.</p>
      </sec>
      <sec id="sec2dot2-microorganisms-09-00160">
        <title>2.2. Extraction of Genomic DNA and Identification of Fungi</title>
        <p>All cultures were grown on MEA prior to the extraction of the genomic DNA. DNA of filamentous fungi was extracted from 5 days old cultures by mechanical lysis of mycelia as recommended by Van den Ende and de Hoog [<xref rid="B20-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">20</xref>]. DNA from 3 days old yeast cultures was extracted with PrepMan Ultra reagent (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, USA) according to the manufacturer&#x2019;s instructions. Obtained DNA samples were stored at &#x2212;20&#xB0;C till further use. </p>
        <p>Depending on their morphological characterization, complete identification of filamentous fungi based either on the rDNA nucleotide sequence analyses of the whole internal transcribed spacer region (ITS: ITS1, 5.8S rDNA and ITS 2), partial beta-tubulin gene exons and introns (<italic>benA</italic>), or the partial actin gene (<italic>act</italic>). Yeasts were identified by their large subunit ribosomal DNA (LSU) sequence (partial 28S rDNA, D1/D2 domains). Amplification and sequencing were carried out with primer pairs ITS5 and ITS4 [<xref rid="B21-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">21</xref>], Bt2a and Bt2b [<xref rid="B22-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">22</xref>], ACT-512F and ACT-783R [<xref rid="B23-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">23</xref>], or NL1 and NL4 [<xref rid="B24-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">24</xref>]. Sequences were obtained at Microsynth AG, Austria and assembled by FinchTV 1.4 (Geospiza, PerkinElmer, Inc., Seattle, USA). The alignments were adjusted using Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) software version 7.0 [<xref rid="B25-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">25</xref>] and identified with the BLAST algorithm on the NCBI web page [<xref rid="B26-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">26</xref>]. Final identification was supported by taxonomically important databases such as Westerdijk Fungal Biodiversity Institute (Utrecht, the Netherlands) and Index Fungorum (<uri xlink:href="www.indexfungorum.org">www.indexfungorum.org</uri>). The sequences of representative strains used in the study were deposited in the GenBank database (NCBI). </p>
      </sec>
      <sec id="sec2dot3-microorganisms-09-00160">
        <title>2.3. Fungal Growth under Oligotrophic Conditions and Their Biodegradation Potential </title>
        <p>Based on their taxonomy and location of isolation, 52 different strains were selected for further analysis. They were tested at different environmental conditions, to determine whether water and materials serve only as vectors for transmission or promoted fungal growth. Fungal adaptation to oligotrophic conditions was tested on 100-times diluted Yeast Nitrogen Base (YNB) solid medium and 2% water agar medium (WA). </p>
        <p>In order to check their biodegradation and biodeterioration potential calcium carbonate (CaCO<sub>3</sub>) agar plates [<xref rid="B27-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">27</xref>] were used. Additionally, changes in pH were measured after incubation in liquid medium with neutral pH [<xref rid="B28-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">28</xref>] using Seven Compact S210 (Mettler Toledo, Switzerland). Growth of fungi in real-life conditions was tested on a commercial product used for concrete coatings (Xypex Concentrate, XYPEX CE s.r.o.), consisting of portland cement (30&#x2013;60%), alkaline earth compounds (10&#x2013;30%), silica sand (30&#x2013;60%) and calcium aluminates (&lt;10%). Xypex plates were prepared according to the manufacturer&#x2019;s instructions and wetted with 5 mL of sterile water prior to use. </p>
        <p>Fungal cell suspensions were prepared from 3&#x2013;5 days old cultures in a sterile saline solution and adjusted to ~1.0 &#xD7; 10<sup>8</sup> CFU/mL. Ten microliters of the suspensions were inoculated on all media and incubated at 15 &#xB0;C for 1 month. One series of inoculated YNB medium was used for testing the ability of strains to grow at human body temperature (37 &#xB0;C, 1 month). Xypex Concentrate plates were incubated at 15 &#xB0;C up to 3 months. After incubation, growth of fungi was checked and described as very good (+++) when mycelium covered &gt; 70% of the plate, good (++; mycelium covered 41&#x2013;70% of the plate), weak (+; mycelium covered 20&#x2013;40% of the plate), poor (-/+; mycelium covered &lt; 20% of the plate) or none (-; no growth was observed).</p>
      </sec>
    </sec>
    <sec sec-type="results" id="sec3-microorganisms-09-00160">
      <title>3. Results</title>
      <sec id="sec3dot1-microorganisms-09-00160">
        <title>3.1. Fungi Are Present at Every Stage of Drinking Water Preparation</title>
        <p>Drinking water was sampled at eight different locations: from a pool after ultrafiltration (1), from a pipe at the beginning of transport toward water storage tanks (2), at the entrance of water storage tanks (3a and 3b), at the exit of water storage tanks (4a and 4b), at the first sampling point for water monitoring (5), and at the last sampling point for regular water monitoring (6) (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="microorganisms-09-00160-f001">Figure 1</xref>). All tested physico-chemical parameters of water samples were in normal range set by Drinking Water Directive (98/83/EC), e.g., water hardness = 15.2 N (medium hard water), electrical conductivity at 20 &#xB0;C = 423&#x2013;430 &#xB5;S/cm, total organic carbon (TOC&lt; 0.3 mg/L), Ammonium &lt; 0.01 mg/L, Nitrite &lt; 0.001 mg/L, Nitrate = 3.92&#x2013;4.53 mg/L, Manganese &lt;0.1&#x2013;0.14 &#xB5;g/L, Iron &lt; 40 &#xB5;g/L, Aluminum = 5.5&#x2013;6.1 &#xB5;g/L, Arsenic = 0.49&#x2013;0.54 &#xB5;g/L, Copper = 0.0035&#x2013;0.0078 mg/L, Cadmium &lt;0.02 &#xB5;g/L, Chromium = 0.54&#x2013;0.57 &#xB5;g/L, Nickel &lt; 0.1 &#xB5;g/L, and Lead = 0.27&#x2013;0.34 &#xB5;g/L. The pH, measured at temperatures 20&#x2013;21&#xB0;C was slightly alkaline, between 7.3 and 7.5. Additionally, chlorination performed with gaseous chlorine (Cl<sub>2</sub>) did not show any discrepancies, with amounts of residual chlorine within the recommended range at all eight sampling points (between 0.15 and 0.30 mg/L). </p>
        <p>Fungi were isolated from all water samples (<xref rid="microorganisms-09-00160-t001" ref-type="table">Table 1</xref>). The most frequently isolated genus was <italic>Cladosporium</italic>, detected in four out of eight sampling locations (50%). One-third of the samples were positive for filamentous fungi of the genera <italic>Acremonium, Exophiala, Gloeotinia, Neopyrenochaeta</italic>, and <italic>Penicillium</italic>, while yeasts were detected only sporadically. Some fungi were not detected throughout the water preparation process. For instance, water from the retention pool yielded after ultrafiltration 146 CFU/L, 143 of them were identified as <italic>Exophiala cancerae</italic>. Nevertheless, this species was completely absent at later stages that followed water chlorination. The number of fungi in chlorinated drinking water was the highest before entering the main pipe system toward water storage tanks and at the immediate entrance to water storage tanks (both uncountable; &gt; 330 CFU/L). The most common fungus in water before entering the pipe system was <italic>Acremonium sclerotigenum</italic> (160 CFU/L), while <italic>Gloeotinia</italic> sp. dominated in samples just before entering the water storage tanks (&gt; 330 CFU/L) and at the exit point of the tanks (153 out of 226 CFU/L). Numbers lowered with the distance and time of water transportation. For instance, species of <italic>Cladosporium</italic> and <italic>Penicillium</italic> were present in water entering and exiting the storage tanks, while only <italic>Cladosporium</italic> was detected also at the first consumers&#x2019; tap sampling point. The lowest number of fungi was detected in the samples at the first and the last regular monitoring spot at consumers&#x2019; taps (both 73 CFU/L). <italic>Cadophora malorum</italic> was with 30 CFU/L the most common fungus at the first consumers&#x2019; tap collection point, and <italic>Aaosphaeria arxii</italic> (60 CFU/L) was the most common species after 30 km of water flow at the last consumers&#x2019; tap collection point (<xref rid="microorganisms-09-00160-t001" ref-type="table">Table 1</xref> and <xref ref-type="fig" rid="microorganisms-09-00160-f002">Figure 2</xref>).</p>
      </sec>
      <sec id="sec3dot2-microorganisms-09-00160">
        <title>3.2. Number and Diversity of Fungi Inside Two Water Storage Tanks</title>
        <p>Both concrete water storage tanks were filled with drinking water of the same origin, following the same preparation procedure. Although only 1.5 years old, both showed local degradations like cracks and peeling. Additionally, walls below the constant water level changed the color from grey to ochre. At some points growth of visible fungal mycelia was observed (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="microorganisms-09-00160-f003">Figure 3</xref>). All samples from the surfaces of water storage tanks were positive for fungi and together yielded 23 isolates. Their numbers were the highest on a dry ceiling (Samples-4a and 4b), locally covered with condensate of water drops. There several species (<italic>Akanthomyces muscarius, Aspergillus protuberus, Cladosporium sphaerospermum, Musicillium elettariae</italic> and <italic>Sarocladium kiliense</italic>) co-occurred in more than 330 CFU/cm<sup>2</sup> (<xref rid="microorganisms-09-00160-t001" ref-type="table">Table 1</xref>). An uncountable number of fungal colonies per cm<sup>2</sup> was observed also on humid walls of water storage tanks, where water level varies depending on the production/consumption ratio of water. Contrary to the dry ceiling with high numbers and diversity of fungi, samples taken from humid walls yielded monoculture of <italic>Furcasterigmium furcatum</italic>. This species was present also on dry (Samples-5a and 5b) and completely wet walls (Samples-7a and 7b) and likely grew also on concrete under constant water level. <italic>Furcasterigmium</italic> often co-existed with <italic>Sarocladium kiliense,</italic> also present on wet walls under constant water level, and on the surface of the metal pipe for water exit inside the tanks. The least contaminated part of the concrete water storage tanks was the bottom, with only few colonies of conidiogenic fungi per cm<sup>2</sup>. The water pressure on the bottom is higher and oxygen level is lower in comparison to upper sampled locations (<xref rid="microorganisms-09-00160-t001" ref-type="table">Table 1</xref>). </p>
      </sec>
      <sec id="sec3dot3-microorganisms-09-00160">
        <title>3.3. Oligotrophic and Aerophilic Conditions Promote Fungal Growth</title>
        <p>All tested strains incubated for a month at 15 &#xB0;C grew well on both oligotrophic media, YNB and WA, mimicking low-nutrient conditions inside water-networks and water storage tanks. However, their growth was slower on Xypex Concentrate plates, incubated at 15 &#xB0;C for 3 months. Only 40.4% of the strains grew weakly (+), 13.5% grew poorly (-/+), while 46.1% of the strains did not grow at these conditions (<xref rid="microorganisms-09-00160-t002" ref-type="table">Table 2</xref>). </p>
        <p>The growth of fungi at different aerobic conditions was determined by the immersion of the mycelium in liquid pH medium in glass tubes without shaking. Fifty percent of tested strains formed mycelium between the top to the middle of glass tubes, 32.7% strains grew throughout the whole medium column, and 17.3% grew from the middle to the bottom of the testing tubes (<xref rid="microorganisms-09-00160-t002" ref-type="table">Table 2</xref>). These results are in accordance with the numbers and diversity of fungi isolated from water storage tanks. Most of these fungi grew better on well-aerated ceilings, upper and middle walls, while the lowest number was detected on the bottom of the retention tanks. </p>
      </sec>
      <sec id="sec3dot4-microorganisms-09-00160">
        <title>3.4. Two-Thirds of Water-Related Strains Produce Acidic Metabolites </title>
        <p>Production of acidic or alkaline fungal metabolites can have a long-term effect on the biodeterioration of materials. Possible biodeterioration ability of isolated strains was tested in liquid medium with neutral pH and on solid medium with added calcium carbonate (CaCO<sub>3</sub>) and glucose. After incubation in the pH medium, 32.7% of strains were classified as producers of alkaline metabolites, since pH rose in a range of 0.01 to 0.5 units. On the other hand, 67.3% of tested strains acidified the medium, most of them (55.8%) lowered pH in a range between 0.01 and 0.5 units and 3.8% lowered pH in a range of 0.5 to 1.5 units (<xref rid="microorganisms-09-00160-t002" ref-type="table">Table 2</xref>). <italic>Penicillium</italic> strains (<italic>P. bialowiezense, P. brevicompactum,</italic> and <italic>P. glabrum;</italic> representing 7.7%) were the best producers of acidic metabolites, lowering pH between 1.5 to 3.0 units. All these penicillia also actively dissolved calcium carbonate on solid plates, with a clearing zone appearing after incubation. Besides <italic>Penicillium</italic>, only four other strains (<italic>A. muscarius, Gloeotinia</italic> sp., <italic>N. fragariae</italic>, and <italic>T. versicolor</italic>) clearly dissolved calcium carbonate, shown as the formation of clearing zones (<xref rid="microorganisms-09-00160-t002" ref-type="table">Table 2</xref>). Additionally, <italic>Gloeotinia</italic> sp. was the only strain that changed during growth on calcium carbonate the color of the mycelium from white-yellowish to ochre.</p>
      </sec>
      <sec id="sec3dot5-microorganisms-09-00160">
        <title>3.5. Water-Borne Fungi and Possible Effect on Human Health </title>
        <p>The ability of fungal strains to grow at 37 &#xB0;C is the most important virulence factor for possible colonization of the human body [<xref rid="B8-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">8</xref>]. Thermotolerant potential of representative strains was thus tested on solid plates with 100-times diluted YNB, incubated at 37&#xB0;C for 1 month. After incubation, 5.8% of the strains expressed very good (+++) growth, 9.6% good growth (++), and 3.8% weak growth (+). Poor growth was observed for 11.5% of the strains, while 69.3% of the strains did not grow at this temperature at all (<xref rid="microorganisms-09-00160-t002" ref-type="table">Table 2</xref>). Best growth was observed for <italic>A. sclerotigenum</italic> and <italic>Moesziomyces aphidis</italic>, followed by <italic>F. furcatum</italic> and <italic>S. kiliense</italic>. </p>
      </sec>
    </sec>
    <sec sec-type="discussion" id="sec4-microorganisms-09-00160">
      <title>4. Discussion</title>
      <p>Preparation of drinking water in EU countries depends on the availability of the main water source and is strictly monitored as requested by Drinking Water Directive (98/83/EC) [<xref rid="B5-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">5</xref>]. Predominant geological structures within the territory of Slovenia are sedimentary rocks and sediment deposits, which are ideal for the development of aquifers [<xref rid="B29-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">29</xref>]. Due to the favorable geological location and relatively easy access, groundwater is the main raw water source in Slovenia. In total, 85% of the country&#x2019;s population drinking water is supplied with groundwater, and only 3% of the population uses surface or rainwater. The rest use water from their own wells [<xref rid="B30-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">30</xref>,<xref rid="B31-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">31</xref>]. The geological specialty of Slovenia is the karst system, covering &gt; 44% of the territory [<xref rid="B29-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">29</xref>]. Underground karstic aquifers occur due to their limestone structure and thin layers that are very sensitive to anthropogenic pollution that may affect water quality [<xref rid="B30-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">30</xref>]. To meet the microbiological criteria set in Drinking Water Directive (98/83/EC), out of 866 active Slovenian water supply areas (WS), 31% do not need disinfection for water preparation, 9% use disinfection procedures occasionally, and 60% have permanent disinfection [<xref rid="B31-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">31</xref>]. Similar to other countries, the most common chemical disinfection process in Slovenia is chlorination with sodium hypochlorite (NaOCl), chlorine gas (Cl<sub>2</sub>), and chlorine dioxide (ClO<sub>2</sub>), being used in 40%, 14.1% and 2.2% of water supplies, respectively. During the last years also use of non-chemical UV disinfection increased [<xref rid="B31-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">31</xref>].</p>
      <p>Drinking water samples analyzed in the study were obtained from the karst area where the raw water source originates as groundwater below thin layers of limestone. The water supply company has installed a modern system of pre-treatment with combined ultrafiltration and disinfection with chlorine gas. Additionally, new ground concrete reservoirs for water storage and distribution have been built. However, after 1.5 years of regular use, cement coatings inside concrete water storage tanks showed changes in color from white to ochre, with sporadically observed local peelings. Additionally, also visible is contamination resembling mold colonies appeared on the upper ceilings and walls. Nevertheless, all microbiological and chemical parameters measured for the regular drinking water monitoring were within the normal range as set in Drinking Water Directive (98/83/EC) [<xref rid="B5-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">5</xref>]. The reasons for following the occurrence and diversity of fungi were (i) possible impact on material degradation and (ii) possible impact on consumers&#x2019; health. </p>
      <p>In order to find out whether fungi caused discoloration, peeling and visible contamination of upper ceilings and walls, six different surface spots inside the two water retention tanks filled with drinking water of the same origin were sampled. Together 12 sampling spots of the tanks&#x2019; surface were sampled. Additionally, samples of drinking water were taken from eight points throughout the water network system to follow related fungal contamination. All samples of drinking water and storage tanks were positive for fungi. Since there is currently no uniform parametric value for fungi in drinking water, we compared our results with the Swedish legislation [<xref rid="B32-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">32</xref>], which limits the presence of fungi to 100 CFU per 100 mL (equivalent to 1000 CFU/L). None of the samples exceeded this number. However, the highest number estimated as ~637 CFU/L and diversity of fungi were determined in water at the entrance of water storage tanks, after being transported from the Water Company through the old system constructed of iron-based pipes. The reason for the high number of fungi could be their presence in well-established biofilms inside the old pipes [<xref rid="B13-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">13</xref>,<xref rid="B33-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">33</xref>]. Their number lowered already at the outflow of the water storage tanks and was the lowest at both consumers&#x2019; endpoints. The lowered counts are likely due to chlorination since residual chlorine was present throughout the entire system [<xref rid="B34-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">34</xref>,<xref rid="B35-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">35</xref>,<xref rid="B36-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">36</xref>]. Although mycobiota differed between the sampling locations, isolated species of the genera <italic>Acremonium, Cadophora, Cladosporium, Epicoccum, Penicillium</italic> and <italic>Rhodotorula</italic> represented the &#x201C;core-species&#x201D;, as described previously in other EU countries, confirming drinking water as an important vector for their transmission [<xref rid="B4-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">4</xref>,<xref rid="B6-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">6</xref>,<xref rid="B8-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">8</xref>]. These fungal genera are also common in surface water or water from karst systems with thin layers of sediments [<xref rid="B4-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">4</xref>,<xref rid="B37-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">37</xref>]. Surprisingly, we did not isolate <italic>Aspergillus, Aureobasidium</italic>, or <italic>Candida</italic> species, which otherwise represent dominant groups of fungi in groundwater-derived drinking water in Slovenia [<xref rid="B38-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">38</xref>]. The reason could be their susceptibility to chlorination [<xref rid="B34-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">34</xref>,<xref rid="B35-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">35</xref>,<xref rid="B36-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">36</xref>,<xref rid="B39-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">39</xref>,<xref rid="B40-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">40</xref>] or the mixed source of water as is common in karstic systems. We additionally successfully isolated yeasts belonging to the genera <italic>Cystobasidium, Filobasidium, Moesziomyces</italic> and <italic>Rhodotorula</italic>. The ratio between isolated yeasts vs. filamentous fungi was 1:29 in favor of the filamentous fungi, in accordance with studies of biofilms in drinking water distribution systems [<xref rid="B33-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">33</xref>,<xref rid="B41-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">41</xref>]. Despite relatively high numbers of different fungi in the entering water, only <italic>Acremonium, Cadophora, Cladosporium,</italic> and <italic>Paraphoma</italic> were isolated from both waters, and the surfaces of water storage tanks. Since sampling was performed only once as a case study, the reasons for a limited number of species found on both surfaces and drinking water may be the fluctuation in mycobiota in the water at the time of the sampling [<xref rid="B42-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">42</xref>]. </p>
      <p>Main pipes, large retention centres and modern water storage tanks are made of rough concrete covered with coatings to prevent leaching and corrosion of metals used in concrete [<xref rid="B19-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">19</xref>]. After the relative humidity of the material in constant contact with water raises above 80% it represents an ideal scaffold for secondary colonizers like <italic>Aspergillus flavus, A. versicolor, Cladosporium cladosporioides, C. herbarum, C. sphaerospermum, Mucor circinelloides</italic> and <italic>Rhizopus oryzae</italic> [<xref rid="B14-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">14</xref>]. With relative humidity above 90%, wet material promotes the growth of a variety of water-related hydrophilic species [<xref rid="B14-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">14</xref>]. Another important factor affecting the growth of fungi on wet materials is the presence of oxygen. Most fungi are aerobes, some are microaerophilic, but both groups need oxygen for the synthesis of cell membrane constituents, like ergosterol and unsaturated fatty acids. Additionally, oxygen is needed in the respiratory chain as the terminal electron acceptor [<xref rid="B43-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">43</xref>]. Considering both, the high relative humidity and fungal need for oxygen, it can be expected that fungi would more likely colonize ceilings and upper humid walls of concrete water storage tanks. Wet concrete and finishing materials thus often harbor the genera <italic>Acremonium, Cladosporium, Aspergillus, Bjerkandera, Sporothrix, Chaetomium, Mucor, Stachybotrys, Ulocladium, Phoma</italic> and <italic>Penicillium.</italic> Yeasts on concrete are less diverse and belong mainly to the genera <italic>Candida, Debaryomyces, Kluyveromyces, Meyerozyma</italic> and <italic>Rhodotorula</italic> [<xref rid="B15-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">15</xref>,<xref rid="B16-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">16</xref>]. Our results, both in diversity and numbers of fungi, are in accordance with previous studies, with <italic>Aspegillus, Cladosporium</italic>, and <italic>Sarocladium, Furcasterigmium</italic> and <italic>Musicillium</italic> (all previously described as <italic>Acremonium</italic>) being the most common. Their numbers were highest on well-aerated dry ceilings and upper walls with locally visible condensate and lower on humid walls and walls constantly under water level (<xref rid="microorganisms-09-00160-t001" ref-type="table">Table 1</xref>). The need for oxygen was confirmed with the test in liquid medium without shaking. Species of <italic>Akanthomyces, Aspergillus</italic> and <italic>Cladosporium,</italic> found on upper ceilings and walls of storage tanks grew only on the top of the medium. On the contrary, <italic>Musicillium, Sarocladium</italic> and <italic>Furcasterigmium</italic>, isolated from dry and humid walls, as well as from the walls under constant water level, grew throughout the whole medium column, from totally aerobic to microaerophilic conditions (<xref rid="microorganisms-09-00160-t002" ref-type="table">Table 2</xref>). </p>
      <p>After a prolonged time of use, materials react with chemical components and disinfectants in water and become more susceptible to biofilm formation and biodegradation [<xref rid="B1-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">1</xref>,<xref rid="B8-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">8</xref>]. The presence and growth of fungi in water and on concrete may affect the material via the production of organic acids [<xref rid="B17-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">17</xref>,<xref rid="B18-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">18</xref>] causing local scaling. The process often involves <italic>Aspergillus</italic>, <italic>Penicillium</italic>, <italic>Fusarium</italic>, <italic>Paecilomyces, Talaromyces, Stachybotrys,</italic> and zygomycetous fungi [<xref rid="B15-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">15</xref>,<xref rid="B44-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">44</xref>]. The opposite process, known as &#x201C;self-healing concrete&#x201D;, was confirmed for <italic>Trichoderma reesei</italic> and <italic>Candida tropicalis</italic> and starts with the dissolution of Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub>, leading to the precipitation of calcite on the surface of fungal cells [<xref rid="B44-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">44</xref>,<xref rid="B45-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">45</xref>]. Production of acidic or alkaline products of isolated fungal strains was tested in liquid medium with neutral pH. Two-thirds of tested strains produced acidic metabolites, with the genus <italic>Penicillium</italic> being able to lower pH up to three units (<xref rid="microorganisms-09-00160-t002" ref-type="table">Table 2</xref>). These strains also displayed the largest clearing zones on the solid medium with added calcium carbonate (CaCO<sub>3</sub>) and glucose, while among other producers of acidic compounds only four strains additionally dissolved CaCO<sub>3</sub> (<xref rid="microorganisms-09-00160-t002" ref-type="table">Table 2</xref>), indicating additional mechanisms, besides acid production, affecting the solubility of calcium carbonate. Among isolated strains, only <italic>Gloeotinia</italic> sp. produced acidic metabolites, dissolved calcium carbonate, and changed the color of mycelium from white-yellowish to ochre. </p>
      <p>Following chemical dissolution, hypothetically, in-depth growth of hyphae causes mechanical degradation of the material [<xref rid="B19-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">19</xref>], as described for water-related genera <italic>Alternaria, Aspergillus</italic>, <italic>Cephalosporium, Cladosporium, Mucor, Penicillium, Rhizopus,</italic> and <italic>Trichoderma</italic> [<xref rid="B44-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">44</xref>,<xref rid="B46-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">46</xref>]. When using Xypex Concentrate as the only source of nutrients, only 40.4% of the strains showed weak growth, seen as thin mycelium on the surface of the plates. Since the test was carried out only for 3 months, with single strains under highly oligotrophic conditions, these fungi nevertheless showed the potential for biomechanical degradation, particularly over a prolonged time, in an environment contaminated with a mixed biofilm and in the presence of additional nutrients carried by water. </p>
      <p>Although the presence of fungi can induce, as side effects, chemical dissolution and mechanical degradation of material, observed as changes of odor and taste of drinking water, these changes alone do not pose danger to human health [<xref rid="B8-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">8</xref>,<xref rid="B47-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">47</xref>]. One of the main worries is the potentially elevated number of opportunistic and/or mycotoxigenic fungi. Fungal ability to colonize the human body does not depend on fungal physiology only, but greatly also on the immune defense of the host [<xref rid="B48-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">48</xref>] and the ability of strains to grow at 37 &#xB0;C. In the case of tested strains from drinking water and storage tanks, 29.7% grew at 37 &#xB0;C, and only 7.7% were classified under Biosafety Level 2 (e.g., <italic>Sarocladium kiliense</italic> and <italic>Filobasidium uniguttulatum</italic>). However, none of them was detected at consumers&#x2019; taps, indicating a low risk for fungal infections through the sampled water.</p>
      <p>Mycotoxins are well described in agriculture and food production, but there are still few data about mycotoxins in water. One of the issues may be their detection and quantification, because only a few are hydrophilic (e.g., fumonisins), while most known toxins are hydrophobic [<xref rid="B49-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">49</xref>]. Chlorination inactivates some mycotoxins (e.g., aflatoxin B1), and recent studies reported low levels of mycotoxins in European chlorinated water, but the caution must be maintained in cases of low- or unchlorinated water, particularly when drawn from surface water sources or water sources of mixed origin [<xref rid="B6-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">6</xref>,<xref rid="B50-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">50</xref>,<xref rid="B51-microorganisms-09-00160" ref-type="bibr">51</xref>].</p>
    </sec>
    <sec sec-type="conclusions" id="sec5-microorganisms-09-00160">
      <title>5. Conclusions</title>
      <p>Building materials in contact with drinking water must be, on one hand, safe for use, and on the other hand, able to sustain quick degradation processes. Yet, many chemical and biological agents present in nature can fasten their degradation. We investigated the presence of fungi, known degraders of recalcitrant materials, inside affected modern concrete water storage tanks. The tanks were filled with chlorinated drinking water originating from a karstic water source. The majority of isolated fungi were able to grow under water level, produced acids and dissolved carbonate media, thus fungi should be taken into consideration also as causative agents of visible coloration and peeling of retention tank surfaces in contact with drinking water. Fungal abundance, followed from storage tanks throughout the distribution system, gradually diminished and was the lowest at consumers&#x2019; taps. No known opportunistic pathogens were detected, yet they need to be taken into consideration in cases with visible overgrowth of mycelia inside retention tanks. </p>
    </sec>
  </body>

      <ref id="B11-microorganisms-09-00160">
        <label>11.</label>
        <element-citation publication-type="book">
          <person-group person-group-type="author">
            <collab>NLZOH</collab>
            <collab>ZAG</collab>
            <collab>NIJZ</collab>
          </person-group>
          <source>Priporo&#x10D;ila za Ocenjevanje Primernosti Materialov in Proizvodov, ki Prihajajo v Stik s Pitno Vodo in So del Vodovodnega Omre&#x17E;ja in Interne Vodovodne Napeljave (P-MPPV)</source>
          <edition>1st ed.</edition>
          <publisher-name>Nacionalni Laboratorij za Zdravje, Okolje in Hrano</publisher-name>
          <publisher-loc>Maribor, Slovenia</publisher-loc>
          <publisher-name>Zavod za Gradbeni&#x161;tvo Slovenije</publisher-name>
          <publisher-loc>Ljubljana, Slovenia</publisher-loc>
          <publisher-name>Nacionalni In&#x161;titut za Javno Zdravje</publisher-name>
          <publisher-loc>Ljubljana, Slovenia</publisher-loc>
          <year>2016</year>

  <floats-group>
    <fig id="microorganisms-09-00160-f001" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <label>Figure 1</label>
      <caption>
        <p>Sampling spots throughout water distribution system and inside concrete water storage tanks. Water samples are indicated as Sample-1, to -3, and Sample-10 to -12. Thick blue arrows indicate water flow. Samples inside the two concrete tanks that were taken by swabbing the surface are indicated as Sample-4 to -9. Thin blue arrows indicate water level as fluctuating or permanent.</p>
      </caption>
      <graphic xlink:href="microorganisms-09-00160-g001"/>
    </fig>
    <fig id="microorganisms-09-00160-f002" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <label>Figure 2</label>
      <caption>
        <p>Presence and diversity of fungal genera throughout water distribution network. Drinking water (DW) was sampled at eight distant locations. Both, the diversity and the numbers (CFU/L) were highest at the point of entrance into the concrete water storage tanks and the lowest at consumers&#x2019; endpoints (taps), indicating sensitivity to chlorine under prolonged exposure time. The genus <italic>Cladosporium</italic> was the most frequently isolated (four out of eight sampling spots).</p>
      </caption>
      <graphic xlink:href="microorganisms-09-00160-g002"/>
    </fig>
    <fig id="microorganisms-09-00160-f003" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <label>Figure 3</label>
      <caption>
        <p>Presence of fungi inside concrete water storage tanks. Fungal growth with visible mycelia was observed as black and ochre colonies on concrete ceilings at the entrance (<bold>A1</bold>) and inside the cell (<bold>B1</bold>), on a dry wall (<bold>C1</bold>), humid wall (<bold>D1</bold>), and wet wall (<bold>E1</bold>). Samples were taken also from the bottom of the tank (<bold>F1</bold>) with visible peeling and change of the colour and from the metal pipe for water outflow (<bold>G1</bold>). (<bold>A2</bold>&#x2013;<bold>G2</bold>): Microscopic observation of adhesive tape samples revealed diverse mycobiota producing brown conidia and brown to hyaline hyphae at all sampling sites. (<bold>A3</bold>&#x2013;<bold>G3</bold>): Fungal colonies on MEA medium grown from swab samples taken from 1 cm<sup>2</sup> surface.</p>
      </caption>
      <graphic xlink:href="microorganisms-09-00160-g003"/>
    </fig>

      <object-id pub-id-type="pii">microorganisms-09-00160-t001_Table 1</object-id>
      <label>Table 1</label>
      <caption>
        <p>Number and diversity of fungi isolated from drinking water through distribution network and from concrete water storage tanks.</p>
      </caption>
      <table frame="hsides" rules="groups">
        <thead>
          <tr>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-top:solid thin;border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Sample Number</th>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-top:solid thin;border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Description</th>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-top:solid thin;border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Total Number of<break/>Fungal Colonies</th>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-top:solid thin;border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Number of Colonies per Species</th>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-top:solid thin;border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Genus</th>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-top:solid thin;border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Species</th>
            <th align="center" valign="middle" style="border-top:solid thin;border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">EXF- No *</th>
          </tr>
        </thead>
        <tbody>
          <tr>
            <td rowspan="2" align="center" valign="middle" style="border-bottom:solid thin" colspan="1">Sample -1 </td>
            <td rowspan="2" align="center" valign="middle" style="border-bottom:solid thin" colspan="1">Water from retention pool after ultrafiltration </td>
            <td rowspan="2" align="center" valign="middle" style="border-bottom:solid thin" colspan="1">146 CFU/L</td>
            <td align="center" valign="middle" rowspan="1" colspan="1">143 <sup>+</sup>CFU/L</td>
            <td align="center" valign="middle" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Exophiala</td>
            <td align="center" valign="middle" rowspan="1" colspan="1">cancerae</td>
            <td align="center" valign="middle" rowspan="1" colspan="1">14903</td>
          </tr>

            <td align="center" valign="middle" style="border-bottom:solid thin" rowspan="1" colspan="1">10 CFU/L</td>

      </table>
      <table-wrap-foot>
        <fn>
          <p>Legend: * EXF- No.: number of fungal strains deposited in the EX Culture Collection in of the Infrastructural Centre Mycosmo, at the Department of Biology, Biotechnical Faculty, University of Ljubljana. <sup>+</sup> CFU: colony-forming units; fungal particles, spores, and conidia germinating in a new colony.</p>
        </fn>

      </table>
      <table-wrap-foot>
        <fn>
          <p>Legend: Growth of fungi is described as very good (+++; mycelium covered &gt; 70% of the plate), good (++; mycelium covered 41&#x2013;70% of the plate), weak (+; mycelium covered 20&#x2013;40% of the plate), poor (-/+; mycelium covered &lt; 20% of the plate) or none (-; no growth was observed). Changes of pH from neutral into acidic zone are indicated with &#x2193;, and into alkali zone with &#x2191;.</p>
        </fn>
      </table-wrap-foot>
    </table-wrap>

          <license-p><bold>Open Access</bold> This article is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License, which permits use, sharing, adaptation, distribution and reproduction in any medium or format, as long as you give appropriate credit to the original author(s) and the source, provide a link to the Creative Commons licence, and indicate if changes were made. The images or other third party material in this article are included in the article's Creative Commons licence, unless indicated otherwise in a credit line to the material.       </permissions>
      <abstract id="Abs1">
        <p id="Par1"><italic>Brassica oleracea</italic> var. <italic>acephala</italic> (kale) is a cruciferous vegetable widely cultivated for its leaves and flower buds in Atlantic Europe and the Mediterranean area, being a food of great interest as a "superfood" today. Little has been studied about the diversity of endophytic fungi in the <italic>Brassica</italic> genus, and there are no studies regarding kale. In this study, we made a survey of the diversity of endophytic fungi present in the roots of six different Galician kale local populations. In addition, we investigated whether the presence of endophytes in the roots was beneficial to the plants in terms of growth, cold tolerance, or resistance to bacteria and insects. The fungal isolates obtained belonged to 33 different taxa. Among those, a <italic>Fusarium</italic> sp. and Pleosporales sp. A between <italic>Setophoma</italic> and <italic>Edenia</italic> (called as <italic>Setophoma</italic>/<italic>Edenia</italic>) were present in many plants of all five local populations, being possible components of a core kale microbiome. For the first time, several interactions between endophytic fungus and <italic>Brassica</italic> plants are described and is proved how different interactions are beneficial for the plant. <italic>Fusarium</italic> sp. and Pleosporales sp. B close to <italic>Pyrenophora</italic> (called as <italic>Pyrenophora</italic>) promoted plant growth and increased cold tolerance. On the other hand, isolates of <italic>Trichoderma</italic> sp., Pleosporales sp. C close to <italic>Phialocephala</italic> (called as <italic>Phialocephala</italic>), <italic>Fusarium</italic> sp., <italic>Curvularia</italic> sp., <italic>Setophoma</italic>/<italic>Edenia</italic> and <italic>Acrocalymma</italic> sp. were able to activate plant systemic resistance against the bacterial pathogen <italic>Xanthomonas campestris</italic>. We also observed that <italic>Fusarium</italic> sp., <italic>Curvularia</italic> sp. and <italic>Setophoma</italic>/<italic>Edenia</italic> confered resistance against <italic>Mamestra brassicae</italic> larvae.</p>
      </abstract>
      <kwd-group kwd-group-type="npg-subject">
