Colonies were sub-cultured on 2 % potato-dextrose agar (PDA), oatmeal agar (OA), MEA (<xref rid="R26" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2009c</xref>), autoclaved pine needles on 2 % tap water agar (PNA) (<xref rid="R83" ref-type="bibr">Smith <italic>et al.</italic> 1996</xref>), or autoclaved banana leaves (BLA), and incubated at 25 &#xB0;C under continuous near-ultraviolet light to promote sporulation. Reference strains and specimens of the studied fungi are maintained in the CBS culture collection (CBS) of the Westerdijk Fungal Biodiversity Institute (WI), Utrecht, the Netherlands.</p>
      </sec>
      <sec id="s2b">
        <title>DNA extraction, amplification (PCR) and phylogeny</title>
        <p>Fungal mycelium (<xref rid="T1" ref-type="table">Table 1</xref>) was scraped from the agar surface of cultures with a sterile scalpel and the genomic DNA was isolated using the Wizard<sup>&#xAE;</sup> Genomic DNA Purification Kit (Promega Corporation, WI, USA) following the manufacturers' protocols. Nine loci were amplified following previously published protocols. First, the 28S nrRNA gene (LSU) and internal transcribed spacer regions with intervening 5.8S nrRNA gene (ITS) of the nrDNA operon were sequenced for all the isolates included in this study (for amplification conditions, see <xref rid="R40" ref-type="bibr">Fan <italic>et al</italic>. 2018</xref>). Other loci were sequenced for various species or genera using primers and conditions specific for those groups of fungi (<xref rid="T1" ref-type="table">Table 1</xref>). Amplification of the partial DNA-directed RNA polymerase II second largest subunit gene (<italic>rpb2</italic>), the partial translation elongation factor 1-alpha gene (<italic>tef1</italic>) and the partial beta-tubulin gene (<italic>tub2</italic>) followed <xref rid="R10" ref-type="bibr">Braun <italic>et al.</italic> (2018)</xref>, while the amplification of the partial actin gene (<italic>act</italic>), the partial calmodulin gene (<italic>cmdA</italic>), the partial glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase gene (gapdh) and the partial histone H3 gene (<italic>his3</italic>) followed <xref rid="R95" ref-type="bibr">Videira <italic>et al</italic>. (2016)</xref>. The resulting fragments were sequenced in both directions using the respective PCR primers and the BigDye Terminator Cycle Sequencing Kit v. 3.1 (Applied Biosystems Life Technologies, Carlsbad, CA, USA); DNA sequencing amplicons were purified through Sephadex G-50 Superfine columns (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO) in MultiScreen HV plates (Millipore, Billerica, MA). Purified sequence reactions were analysed on an Applied Biosystems 3730xl DNA Analyzer (Life Technologies, Carlsbad, CA, USA). The DNA sequences were analysed and consensus sequences were computed using SeqMan Pro v. 13 (DNASTAR, Madison, WI, USA).</p>
        <p>The sequences for each gene region were subjected to megablast searches (<xref rid="R101" ref-type="bibr">Zhang <italic>et al</italic>. 2000</xref>) to identify closely related sequences in the NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database. The results are provided as part of the species notes or as selected phylogenetic trees. Phylogenetic trees were generated using Bayesian analyses performed with MrBayes v. 3.2.6 (<xref rid="R78" ref-type="bibr">Ronquist <italic>et al</italic>. 2012</xref>) for the overview trees and Maximum Parsimony analyses performed with PAUP v. 4.0b10 (<xref rid="R85" ref-type="bibr">Swofford 2003</xref>) as explained in <xref rid="R10" ref-type="bibr">Braun <italic>et al</italic>. (2018)</xref> for the genus and species trees. All resulting trees were printed with Geneious v. 11.0.3 (<ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="http://www.geneious.com">http://www.geneious.com</ext-link>, <xref rid="R61" ref-type="bibr">Kearse <italic>et al.</italic> 2012</xref>) and the layout of the trees was done in Adobe Illustrator v. CC 2017. Statistical measures calculated included tree length (TL), consistency index (CI), retention index (RI) and rescaled consistency index (RC).</p>
      </sec>
      <sec id="s2c">
        <title>Morphology</title>
        <p>Slide preparations were mounted in lactic acid, Shear&#x2019;s mounting fluid or water, from colonies sporulating on MEA, PDA, PNA, BLA or OA. Sections through conidiomata were made by hand. Observations were made with a Nikon SMZ25 dissection-microscope, and with a Zeiss Axio Imager 2 light microscope using differential interference contrast (DIC) illumination and images recorded on a Nikon DS-Ri2 camera with associated software. Colony characters and pigment production were noted after 2&#x2013;4 wk of growth on MEA, PDA and OA (<xref rid="R26" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2009c</xref>) incubated at 25 &#xB0;C. Colony colours (surface and reverse) were scored using the colour charts of <xref rid="R76" ref-type="bibr">Rayner (1970)</xref>. Sequences derived in this study were deposited in GenBank (<xref rid="T1" ref-type="table">Table 1</xref>), the alignment in TreeBASE (<ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="www.treebase.org">www.treebase.org</ext-link>; study number S23853), and taxonomic novelties in MycoBank (<ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="www.MycoBank.org">www.MycoBank.org</ext-link>; <xref rid="R19" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2004</xref>).</p>
      </sec>
    </sec>
    <sec id="s3">
      <title>RESULTS</title>
      <sec id="s3a">
        <title>Phylogeny</title>
        <p><italic>Dothideomycetes</italic> LSU phylogeny (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F1">Fig. 1</xref>): The alignment contained 254 isolates and <italic>Helotium subcorticale</italic> (CBS 248.62, GenBank MH869740.1) was used as outgroup. The final alignment contained a total of 809 characters used for the phylogenetic analyses, including alignment gaps. The alignment contained a total of 392 unique site patterns. Based on the results of MrModelTest, dirichlet base frequencies and the GTR+I+G model was used for the Bayesian analysis. The Bayesian analyses generated 133 802 trees from which 100 352 were sampled after 25 % of the trees were discarded as burn-in. The posterior probability values (PP) higher than 0.84 are plotted on the tree (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F1">Fig. 1</xref>).</p>
        <p><italic>Eurotiomycetes</italic> LSU phylogeny (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F2">Fig. 2</xref>): The alignment contained 71 isolates and <italic>Saccharata proteae</italic> (CBS 119218, GenBank EU552145.1) was used as outgroup. The final alignment contained a total of 772 characters used for the phylogenetic analyses, including alignment gaps. The alignment contained a total of 265 unique site patterns. Based on the results of MrModelTest, dirichlet base frequencies and the GTR+I+G model was used for the Bayesian analysis. The Bayesian analyses generated 30 502 trees from which 22 878 were sampled after 25 % of the trees were discarded as burn-in. The posterior probability values (PP) higher than 0.84 are plotted on the tree (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F2">Fig. 2</xref>).</p>
        <p><italic>Lecanoromycetes</italic> and <italic>Leotiomycetes</italic> LSU phylogeny (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F3">Fig. 3</xref>): The alignment contained 42 isolates and <italic>Saccharata proteae</italic> (CBS 119218, GenBank EU552145.1) was used as outgroup. The final alignment contained a total of 838 characters used for the phylogenetic analyses, including alignment gaps. The alignment contained a total of 222 unique site patterns. Based on the results of MrModelTest, dirichlet base frequencies and the GTR+I+G model was used for the Bayesian analysis. The Bayesian analyses generated 9 102 trees from which 6 828 were sampled after 25 % of the trees were discarded as burn-in. The posterior probability values (PP) higher than 0.84 are plotted on the tree (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F3">Fig. 3</xref>).</p>
        <p><italic>Sordariomycetes</italic> LSU phylogeny (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F4">Fig. 4</xref>): The alignment contained 174 isolates and <italic>Saccharata proteae</italic> (CBS 119218, GenBank EU552145.1) was used as outgroup. The final alignment contained a total of 778 characters used for the phylogenetic analyses, including alignment gaps. The alignment contained a total of 334 unique site patterns. Based on the results of MrModelTest, dirichlet base frequencies and the GTR+I+G model was used for the Bayesian analysis. The Bayesian analyses generated 161 202 trees from which 120 902 were sampled after 25 % of the trees were discarded as burn-in. The posterior probability values (PP) higher than 0.84 are plotted on the tree (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F4">Fig. 4</xref>).</p>
        <p>Species phylogenies: Specific phylogenetic analyses were run for selected species and the resulting phylogenies are discussed in the species notes where applicable. Statistics associated with those phylogenies are provided in the figure legends.</p>
      </sec>
      <sec id="s3b">
        <title>Taxonomy</title>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Amycosphaerella africana</italic></bold> (Crous &amp; M.J. Wingf.) Quaedvl. &amp; Crous, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>33</bold>: 23. 2014. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F5">Fig. 5</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Mycosphaerella africana</italic> Crous &amp; M.J. Wingf., <italic>Mycologia</italic>
<bold>88</bold>: 450. 1996.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>In vitro. Ascomata</italic> pseudothecial, erumpent to superficial on agar, black, globose, 70&#x2013;90 &#xB5;m diam; apical ostiole; wall of 2&#x2013;4 layers of medium brown <italic>textura angularis</italic>. <italic>Asci</italic> aparaphysate, fasciculate, bitunicate, narrowly ellipsoid to subcylindrical, straight to incurved, 8-spored, 28&#x2013;37 &#xD7; 6&#x2013;7 &#xB5;m. <italic>Ascospores</italic> multiseriate, overlapping, hyaline, guttulate, thin-walled, straight to slightly curved, fusoid-ellipsoid with obtuse ends, widest in middle of the apical cell, medianly 1-septate, not to slightly constricted at septum, tapering toward both ends, 10&#x2013;12 &#xD7; (2&#x2013;)2.5 &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium, and smooth, lobate margins, covering dish in 2 wk. On MEA surface pale olivaceous grey to olivaceous grey, reverse iron-grey; on PDA surface olivaceous grey with patches of pale olivaceous grey, reverse iron-grey; on OA surface olivaceous grey with patches of dirty white.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>New Zealand</bold>, Auckland, Bucklands Beach, 22 Wells Road, on leaves of <italic>Metrosideros excelsa</italic> ( <italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), 2015, <italic>R. Thangavel</italic>, T16_03926C = CBS H-23809, culture CBS 144635 = CPC 32782.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Amycosphaerella africana</italic>, which is the oldest name for this taxon, is known from Australia (<italic>Buckinghamia</italic> sp., <italic>Eucalyptus grandis, E. globulus</italic>), Colombia (<italic>E. grandis</italic>), New Zealand (<italic>Dracaena draco</italic>), Portugal (<italic>E. globulus</italic>), South Africa (<italic>E. cladocalyx</italic>, <italic>E. deanei</italic>, <italic>E. grandis</italic>, <italic>E. radiata</italic>, <italic>E. smithii, E. viminalis</italic>), and Zambia (<italic>E. globulus</italic>) (<xref rid="R96" ref-type="bibr">Videira <italic>et al</italic>. 2017</xref>).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence was identical to <italic>Mycosphaerella buckinghamiae</italic> (GenBank EU707856.2; Identities = 523/523 (100 %)), <italic>Amycosphaerella africana</italic> (as <italic>Mycosphaerella africana</italic>, GenBank AY626981.1; Identities = 523/523 (100 %)), and related to <italic>Pantospora guazumae</italic> (GenBank NR_119971.1; Identities = 521/523 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Amycosphaerella africana</italic> (GenBank MH874180.1; Identities = 785/785 (100 %)), <italic>Mycosphaerella buckinghamiae</italic> (GenBank EU707856.2; Identities = 785/785 (100 %)), and <italic>Distomycovellosiella brachycarpa</italic> (as <italic>Passalora brachycarpa</italic>, GenBank GU214664.1; Identities = 782/785 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). The <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence was identical to numerous sequences of <italic>Amycosphaerella africana</italic> (e.g. as <italic>Mycosphaerella ellipsoidea</italic>, GenBank JX901653.1; Identities = 394/394 (100 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Amycosphaerella africana</italic> (GenBank LC121222.1; Identities = 571/572 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Pseudocercospora fijiensis</italic> (GenBank XM_007921924.1; Identities = 566/616 (92 %), no gaps), and <italic>Zymoseptoria tritici</italic> (GenBank XM_003856727.1; Identities = 552/616 (90 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Bacillicladium clematidis</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829299. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F6">Fig. 6</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name reflects the host genus <italic>Clematis</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of pale brown, smooth, branched, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam hyphae that become swollen and constricted at septa in the conidiogenous region, where individual cells become more ellipsoid and clavate to globose, up to 5 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells on hyphae, pale brown, smooth, phialidic, 0.5&#x2013;1 &#xD7; 1 &#xB5;m, with inconspicuous collarette, not flared. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, ellipsoid, pale brown, smooth, guttulate, aseptate, apex obtuse, basal locus truncate, 0.5 &#xB5;m diam; older conidia undergoing microcyclic conidiation, (3&#x2013;)4&#x2013;4.5(&#x2013;5) &#xD7; (1.5&#x2013;)2.5&#x2013;3(&#x2013;5) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, lacking aerial mycelium and even, lobate margin, reaching 6 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse umber.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Austria</bold>, Gaaden, branch of <italic>Clematis vitalbae</italic> (<italic>Ranunculaceae</italic>), 21 Apr. 2017, <italic>M. Mann &amp; R.K. Schumacher</italic>, HPC 2101, RKS 102 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23828, culture ex-type CPC 33882 = CBS 145035).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Bacillicladium clematidis</italic> is phylogenetically allied to the genus <italic>Bacillicladium</italic>, based on <italic>B</italic>.<italic> lobatum. Bacillicladium lobatum</italic>, which grows on bare granite walls, has three different growth habits <italic>in vitro</italic>, dependent on cultivation medium, temperature and colony age. But morphologically, <italic>B. clematidis</italic> provides an appropriate fit for the genus, sharing the black yeast-like growth in culture (<xref rid="R77" ref-type="bibr">R&#xE9;blov&#xE1; <italic>et al.</italic> 2016</xref>).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Camptophora hylomeconis</italic> (GenBank NR_132881.1; Identities = 352/402 (88 %), 20 gaps (5 %)), <italic>Aphanophora eugeniae</italic> (GenBank NR_132829.1; Identities = 394/466 (85 %), 24 gaps (5 %)), and <italic>Ceramothyrium thailandicum</italic> (GenBank NR_137768.1; Identities = 346/415 (83 %), 36 gaps (8 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Bacillicladium lobatum</italic> (GenBank LT558703.1; Identities = 822/863 (95 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Veronaea botryosa</italic> (GenBank MH875937.1; Identities = 818/869 (94 %), 5 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Veronaea constricta</italic> (GenBank MH873920.1; Identities = 811/862 (94 %), 5 gaps (0 %)). No significant hits were obtained when the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence was used in blastn and megablast searches.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Beltrania rhombica</italic></bold> Penz., <italic>Michelia</italic>
<bold>2</bold>(8): 474. 1882. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F7">Fig. 7</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Setae</italic> rarely observed, erect, dark brown, thick-walled, 7&#x2013;10-septate, straight to flexuous, tapering to an acute apex, 200&#x2013;300 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m, with lobed basal cell, 6&#x2013;8 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> erect, unbranched, medium brown, smooth, multi-septate, 50&#x2013;300 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;7 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, pale brown, smooth, 15&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;6 &#xB5;m, polyblastic with several flat-tipped denticles, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m. <italic>Separating cells</italic> pale brown, finely roughened, 7&#x2013;13 &#xD7; 5&#x2013;7 &#xB5;m, with several apical, flat-tipped denticles, 1&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, biconic, pale brown, aseptate, with a distinct median transverse band of paler pigment, (22&#x2013;)24&#x2013;27(&#x2013;29) &#xD7; (9&#x2013;)10&#x2013;11 &#xB5;m; apical appendage (10&#x2013;)12&#x2013;14(&#x2013;15) &#xD7; 1 &#xB5;m, tapering to an acutely rounded tip.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium, covering dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface dark brick, reverse fawn; on PDA surface and reverse umber; on OA surface umber.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Chile</bold>, Llanos, on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus urophylla</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), Jul. 2010, <italic>M.J. Wingfield</italic>, HPC 1412, CBS H-23264, culture CPC 31775 = CBS 144521.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Beltrania pseudorhombica</italic> was described from needles of <italic>Pinus tabulaeformis</italic> collected in Beijing, China (<xref rid="R25" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2014</xref>), and distinguished from <italic>B. rhombica</italic>, which has longer setae (can be up to 330 &#xB5;m long, and wider conidia 15&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 7&#x2013;14 &#xB5;m; <xref rid="R37" ref-type="bibr">Ellis 1971</xref>). There is no ex-type strain for <italic>B. rhombica</italic>, and it needs to be recollected on <italic>Citrus limon</italic> in Italy to clarify its taxonomy.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Beltrania rhombica</italic> (GenBank MH857718.1; Identities = 574/577 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Beltrania pseudorhombica</italic> (GenBank NR_148074.1; Identities = 574/577 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Beltrania querna</italic> (GenBank MH856775.1; Identities = 530/538 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Beltrania rhombica</italic> (GenBank MF580252.1; Identities = 823/823 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Beltrania pseudorhombica</italic> (GenBank NG_058667.1; Identities = 810/812 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Beltrania querna</italic> (GenBank MH875474.1; Identities = 859/866 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Brevistachys lateralis</italic></bold> L. Lombard &amp; Crous, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>36</bold>: 183. 2016. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F8">Fig. 8</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of hyaline, branched, septate, smooth, 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam hyphae (hyphae thick-walled and brown in conidiogenous region). <italic>Conidiophores</italic> erect, simple, single, rarely in groups, mostly unbranched, straight to slightly flexuous, 2&#x2013;3-septate, thick-walled on PDA, thin-walled on OA, olivaceous brown, verruculose, 80&#x2013;100 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3.5 &#xB5;m, with bulbous apex, 6&#x2013;7 &#xB5;m diam, bearing a whorl of 10&#x2013;12 conidiogenous cells. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, elongate, doliiform to subcylindrical, pale brown, smooth, 9&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;4.5 &#xB5;m, with conspicuous collarettes. <italic>Conidia</italic> aggregating in slimy mass with brown exudate on PDA, but in long unbranched dry chains on OA (without exudate), dimorphic, conidia globose, becoming dark brown and verruculose, (4&#x2013;)5(&#x2013;6) &#xB5;m diam, or ellipsoid, pale brown, verruculose, 9&#x2013;10 &#xD7;4&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse to moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 30 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface olivaceous grey, reverse umber in middle, sienna in outer region; on PDA surface ochreous with diffuse saffron pigment, reverse vinaceous; on OA surface saffron.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Thailand</bold>, Rachaburi Province, Bangkok, on leaves of <italic>Musa</italic> sp. (<italic>Musaceae</italic>), 2008, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, HPC 2156, CBS H-23831, culture CPC 33958 = CBS 145062.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Brevistachys lateralis</italic> was described from leaves of <italic>Musa</italic> sp. collected in Queensland, Australia (<xref rid="R64" ref-type="bibr">Lombard <italic>et al</italic>. 2016</xref>). This is the first record of the fungus from Thailand where it also occurs on <italic>Musa</italic> leaves.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Brevistachys variabilis</italic> (GenBank NR_153620.1; Identities = 531/542 (98 %), 6 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Brevistachys globosa</italic> (GenBank NR_145070.1; Identities = 555/569 (98 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Brevistachys subsimplex</italic> (as <italic>Stachybotrys subsimplex</italic>, GenBank AF205439.1; Identities = 558/573 (97 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Brevistachys lateralis</italic> (GenBank KU846062.1; Identities = 823/825 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Brevistachys variabilis</italic> (GenBank KU846066.1; Identities = 822/825 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and <italic>Brevistachys subsimplex</italic> (as <italic>Stachybotrys subsimplex</italic>, GenBank AY489711.1; Identities = 829/833 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>cmdA</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Brevistachys lateralis</italic> (GenBank KU846027.1; Identities = 360/360 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Brevistachys variabilis</italic> (GenBank KU846030.1; Identities = 360/360 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Brevistachys globosa</italic> (GenBank KU846023.1; Identities = 315/326 (97 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>Brevistachys ossiformis</italic> (GenBank KU846028.1; Identities = 307/326 (94 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and distant hits with <italic>Stachybotrys chlorohalonata</italic> (GenBank AY180255.1; Identities = 125/133 (94 %), no gaps), <italic>Stachybotrys chartarum</italic> (GenBank KM231452.1; Identities = 124/133 (93 %), no gaps), and <italic>Xenoacremonium recifei</italic> (GenBank KM231420.1; Identities = 122/131 (93 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Brevistachys lateralis</italic> (GenBank KU846074.1; Identities = 760/760 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Brevistachys subsimplex</italic> (as <italic>Stachybotrys subsimplex</italic>, GenBank EF692519.1; Identities = 762/785 (97 %), no gaps), and <italic>Brevistachys ossiformis</italic> (GenBank KU846075.1; Identities = 738/760 (97 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Brevistachys lateralis</italic> (GenBank KU846090.1; Identities = 439/442 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Brevistachys globosa</italic> (GenBank KU846085.1; Identities = 423/442 (96 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Brevistachys ossiformis</italic> (GenBank KU846091.1; Identities = 412/443 (93 %), 10 gaps (2 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Brevistachys lateralis</italic> (GenBank KU846106.1; Identities = 361/361 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Brevistachys variabilis</italic> (GenBank KU846110.1; Identities = 359/361 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Brevistachys globosa</italic> (GenBank KU846101.1; Identities = 351/362 (97 %), 1 gap (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Cercospora gomphrenigena</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829300. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F9">Fig. 9</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Gomphrena</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Leaf spots</italic> circular, 1&#x2013;4 mm diam, medium brown, with broad purple-red border. <italic>Fascicles</italic> only developing in moist chambers. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, arising from weakly developed stroma of a few brown globoid cells, subcylindrical, medium brown, smooth, flexuous, multiseptate, up to 800 &#xB5;m tall, 3&#x2013;6 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> subcylindrical, brown, smooth, terminal and intercalary, 30&#x2013;160 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m; scars thickened, darkened and refractive, 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, acicular, hyaline, smooth, flexuous, multiseptate, apex subobtuse, base truncate, 150&#x2013;300 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m; hila thickened, darkened and refractive, 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m diam.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and even, lobate margin, reaching 50 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface smoke grey, reverse scarlet with diffuse scarlet pigment; on PDA surface smoke grey, reverse olivaceous grey; on OA surface olivaceous grey with patches of dirty white, with diffuse scarlet pigment.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>South Africa</bold>, Gauteng Province, Gauteng, on leaves of <italic>Gomphrena globosa</italic> (<italic>Amaranthaceae</italic>), 2010, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, HPC 1516 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23803, culture ex-type CPC 32470 = CBS 144613).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: A DNA phylogeny for most common species of <italic>Cercospora</italic> known from culture was presented by <xref rid="R49" ref-type="bibr">Groenewald <italic>et al</italic>. (2013)</xref>, with secondary barcode genes treated by <xref rid="R5" ref-type="bibr">Bakhshi <italic>et al.</italic> (2018)</xref>. <italic>Cercospora gomphrenigena</italic> was collected from leaves of <italic>Gomphrena globosa</italic> in South Africa in an attempt to resolve the identity of <italic>Cercospora pretoriensis</italic> that occurs on this host (conidia narrowly cylindrical to subacicular, 15&#x2013;90 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;4.5 &#x3BC;m; <xref rid="R9" ref-type="bibr">Braun <italic>et al.</italic> 2015</xref>), from which <italic>C</italic>. <italic>gomphrenigena</italic> is morphologically distinct, having much longer and wider conidia. It is morphologically closer to C. <italic>gomphrenae</italic> [conidiophores in small, divergent fascicles, 30&#x2013;300 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;7 &#x3BC;m, conidiogenous cells 10&#x2013;30 &#x3BC;m long, conidia 30&#x2013;300(&#x2013;450) &#xD7; 2&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m, 3&#x2013;20-septate; Braun <italic>et al.</italic> 2015], but is distinct in having longer conidiophores and conidiogenous cells, wider scars, and wider conidia.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence was identical to <italic>Cercospora dichondrae</italic> (GenBank MK039698.1; Identities = 525/525 (100 %)), <italic>Cercospora beticola</italic> (GenBank MH424448.1; Identities = 525/525 (100 %)), and <italic>Cercospora malayensis</italic> (GenBank MH129519.1; Identities = 525/525 (100 %)). The <bold>LSU</bold> sequence is identical to those of numerous <italic>Cercospora</italic> species, e.g. <italic>Cercospora sesami</italic> (GenBank MK029365.1; Identities = 783/783 (100 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>cmdA</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Cercospora samambaiae</italic> (GenBank KT037463.1; Identities = 448/448 (100 %)), <italic>Cercospora</italic> sp. G NV-2018 (GenBank MF681410.1; Identities = 443/444 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Cercospora cyperina</italic> (GenBank KT193729.1; Identities = 444/448 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>his3</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Cercospora</italic> sp. 3 LO-2017 (GenBank KX522813.1; Identities = 375/375 (100 %)), <italic>Cercospora kikuchii</italic> (GenBank KP825147.1; Identities = 375/375 (100 %)), and <italic>Cercospora</italic> cf.<italic> physalidis</italic> (GenBank JX142654.1; Identities = 380/381 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Cercospora</italic> sp. 3 LO-2017 (GenBank KX522847.1; Identities = 280/280 (100 %)), <italic>Cercospora</italic> cf.<italic> alchemillicola</italic> (GenBank KR733109.1; Identities = 279/279 (100 %)), and <italic>Cercospora samambaiae</italic> (GenBank KT037468.1; Identities = 487/488 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Cercospora kikuchii</italic> (GenBank AB240222.1; Identities = 581/581 (100 %)), <italic>Cercospora beticola</italic> (GenBank XM_023592737.1; Identities = 754/784 (96 %), no gaps), and <italic>Cercospora</italic> sp. Q (GenBank JX142482.1; Identities = 1016/1054 (96 %), 4 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Cladoriella xanthorrhoeae</italic></bold> Crous, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>39</bold>: 417. 2017. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F10">Fig. 10</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of pale brown, smooth, septate, branched, 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, flexuous, medium brown, smooth, subcylindrical, unbranched, 1&#x2013;4-septate, 20&#x2013;40 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m; at times conidiophores can be reduced to conidiogenous cells arising from hyphae, 5&#x2013;8 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, integrated, medium brown, smooth to finely roughened, subcylindrical, with 1&#x2013;2 flat-tipped loci, 2&#x2013;2.5 &#xB5;m diam, darkened, somewhat thickened, 7&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 3.5&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m. <italic>Ramoconidia</italic> medium brown, finely verruculose, 1(&#x2013;2)-septate, subcylindrical to somewhat fusoid-ellipsoid, 12&#x2013;19 &#xD7; 3.5&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m; loci thickened, darkened, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> in short (2&#x2013;6), branched chains, medium brown, verruculose, fusoid-ellipsoid, 1-septate; hila truncate, thickened, darkened, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam, (9&#x2013;)12&#x2013;15(&#x2013;17) &#xD7; (3.5&#x2013;)4 &#xB5;m; hila thickened, somewhat darkened, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and feathery margin, reaching 7 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface iron-grey; diffuse red pigment visible in agar on PDA and OA.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Nullica State Forest, on leaves of <italic>Xanthorrhoea</italic> sp. (<italic>Asphodelaceae</italic>), Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, HPC 1830, CBS H-23804, culture CPC 32609 = CBS 144523.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Cladoriella xanthorrhoeae</italic> was recently described on <italic>Xanthorrhoea</italic> sp. from Australia (<xref rid="R27" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2017</xref>), and CPC 32609 represents the second collection of this fungus from the type locality, where it appears to be well established on Xanthorrhoea.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence was identical to <italic>Cladoriella xanthorrhoeae</italic> (GenBank NR_156392.1; Identities = 602/602 (100 %)); and related to <italic>Cladoriella rubrigena</italic> (GenBank NR_156219.1; Identities = 498/552 (90 %), 15 gaps (2 %)) and <italic>Cladoriella eucalypti</italic> (GenBank EU040224.1; Identities = 589/641 (92 %), 15 gaps (2 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Cladoriella rubrigena</italic> (GenBank NG_058780.1; Identities = 867/881 (98 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Cladoriella eucalypti</italic> (GenBank EU040224.1; Identities = 861/876 (98 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Cladoriella paleospora</italic> (GenBank MH874922.1; Identities = 823/880 (94 %), 3 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Creosphaeria sassafras</italic></bold> (Schwein.) Y.M. Ju <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Mycotaxon</italic>
<bold>47</bold>: 223. 1993. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F11">Fig. 11</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Sphaeria sassafras</italic> Schwein., <italic>Schr. naturf. Ges. Leipzig</italic>
<bold>1</bold>: 36 (10 of repr.). 1822.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>In vitro: Mycelium</italic> consisting of hyaline to brown, smooth to warty, 1.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells occurring on narrower hyphae (1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam), solitary, erect, pale brown to hyaline, smooth, nodes 1&#x2013;3 &#xD7; 1&#x2013;1.5 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> hyaline, smooth, aseptate, curved, spindle-shaped, apex subobtuse, base truncate, 20&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 2 &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, covering dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface hazel, reverse sepia in inner region, orange in outer zone; on PDA surface hazel, reverse brown vinaceous; on OA surface hazel.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Spain</bold>, Barcelona, dead branch of <italic>Laurus nobilis</italic> (<italic>Lauraceae</italic>), Mar. 2017, <italic>M. Vera Intrago &amp; R.K. Schumacher</italic>, HPC 2043, RKS 90, culture CPC 33410 = CBS 144984.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <xref rid="R8" ref-type="bibr">Bills &amp; Pel&#xE1;ez (1996)</xref> reported conidia of the asexual morph to be 16&#x2013;22 &#xD7; 1.2&#x2013;1.8 &#xB5;m. Based on a megablast search of NCBI's GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had the greatest similarity to several sequences of <italic>Creosphaeria sassafras</italic> (e.g. GenBank HQ660446.1; Identities = 515/516 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Creosphaeria sassafras</italic> (GenBank MH876173.1; Identities = 854/854 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Lopadostoma lechatii</italic> (GenBank KC774590.1; Identities = 833/854 (98 %), no gaps), and <italic>Lopadostoma meridionale</italic> (GenBank KC774599.1; Identities = 833/855 (97 %), 3 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Cylindrocladiella peruviana</italic></bold> (Bat. <italic>et al.</italic>) Boesew., <italic>Canad. J. Bot.</italic>
<bold>60</bold>: 2289. 1982. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F12">Fig. 12</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Cylindrocladium peruvianum</italic> Bat. <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Atas Inst. Micol. Univ. Recife</italic>
<bold>2</bold>: 386. 1965.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiophores</italic> dimorphic, penicillate and subverticillate, mononematous and hyaline, comprising a stipe, a penicillate arrangement of fertile branches, a stipe extension and a terminal vesicle; <italic>stipe extension</italic> aseptate, straight, 50&#x2013;70 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m, thick-walled with one basal septum, terminating in thin-walled, ellipsoid to lanceolate vesicles, 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m wide. <italic>Penicillate conidiogenous apparatus</italic> with primary branches 0&#x2013;1-septate, 15&#x2013;25 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m, secondary branches aseptate, 8&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m, each terminal branch producing 2&#x2013;4 phialides; <italic>phialides</italic> cylindrical, doliiform to reniform to cymbiform, hyaline, aseptate, 9&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m, apex with minute periclinal thickening and collarette. <italic>Subverticillate conidiophores</italic> comprising of a septate stipe and rarely primary branches terminating in 2&#x2013;4 phialides; <italic>phialides</italic> cymbiform to cylindrical, hyaline, aseptate, 20&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;2.5 &#x3BC;m, apex with minute periclinal thickening and collarette. <italic>Conidia</italic> cylindrical, rounded at both ends, straight, (0&#x2013;)1-septate, (9&#x2013;)10&#x2013;12(&#x2013;13) &#xD7; 2(&#x2013;2.5) &#x3BC;m, held in asymmetrical clusters by colourless slime. <italic>Sexual morph</italic> unknown.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with fluffy, moderate aerial mycelium, covering dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface sienna with patches of ochreous, reverse umber to sienna.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>South Africa</bold>, Western Cape Province, Stellenbosch, <italic>Pelargonium</italic> sp. (<italic>Geraniaceae</italic>), 1 Feb. 2010, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, CBS H-23821, culture CPC 33527 = CBS 145053.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Cylindrocladiella peruviana</italic> is known to occur in South Africa (<xref rid="R94" ref-type="bibr">van Coller <italic>et al.</italic> 2005</xref>), and has been confirmed from hosts such as <italic>Acacia mearnsii, Eucalyptus</italic> spp., and <italic>Vitis vinifera</italic>, but this is the first record from <italic>Pelargonium</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence was identical to <italic>Cylindrocladiella peruviana</italic> (GenBank KU896173.1; Identities = 550/550), <italic>Cylindrocladiella parvispora</italic> (GenBank MH017028.1; Identities = 546/546), and <italic>Cylindrocladiella malesiana</italic> (GenBank MH017019.1; Identities = 546/546). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Cylindrocladiella peruviana</italic> (GenBank JN099266.1; Identities = 841/841 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Cylindrocladiella longiphialidica</italic> (GenBank MH876846.1; Identities = 840/841 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Cylindrocladiella camelliae</italic> (GenBank JN099248.1; Identities = 840/841 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>his3</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Cylindrocladiella peruviana</italic> (GenBank MH017011.1; Identities = 480/480 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Cylindrocladiella microcylindrica</italic> (as <italic>Nectricladiella camelliae</italic>, GenBank AY793523.1; Identities = 442/457 (97 %), 5 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Cylindrocladiella solicola</italic> (GenBank MH017002.1; Identities = 469/485 (97 %), 5 gaps (1 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Cylindrocladiella camelliae</italic> (GenBank KM232304.1; Identities = 819/837 (98 %), no gaps), <italic>Cylindrocladiella lageniformis</italic> (GenBank KM232303.1; Identities = 648/722 (90 %), no gaps), and <italic>Calonectria brevistipitata</italic> (GenBank KY653367.1; Identities = 744/861 (86 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Cylindrocladiella peruviana</italic> (GenBank JN099007.1; Identities = 482/483 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Cylindrocladiella obpyriformis</italic> (GenBank MH016985.1; Identities = 475/489 (97 %), 7 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Cylindrocladiella arbusta</italic> (GenBank MH016978.1; Identities = 475/489 (97 %), 7 gaps (1 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Cylindrocladiella peruviana</italic> (GenBank JN098801.1; Identities = 618/618 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Cylindrocladiella terrestris</italic> (GenBank MF444930.1; Identities = 482/493 (98 %), no gaps), and <italic>Cylindrocladiella camelliae</italic> (GenBank JN098749.1; Identities = 604/618 (98 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Cyphellophora clematidis</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829301. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F13">Fig. 13</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name reflects the host genus <italic>Clematis</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of pale brown, smooth, septate, branched, (1.5&#x2013;)2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiomata</italic> sporodochial, round, erumpent, olivaceous, 30&#x2013;120 &#xB5;m diam, consisting of a basal stroma of globose to ellipsoid, olivaceous, smooth-walled cells, 2&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m diam, giving rise to aggregated conidiogenous cells. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> ellipsoid to ampulliform, olivaceous brown, smooth, 4&#x2013;6(&#x2013;10) &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m, phialidic with darker brown, flared collarette, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> aseptate, aggregated in mucoid mass, olivaceous, smooth, guttulate, ellipsoid, apex obtuse, tapering toward a truncate base, 0.5 &#xB5;m diam, (3&#x2013;)4&#x2013;5(&#x2013;6.5) &#xD7; (1.5&#x2013;)2(&#x2013;2.5) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading with sparse to moderate aerial mycelium, and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 40 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xBA;C. On MEA surface umber, reverse chestnut; on PDA surface hazel, reverse iron-grey; on OA surface olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Austria</bold>, lower Austria, Gaaden, on <italic>Clematis vitalba</italic> (<italic>Ranunculaceae</italic>), 21 Apr. 2017, <italic>M. Mann &amp; R.K. Schumacher</italic>, HPC 2101 = RKS 102 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23827, culture ex-type CPC 33880 = CBS 144983).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Although <italic>Cyphellophora clematidis</italic> was isolated from <italic>Clematis vitalba</italic>, <italic>Cyphellophora</italic> also contains species that are associated with human and animal skin and nails (<xref rid="R43" ref-type="bibr">Gao <italic>et al.</italic> 2015</xref>). <italic>Cyphellophora clematidis</italic> is phylogenetically distinct from other species presently known based on their DNA sequences, and is introduced here as new, being morphologically distinct in that it has predominantly aseptate conidia.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Anthopsis deltoidea</italic> (GenBank NR_153555.1; Identities = 492/557 (88 %), 40 gaps (7 %)), <italic>Cyphellophora pluriseptata</italic> (GenBank MH063042.1; Identities = 481/562 (86 %), 24 gaps (4 %)), and <italic>Cyphellophora eucalypti</italic> (GenBank GQ303274.1; Identities = 530/633 (84 %), 48 gaps (7 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Cyphellophora fusarioides</italic> (GenBank MH877022.1; Identities = 836/861 (97 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Cyphellophora musae</italic> (GenBank KP122932.1; Identities = 835/861 (97 %), 3 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Cyphellophora suttonii</italic> (GenBank MH874978.1; Identities = 834/861 (97 %), 4 gaps (0 %)). No significant hits were obtained when the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence was used in blastn and megablast searches.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Diaporthe anacardii</italic></bold> (Early &amp; Punith.) R.R. Gomes <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>31</bold>: 15. 2013. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F14">Fig. 14</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>:<italic> Phomopsis anacardii</italic> Early &amp; Punith., <italic>Trans. Brit. Mycol. Soc.</italic>
<bold>59</bold>: 345. 1972.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> black, globose, erumpent, 250&#x2013;350 &#xB5;m diam, exuding a creamy conidial mass. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> hyaline, smooth, branched, 2&#x2013;3-septate, subcylindrical, 25&#x2013;50 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3.5 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> subcylindrical, smooth, terminal, intercalary, 15&#x2013;35 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;2.5 &#xB5;m, apex 1.5 &#xB5;m diam, mostly without collarette. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, hyaline, smooth, guttulate, fusoidellipsoid, straight, apex subobtuse, base truncate, 1 &#xB5;m diam, (7&#x2013;)8&#x2013;10(&#x2013;11) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3 &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium, covering dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface buff with patches of pale olivaceous grey, reverse cinnamon.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>South Africa</bold>, Western Cape Province, Stellenbosch, on unidentified leaf litter, 2010, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, HPC 1692, culture CPC 33074 = CBS 144610.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: This collection is closely related to <italic>Diaporthe anacardii</italic> (from <italic>Anacardi occidentalis</italic> in Kenya, and also recorded from Nigeria, Guinea and Cuba; <xref rid="R47" ref-type="bibr">Gomes <italic>et al.</italic> 2013</xref>), and <italic>Diaporthe velutina</italic> (from leaves of <italic>Neolitsea</italic> sp., <italic>Callerya cinerea</italic> and <italic>Camellia sinensis</italic> collected in China; <xref rid="R44" ref-type="bibr">Gao <italic>et al</italic>. 2017</xref>). Based on the <italic>cmdA</italic> and <italic>tef1</italic> sequence data, this isolate is identified as <italic>Diaporthe anacardii</italic>, which represents the first record from South Africa.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Diaporthe velutina</italic> (GenBank NR_152470.1; Identities = 561/563 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Diaporthe foeniculina</italic> (GenBank KP050598.1; Identities = 534/538 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Diaporthe inconspicua</italic> (GenBank KC343125.1; Identities = 556/561 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Diaporthe velutina</italic> (GenBank NG_059146.1; Identities = 788/788 (100 %)), <italic>Diaporthe phragmitis</italic> (GenBank MH878644.1; Identities = 785/788 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Diaporthe cotoneastri</italic> (GenBank MH873257.1; Identities = 785/788 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>cmdA</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Diaporthe anacardii</italic> (GenBank KC343266.1; Identities = 681/682 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Diaporthe portugallica</italic> (as <italic>Diaporthe</italic> sp. VG2018, GenBank MH063893.1; Identities = 469/486 (97 %), no gaps), and <italic>Diaporthe velutina</italic> (GenBank KX999286.1; Identities = 444/461 (96 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Diaporthe anacardii</italic> (GenBank KC343750.1; Identities = 335/341 (98 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Diaporthe portugallica</italic> (as <italic>Diaporthe</italic> sp. VG-2018, GenBank MH063911.1; Identities = 324/339 (96 %), no gaps), and <italic>Diaporthe velutina</italic> (GenBank KX999178.1; Identities = 324/339 (96 %), 2 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Diaporthe eres</italic></bold> Nitschke, <italic>Pyrenomyc. Germ.</italic>
<bold>2</bold>: 245. 1870. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F15">Fig. 15</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, globose, erumpent, brown, up to 400 &#xB5;m diam; creamy conidial droplets exude from ostiole; walls of 3&#x2013;6 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Conidiophores</italic> lining the inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, 1&#x2013;3-septate, branched, densely aggregated, subcylindrical, straight to sinuous, 15&#x2013;35 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m<italic>. Conidiogenous cells</italic> 6&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;2.5 &#xB5;m, phialidic, subcylindrical, terminal and intercalary, with slight apical taper towards apex, 0.5 &#xB5;m diam with visible periclinal thickening; collarette inconspicuous. <italic>Conidia</italic> aseptate, hyaline, smooth, fusoid, tapering towards both ends, straight, apex subobtuse, base truncate, (7&#x2013;)8&#x2013;9(&#x2013;10) &#xD7; (2&#x2013;)2.5(&#x2013;3) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse to moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, covering dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface isabelline with patches of sepia and honey, reverse brown vinaceous with patches of hazel and ochreous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Netherlands</bold>, on <italic>Lactuca sativa</italic> (<italic>Asteraceae</italic>), Jun. 2017, <italic>W. Quaedvlieg</italic>, NAK Tuinbouw INS-17-08263A, culture CPC 34055 = CBS 145040.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Diaporthe</italic> includes important plant pathogens, saprobes, and endophytes on a wide range of plant hosts (<xref rid="R52" ref-type="bibr">Guarnaccia &amp; Crous 2017</xref>). <italic>Diaporthe eres</italic>, the type species of <italic>Diaporthe</italic>, was circumscribed by <xref rid="R91" ref-type="bibr">Udayanga <italic>et al</italic>. (2014)</xref>. The present collection from <italic>Lactuca sativa</italic> in the Netherlands fits within the broad concept of <italic>D. eres</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence was identical to <italic>Diaporthe eres</italic> (GenBank MG281122.1; Identities = 576/576 (100 %)) and <italic>Diaporthe cotoneastri</italic> (GenBank KC145903.1; Identities = 576/576 (100 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Diaporthe eres</italic> (GenBank MH867392.1; Identities = 893/893 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Diaporthe cotoneastri</italic> (GenBank MH873257.1; Identities = 891/891 (100 %), no gaps), and <italic>Diaporthe ambigua</italic> (GenBank MH867598.1; Identities = 892/893 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>actA</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Diaporthe eres</italic> (GenBank KJ420750.1; Identities = 234/234 (100 %)), <italic>Diaporthe cotoneastri</italic> (GenBank KC843231.1; Identities = 273/275 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Phomopsis fukushii</italic> (GenBank JN230379.1; Identities = 265/268 (99 %),no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>cmdA</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Diaporthe</italic> cf. <italic>nobilis</italic> (GenBank KC343391.1; Identities = 409/409 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Diaporthe eres</italic> (GenBank KC343331.1; Identities = 409/409 (100 %), no gaps), and <italic>Diaporthe cotoneastri</italic> (GenBank KC763137.1; Identities = 403/409 (99 %), 4 gaps (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Diaporthe ampelina</italic> (as <italic>Phomopsis viticola</italic>, GenBank HQ446836.1; Identities = 632/683 (93 %), no gaps), <italic>Diaporthe limonicola</italic> (GenBank MH797629.1; Identities = 622/683 (91 %), no gaps), and <italic>Diaporthe foeniculina</italic> (GenBank MG922553.1; Identities = 619/680 (91 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Diaporthe eres</italic> (GenBank MG281568.1; Identities = 610/610 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Diaporthe</italic> cf. <italic>nobilis</italic> (GenBank KC343875.1; Identities = 346/347 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Diaporthe phaseolorum</italic> (GenBank HQ445915.1; Identities = 355/359 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Diaporthe hungariae</italic> (GenBank MG281303.1; Identities = 317/317 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Diaporthe rosicola</italic> (GenBank MG843877.1; Identities = 311/313 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Diaporthe betulae</italic> (GenBank KT733021.1; Identities = 429/439 (98 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Dichotomophthora basellae</italic></bold> Hern.-Restr. <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Stud. Mycol.</italic>
<bold>92</bold>: 69. 2018. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F16">Fig. 16</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Hyphae</italic> hyaline to brown, septate, smooth to verruculose, 6&#x2013;8 &#xB5;m wide. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> macronematous, unbranched or irregularly branched, lobed at the apex, forming a stipe and head; <italic>stipe</italic> pale brown, smooth, 500&#x2013;2000 &#xD7; 9&#x2013;17 &#xB5;m; head 30&#x2013;60 &#xB5;m diam, pale brown. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> polytretic, integrated and terminal, lobed, cicatrized, individual lobes 15&#x2013;25 &#xD7; 9&#x2013;20 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> (50&#x2013;)80&#x2013;95(&#x2013;105) &#xD7; (9&#x2013;)12&#x2013;14(&#x2013;15), solitary, dry, subcylindrical, rounded at the ends, pale yellow-brown, 3&#x2013;5-distoseptate, at times forking at apex, giving rise to bifurcate appearance, two apical branches 0&#x2013;2-septate, 7&#x2013;30 &#xB5;m long. <italic>Microconidia</italic> obovoid to ellipsoid, 0&#x2013;2-distoseptate, 10&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 10&#x2013;11 &#xB5;m. <italic>Sclerotia</italic> and s<italic>exual morph</italic> unknown.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies spreading, with sparse to moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, even margin, reaching 50 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface and reverse umber, with diffuse apricot pigment; on PDA surface and reverse orange, with patches of umber, and orange pigment; on OA surface orange, with patches of umber, apricot to orange pigment.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Thailand</bold>, Chiang Mai Province, Chiang Mai, on unidentified host plant, 2008, <italic>R. Cheewangkoon</italic>, CBS H-23813, culture CPC 33044 = CBS 145050.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The genus <italic>Dichotomophthora</italic> was recently revised by <xref rid="R65" ref-type="bibr">Marin-Felix <italic>et al.</italic> (2019)</xref>, who accepted four species associated with leaf spots on various host plants. D<italic>ichotomophthora basellae</italic> was described as having conidia that are 32&#x2013;86 &#xD7; 10&#x2013;18 &#x3BC;m, ellipsoid to cylindrical rounded at ends, and 2&#x2013;5-distoseptate. The present isolate is morphologically atypical, as its conidia are frequently forking at the apex. Phylogenetically however, it is identical to <italic>D. basellae</italic>, and was collected at the same locality.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Dichotomophthora basellae</italic> (GenBank NR_158422.1; Identities = 595/595 (100 %), no gaps) and <italic>Dichotomophthora lutea</italic> (GenBank NR_158420.1; Identities = 590/596 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence of CPC 33044 are <italic>Dichotomophthora portulacae</italic> (GenBank LT990624.1; Identities = 833/833 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Dichotomophthora lutea</italic> (GenBank LT990622.1; Identities = 810/810 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Curvularia papendorfii</italic> (GenBank MH875471.1; Identities = 855/855 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Bipolaris cactivora</italic> (GenBank LT715590.1; Identities = 855/855 (100 %), no gaps), and <italic>Drechslera helianthi</italic> (GenBank MH876194.1; Identities = 854/855 (99 %), no gaps). There are no LSU sequences of <italic>Dichotomophthora basellae</italic> available on GenBank. Closest hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Dichotomophthora basellae</italic> (GenBank LT990640.1; Identities = 860/860 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Dichotomophthora lutea</italic> (GenBank LT990636.1; Identities = 906/911 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Bipolaris cactivora</italic> (GenBank LT715726.1; Identities = 718/739 (97 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Exophiala abietophila</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829302. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F17">Fig. 17</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Abies</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of smooth, septate, brown, branched, 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells or with a supporting cell. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> pale brown, smooth, reduced to conidiogenous loci, 0.5 &#xB5;m diam, or ampulliform to doliiform, 4&#x2013;6 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> aseptate, (2.5&#x2013;)3(&#x2013;3.5) &#xD7; 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m, ellipsoid, hyaline, smooth-walled, guttulate, apex obtuse, tapering to a truncate base, 0.5 &#xB5;m diam.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with folded surface, sparse aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 10 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse umber.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Norway</bold>, Oppland, Vestre Sildre, on bark of <italic>Abies alba</italic> (<italic>Pinaceae</italic>), 29 Jul. 2017, <italic>F. Sanchez et al.,</italic> HPC 2230 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23836, culture ex-type CPC 34580 = CBS 145038).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Exophiala</italic> includes several species of dematiaceous hyphomycetes that are clinically relevant (<xref rid="R33" ref-type="bibr">de Hoog 1977</xref>). Species of <italic>Exophiala</italic> are however commonly isolated from plant litter and soil. Phylogenetically <italic>E. abietophila</italic> is distinct from all species presently known from their DNA sequence data.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Exophiala moniliae</italic> (GenBank HE605213.1; Identities = 567/643 (88 %), 34 gaps (5 %)), <italic>Exophiala bergeri</italic> (GenBank MH857080.1; Identities = 484/544 (89 %), 25 gaps (4 %)), and <italic>Atrokylindriopsis setulosa</italic> (GenBank KP337330.1; Identities = 516/576 (90 %), 19 gaps (3 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Exophiala dermatitidis</italic> (GenBank DQ823100.1; Identities = 1112/1194 (93 %), 24 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Exophiala bergeri</italic> (GenBank NG_059199.1; Identities = 1099/1184 (93 %), 27 gaps (2 %)), and <italic>Capronia pilosella</italic> (GenBank DQ823099.1; Identities = 1106/1199 (92 %), 27 gaps (2 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Exophiala lignicola</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Akulov, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829303. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F18">Fig. 18</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to rotten wood from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of smooth, pale brown, septate, branched, 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> penicillate with conidia in apical slimy mass, or reduced to solitary conidiogenous cells or loci on hyphae; conidiophores erect, arising from superficial hyphae, pale to medium brown, smooth, subcylindrical, flexuous, branched or not, stipe 10&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m, with apical and lateral penicillate conidiophores; primary branches aseptate, medium brown, smooth, 5&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;2.5 &#xB5;m; secondary and tertiary branches subcylindrical, medium brown, smooth, aseptate, 8&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m, giving rise to 1&#x2013;4 phialides, pale brown, smooth, subcylindrical to fusoid-ellipsoid, with prominent taper at apex to form a narrow cylindrical channel with percurrent proliferations, (1&#x2013;)8&#x2013;16 &#xD7; (1.5&#x2013;)2 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, pale brown, smooth, fusoid-ellipsoid, apex obtuse, base truncate, slightly reflective, (3.5&#x2013;)4(&#x2013;5.5) &#xD7; 2(&#x2013;3) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 12 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Ukraine</bold>, Kharkiv, Forest park, on fallen decorticated trunk of cf. <italic>Quercus</italic> sp. (<italic>Fagaceae</italic>) in a native oak-maple-ash forest, 28 Oct. 2016, <italic>A. Akulov</italic>, CWU (MYC) AS 6112 = HPC 1509 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23802, culture ex-type CPC 32464 = CBS 144622).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Exophiala</italic> (<italic>Herpotrichiellaceae</italic>) is commonly isolated from decaying wood, soil, and plant litter. This genus of dematiaceous hyphomycetes, commonly referred to as black yeasts, is morphologically variable, with conidiophores ranging from well-defined penicillate structures as in <italic>E. lignicola</italic>, or solitary loci on hyphae. The genus presently contains approximately 60 epithets, several of which have Capronia sexual morphs (<xref rid="R92" ref-type="bibr">Untereiner 1997</xref>). Numerous species of <italic>Exophiala</italic> / <italic>Capronia</italic> are known as host-specific fungicolous or lichenicolous fungi (<xref rid="R54" ref-type="bibr">Halici <italic>et al</italic>., 2010</xref>; <xref rid="R42" ref-type="bibr">Friebes, 2012</xref>). Phylogenetically, <italic>E. lignicola</italic> is distinct from those species known from their DNA sequences, and based on its unique conidiophores, it is treated as a unique taxon.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Rhinocladiella coryli</italic> (GenBank NR_155727.1; Identities = 542/612 (89 %), 18 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Exophiala eucalypticola</italic> (GenBank NR_158438.1; Identities = 518/589 (88 %), 21 gaps (3 %)), and <italic>Rhinocladiella aquaspersa</italic> (GenBank MH374866.1; Identities = 539/619 (87 %), 32 gaps (5 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Exophiala angulospora</italic> (GenBank MH874033.1; Identities = 875/885 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Capronia coronata</italic> (GenBank AF050242.1; Identities = 875/885 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Fonsecaea pedrosoi</italic> (GenBank AF050276.1; Identities = 872/887 (98 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). No significant hits were obtained when the <bold><italic>cmdA</italic></bold> sequence was used in blastn and megablast searches. Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Exophiala dermatitidis</italic> (GenBank DQ840566.1; Identities = 186/192 (97 %), no gaps), <italic>Capronia munkii</italic> (GenBank EF413607.1; Identities = 184/193 (95 %), no gaps), and <italic>Capronia coronata</italic> (GenBank XM_007726769.1; Identities = 187/198 (94 %), 2 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Fuscostagonospora banksiae</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Carnegie, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829304. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F19">Fig. 19</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name reflects the host genus <italic>Banksia</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> solitary, pycnidial, globose, brown, 180&#x2013;200 &#xB5;m diam, exuding a milky white conidial mass. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> lining the inner cavity, reduced to conidiogenous cells or with a supporting cell, branched at base or not, 5&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> ampulliform to doliiform, hyaline, smooth, 5&#x2013;7 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m; proliferating indistinctly percurrently at apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, hyaline, smooth, guttulate, ellipsoid, apex obtuse, base bluntly rounded, (3&#x2013;)4(&#x2013;5) &#xD7; (2&#x2013;)2.5(&#x2013;3) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and lobed, feathery margin, reaching 40 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface ochreous to dirty white with chestnut sectors, reverse ochreous with chestnut; on PDA surface umber with sections of dirty white and scarlet, reverse chestnut with sectors of scarlet and umber; on OA surface umber to pale luteous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Riamukka State Forest, 31.376993S 151.693569E, on <italic>Banksia</italic> sp. (<italic>Proteaceae</italic>), 2015, <italic>A.J. Carnegie,</italic> HPC 1445 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23796, culture ex-type CPC 31724 = CBS 144621).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Fuscostagonospora</italic> was introduced for a sexual species occurring on bamboo (<xref rid="R86" ref-type="bibr">Tanaka <italic>et al</italic>. 2015</xref>). The present collection represents an asexual morph, and is thus difficult to compare with the known sexual species in the genus, but it is placed in <italic>Fuscostagonospora</italic> based on its phylogeny.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Periconia pseudobyssoides</italic> (GenBank KY364628.1; Identities = 426/464 (92 %), 10 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Periconia byssoides</italic> (GenBank KY364620.1; Identities = 426/464 (92 %), 10 gaps (2 %)), and<italic> Fuscostagonospora sasae</italic> (GenBank NR_153964.1; Identities = 425/468 (91 %), 16 gaps (3 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Fuscostagonospora cytisi</italic> (GenBank KY770978.1; Identities = 839/846 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Fuscostagonospora sasae</italic> (GenBank AB807548.1; Identities = 838/850 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Corynespora olivacea</italic> (GenBank JQ044448.1; Identities = 858/879 (98 %), 5 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Gaeumannomycella caricicola</italic></bold> Hern.-Restr., Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829305. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F20">Fig. 20</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Carex</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>In vivo. Ascomata</italic> perithecial, immersed or semi-immersed on the substrate, globose, subglobose to elliptical, pale brown, 275&#x2013;390 &#xD7; 135&#x2013;235 &#xB5;m, with a lateral, central cylindrical neck, 108&#x2013;167 &#xD7; 57&#x2013;97 &#xB5;m; <italic>ascomatal wall textura intrincata</italic> to <italic>epidermoidea</italic>. <italic>Paraphyses</italic> sparse, basally moniliform, upwards filiform, unbranched, multi-celled, hyaline, thin-walled and smooth, evanescent. <italic>Asci</italic> numerous, unitunicate, cylindrical to elongated clavate, stalked, 8-spored, 73&#x2013;210 &#xD7; 9&#x2013;18 &#xB5;m. <italic>Ascospores</italic> cylindrical, to slightly curved at one or both ends, widest in the middle, tapering to the base, ends rounded, multi-guttulate, 0&#x2013;3-septate, septa often indistinct, hyaline, 32&#x2013;45 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;3.5 &#xB5;m. <italic>Hyphopodia</italic> brown, lobed (few hyphopodia were observed close to the perithecial neck).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with folded surface, sparse to moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, covering dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface pale olivaceous, reverse luteous; on PDA surface and reverse olivaceous grey; on OA surface olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, on dead leaf of <italic>Carex remota</italic> (<italic>Cyperaceae</italic>), 2 Jun. 2017, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic>, HPC 2136 = RKS 122 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23793, culture ex-type CPC 33925 = CBS 145041).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Gaeumannomycella</italic> was introduced by <xref rid="R58" ref-type="bibr">Hern&#xE1;ndez-Restrepo<italic> et al.</italic> (2016)</xref> for a genus of fungi morphologically similar to <italic>Gaeumannomyces</italic>, and associated with a disease on <italic>Cyperaceae. Gaeumannomycella caricicola</italic> is phylogenetically distinct from <italic>Gaeumannomycella caricis</italic>, the only other species presently known in the genus. Of interest is the fact that both species occur on <italic>Carex</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Slopeiomyces cylindrosporus</italic> (as <italic>Gaeumannomyces cylindrosporus</italic>, GenBank JF508361.1; Identities = 506/519 (97 %), 3 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Gaeumannomycella caricis</italic> (GenBank KX306478.1; Identities = 523/553 (95 %), 10 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Nakataea oryzae</italic> (GenBank FJ746639.1; Identities = 511/550 (93 %), 9 gaps (1 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Slopeiomyces cylindrosporus</italic> (GenBank KM009159.1; Identities = 835/848 (98 %), no gaps), <italic>Omnidemptus affinis</italic> (GenBank NG_059478.1; Identities = 832/848 (98 %), no gaps), and <italic>Gaeumannomyces graminicola</italic> (GenBank DQ341496.1; Identities = 832/848 (98%), no gaps). Distant hits using the <bold><italic>his3</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Colletotrichum arxii</italic> (GenBank KF687846.1; Identities = 173/183 (95 %), no gaps), <italic>Verticillium albo-atrum</italic> (GenBank DQ266200.1; Identities = 173/184 (94 %), no gaps), and <italic>Colletotrichum vietnamense</italic> (GenBank KF687854.1; Identities = 172/183 (94 %), no gaps). Distant hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Gibellina cerealis</italic> (GenBank KT377187.1; Identities = 334/409 (82 %), 28 gaps (6 %)), <italic>Slopeiomyces cylindrosporus</italic> (<italic>Gaeumannomyces cylindrosporus</italic> as, GenBank AY435448.1; Identities = 333/425 (78 %), 32 gaps (7 %)), and <italic>Magnaporthiopsis maydis</italic> (as <italic>Cephalosporium maydis</italic>, GenBank AY435435.1; Identities = 265/351 (75 %), 27 gaps (7 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Hansfordiaceae</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>fam. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829455.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> superficial to immersed. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, straight to flexuous, branched, medium brown, smooth, arising from superficial mycelium, at times setiform, multiseptate with lateral branches, each giving rise to several smaller, pale brown branches that form <italic>conidiogenous cells</italic>, subhyaline, subcylindrical or clavate; subdenticulate apical loci with rhexolytic conidiogenesis. <italic>Conidia</italic> aseptate, solitary, dry, globose to ellipsoid to fusoid, hyaline to pale brown, smooth or finely roughened, with minute basal frill derived from the apex of the separating cell.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type genus</italic>: <italic>Hansfordia</italic> S. Hughes.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>: <italic>H. ovalispora</italic> S. Hughes.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Hansfordia pruni</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829306. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F21">Figs 21</xref>, <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F22">22</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the genus <italic>Prunus</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, straight to flexuous, branched, medium brown, smooth, arising from superficial mycelium, 100&#x2013;1000 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m, multi-septate with lateral branches in upper half, each giving rise to several smaller, pale brown branches that form 1&#x2013;2 <italic>conidiogenous cells</italic>, subhyaline, subcylindrical with apical taper, 5&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m, with 2&#x2013;6 subdenticulate apical loci with rhexolytic conidiogenesis. <italic>Conidia</italic> aseptate, solitary, dry, globose to subglobose, subhyaline, finely roughened, (4&#x2013;) 5(&#x2013;6) &#xD7; 4 &#xB5;m diam, with minute basal frill derived from the apex of the separating cell.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and feathery, lobate margins, reaching 35 mm diam after 2 wk. On MEA fawn, reverse cinnamon; on PDA isabelline, reverse brown vinaceous; on OA vinaceous buff.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Italy</bold>, on twig of <italic>Prunus persica</italic> (<italic>Rosaceae</italic>), deposited in 1956, <italic>M. Ribaldi</italic> (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23837, culture ex-type IMI 146912 = CBS 194.56).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Hansfordia pulvinata</italic> has many proposed synonyms (<xref rid="R34" ref-type="bibr">Deighton 1972</xref>), which based on morphology, appear similar to the type. However, <italic>H. pruni</italic> differs in that it has longer conidiophores, more aggregated sub-denticulate loci on its conidiogenous cells, and smaller conidia.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence was identical to <italic>Hansfordia pulvinata</italic> (GenBank KU683763.1; Identities = 1040/1040 (100 %)); other closest hits included <italic>Entosordaria quercina</italic> (GenBank MF488994.1; Identities = 842/915 (92 %), 20 gaps (2 %)), and <italic>Entosordaria perfidiosa</italic> (GenBank MF488993.1; Identities = 840/914 (92 %), 18 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Hansfordia pulvinata</italic></bold> (Berk. &amp; M.A. Curtis) S. Hughes, <italic>Canad. J. Bot.</italic>
<bold>36</bold>: 771. 1958. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F21">Fig. 21</xref>, <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F23">23</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Polyactis pulvinata</italic> Berk. &amp; M.A. Curtis, <italic>Grevillea</italic>
<bold>3</bold>(27): 110. 1875.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, flexuous, branched, medium brown, smooth, arising from superficial mycelium, 200&#x2013;600 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m, multi-septate with lateral branches in upper half, each giving rise to several smaller, pale brown branches that form 1&#x2013;2 <italic>conidiogenous cells</italic>, subhyaline, subcylindrical with apical taper, 10&#x2013;17 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;3.5 &#xB5;m, with 1&#x2013;2 subdenticulate apical loci with rhexolytic conidiogenesis. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, dry, globose, subhyaline, finely roughened, (5&#x2013;)6(&#x2013;7) &#xB5;m diam, with minute basal frill derived from apex of the separating cell.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and feathery, lobate margin, reaching 25 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface olivaceous grey in centre, smoke grey in outer region, luteous in reverse; on PDA surface olivaceous grey in centre, smoke grey in outer region, reverse olivaceous grey in centre, luteous in outer region; on OA surface pale olivaceous grey, outer region pale luteous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Australian Botanical Garden Mount Annan, on leaves of <italic>Macrozamia miquelii</italic> (<italic>Zamiaceae</italic>), 25 Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, HPC 1734, CBS H-23581, culture CPC 32119 = CBS 144422.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Hansfordia pulvinata</italic> (a mycoparasite on other fungi, including <italic>Fulvia fulva</italic> on tomatoes; <xref rid="R70" ref-type="bibr">Peresse &amp; le Picard 1980</xref>) was originally described from branches of <italic>Alnus</italic> sp. collected in North America.
