It needs to be recollected in the USA to fix the application of the name. Morphologically however, the culture considered in this study applies best to the current concept for this taxon (<xref rid="R37" ref-type="bibr">Ellis 1971</xref>, <xref rid="R38" ref-type="bibr">1976</xref>, <xref rid="R34" ref-type="bibr">Deighton 1972</xref>). <italic>Hansfordia pulvinata</italic> has been suggested as possible biological control agent for plant pathogenic fungi (<xref rid="R66" ref-type="bibr">Mitchell &amp; Taber 1986</xref>, <xref rid="R2" ref-type="bibr">Alderman <italic>et al.</italic> 2010</xref>).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Hansfordia pulvinata</italic> (GenBank LC177970.1; Identities = 468/471 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Hansfordia pulvinata</italic> (GenBank MH863749.1; Identities = 510/546 (93 %), 11 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Gyrothrix verticiclada</italic> (GenBank KC775750.1; Identities = 407/463 (88 %), 17 gaps (3 %)), <italic>Selenodriella fertilis</italic> (GenBank KP859055.1; Identities = 473/544 (87 %), 24 gaps (4 %)), and <italic>Daldinia bambusicola</italic> (GenBank KY610385.1; Identities =474/553 (86 %), 22 gaps (3 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Gyrothrix circinata</italic> (GenBank KJ476964.1; Identities = 793/830 (96 %), 5 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Circinotrichum maculiforme</italic> (GenBank KR611896.1; Identities = 805/844 (95 %), 5 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Oxydothis garethjonesii</italic> (GenBank KY206762.1; Identities = 799/842 (95 %), 2 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Hypsotheca</italic></bold> Ellis &amp; Everh., <italic>J. Mycol.</italic>
<bold>1</bold>: 128. 1885.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonyms</italic>: <italic>Capnodiella</italic> (Sacc.) Sacc. &amp; D. Sacc., <italic>Syll. fung.</italic> (Abellini) <bold>17</bold>: 621. 1905. [based on <italic>Capnodium maximum</italic>]</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Sorica</italic> Giesenh., <italic>Ber. dt. bot. Ges.</italic>
<bold>22</bold>: 195. 1904. [based on <italic>Sorica dusenii</italic>]</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Ascomata</italic> separate or loosely grouped, not arising from a visible stroma, dark brown to black, ventricose, straight or curved, elongate with a submedian to suprabasal swollen ascigerous locule. Ascomatal wall of <italic>textura porrecta</italic> to <italic>textura intricata. Asci</italic> 8-spored, elongating at maturity and extending up the ascoma neck to the apex before deliquescing to release ascospores at or below the ostiole; discharged ascospores accumulating in a dry reddish brown mass at the ostiole. <italic>Ascospores</italic> golden brown, thick-walled, smooth, depressed globose to subellipsoid. Pycnidial and hyphomycetous morphs produced. <italic>Pycnidial conidiomata</italic> solitary, dark brown to black, globose or depressed globose, or short stipitate, with a prominent papillate ostiole, wall of <italic>textura angulata</italic> to <italic>textura intricata. Conidiophores</italic> hyaline, arising from the inner cells of the pycnidial wall, simple ampulliform or elongate, septate. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> phialidic with an inconspicuous collarette. <italic>Conidia</italic> hyaline, asymmetrical, oblong to allantoid or fusoid, aseptate, smooth. <italic>Hyphomycetous morph</italic> with mucoid heads of conidia scattered on short lateral phialodes, phaeoacremonium-like, sub-hyaline to pale brown, smooth or rough. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> lageniform, the collarettes usually inconspicuous or flared (phialophora-like). <italic>Conidia</italic> aseptate, ellipsoid-ovoid, smooth.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>: <italic>Hypsotheca subcorticalis</italic> [<italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Sphaeronaema subcorticale,</italic> perithecia occurring inside the bark of <italic>Quercus</italic>, New Jersey, USA, type at K].</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Hypsotheca nigra</italic></bold> (Schrad. ex DC.) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829445.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Stilbum nigrum</italic> Schrad. ex DC., <italic>Flore fran&#xE7;aise</italic>
<bold>2</bold>: 593. 1805.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonyms</italic>: <italic>Lagenula nigra</italic> (Schrad. ex DC.) G. Arnaud, <italic>Annls &#xC9;piphyt.</italic>
<bold>16</bold>: 267. 1930.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Caliciopsis nigra</italic> (Schrad. ex DC) Fitzp., <italic>Mycologia</italic>
<bold>34</bold>: 501. 1942.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Hypsotheca maxima</italic></bold> (Berk. &amp; M.A. Curtis) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829446.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Capnodium maximum</italic> Berk. &amp; M.A. Curtis, <italic>J. Linn. Soc., Bot.</italic>
<bold>10</bold>: 391. 1868 (1869).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Polychaeton maximum</italic> (Berk. &amp; M.A. Curtis) Kuntze, <italic>Revis. gen. pl.</italic> (Leipzig) <bold>1</bold>: 13. 1891.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Sorica maxima</italic> (Berk. &amp; M.A. Curtis) Giesenh., <italic>Ber. dt. bot. Ges.</italic>
<bold>22</bold>: 358. 1904.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Capnodiella maxima</italic> (Berk. &amp; M.A. Curtis) Sacc. &amp; D. Sacc., <italic>Syll. fung.</italic> (Abellini) <bold>17</bold>: 621. 1905.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Caliciopsis maxima</italic> (Berk. &amp; M.A. Curtis) H&#xF6;hn., <italic>Sitzungsber. Akad. Wiss. Wien, Math.-Naturwiss. Kl</italic>., Abt. 1, <bold>128</bold>: 84. 1919.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Cuba</bold>, on fronds of <italic>Niphidium</italic> sp. (<italic>Polypodiaceae</italic>) (originally identified as <italic>Polypodium</italic> sp.), 1941, <italic>Wright</italic> (<bold>holotype</bold> CUP-029913). <bold>Brazil</bold>, Rio de Janeiro, Nova Friburgo, on fronds of <italic>Niphidium crassifolium</italic> (<italic>Polypodiaceae</italic>), 5 Nov. 2011, <italic>R.W. Barreto</italic> (<bold>epitype</bold> VIC 42568, culture ex-epitype COAD 1983 = CPC 24674).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Brazil</bold>, Rio de Janeiro, Nova Friburgo, on fronds of <italic>Microgramma squamulosa</italic> (<italic>Polypodiaceae</italic>), 10 Oct. 2013, <italic>R.W. Barreto</italic>, VIC 42602.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Hypsotheca pleomorpha</italic></bold> (Patricia McGee &amp; I. Pascoe) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829312. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F24">Fig. 24</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Caliciopsis pleomorpha</italic> Patricia McGee &amp; I. Pascoe, <italic>Fungal Syst. Evol.</italic>
<bold>2</bold>: 50. 2018.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, globose, ostiolate, brown, 50&#x2013;200 &#xB5;m diam, separate (on PNA), or aggregated in a brown stroma (on PDA, MEA). <italic>Conidiophores</italic> arising from inner layer, hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical, branched, 1&#x2013;4-septate, 5&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> subcylindrical to doliiform, hyaline, smooth, terminal and intercalary, phialidic with prominent periclinal thickening, 3&#x2013;6 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, hyaline, smooth, granular, fusoid-ellipsoid, mostly somewhat curved, apex obtuse, tapered towards base, truncate, 0.5 &#xB5;m diam, (3&#x2013;) 4&#x2013;5(&#x2013;6) &#xD7; 1.5(&#x2013;2) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies spreading, surface folded, with sparse to moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, reaching 50 mm diam after 2 wk. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse chestnut.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus piperita</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), 2014, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, HPC 1762, culture CBS 144636 = CPC 32144.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The genus <italic>Caliciopsis</italic> (based on <italic>C. pinea</italic>) represents two phylogenetically distinct, well-supported clades, one of which is ascribed here to the former generic synonym, <italic>Hypsotheca</italic>, which appears to be the oldest name available for this clade<italic>. Hypsotheca</italic> (based on <italic>Hypsotheca subcorticalis</italic>; globose ascospores) was formerly distinguished from <italic>Caliciopsis</italic> (<italic>Caliciopsis pinea</italic>; ellipsoid ascospores) based on ascospore shape, although Fitzpatrick (1942) did not consider this character to be significant at generic level<italic>.</italic> Morphologically there are few differences between these genera, except that species of <italic>Hypsotheca</italic> known from culture also form a phaeoacremoniumlike synasexual morph in culture, which has not yet been observed for species of <italic>Caliciopsis s.str</italic>. <italic>Hypsotheca pleomorpha</italic> was recently described as the causal agent of a canker disease of <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> spp. in Australia (<xref rid="R69" ref-type="bibr">Pascoe <italic>et al</italic>. 2018</xref>), and is reported here from leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus piperita</italic>, although its possible role as foliar pathogen remains unknown.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence was identical to <italic>Caliciopsis pleomorpha</italic> (GenBank MG641785.1; Identities = 523/523 (100 %)), and related to <italic>Corynelia uberata</italic> (GenBank KU204606.1; Identities = 511/526 (97 %), 5 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Caliciopsis maxima</italic> (GenBank KX891229.1; Identities = 467/533 (88 %), 20 gaps (3 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Caliciopsis nigra</italic> (GenBank KP144011.1; Identities = 769/826 (93 %), 9 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Caliciopsis pinea</italic> (GenBank DQ678097.1; Identities = 781/843 (93 %), 8 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Caliciopsis beckhausii</italic> (GenBank NG_060418.1; Identities = 789/855 (92 %), 5 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Jeremyomyces</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829307.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to Jeremy, a young man who due to social circumstances has to live in a children&#x2019;s home in Germany. Despite these difficult circumstances, he has proven to be an attentive observer with a special interest in fungi.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Ascomata</italic> pseudothecial, intracorticolous, singly, gregarious, unilocular, sphaerical, black; ostiole indistinct. <italic>Peridium</italic> few-layered, consisting of a <italic>textura angularis</italic> with thick-walled, smooth, and eguttulate cells, inner layers hyaline, outer layers red brown. <italic>Paraphysoids</italic> numerous, distinctly longer than the asci, basally moniliform, upwards tapered and filiform, end cells gnarled, multi-celled, hyaline, thin-walled, smooth, eguttulate, branched, with anastomoses. <italic>Asci</italic> 8-spored, clavate, apically rounded with an ocular chamber, pedicel short and furcate, thick-walled, bitunicate, fissitunicate, apical chamber well-defined, clavate to subcylindrical, spores oblique biseriate overlapped. <italic>Ascospores</italic> hyaline, smooth, guttulate, 1-septate (3-septate with age), fusoid, widest above septum, prominently constricted with well-defined mucoid sheath; basal cell somewhat longer and apical cell. <italic>Conidiomata</italic> developing in culture, pycnidial, brown, globose with central ostiole. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells, lining the inner cavity, ampulliform to doliiform, hyaline, smooth, phialidic. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical with obtuse ends.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>: <italic>Jeremyomyces labinae</italic> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Jeremyomyces labinae</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829309. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F25">Fig. 25</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to Mrs. Elena Labina, a Russian colleague who has dedicated much of her personal time to collaborating with the authorities of this species in fungal research.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Ascomata</italic> pseudothecial, intracorticolous, singly, gregarious, unilocular, sphaerical, black, soft, +/-thin, ostiole indistinct, basally with a few short and red brown hyphae, up to 200 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Peridium</italic> few-layered, consisting of a <italic>textura angularis</italic> with thick-walled, smooth, and eguttulate cells, inner layers hyaline, outer layers red brown. <italic>Paraphysoids</italic> numerous, distinctly longer than the asci, basally moniliform, upwards tapered and filiform, end cells gnarled, multi-celled, 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam, hyaline, thin-walled, smooth, eguttulate, branched, with anastomoses. <italic>Asci</italic> 8-spored, clavate, apically rounded with an ocular chamber, pedicel short and furcate, thick-walled, bitunicate, fissitunicate, 75&#x2013;115 &#xD7; 10&#x2013;13 &#xB5;m, apical chamber well-defined, 2 &#xB5;m diam, clavate to subcylindrical, spores oblique biseriate overlapped. <italic>Ascospores</italic> hyaline, smooth, guttulate (at least 2 guttules per cell), 1-septate (3-septate with age), fusoid, widest above septum, prominently constricted with well-defined mucoid sheath, 5 &#xB5;m diam; basal cell somewhat longer and apical cell, (19&#x2013;)22&#x2013;24(&#x2013;26) &#xD7; (4&#x2013;)5(&#x2013;6) &#xB5;m. In culture: <italic>Conidiomata</italic> developing in culture, pycnidial, brown, globose with central ostiole, 150&#x2013;180 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells, lining the inner cavity, ampulliform to doliiform, hyaline, smooth, phialidic, 3&#x2013;4 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical with obtuse ends, (3&#x2013;)4&#x2013;5 &#xD7; 2 &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 35 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface pale olivaceous grey, reverse olivaceous grey; on PDA surface olivaceous grey in centre, scarlet in outer region, reverse scarlet with diffuse scarlet pigment; on OA surface olivaceous grey with patches of scarlet and diffuse scarlet pigment.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, on twig of <italic>Salix alba</italic> (<italic>Salicaceae</italic>), 21 Jan. 2017, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic>, HPC 1956 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23817, culture ex-type CPC 33154 = CBS 144617).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Morphologically <italic>Jeremyomyces</italic> is similar to <italic>Angustimassarina</italic> (<xref rid="R88" ref-type="bibr">Thambugala <italic>et al</italic>. 2015</xref>), except that it has a coelomycetous asexual morph. Strangely, the LSU sequence clusters with the type sequence of <italic>Acericola italica,</italic> a fungus that is morphologically quite distinct, having brown, three-septate ascospores. This suggests that the GenBank sequence of <italic>Acericola</italic> is incorrect. Based on this sequence however, this fungus was placed in a new genus, <italic>Acericola</italic>, rather than <italic>Setomelanomma</italic>, which is probably where it belongs.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Acericola italica</italic> (GenBank NR_156344.1; Identities = 523/534 (98 %), 3 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Xenophoma puncteliae</italic> (as <italic>Phoma</italic> sp. JDL-2012a, GenBank JQ238617.1; Identities = 553/578 (96 %), 9 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Phaeosphaeria caricis</italic> (GenBank KY090633.1; Identities = 536/583 (92 %), 13 gaps (2 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Acericola italica</italic> (GenBank MF167429.1; Identities = 883/883 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Phaeosphaeria sowerbyi</italic> (GenBank MH873687.1; Identities = 891/896 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Phaeosphaeria herpotrichoides</italic> (GenBank MH873664.1; Identities = 891/896 (99 %), no gaps). No significant hits were obtained when the <bold><italic>cmdA</italic></bold> sequence was used in blastn and megablast searches. Distant hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Phaeosphaeriopsis triseptata</italic> (GenBank KJ522486.1; Identities = 877/1003 (87 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Hawksworthiana alliariae</italic> (as <italic>Dematiopleospora</italic>
<italic>alliariae</italic>, GenBank KX507261.1; Identities = 846/1008 (84 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and <italic>Dematiopleospora salsolae</italic> (GenBank MG829254.1; Identities = 830/1005 (83 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). Distant hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Didymocyrtis cladoniicola</italic> (as <italic>Diederichomyces cladoniicola</italic>, GenBank KP170668.1; Identities = 435/521 (83 %), 16 gaps (3 %)), <italic>Phaeosphaeria ammophilae</italic> (GenBank MF795877.1; Identities = 411/495 (83 %), 30 gaps (6 %)), and <italic>Chaetosphaeronema hispidulum</italic> (GenBank KF253108.1; Identities = 394/472 (83 %), 23 gaps (4 %)). Distant hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Xenophoma puncteliae</italic> (GenBank KP170711.1; Identities = 249/278 (90 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Didymocyrtis banksiae</italic> (GenBank KY979923.1; Identities = 245/279 (88 %), 9 gaps (3 %)), and <italic>Phoma haematocycla</italic> (GenBank KT309405.1; Identities = 239/272 (88 %), 3 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Macgarvieomyces luzulae</italic></bold> (Ond&#x159;ej) Y. Mar&#xED;n <italic>et al</italic>., Stud. Mycol. 92: 84. 2018 (2019). <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F26">Fig. 26</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Pyricularia luzulae</italic> Ond&#x159;ej, Cesk&#xE1; Mykol. 42: 81. 1988.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, straight to flexuous, subcylindrical, unbranched, thick-walled, brown, smooth-walled, 1&#x2013;3-septate, arising from hyphae looking lacking a swollen base, 60&#x2013;120 &#xD7; 5&#x2013;6 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> integrated, terminal, pale brown, smooth-walled, subcylindrical with apical taper towards a rachis of sympodially arranged denticles, 1&#x2013;2 &#xD7; 1&#x2013;1.5 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, pale brown, finely roughened, guttulate, fusoid, apex appendiculate, base tapering to protruding hilum, 1&#x2013;1.5 &#xB5;m diam, somewhat darkened, (21&#x2013;)22&#x2013;23(&#x2013;25) &#xD7; (5.5&#x2013;)6&#x2013;7(&#x2013;8) &#xB5;m with a single supramedian transverse septum; when sporulating on PNA, germinating conidia form appressoria that are brown, irregularly lobed, 5&#x2013;10 &#xB5;m diam, with a hyaline central infection pore, 1 &#xB5;m diam.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, covering dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface and reverse saffron; on PDA and OA surface and reverse pale luteous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Ukraine</bold>, Rakhiv district, Transcarpathian region, Sidlovyana stow, Petros mountains, on <italic>Luzula sylvatica</italic> (<italic>Juncaceae</italic>), 9 Aug. 2017, <italic>A. Akulov</italic>, CWU (MYC) AS 6437 = HPC 2197, CBS H-23833, culture CPC 34292 = CBS 145042.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Macgarvieomyces</italic> was introduced by <xref rid="R62" ref-type="bibr">Klaubauf <italic>et al</italic>. (2014)</xref> for a genus of fungi resembling <italic>Pyricularia</italic> in general morphology, but which was distinct from the latter genus in having fusoid, 1-septate conidia, and occurring on <italic>Juncaceae</italic>. <italic>Macgarvieomyces luzulae</italic> was recently treated by <xref rid="R65" ref-type="bibr">Marin-Felix <italic>et al.</italic> (2019)</xref>, and this is the second collection from <italic>Luzula sylvatica</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Macgarvieomyces luzulae</italic> (GenBank MG934442.1; Identities = 548/548 (100 %)), <italic>Macgarvieomyces borealis</italic> (GenBank NR_145384.1; Identities = 485/517 (94 %), 10 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Macgarvieomyces juncicola</italic> (GenBank KM009165.1; Identities = 462/494 (94 %), 11 gaps (2 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Macgarvieomyces juncicola</italic> (GenBank KM009153.1; Identities = 854/864 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Macgarvieomyces borealis</italic> (GenBank NG_058088.1; Identities = 853/863 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Deightoniella roumeguerei</italic> (as <italic>Utrechtiana cibiessia</italic>, GenBank JF951176.1; Identities = 877/895 (98 %), no gaps).         <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Microdochium rhopalostylidis</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Thangavel, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829310. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F27">Fig. 27</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the genus <italic>Rhopalostylis</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> immersed and superficial, consisting of hyaline, smooth, branched, septate, 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam hyphae. <italic>Sporodochia</italic> slimy, hyaline, becoming pale brown with age. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> tightly aggregated, irregularly branched, hyaline, smooth, 0&#x2013;4-septate, 5&#x2013;25 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3.5 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> smooth, hyaline, ampulliform, terminal and lateral with sympodial proliferation and inconspicuous flat-tipped loci, 4&#x2013;10 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;3.5 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aggregating in mucoid packets, hyaline, smooth-walled, guttulate, fusoid, curved, apex subobtuse, base truncate, 1&#x2013;3-septate, (13&#x2013;)16&#x2013;20(&#x2013;23) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3(&#x2013;4) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, covering dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA and PDA surface saffron to luteous, reverse sienna; on OA surface umber to saffron.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>New Zealand</bold>, Auckland, Auckland Botanical Garden, on leaves of <italic>Rhopalostylis sapida</italic> (<italic>Arecaceae</italic>), 2017, <italic>R. Thangavel</italic>, T17_03052B (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23835, culture ex-type CPC 34449 = CBS 145125).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Note</italic>: <italic>Microdochium</italic> and allied genera were revised by <xref rid="R58" ref-type="bibr">Hern&#xE1;ndez-Restrepo <italic>et al</italic>. (2016)</xref>. Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pseudofusarium fusarioideum</italic> (GenBank MH860033.1; Identities = 537/551 (97 %), 7 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Microdochium phragmitis</italic> (GenBank NR_132916.1; Identities = 529/544 (97 %), 7 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Microdochium lycopodinum</italic> (GenBank KP859005.1; Identities = 529/544 (97 %), 8 gaps (1 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Microdochium phragmitis</italic> (GenBank KP858948.1; Identities = 893/893 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Microdochium lycopodinum</italic> (GenBank KP858929.1; Identities = 847/855 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Microdochium fisheri</italic> (GenBank KP858951.1; Identities = 825/844 (98 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). Distant hits using the <bold><italic>actA</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Penicillifer pulcher</italic> (GenBank KM231107.1; Identities = 406/420 (97 %), no gaps), <italic>Penicillifer bipapillatus</italic> (GenBank KM231105.1; Identities = 404/420 (96 %), no gaps), and <italic>Gliocephalotrichum longibrachium</italic> (GenBank KM231117.1; Identities = 403/419 (96 %), no gaps). Only very distant hits were obtained using the <bold><italic>cmdA</italic></bold> sequence, for example with <italic>Penicillium johnkrugii</italic> (GenBank JN686399.1; Identities = 135/142 (95 %), no gaps), <italic>Penicillium exsudans</italic> (GenBank KX885052.1; Identities = 133/139 (96 %), no gaps), and <italic>Penicillium austrosinicum</italic> (GenBank KX885051.; Identities = 133/139 (96 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Microdochium phragmitis</italic> (GenBank KP859122.1; Identities = 798/849 (94 %), no gaps), <italic>Microdochium lycopodinum</italic> (GenBank KP859102.1; Identities = 789/837 (94 %), no gaps), and <italic>Microdochium fisheri</italic> (GenBank KP859124.1; Identities = 750/841 (89 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). The best hit using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Microdochium musae</italic> (GenBank MH108044.1; Identities = 115/135 (85 %), 5 gaps (3 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Neocordana malayensis</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829313. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F28">Fig. 28</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to Malaysia where it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of pale brown, smooth, branched, septate, 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> subcylindrical, flexuous, erect, medium brown, smooth, multiseptate, 200&#x2013;500 &#xD7; 7&#x2013;9 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> polyblastic, terminal and intercalary, 10&#x2013;40 &#xD7; 6&#x2013;8 &#xB5;m, denticulate; denticles up to 1 &#xB5;m long, 0.5&#x2013;1 &#xB5;m wide. <italic>Conidia</italic> oblong to obovoid, (12&#x2013;)14&#x2013;18(&#x2013;20) &#xD7; (8&#x2013;)10 &#xB5;m, 1-septate, thick-walled, brown with truncate hilum, 1 &#xB5;m diam.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and feathery margin, reaching 65 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface dirty white with patches of pale olivaceous grey or pale luteous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Malaysia</bold>, on leaves of <italic>Musa</italic> sp. (<italic>Musaceae</italic>), Feb. 2010, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, HPC 1595 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23812, culture ex-type CPC 32837 = CBS 144604).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Neocordana</italic> was introduced by <xref rid="R57" ref-type="bibr">Hern&#xE1;ndez-Restrepo <italic>et al.</italic> (2015)</xref> to accommodate several species of hyphomycetes causing a foliar disease on <italic>Canna</italic> and <italic>Musa</italic>. The morphological characteristics of <italic>N. malayensis</italic> overlap with those of <italic>N. musae</italic> and <italic>N. musicola</italic> in conidial dimensions, but are distinct from them in having very long, flexuous conidiophores. Phylogenetically, it also clusters apart from <italic>N. musae</italic> and <italic>N. musicola.</italic></p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Neocordana musigena</italic> (GenBank KY979749.1; Identities = 553/575 (96 %), 15 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Neocordana musarum</italic> (GenBank KY173425.1; Identities = 553/575 (96 %), 15 gaps (2 %)), and <italic>Neocordana musae</italic> (GenBank LN713276.1; Identities = 553/575 (96 %), 15 gaps (2 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Neocordana musicola</italic> (GenBank LN713287.1; Identities = 843/847 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Neocordana musarum</italic> (GenBank KY173515.1; Identities = 820/824 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Neocordana musae</italic> (GenBank LN713290.1; Identities = 873/878 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>actA</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Neocordana musigena</italic> (GenBank KY979854.1; Identities = 746/746 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Neocordana musarum</italic> (GenBank KY173568.1; Identities = 357/358(99%), no gaps), and <italic>Gaeumannomyces tritici</italic> (GenBank XM_009225830.1; Identities = 386/414 (93 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Neocordana musigena</italic> (GenBank KY979915.1; Identities = 553/559 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Hypoxylon calileguense</italic> (GenBank KU604578.1; Identities = 714/797 (90 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and <italic>Chaetomium globosum</italic> (GenBank XM_001226965.1; Identities = 654/735 (89 %), 2 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Neocucurbitaria prunicola</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Akulov, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829314. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F29">Fig. 29</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Prunus</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, solitary to aggregated, globose, medium brown, 100&#x2013;200 &#xB5;m diam, with central ostiole, 20&#x2013;40 &#xB5;m diam, surrounded with erect, unbranched, brown, smooth, 1&#x2013;2-septate, thick-walled setae, 20&#x2013;40(&#x2013;70) &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m, with obtuse ends; conidiomatal wall of 3&#x2013;4 layers of flattened, brown <italic>textura angularis. Conidiophores</italic> lining the inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical, branched, 1&#x2013;3-septate, 10&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical to doliiform, phialidic, terminal and intercalary, 3&#x2013;10 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> hyaline, smooth, aseptate, guttulate, subcylindrical with obtuse ends, (2&#x2013;)3&#x2013;3.5(&#x2013;4) &#xD7; 1.5(&#x2013;2) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 40 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse grey olivaceous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Ukraine</bold>, Ternopil region, Dniester Canyon N.P., forest, fallen twigs of <italic>Prunus padus</italic> (= <italic>Padus avium</italic>) (<italic>Rosaceae</italic>), 6 Oct. 2016, <italic>A. Akulov</italic>, CWU AS 6209 = HPC 2045 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23824, culture ex-type CPC 33709 = CBS 145033).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Neocucurbitaria</italic> was treated by <xref rid="R60" ref-type="bibr">Jaklitsch <italic>et al.</italic> (2018)</xref>, and shown to have phoma-like asexual morphs. <italic>Neocucurbitaria prunicola</italic> is phylogenetically distinct from other species presently known in the genus.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Neocucurbitaria rhamni</italic> (GenBank MF795778.1; Identities = 446/483 (92 %), 5 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Neocucurbitaria rhamnioides</italic> (GenBank MF795784.1; Identities = 447/486 (92 %), 7 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Astragalicola vasilyevae</italic> (GenBank NR_157504.1; Identities = 453/494 (92 %), 13 gaps (2 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Neocucurbitaria unguis-hominis</italic> (GenBank GQ387621.1;Identities = 850/854 (99 %),no gaps),<italic>Neocucurbitaria keratinophila</italic> (GenBank MH874704.1; Identities = 849/854 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Neocucurbitaria quercina</italic> (GenBank GQ387620.1; Identities = 849/854 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Neocucurbitaria unguishominis</italic> (as <italic>Pyrenochaeta unguis-hominis</italic>, GenBank LT717682.1; Identities = 760/866 (88 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Cucurbitaria berberidis</italic> (GenBank LT854936.1; Identities = 768/876 (88 %), 7 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Neocucurbitaria cava</italic> (as <italic>Pyrenochaeta cava</italic>, GenBank LT717681.1; Identities = 744/856 (87 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). Distant hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Neocucurbitaria juglandicola</italic> (GenBank MF795901.1; Identities = 452/495 (91 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Neocucurbitaria populi</italic> (GenBank MF795902.1; Identities = 451/495 (91 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Neocucurbitaria rhamnioides</italic> (GenBank MF795908.1; Identities = 448/493 (91 %), 7 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Leptosphaeria biglobosa</italic> (as <italic>Leptosphaeria maculans</italic>, GenBank FO906902.1; Identities = 887/999 (89 %), 11 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Leptosphaeria biglobosa</italic> (GenBank FO905876.1; Identities = 877/987 (89 %), 10 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Helminthosporium solani</italic> (GenBank AF461130.1; Identities = 702/803 (87 %), 10 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Neocucurbitaria salicis-albae</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829315. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F30">Fig. 30</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Salix alba</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, solitary or aggregated, brown, globose, 70&#x2013;120 &#xB5;m diam, with prominent papillate darker brown central ostiole 1(&#x2013;3), 20&#x2013;30 &#xB5;m diam; wall of 3&#x2013;6 layers of pale brown <italic>textura angularis</italic>. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> lining the inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, reduced to conidiogenous cells, ampulliform, phialidic, 5&#x2013;7 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, hyaline, smooth, prominently guttulate, thin-walled, subcylindrical to fusoid-ellipsoid, (2.5&#x2013;)3&#x2013;3.5(&#x2013;4) &#xD7; 2 &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 17&#x2013;30 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, on <italic>Salix alba</italic> twig, 21 Jan. 2017, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic>, HPC 1963 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23818, culture ex-type CPC 33162 = CBS 144611).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Pyrenochaeta</italic> (= <italic>Cucurbitaria</italic>) was resurrected as discrete genus by <xref rid="R31" ref-type="bibr">De Gruyter <italic>et al.</italic> (2010</xref>). <italic>Neocucurbitaria</italic> was established by <xref rid="R97" ref-type="bibr">Wanasinghe <italic>et al</italic>. (2017</xref>) for a sister genus with pyrenochaeta-like asexual morphs, and cucurbitaria-like sexual morphs. <italic>Neocucurbitaria</italic> and several pyrenochaeta-like genera and their respective families were clarified further by <xref rid="R93" ref-type="bibr">Valenzuela-Lopez <italic>et al.</italic> (2018)</xref>. <italic>Neocucurbitaria salicis-albae</italic> is a new species from <italic>Salix</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Neocucurbitaria quercina</italic> (as <italic>Pyrenochaeta quercina</italic>, GenBank LT623220.1; Identities = 519/533 (97 %), no gaps), <italic>Neocucurbitaria acanthocladae</italic> (GenBank MF795766.1; Identities = 515/535 (96 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Neocucurbitaria unguis-hominis</italic> (as <italic>Pyrenochaeta unguis-hominis</italic>, GenBank KP794081.1; Identities = 472/490 (96 %), 7 gaps (1 %)). The ITS sequence is identical to &#x201C;<italic>Cucurbitariaceae</italic> sp. MUT 4403&#x201D; (GenBank KC339238.1; Identities = 491/491 (100 %)), isolated from <italic>Posidonia oceanica</italic> in the Punta Manara-Riva Trigoso Bay, Italy. Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Neocucurbitaria keratinophila</italic> (GenBank MH874704.1; Identities = 859/861 (99 %), no gaps)), <italic>Neocucurbitaria quercina</italic> (GenBank GQ387620.1; Identities = 859/861 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Neocucurbitaria aquatica</italic> (GenBank EU754177.1; Identities = 859/861 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Neocucurbitaria quercina</italic> (as <italic>Pyrenochaeta quercina</italic>, GenBank LT623277.1; Identities = 919/956 (96 %), no gaps), <italic>Neocucurbitaria unguis-hominis</italic> (as <italic>Pyrenochaeta unguishominis</italic>, GenBank LT623279.1; Identities = 872/952 (92 %), no gaps), and <italic>Neocucurbitaria aetnensis</italic> (GenBank MF795811.1; Identities = 832/900 (92 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Neocucurbitaria acanthocladae</italic> (GenBank MF795894.1; Identities = 440/457 (96 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Neocucurbitaria cinereae</italic> (GenBank MF795899.1; Identities = 438/457 (96 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Neocucurbitaria ribicola</italic> (GenBank MF795912.1; Identities = 432/457 (95 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Leptosphaeria biglobosa</italic> (GenBank FO905876.1; Identities = 932/1036 (90 %), 6 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Westerdykella cylindrica</italic> (GenBank JX235707.1; Identities = 689/777 (89 %), 10 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Helminthosporium solani</italic> (GenBank AF461130.1; Identities = 745/861 (87 %), 12 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Neodevriesia metrosideri</italic></bold> Crous, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>41</bold>: 303. 2018. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F31">Fig. 31</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Metrosideros</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of branched, septate, brown, smooth, 3(&#x2013;5) &#xB5;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> erect, solitary, arising directly from superficial hyphae, subcylindrical, straight to somewhat curved, smooth, brown, 0&#x2013;2-septate, 10&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, integrated, subcylindrical, brown, smooth, 5&#x2013;10 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m; hila truncate, 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam, not darkened nor thickened. <italic>Conidia</italic> occurring in branched chains (&#x2013;15), medium brown, smooth, subcylindrical to fusoid-ellipsoid, 0&#x2013;1(&#x2013;2)-septate, (10&#x2013;)13&#x2013;15(&#x2013;20) &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3(&#x2013;4) &#xB5;m; hila unthickened, not darkened, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, with moderate aerial mycelium, and smooth, lobate margins, reaching 20 mm diam after 2 wk. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse iron-grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>New Zealand</bold>, Auckland, Bucklands Beach, 22 Wells Road, on leaves of <italic>Metrosideros excelsa</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), 2015, <italic>R. Thangavel</italic>, T16_03926G, CBS H-23810, culture CBS 144638 = CPC 32786.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Neodevriesia metrosideri</italic> was recently described from <italic>Metrosideros</italic> sp. on the Great Barrier Island in New Zealand (<xref rid="R21" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2018b</xref>), and this is the second collection of this taxon from this country.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Neodevriesia lagerstroemiae</italic> (GenBank GU214634.1; Identities = 518/533 (97 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Neodevriesia fraserae</italic> (as <italic>Devriesia fraseriae</italic>, GenBank NR_144961.1; Identities = 508/535 (95 %), 9 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Devriesia sardiniae</italic> (GenBank KP791766.1; Identities = 504/531 (95 %), 4 gaps (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Neodevriesia lagerstroemiae</italic> (GenBank KF902149.1; Identities = 732/741 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Neodevriesia knoxdaviesii</italic> (as <italic>Teratosphaeria knoxdaviesii</italic>, GenBank EU707865.1; Identities = 801/814 (98 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Neodevriesia cladophorae</italic> (as <italic>Devriesia</italic> sp. MW-2016a, GenBank KU578114.1; Identities = 798/813 (98 %), no gaps). No <bold><italic>actA</italic></bold> sequences of <italic>Neodevriesia</italic> or <italic>Devriesia</italic> are currently available for comparison on GenBank. No significant hits were obtained when the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence was used in blastn and megablast searches.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Neodothidotthia</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829317.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name reflects its morphological similarity to the genus <italic>Dothidotthia</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Sporodochia</italic> dark brown, punctiform. <italic>Stromata</italic> immersed to superficial, brown. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> brown, finely roughened, subcylindrical, septate. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> brown, subcylindrical, finely roughened, proliferating percurrently at apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> fusoid to ellipsoid, medium brown, transversely septate, apex obtuse, base truncate.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>:<italic> Neodothidotthia negundinicola</italic> Crous &amp; Akulov.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Neodothidotthia negundinicola</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Akulov, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829318. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F32">Fig. 32</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Acer negundo</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Sporodochia</italic> dark brown, punctiform, 100&#x2013;300 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Stromata</italic> immersed to superficial, brown, 80&#x2013;150 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> brown, finely roughened, subcylindrical, 4&#x2013;6-septate, 60&#x2013;150 &#xD7; 7&#x2013;12 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> brown, subcylindrical, finely roughened, 8&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 5&#x2013;7 &#xB5;m, proliferating percurrently at apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> fusoid to ellipsoid, medium brown, transversely (1&#x2013;)2-septate, apex obtuse, base truncate, 4&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m diam, (25&#x2013;)30&#x2013;35(&#x2013;37) &#xD7; (12&#x2013;)13&#x2013;15(&#x2013;16) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth to feathery, lobate margin, covering dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Ukraine</bold>, Kharkiv region, Zolochiv district, on the dead branches of <italic>Acer negundo</italic> (<italic>Sapindaceae</italic>) still attached to the tree, 28 May 2017, <italic>A. Akulov &amp; R.K. Schumacher</italic>, CWU AS 6293 = HPC 2127 = RKS 116 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23832, culture ex-type CPC 34071 = CBS 145039).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Neodothidotthia negundinis</italic></bold> (Berk. &amp; M.A. Curtis) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829319.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym: Coryneum negundinis</italic> Berk. &amp; M.A. Curtis, <italic>Grevillea</italic>
<bold>2</bold>(22): 153. 1874.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonym</italic>: <italic>Thyrostroma negundinis</italic> (Berk. &amp; M.A. Curtis) A.W. Ramaley, <italic>Mycotaxon</italic>
<bold>94</bold>: 131. 2006 (2005).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Illustration</italic>: See <xref rid="R71" ref-type="bibr">Phillips <italic>et al.</italic> (2008)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>USA</bold>, Colorado, Durango, 7 Animas Place, dead twigs of <italic>Euonymus alatus</italic>, 29 Jun. 2004, <italic>A.W. Ramaley 0411</italic>, BPI 871820, culture CPC 12930 = CBS 119688; Colorado, Durango, between Animas Place and Animas River, dead twigs of <italic>Acer negundo</italic>, 8 Jul. 2004, <italic>A.W. Ramaley 0414</italic>, BPI 871819, asexual morph culture CPC 12933 = CBS 119691, sexual morph CPC 12932 = CBS 119690; Colorado, La Plata Co, <italic>ca</italic>. 1.75 mile up Carbon Junction Trail, dead twigs of <italic>Fendlera rupicola</italic>, 11 May 2004, <italic>A.W. Ramaley 0403</italic>, BPI 871821, culture CPC 12928 = CBS 119686.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Thyrostroma negundinis</italic> (as <italic>Stigmina negundinis</italic>, on twigs of <italic>Acer negundo</italic>, North America) has conidia that are ellipsoid, 2-septate, 25&#x2013;38 &#xD7; 12&#x2013;18 &#xB5;m, base 4&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m diam (<xref rid="R37" ref-type="bibr">Ellis 1971</xref>), thus closely fitting with the present collection, although they are phylogenetically distinct. <xref rid="R73" ref-type="bibr">Ramaley (2005)</xref> found conidia on the type specimen of <italic>Amphisphaeria aspera</italic> to be much smaller, namely (10&#x2013;)12&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 6&#x2013;7 &#xB5;m, suggesting that the latter collection represents a different species in this complex.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><xref rid="R73" ref-type="bibr">Ramaley (2005)</xref> and <xref rid="R71" ref-type="bibr">Phillips <italic>et al.</italic> (2008)</xref> showed that <italic>Dothidotthia</italic> (based on <italic>D. symphoricarpi</italic> from the USA; CBS 119687) has a <italic>Thyrostroma</italic> (based on <italic>T. compactum</italic>, reference strain CBS 335.37) asexual morph, which they ascribed to <italic>Thyrostroma negundinis</italic>. The link between the two genera has however, not been confirmed in culture. It has thus been proposed to continue using both names until this question has been resolved (Wijayawardene <italic>et al.</italic> 2014, <xref rid="R79" ref-type="bibr">Rossman <italic>et al.</italic> 2015</xref>). As we show here, <italic>Thyrostroma</italic> is closely allied, but not congeneric with <italic>Dothidotthia</italic>, thus both generic names should be retained. Furthermore, the European collection of &#x201C;<italic>Thyrostroma negundinis</italic>&#x201D; is allied to <italic>D</italic>. <italic>symphoricarpi</italic>, but is phylogenetically distinct, and therefore described here as a new genus, <italic>Neodothidotthia</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Thyrostroma cornicola</italic> (GenBank NR_154514.1; Identities = 517/540 (96 %), 6 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Thyrostroma compactum</italic> (GenBank MH859911.1; Identities = 516/540 (96 %), 6 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Phaeomycocentrospora cantuariensis</italic> (GenBank MH866055.1; Identities = 515/539 (96 %), 6 gaps (1 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Phaeomycocentrospora cantuariensis</italic> (GenBank GU253716.1; Identities = 866/877 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Pleiochaeta setosa</italic> (GenBank EU167563.1; Identities = 847/859 (99 %), 3 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Pleiochaeta ghindensis</italic> (GenBank EU167561.1; Identities = 845/858 (98 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Phaeomycocentrospora cantuariensis</italic> (GenBank GU384382.1; Identities = 265/308 (86 %), 9 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Thyrostroma cornicola</italic> (GenBank KX228372.1; Identities = 312/372 (84 %), 12 gaps (3 %)), and <italic>Pyrenophora biseptata</italic> (as <italic>Drechslera biseptata</italic>, GenBank JN712588.1; Identities = 321/402 (80 %), 30 gaps (7 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Neohelicomyces deschampsiae</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829320. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F33">Fig. 33</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Deschampsia</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiophores</italic> erect, flexuous, mostly unbranched, subcylindrical with slight apical taper, 10&#x2013;15-septate, 150&#x2013;220 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m, brown, smooth-walled, tapering toward subobtuse apex. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> intercalary, consisting of short, lateral, cylindrical pegs, pale brown, monoblastic, rarely polyblastic, 2&#x2013;5 &#xD7; 1.5&#x2013;2.5 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, coiled 2&#x2013;3 times, multiseptate, coils 19&#x2013;22 &#xB5;m diam, cells 2&#x2013;2.5 &#xB5;m diam.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with folded surface and feathery lobate margin, reaching 20 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface umber, reverse sienna; on PDA surface umber, reverse ochreous; on OA surface umber.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, culm base of dead leaf sheath of <italic>Deschampsia cespitosa</italic> (<italic>Poaceae</italic>), 3 May 2017, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic>, HPC 2109 = RKS 101 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23590, culture ex-type CPC 33686 = CBS 145029).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Neohelicomyces</italic> differs from <italic>Tubeufia</italic> and allied genera, especially from <italic>Helicomyces</italic>, in having elongate, erect, conspicuous conidiophores, and differs from <italic>Helicosporium</italic> based on conidial morphology (<xref rid="R89" ref-type="bibr">Tsui <italic>et al</italic>. 2006</xref>). Based on the species known from their DNA, <italic>N. deschampsiae</italic> appears to represent a new species, being phylogenetically distinct from <italic>T. helicomyces</italic> and <italic>T. paludosa</italic>, which have also been reported from this host (<xref rid="R39" ref-type="bibr">Ellis &amp; Ellis 1997</xref>).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Tubeufia helicomyces</italic> (GenBank MH857031.1; Identities = 556/591 (94 %), 18 gaps (3 %)), <italic>Helicosporium lumbricoides</italic> (GenBank MH856861.1; Identities = 554/590 (94 %), 16 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Helicosporium pallidum</italic> (GenBank AY916462.1; Identities = 550/586 (94 %), 16 gaps (2 %)), and <italic>Neohelicomyces</italic>
<italic>aquaticus</italic> (as <italic>Tubeufiaceae</italic> sp. ZL-2017b, GenBank KY320528.1; Identities = 422/452 (93 %), 20 gaps (4 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Neohelicomyces aquaticus</italic> (as <italic>Tubeufiaceae</italic> sp. ZL-2017b, GenBank KY320545.1; Identities = 849/849 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Neohelicomyces hyalosporus</italic> (as <italic>Neohelicomyces</italic> sp. YZL-2018a, GenBank MH558870.1; Identities = 841/843 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Neohelicomyces submersus</italic> (as <italic>Tubeufiaceae</italic> sp. ZL-2017c, GenBank KY320547.1; Identities = 827/830 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Tubeufia helicomyces</italic> (GenBank MH868562.1; Identities = 854/860 (99 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Neomedicopsis</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Akulov, <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829321.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the genus <italic>Medicopsis</italic>, which is phylogenetically allied to it.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, globose, erumpent with central ostiole; wall of 6&#x2013;12 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells, hyaline, smooth, ampulliform with long cylindrical neck, proliferating percurrently. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, globose to subglobose, initially pale brown, becoming dark brown, thick-walled, guttulate, granular, apex obtuse, base truncate.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>: <italic>Neomedicopsis prunicola</italic> Crous &amp; Akulov.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Neomedicopsis prunicola</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Akulov, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829322. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F34">Fig. 34</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Prunus</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, globose, 200&#x2013;300 &#xB5;m diam, erumpent with central ostiole; wall of 6&#x2013;12 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells, hyaline, smooth, ampulliform with long cylindrical neck, 10&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;6 &#xB5;m, proliferating percurrently. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, globose to subglobose, initially pale brown, becoming dark brown, thick-walled, guttulate, granular, apex obtuse, base truncate, 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m diam, (12&#x2013;)17&#x2013;20(&#x2013;22) &#xD7; (12&#x2013;)14&#x2013;16(&#x2013;17) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 25 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface pale olivaceous grey, reverse olivaceous grey; on PDA surface and reverse olivaceous grey; on OA surface olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Ukraine</bold>, Ternopil region, Dniester Canyon N.P., forest, fallen twigs of <italic>Prunus padus</italic> (= <italic>Padus avium</italic>) (<italic>Rosaceae</italic>), 6 Oct. 2016, <italic>A. Akulov</italic>, HPC 2045 = CWU AS 6209 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23825, culture ex-type CPC 33711 = CBS 145031).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <xref rid="R31" ref-type="bibr">de Gruyter <italic>et al</italic>. (2013)</xref> introduced the genus <italic>Medicopsis</italic> to accommodate <italic>P. romeroi</italic>, a pathogen associated with mycetoma in humans (<xref rid="R1" ref-type="bibr">Ahmed <italic>et al.</italic> 2014</xref>). <italic>Medicopsis</italic> is phoma-like in morphology, and <italic>Neomedicopsis</italic> is distinct in having globose, dark brown, thick-walled conidia that arise from long cylindrical conidiogenous cells that proliferate percurrently. <italic>Neomedicopsis</italic> is somewhat reminiscent of <italic>Lasmeniella</italic>, except that it lacks multilocular conidiomata.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Medicopsis romeroi</italic> (GenBank JX088727.1; Identities = 506/557 (91 %), 13 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Pleomassaria acericola</italic> (GenBank MH863515.1; Identities = 490/555 (88 %), 22 gaps (3 %)), and <italic>Neohendersonia kickxii</italic> (GenBank KX820257.1; Identities = 483/555 (87 %), 21 gaps (3 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Medicopsis romeroi</italic> (GenBank MH869528.1; Identities = 837/861 (97 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Lentithecium aquaticum</italic> (GenBank MH874800.1; Identities = 837/867 (97 %), 12 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Murilentithecium clematidis</italic> (GenBank KM408758.1; Identities = 834/864 (97 %), 7 gaps (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Medicopsis romeroi</italic> (GenBank LT797035.1; Identities = 584/706 (83 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Crassiparies quadrisporus</italic> (GenBank LC271252.1; Identities = 578/718 (81 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Farasanispora avicenniae</italic> (GenBank MG973031.1; Identities = 576/726 (79 %), 12 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Phaeoappendicosporaceae</italic></bold> Crous &amp; M.J. Wingf., <bold><italic>fam. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829458.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Pseudostroma</italic> immersed, becoming erumpent; ectostroma pale brown to grey, containing periphyses; ostioles cylindrical. <italic>Perithecia</italic> globose to lenticular, dark brown, wall of <italic>textura angularis. Paraphyses</italic> hyaline, septate, unbranched, hypha-like. <italic>Asci</italic> ellipsoid to fusoid, 8-spored, without a refractive canal at apex. <italic>Ascospores</italic> ellipsoid-fusoid, brown, 1-euseptate, with gelatinous appendage at each truncate end. <italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, multilocular, forming a long neck. <italic>Paraphyses</italic> hyaline, cylindrical, septate, unbranched, hypha-like. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> subcylindrical, hyaline to pale brown, septate, unbranched. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> cylindrical, hyaline to pale brown, proliferating percurrently at apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> ellipsoid to oblong, straight to slightly curved, thick-walled, transversely euseptate with oblique septa.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type genus</italic>:<italic> Phaeoappendicospora</italic> Senan., Q.R. Li &amp; K.D. Hyde</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Neophaeoappendicospora</italic></bold> Crous &amp; M.J. Wingf., <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829323.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name reflects its morphological similarity to <italic>Phaeoappendicospora.</italic></p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Pseudostroma</italic> immersed, becoming erumpent, causing fissures; ectostroma pale brown to grey, containing tightly packed periphyses; ostioles cylindrical, inconspicuous with brown walls, not projecting; entostroma confined to a network of pale brown hyphae, enclosing a circular group of tightly packed perithecial ascomata with convergent ostioles. <italic>Perithecia</italic> globose to lenticular, dark brown, wall of <italic>textura angularis. Paraphyses</italic> intermingled among asci, hyaline, septate, unbranched, constricted at septa, hypha-like. <italic>Asci</italic> ellipsoid to fusoid, with 8 biseriate ascospores, without a refractive canal at apex (Melzer&#x2019;s reagent). <italic>Ascospores</italic> ellipsoid-fusoid, brown, 1-euseptate, thick-walled, with gelatinous appendage at each truncate end, smooth, becoming verruculose with age, granular to guttulate, with truncate apices and central apiculus. <italic>Conidiomata</italic> immersed in bark, pycnidial, multilocular, forming a long neck. <italic>Paraphyses</italic> hyaline, cylindrical, septate, unbranched, hypha-like. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> subcylindrical, hyaline to pale brown, septate, unbranched. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> cylindrical, hyaline to pale brown, proliferating percurrently with numerous percurrent proliferations at apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> ellipsoid to oblong, straight to slightly curved, thick-walled, guttulate, transversely euseptate with oblique septa.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>: <italic>Neophaeoappendicospora leucaenae</italic> Crous &amp; M.J. Wingf.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Neophaeoappendicospora leucaenae</italic></bold> Crous &amp; M.J. Wingf., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829324. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F35">Fig. 35</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Leucaena</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Pseudostroma</italic> immersed in bark, up to 2 mm diam, becoming erumpent, causing fissures; ectostroma pale brown to grey, containing tightly packed periphyses; ostioles cylindrical, inconspicuous with brown walls, not projecting; entostroma confined to a network of pale brown hyphae, enclosing a circular group of up to 12 tightly packed perithecial ascomata with convergent ostioles. <italic>Perithecia</italic> globose to lenticular, dark brown, wall of <italic>textura angularis. Paraphyses</italic> intermingled among asci, hyaline, septate, unbranched, constricted at septa, hypha-like, 5&#x2013;6 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Asci</italic> ellipsoid to fusoid, with 8 biseriate ascospores, without a refractive canal at apex (Melzer&#x2019;s reagent), 130&#x2013;180 &#xD7; 17&#x2013;25 &#xB5;m. <italic>Ascospores</italic> ellipsoid-fusoid, brown, 1-euseptate, thick-walled, with gelatinous appendage at each truncate end, smooth, becoming verruculose with age, granular to guttulate, (34&#x2013;)36&#x2013;42(&#x2013;47) &#xD7; (9&#x2013;)10(&#x2013;11) &#xB5;m; at times slightly swollen at septum (wall appearing thickened), and truncate apices with central apiculus. <italic>Conidiomata</italic> immersed in bark, pycnidial, up to 800 &#xB5;m diam, multilocular, forming a long neck on host, up to 1 mm tall. <italic>Paraphyses</italic> hyaline, cylindrical, septate, unbranched, hypha-like, 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> subcylindrical, hyaline to pale brown, 0&#x2013;2-septate, unbranched, 15&#x2013;50 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;6 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> cylindrical, hyaline to pale brown, proliferating percurrently with numerous percurrent proliferations at apex, 15&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;6 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> ellipsoid to oblong, straight to slightly curved, thick-walled, guttulate, 3-transversely euseptate with 1&#x2013;3 oblique septa, apex obtuse, base truncate, 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m diam, (24&#x2013;)26&#x2013;29(&#x2013;34) &#xD7; (11&#x2013;)12(&#x2013;13) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, with sparse aerial mycelium, slow-growing, with lobate margins. On MEA surface umber with patches of dirty white, reverse chestnut. On PDA surface umber, reverse umber with patches of diffuse sienna pigment. On OA surface isabelline.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>France</bold>, La R&#xE9;union, stems of <italic>Leucaena leucocephala</italic> (<italic>Fabaceae</italic>), 13 Mar. 2014, <italic>M.J. Wingfield</italic>, HPC 309 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23794, culture ex-type CPC 27240).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Neophaeoappendicospora</italic> is morphologically similar to <italic>Phaeoappendicospora</italic>, which was established as monotypic genus by <xref rid="R82" ref-type="bibr">Senanayake <italic>et al</italic>. (2017)</xref> for a fungus occurring on dead twigs of <italic>Quercus</italic> in Thailand. <italic>Neophaeoappendicospora leucaenae</italic> is distinct from <italic>P. thailandensis</italic> (ascospores 26&#x2013;34.5 &#xD7; 11&#x2013;13 &#x3BC;m) by its larger ascospores, and the fact that <italic>Neophaeoappendicospora</italic> readily forms an asexual morph in culture, which is absent in <italic>Phaeoappendicospora</italic>. <italic>Phaeoappendicospora</italic> and <italic>Neophaeoappendicospora</italic> represent genera in a new family, introduced here as <italic>Phaeoappendicosporaceae.</italic></p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Diaporthe australafricana</italic> (GenBank KR534731.1; Identities = 395/458 (86 %), 22 gaps (4 %)), <italic>Diaporthe phaseolorum</italic> (GenBank LC171670.1; Identities = 505/615 (82 %), 55 gaps (8 %)), and <italic>Diaporthe helianthi</italic> (GenBank MF033502.1; Identities = 505/615 (82 %), 55 gaps (8 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Pachytrype rimosa</italic> (GenBank FJ532381.1; Identities = 806/851 (95 %), 8 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Hapalocystis berkeleyi</italic> (GenBank MG548637.1; Identities = 797/844 (94 %), 6 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Melanconium elaeidicola</italic> (GenBank NG_058172.1; Identities = 803/851 (94 %), 5 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Ochroconis musae</italic></bold> (G.Y. Sun &amp; Lu Hao) Samerp. &amp; de Hoog, <italic>Mycol. Progr.</italic>
<bold>14</bold> (no. 6): 8. 2015. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F36">Fig. 36</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Scolecobasidium musae</italic> G.Y. Sun &amp; Lu Hao, <italic>Mycol. Progr.</italic>
<bold>12</bold>: 492. 2012 (2013).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonym</italic>: <italic>Ochroconis mirabilis</italic> Samerp. &amp; de Hoog, <italic>Fungal Divers</italic>. <bold>65</bold>: 110. 2013 (2014).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of pale brown, smooth, branched, septate, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> erect to flexuous, arising from vegetative hyphae, subcylindrical, 1&#x2013;3-septate, 7&#x2013;40 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m, branched or not, brown, smooth-walled, proliferating sympodially with several denticles that are 1&#x2013;2 &#xD7; 1 &#xB5;m; conidiogenous cells 7&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 1.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> subcylindrical, (8&#x2013;)11&#x2013;13(&#x2013;16) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3(&#x2013;4) &#xB5;m, smooth-walled, pale brown, 1(&#x2013;3)-septate, becoming verruculose and constricted at septa with age, apex obtuse, tapering to truncate hilum, 1 &#xB5;m diam.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 25 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface umber with diffuse sienna pigment, reverse chestnut; on PDA surface and reverse umber; on OA surface umber.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Thailand</bold>, Chiang Mai, on leaf trichomes of <italic>Persea americana</italic> (<italic>Lauraceae</italic>), 2008, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, CBS H-23830, culture CPC 33947 = CBS 145061.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Ochroconis</italic> has pigmented conidiophores, and sympodial conidiogenesis with denticles that give rise to septate, pigmented, verruculose conidia (<xref rid="R46" ref-type="bibr">Giraldo <italic>et al</italic>. 2014</xref>, <xref rid="R27" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2017</xref>). The present collection is closely related to <italic>O. musae</italic> (<xref rid="R80" ref-type="bibr">Samerpitak <italic>et al</italic>. 2015</xref>).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Ochroconis musae</italic> (GenBank KT272078.1; Identities = 581/588 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Acroconidiellina arecae</italic> (GenBank KX306747.1; Identities = 663/672 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Ochroconis musae</italic> (as <italic>Ochroconis mirabilis</italic>, GenBank KF156028.1; Identities = 580/589 (98 %), 1 gap (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Ochroconis musae</italic> (as <italic>Ochroconis mirabilis</italic>, GenBank KF156139.1; Identities = 791/793 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Ochroconis musae</italic> (GenBank KT272086.1; Identities = 815/818 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Ochroconis dracaenae</italic> (GenBank MH878221.1; Identities = 808/813 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>actA</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Ochroconis mirabilis</italic> (GenBank HQ916972.1; Identities = 263/264 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Ochroconis constricta</italic> (GenBank KF155942.1; Identities = 263/264 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Ochroconis musae</italic> (as <italic>Ochroconis mirabilis</italic>, GenBank KT272055.1; Identities = 263/264 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Ochroconis humicola</italic> (GenBank AB564640.1; Identities = 430/433 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Ochroconis dracaenae</italic> (GenBank KX228377.1; Identities = 492/510 (96 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and <italic>Ochroconis musae</italic> (GenBank KF156002.1; Identities = 367/370 (99 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Paradevriesiaceae</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>fam. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829459.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Paradevriesia</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829325.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name reflects the fact that it is phylogenetically allied to <italic>Devriesia s.str</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of branched, septate, hyphae, irregular in width, smooth to verruculose, at times forming hyphal strands and hyphal coils; hyphae frequently forming dark brown, thick-walled, intercalary, muriformly septate chlamydospores in culture. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> macro- and micronematous subcylindrical, medium brown, straight to irregularly curved, septate, or reduced to conidiogenous cells. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal or lateral on hyphae, medium brown, smooth, guttulate, subcylindrical, mono- to polyblastic; scars somewhat darkened and thickened, but not refractive. <italic>Conidia</italic> medium brown, guttulate, smooth, in mostly unbranched chains, subcylindrical to narrowly ellipsoidal, septate; hila darkened, somewhat thickened, not refractive.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>:<italic> Paradevriesia americana</italic> (Arzanlou &amp; Crous) Crous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Paradevriesia americana</italic></bold> (Crous &amp; Dugan) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829326.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>:<italic> Devriesia americana</italic> Crous &amp; Dugan, <italic>Stud. Mycol.</italic>
<bold>58</bold>: 42. 2007.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Paradevriesia pseudoamericana</italic></bold> (J. Frank <italic>et al.</italic>) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829328.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Devriesia pseudoamericana</italic> J. Frank <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>24</bold>: 97. 2010.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Although morphologically similar, members of <italic>Paradevriesia</italic> have a different ecology to members of <italic>Devriesia</italic>
<italic>s. str</italic>. (<xref rid="R81" ref-type="bibr">Seifert <italic>et al.</italic> 2004</xref>), which usually occur in soil, and are thermotolerant. Species of <italic>Paradevriesia</italic> are presently known from plant and rock surfaces, and do not grow at high temperatures. Phylogenetically, <italic>Paradevriesia</italic> also represents a distinct family in <italic>Capnodiales</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pararamichloridium livistonae</italic></bold> Crous, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>39</bold>: 357. 2017. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F37">Fig. 37</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of hyaline, smooth, branched, septate, 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, cylindrical, erect, straight to flexuous, arising from superficial hyphae, pale brown, smooth, 2&#x2013;6-septate, 25&#x2013;65 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, integrated, cylindrical, pale brown, smooth, 14&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m, with terminal rachis of aggregated, short denticles, 1 &#xD7; 1 &#xB5;m, flat-tipped, not darkened nor thickened. <italic>Conidia</italic> aseptate, solitary, hyaline, smooth-walled, fusoid-ellipsoid to clavate, apex obtuse, tapering from middle to truncate hilum, 0.5 &#xB5;m diam, slightly reflective, 7&#x2013;8 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;2.5 &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 15 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface and reverse sienna with diffuse sienna pigment; on PDA surface pale luteous, reverse sienna with diffuse sienna pigment; on OA surface pale luteous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Murramarang National Park, on leaves of <italic>Livistona australis</italic> (<italic>Arecaceae</italic>), Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, CBS H-23800, culture CPC 32152 = CBS 144522.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Pararamichloridium livistonae</italic> was described from leaves of <italic>Livistona australis</italic> collected in Australia (<xref rid="R27" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 2017</xref>), and isolate CPC 32152 represents the second collection of this fungus from the type locality.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pararamichloridium livistonae</italic> (GenBank NR_156652.1; Identities = 616/617 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Pararamichloridium verrucosum</italic> (GenBank NR_156653.1; Identities = 380/447 (85 %), 22 gaps (4 %)), and <italic>Paramicrothyrium chinense</italic> (GenBank KM246198.1; Identities = 507/632 (80 %), 63 gaps (9 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Pararamichloridium livistonae</italic> (GenBank NG_058504.1; Identities = 834/835(99%), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Pararamichloridium verrucosum</italic> (GenBank MH873621.1; Identities = 844/877 (96 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Magnaporthiopsis poae</italic> (GenBank KM401651.1; Identities = 824/870 (95 %), 3 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pararoussoella juglandicola</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829329. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F38">Fig. 38</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Juglans</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> erumpent, globose, brown, pycnidial, 150&#x2013;300 &#xB5;m diam with central ostiole, exuding a black conidial mass. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells lining the inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, ampulliform to doliiform, phialidic with periclinal thickening at apex, 5&#x2013;7 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> aseptate, solitary, subcylindrical, guttulate, apex bluntly rounded, base truncate, hyaline becoming brown, smooth, (5&#x2013;)6(&#x2013;7) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3 &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and feathery, lobate margin, reaching 60 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, on twig of <italic>Juglans regia</italic> (<italic>Juglandaceae</italic>), 21 Jan. 2017, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic>, HPC 1953 = RKS 12 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23820, culture ex-type CPC 33400 = CBS 145037).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pararoussoella mukdahanensis</italic></bold> (Phook. <italic>et al.</italic>) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829330.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Roussoella mukdahanensis</italic> Phook. <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Fungal Diversity</italic>
<bold>82</bold>: 32. 2016 (2017).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Species of <italic>Thyridariaceae</italic> are commonly isolated from various plant substrates. The family was recently treated by <xref rid="R98" ref-type="bibr">Wanasinghe <italic>et al</italic>.
