(2018)</xref>, in which the genus <italic>Pararoussoella</italic> was established based on its distinct phylogenetic relationship to <italic>Roussoella</italic>. <italic>Pararoussoella juglandicola</italic> represents a new member of the genus, which is phylogenetically distinct from other species, including <italic>Roussoella mukdahanensis</italic>, for which a new combination is required.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Roussoella mukdahanensis</italic> (GenBank NR_155722.1; Identities = 488/497 (98 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Pararoussoella rosarum</italic> (GenBank NR_157529.1; Identities = 492/505 (97 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Aaosphaeria arxii</italic> (GenBank MH872962.1; Identities = 541/587 (92 %), 7 gaps (1 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Roussoella neopustulans</italic> (GenBank KJ474841.1; Identities = 824/837 (98 %), no gaps), <italic>Arthopyrenia salicis</italic> (GenBank KP671722.1; Identities = 852/866 (98 %), no gaps), and <italic>Roussoella pustulans</italic> (GenBank AB524623.1; Identities = 820/834 (98 %), no gaps). Distant hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Roussoella percutanea</italic> (GenBank KF366453.1; Identities = 575/710 (81 %), 10 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Parathyridaria percutanea</italic> (GenBank LT797063.1; Identities = 730/905 (81 %), 6 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Flammeascoma lignicola</italic> (GenBank KT324586.1; Identities = 696/898 (78 %), 8 gaps (0 %)). Very distant hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Roussoella scabrispora</italic> (GenBank KX650537.1; Identities = 130/140 (93 %), no gaps), <italic>Thyrostroma franseriae</italic> (GenBank KY905680.1; Identities = 203/235 (86 %), 3 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Stachybotrys limonispora</italic> (GenBank KU847058.1; Identities = 131/136 (96 %), no gaps), and <italic>Trichoderma applanatum</italic> (GenBank KJ634759.1; Identities = 141/150 (94 %), 3 gaps (2 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Petriella sordida</italic></bold> (Zukal) G.L. Barron &amp; J.C. Gilman, <italic>Canad. J. Bot.</italic>
<bold>39</bold>: 839. 1961. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F39">Fig. 39</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Microascus sordidus</italic> Zukal, <italic>Ber. dt. bot. Ges.</italic>
<bold>8</bold>: 297. 1890.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiophores</italic> synnematal, erect, flexuous, olivaceous brown, smooth, arising from a reduced basal stroma, consisting of numerous (30&#x2013;100) individual conidiophores, septate (septa 10&#x2013;30 &#xB5;m apart), 250&#x2013;350 &#xB5;m long, stipe (7&#x2013;)15&#x2013;30(&#x2013;90) &#xB5;m diam, with flaring conidiogenous head, containing an olivaceous brown, mucoid conidial mass<italic>. Conidiogenous cells</italic> subcylindrical, olivaceous, smooth, 10&#x2013;25 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;2.5 &#xB5;m, proliferating inconspicuously percurrently at apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, guttulate, smooth, subcylindrical, apex obtuse, slightly constricted in middle, base truncate, 2 &#xB5;m diam, slightly darkened, (7&#x2013;)9&#x2013;10(&#x2013;12) &#xD7; (3&#x2013;)3.5(&#x2013;4) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 25 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface saffron, reverse ochreous; on PDA surface pale luteous, reverse buff, on OA surface buff.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Ukraine</bold>, Rakhiv district, Transcarpathian region, on leaves of<italic> Luzula</italic> sp. (<italic>Juncaceae</italic>), Nov. 2016, <italic>A. Akulov</italic>, HPC 1497, CBS H-23801, culture CBS 144612 = CPC 32460).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Species of <italic>Petriella</italic> are commonly isolated from soil and dung (<xref rid="R63" ref-type="bibr">Lackner &amp; de Hoog 2011</xref>), and thus it is assumed that the isolate in the present study was probably an opportunist on leaves of <italic>Luzula</italic> sp. <italic>Petriella sordida</italic> was described to have synnemata with conidia being (5&#x2013;)6.5&#x2013;11.5(&#x2013;14) &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;5.5 &#xB5;m (<xref rid="R14" ref-type="bibr">Corlett &amp; MacLatchy 1987</xref>).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence of CPC 32460 had highest similarity to <italic>Petriella sordida</italic> (GenBank MH863637.1; Identities = 564/565 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Melanospora asymmetrica</italic> (GenBank KY628677.1; Identities = 554/556 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Petriella guttulata</italic> (GenBank MF782707.1; Identities = 558/565 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)). The ITS sequence was identical to that of &#x201C;<italic>Petriella</italic> sp. Vega423&#x201D; (GenBank EU002908.1, 565/565) isolated as root endophyte of <italic>Coffea arabica</italic> in Colombia. The ITS sequences of CPC 32460 and 32461 are identical. Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence of CPC 32460 are <italic>Petriella setifera</italic> (GenBank MH872684.1; Identities = 794/794 (100 %)), <italic>Petriella sordida</italic> (GenBank MH875102.1; Identities = 793/794 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Petriella asymmetrica</italic> var. <italic>cypria</italic> (GenBank MH867451.1; Identities = 793/794 (99 %), no gaps). The LSU sequences of CPC 32460 and 32461 are identical. The <bold><italic>cmdA</italic></bold> sequence of CPC 32460 was identical to that of <italic>Petriella sordida</italic> (strain UTHSC 03-394, GenBank AM409103.1; Identities = 449/449 (100 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence of CPC 32461 had highest similarity to <italic>Petriella setifera</italic> (GenBank DQ368640.1; Identities = 701/702 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Scedosporium boydii</italic> (GenBank KP981186.1; Identities = 510/600 (85 %), no gaps), and <italic>Pseudallescheria fusoidea</italic> (GenBank KP981195.1; Identities = 509/600 (85 %), no gaps). No <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequences of <italic>Petriella</italic> which cover the same region amplified here are available for comparison in GenBank; distant hits include <italic>Scedosporium aurantiacum</italic> (GenBank KJ784086.1; Identities = 278/334 (83 %), 8 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Scopulariopsis brevicaulis</italic> (GenBank KP009002.1; Identities = 148/159 (93 %), no gaps), and <italic>Thyronectria rhodochlora</italic> (GenBank KM225694.1; Identities = 144/154 (94 %), no gaps). The <italic>tef1</italic> sequences of CPC 32460 and 32461 are identical. The <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence of CPC 32460 was identical to both <italic>Petriella setifera</italic> (GenBank EU977491.1; Identities = 488/488 (100 %)) and <italic>Petriella sordida</italic> (GenBank AM409104.1; Identities = 399/399 (100 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pezicula eucalyptigena</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829331. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F40">Fig. 40</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>In vitro</italic>. <italic>Conidiomata</italic> sporodochial, forming superficially on agar, scattered, dark brown, 100&#x2013;250 &#xB5;m diam, exuding a creamy conidial mass. <italic>Macroconidiophores</italic> hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical, branched, 1&#x2013;4-septate, 40&#x2013;90 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m. <italic>Macroconidiogenous cells</italic> integrated, terminal and intercalary, subcylindrical, hyaline, smooth, phialidic with indistinct percurrent proliferations, 10&#x2013;25 &#xD7; &#xD7; 3.5&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m. <italic>Macroconidia</italic> aseptate, hyaline, smooth, guttulate, ellipsoid-clavate, straight to slightly curved, with prominently protruding truncate hilum, 2 &#xB5;m diam, (23&#x2013;)24&#x2013;27(&#x2013;30) &#xD7; (6&#x2013;)7(&#x2013;8) &#xB5;m. <italic>Microconidiophores</italic> hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical, branched, 6&#x2013;12-septate, 60&#x2013;130 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3.5 &#xB5;m. <italic>Microconidiogenous cells</italic> integrated, terminal and intercalary, subcylindrical, hyaline, smooth, phialidic, 10&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m. <italic>Microconidia</italic> hyaline, smooth, aseptate, subcylindrical, apex obtuse, base truncate, straight to irregularly curved, (7&#x2013;)10&#x2013;12(&#x2013;15) &#xD7; 2(&#x2013;2.5) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies spreading with moderate aerial mycelium, covering dish in 2 wk. On MEA surface honey to hazel, reverse hazel; on PDA surface buff, reverse isabelline; on OA surface honey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>South Africa</bold>, Western Cape Province, Malmesbury, on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> sp. (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), 2006, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23799, culture ex-type CBS 144637 = CPC 32129).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The <italic>Pezicula</italic> generic complex was recently revised by Chen <italic>et al</italic>. (2016). Species from this complex known to occur on <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> include <italic>Parafabraea caliginosa</italic>, <italic>Parafabraea eucalypti</italic>, and <italic>Pezicula californiae</italic> (from <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> leaves in California, USA). <italic>Pezicula eucalyptigena</italic> is phylogenetically closely related to <italic>P. californiae</italic> (conidia 12.5&#x2013;27.5 &#xD7; 4.2&#x2013;5.8 &#xB5;m), but morphologically distinct in that it has larger conidia (<xref rid="R11" ref-type="bibr">Cheewangkoon <italic>et al</italic>. 2010</xref>, <xref rid="R12" ref-type="bibr">Chen <italic>et al.</italic> 2016</xref>).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pezicula cinnamomea</italic> (GenBank KR859109.1; Identities = 498/524 (95 %), 5 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Pezicula sporulosa</italic> (GenBank JN693514.1; Identities = 495/519 (95%), 4 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Pezicula californiae</italic> (GenBank JX144747.1; Identities = 495/519 (95 %), 4 gaps (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Pezicula brunnea</italic> (GenBank KR858894.1; Identities = 842/848 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Pezicula ericae</italic> (GenBank MH874637.1; Identities = 876/883 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Pezicula melanigena</italic> (GenBank KR859003.1; Identities = 838/845 (99 %), no gaps. Closest hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pezicula eucrita</italic> (GenBank KF376205.1; Identities = 866/915 (95 %), no gaps), <italic>Pezicula neoheterochroma</italic> (GenBank KR859338.1; Identities = 850/899 (95 %), no gaps), and <italic>Pezicula</italic> aff.<italic> cinnamomea</italic> (GenBank KF376209.1; Identities = 864/915 (94 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Phaeoseptoriella</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829332.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to its morphological similarity to small species of <italic>Phaeoseptoria</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Associated with leaf spots. <italic>Conidiomata</italic> solitary, globose, brown with central ostiole. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells lining the inner cavity. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> ampulliform to doliiform, pale brown, smooth, proliferating percurrently at apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, pale brown, finely roughened, straight to slightly curved, fusoid-ellipsoid, septate, apex subobtuse, base truncate.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>: <italic>Phaeoseptoriella zeae</italic> Crous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Phaeoseptoriella zeae</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829333. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F41">Fig. 41</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host <italic>Zea mays</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Associated with small, subcircular, pale brown, amphigenous leaf spots, 2&#x2013;6 mm diam. <italic>Conidiomata</italic> solitary, globose, 200&#x2013;250 &#xB5;m diam, brown with central ostiole. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells lining the inner cavity. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> ampulliform to doliiform, pale brown, smooth, proliferating percurrently at apex, 4&#x2013;6 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;6 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, pale brown, finely roughened, straight to slightly curved, fusoid-ellipsoid, apex subobtuse, base truncate, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam, (1&#x2013;)3-septate, (14&#x2013;)17&#x2013;20(&#x2013;23) &#xD7; (3&#x2013;)4 &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, covering dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface dirty white, reverse cinnamon; on PDA surface dirty white, reverse rosy buff; on OA surface rosy vinaceous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>South Africa</bold>, Gauteng Province, Gauteng, on leaves of <italic>Zea mays</italic> (<italic>Poaceae</italic>), 12 Apr. 2010, <italic>T.A. Coutinho</italic>, HPC 2038 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23814, culture ex-type CPC 33064 = CBS 144614).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Phaeosphaeria leaf spot (PLS) has previously been attributed to <italic>Phaeosphaeria maydis</italic> (described from leaves of <italic>Zea mays</italic> in Sao Paulo, Brazil), which has been linked to various asexual morphs including a <italic>Phyllosticta</italic> sp. (= <italic>Guignardia</italic> sexual morph), and <italic>Phoma maydis</italic>. <xref rid="R3" ref-type="bibr">Amaral <italic>et al</italic>. (2005)</xref> reported a phoma-like asexual morph associated with PLS as similar in culture to colonies of <italic>Phaeosphaeria maydis</italic>, and postulated that several fungal species were involved in causing PLS<italic>.</italic> However, in a recent study, <xref rid="R48" ref-type="bibr">Gon&#xE7;alves <italic>et al.</italic> (2013)</xref> showed that a bacterium, <italic>Pantoea ananatis</italic>, was the primary disease-causing agent, and that the fungi isolated from these lesions, were secondary colonist of the diseased tissue, stating also that the disease symptoms shown by <xref rid="R3" ref-type="bibr">Amaral <italic>et al</italic>. (2005)</xref> were atypical for PLS. In South Africa, prominent tan-coloured subcircular leaf spots were found on<italic> Z. mays</italic> to be associated with a new genus, described here as <italic>Phaeoseptoriella zeae.</italic> Further studies are now required to determine the relative importance of this fungus, and confirm its role as maize pathogen.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Parastagonospora avenae</italic> (as <italic>Phaeosphaeria avenaria</italic>, GenBank FJ605258.1; Identities = 526/546 (96 %), 6 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Camarosporioides phragmitis</italic> (GenBank NR_153925.1; Identities = 425/474 (90 %), 15 gaps (3 %)), and <italic>Coniothyrium ferrarisianum</italic> (GenBank MH860854.1; Identities = 424/474 (89 %), 15 gaps (3 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Didymocyrtis consimilis</italic> (GenBank MH876627.1; Identities = 878/882 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Parastagonospora nodorum</italic> (GenBank MH868570.1; Identities = 878/882 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Kalmusia utahensis</italic> (GenBank MH876142.1; Identities = 877/882 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Didymocyrtis banksiae</italic> (GenBank KY979850.1; Identities = 759/902 (84 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Parastagonospora nodorum</italic> (as <italic>Phaeosphaeria nodorum</italic>, GenBank DQ499803.1; Identities = 757/903 (84 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Parastagonospora avenaria</italic> f. sp. <italic>tritici</italic> (as <italic>Phaeosphaeria avenaria</italic> f. sp. <italic>triticae</italic>, GenBank DQ499799.1; Identities = 757/905 (84 %), 6 gaps (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Sclerostagonospora ericae</italic> (GenBank KX228375.1; Identities = 417/515 (81 %), 28 gaps (5 %)), <italic>Didymocyrtis cladoniicola</italic> (as <italic>Diederichomyces cladoniicola</italic>, GenBank KP170668.1; Identities = 409/516 (79 %), 10 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Septoria oudemansii</italic> (GenBank KF253436.1; Identities = 333/409 (81 %), 8 gaps (1 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Sclerostagonospora ericae</italic> (GenBank KX228383.1; Identities = 263/287 (92 %), 4 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Diederichomyces ficuzzae</italic> (GenBank KP170697.1; Identities = 262/290 (90 %), 6 gaps (2 %)), and <italic>Didymocyrtis foliaceiphila</italic> (as <italic>Diederichomyces foliaceiphila</italic>, GenBank KP170698.1; Identities = 260/288 (90 %), 3 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Phlogicylindrium dunnii</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829334. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F42">Fig. 42</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Eucalyptus dunnii</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> eustromatic, multilocular, locules 100&#x2013;200 &#xB5;m diam, occurring solitary on leaves, but in clusters on agar, exuding a slimy pink conidial mass. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> arising from a brown stroma of 3&#x2013;6 layers of <italic>textura angularis</italic>, subcylindrical, branched, 1&#x2013;3-septate, brown, smooth, 30&#x2013;70 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> pale brown, smooth, subcylindrical, 15&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m, proliferating sympodially and percurrently near apex. <italic>Macroconidia</italic> hyaline, smooth, narrowly fusoid to widest in the middle with slight taper towards ends, subcylindrical, 1-septate, apex subobtuse, base truncate, curved, (32&#x2013;)35&#x2013;42(&#x2013;47) &#xD7; (2&#x2013;) 2.5(&#x2013;3) &#xB5;m. <italic>Microconidia</italic> hyaline, smooth, aseptate, cylindrical, curved, apex obtuse, base truncate, 15&#x2013;18 &#xD7; 1.5 &#xB5;m, forming in same conidioma as macroconidia.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and folded surface and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 10 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface ochreous, reverse umber; on PDA surface ochreous, reverse salmon to ochreous; on OA surface smoke grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Tooloom State Forest, on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus dunnii</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), 20 Jan. 2016, <italic>A.J. Carnegie</italic>, HPC 1447 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23264, culture ex-type CPC 31818 = CBS 144620).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Phlogicylindrium</italic> was established by <xref rid="R84" ref-type="bibr">Summerell <italic>et al.</italic> (2006)</xref> to accommodate a genus with erect, flame-like conidiomatal tufts to sporodochial conidiomata, and cylindrical, hyaline conidia forming on brown, percurrently proliferating conidiogenous cells. <italic>Phlogicylindrium dunnii</italic> is rather atypical in the fact that it has eustromatic, multilocular conidiomata, that with age appear sporodochial as they age.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Phlogicylindrium tereticornis</italic> (GenBank NR_156660.1; Identities = 550/566 (97 %), 3 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Phlogicylindrium eucalyptorum</italic> (GenBank EU040223.1; Identities = 411/432 (95 %), 3 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Phlogicylindrium mokarei</italic> (GenBank KY173431.1; Identities = 409/432 (95 %), 3 gaps (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Phlogicylindrium tereticornis</italic> (GenBank NG_058510.1; Identities = 788/789 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Phlogicylindrium mokarei</italic> (GenBank NG_059750.1; Identities = 782/789 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Phlogicylindrium uniforme</italic> (GenBank JQ044445.1; Identities = 780/789 (99 %), no gaps). The best hit using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence was with <italic>Phlogicylindrium tereticornis</italic> (GenBank MG386142.1; Identities = 861/871 (99 %), no gaps). The best hit using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence was with <italic>Phlogicylindrium tereticornis</italic> (GenBank MG386151.1; Identities = 396/402 (99 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Phyllosticta austroafricana</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829336. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F43">Fig. 43</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the continent Africa where it was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Associated with leaf spots on leaf litter of unidentified deciduous tree host. <italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, solitary, black, erumpent, globose, exuding hyaline conidial masses; pycnidia up to 200 &#xB5;m diam; wall of several layers of brown <italic>textura angularis</italic>. <italic>Ostiole</italic> central, up to 20 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> subcylindrical, with 1&#x2013;2 supporting cells, at times branched at base, 20&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m<italic>. Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, subcylindrical, hyaline, smooth, coated in a mucoid layer, 10&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m, proliferating several times percurrently near apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> (11&#x2013;)14&#x2013;17(&#x2013;23) &#xD7; (6&#x2013;)8&#x2013;10(&#x2013;11) &#xB5;m, solitary, hyaline, aseptate, thin- and smooth-walled, coarsely guttulate, ellipsoid to obovoid, tapering towards a truncate base, 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam, enclosed in a mucoid sheath, 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m thick, and bearing a hyaline apical mucoid appendage, (5&#x2013;) 7&#x2013;8(&#x2013;10) &#xD7; 1.5(&#x2013;2) &#xB5;m, tapering towards an acutely rounded tip. <italic>Spermatia</italic> bacilliform, hyaline, smooth, guttulate, 6&#x2013;8 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and uneven surface and lobed margin, reaching 5 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface iron-grey, and reverse iron-grey, with diffuse yellow pigment on OA.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>South Africa</bold>, Western Cape Province, on leaf spots of unidentified deciduous tree host, 2010, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23797, culture ex-type CPC 31920 = CBS 144593).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Phyllosticta</italic> includes several important plant pathogens causing leaf and fruit spot diseases. Important species are <italic>P. ampelicida</italic> causing black rot disease on grapevines (<xref rid="R102" ref-type="bibr">Zhou <italic>et al</italic>. 2015</xref>), species in the <italic>P. musarum</italic> species complex causing banana freckle disease (<xref rid="R100" ref-type="bibr">Wong <italic>et al.</italic> 2012</xref>), and <italic>P. citricarpa</italic> causing citrus black spot (<xref rid="R52" ref-type="bibr">Guarnaccia <italic>et al</italic>. 2017</xref>). <italic>Phyllosticta austroafricana</italic> is a phylogenetically distinct species, associated with leaf spots on an unidentified tree host.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Phyllosticta pseudotsugae</italic> (GenBank KF154277.1; Identities = 539/573 (94 %), 5 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Phyllosticta carissicola</italic> (GenBank NR_147363.1; Identities = 574/613 (94 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Phyllosticta podocarpi</italic> (GenBank KF154276.1; Identities = 535/572 (94 %), 3 gaps (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Phyllosticta carissicola</italic> (GenBank KT950863.1; Identities = 848/851 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Phyllosticta podocarpi</italic> (GenBank KF766383.1; Identities = 835/840 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Phyllosticta hymenocallidicola</italic> (GenBank NG_057947.1; Identities = 869/882 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>actA</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Phyllosticta acaciigena</italic> (GenBank KY173570.1; Identities = 517/562 (92 %), 5 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Exserohilum khartoumense</italic> (as <italic>Setosphaeria khartoumensis</italic>, GenBank LT837600.1; Identities = 474/526 (90 %), 11 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Exserohilum rostratum</italic> (as <italic>Setosphaeria rostrata</italic>, GenBank LT837683.1; Identities = 473/526 (90 %), 11 gaps (2 %)), and <italic>Exserohilum prolatum</italic> (GenBank LT837660.1; Identities = 473/526 (90 %), 11 gaps (2 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Phyllosticta ericarum</italic> (GenBank KR025452.1; Identities = 303/331 (92 %), 5 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Phyllosticta carissicola</italic> (GenBank KT950879.1; Identities = 367/403 (91 %), 19 gaps (4 %)), and <italic>Phyllosticta catimbauensis</italic> (GenBank MF466155.1; Identities = 299/331 (90 %), 4 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Phyllosticta hagahagaensis</italic></bold> Crous &amp; M.J. Wingf., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829335. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F44">Fig. 44</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name reflects Haga Haga in the Eastern Cape Province of South Africa where it was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, solitary, black, erumpent, globose, exuding hyaline conidial masses; pycnidia 250&#x2013;350 &#xB5;m diam; wall of several layers of brown <italic>textura angularis</italic>. <italic>Ostiole</italic> central, up to 20 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> subcylindrical, unbranched or branched below, 0&#x2013;2-septate, 15&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m<italic>. Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal and intercalary, subcylindrical, hyaline, smooth, coated in a mucoid layer, 7&#x2013;16 &#xD7; 3.5&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m, proliferating several times percurrently near apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> (11&#x2013;)13&#x2013;14(&#x2013;15) &#xD7; (7&#x2013;) 8(&#x2013;9) &#xB5;m, solitary, hyaline, aseptate, thin- and smooth-walled, guttulate, granular, ellipsoid to obovoid, tapering towards a truncate base, 3&#x2013;3.5 &#xB5;m diam, enclosed in a mucoid sheath, 2.5&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m thick, and bearing a hyaline apical mucoid appendage, 5&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m, tapering towards an acutely rounded tip.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with sparse to moderate aerial mycelium and uneven surface and margin, reaching 18 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface smoke grey to grey olivaceous, reverse olivaceous grey; on PDA surface and reverse olivaceous grey; on OA surface olivaceous grey to grey olivaceous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>South Africa</bold>, Eastern Cape Province, Haga Haga, on leaf litter of <italic>Carissa bispinosa</italic> (<italic>Apocynaceae</italic>), 23 Dec. 2010, <italic>M.J. Wingfield</italic>, HPC 1545 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23811, culture ex-type CPC 32799 = CBS 144592).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Phyllosticta carissicola</italic> [conidia (11&#x2013;)12&#x2013;14(&#x2013;15) &#xD7; (9&#x2013;) 10(&#x2013;11) &#xB5;m, sheath 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m thick apical mucoid appendage, (10&#x2013;)12&#x2013;17(&#x2013;25) &#xD7; 1.5(&#x2013;2) &#xB5;m] was described from leaves of <italic>Carissa macrocarpa</italic> (CPC 25665) in South Africa by <xref rid="R28" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> (2015)</xref>. <italic>Phyllosticta hagahagaensis</italic> differs morphologically from <italic>P. carissicola</italic> in having wider conidia, a wider mucoid sheath, and shorter appendages.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Phyllosticta podocarpi</italic> (GenBank KF766217.1; Identities = 591/603 (98 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Phyllosticta pseudotsugae</italic> (GenBank KF154277.1; Identities = 559/572 (98 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and <italic>Phyllosticta owaniana</italic> (GenBank JF261462.1; Identities = 569/588 (97 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Phyllosticta carissicola</italic> (GenBank KT950863.1; Identities = 855/856 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Phyllosticta podocarpi</italic> (GenBank KF766383.1; Identities = 837/840 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Phyllosticta hymenocallidicola</italic> (GenBank NG_057947.1; Identities = 876/887 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>actA</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Phyllosticta acaciigena</italic> (GenBank KY173570.1; Identities = 521/560 (93 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Phyllosticta carissicola</italic> (GenBank KT950872.1; Identities = 233/243 (96 %), no gaps), <italic>Cladosporium velox</italic> (GenBank KT600654.1; Identities = 459/510 (90 %), 3 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Alternaria frumenti</italic> (GenBank JQ671649.1; Identities = 467/523 (89 %), 9 gaps (1 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>gapdh</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Phyllosticta owaniana</italic> (GenBank JF343766.1; Identities = 299/300 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Phyllosticta podocarpi</italic> (GenBank KF289168.1; Identities = 298/300 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Phyllosticta carissicola</italic> (GenBank KT950876.1; Identities = 501/510 (98 %), 1 gap (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Phyllosticta carissicola</italic> (GenBank KT950879.1; Identities = 379/389 (97 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Phyllosticta hakeicola</italic> (GenBank MH108025.1; Identities = 328/353 (93 %), 10 gaps (2 %)), and <italic>Phyllosticta yuccae</italic> (GenBank JX227948.1; Identities = 355/398 (89 %), 14 gaps (3 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Piniphoma</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829337.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name combined the name of the host genus <italic>Pinus</italic>, and the fungal genus <italic>Phoma</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> solitary, pycnidial, globose with central ostiole, pale brown, exuding a creamy conidial mass. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells lining inner cavity, ampulliform, hyaline, smooth, phialidic. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, smooth, hyaline, straight, guttulate, subcylindrical with obtuse ends.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>: <italic>Piniphoma wesendahlina</italic> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Piniphoma wesendahlina</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829338. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F45">Fig. 45</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name reflects to the city of Berlin where it was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> solitary, pycnidial, 80&#x2013;120 &#xB5;m diam, globose with central ostiole, pale brown, only observed on PNA, exuding a creamy conidial mass. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells lining inner cavity, ampulliform, hyaline, smooth, phialidic, 4&#x2013;5 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, smooth, hyaline, straight, guttulate, subcylindrical with obtuse ends, (3&#x2013;)4(&#x2013;5) &#xD7; 2 &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 45 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, Berlin, wood debris of <italic>Pinus sylvestris</italic> (<italic>Pinaceae</italic>), 1 May 2017, <italic>H. Schreiber &amp; R.K. Schumacher</italic>, HPC 2114 = RKS 106 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23823, culture ex-type CPC 33693 = CBS 145032).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Piniphoma wesendahlina</italic> is a phoma-like genus occurring on <italic>Pinus sylvestris</italic> wood debris collected in Berlin, Germany. Phylogenetically, it appears distinct from other phoma-like genera presently known (<xref rid="R13" ref-type="bibr">Chen <italic>et al.</italic> 2015</xref>, <xref rid="R93" ref-type="bibr">Valenzuela-Lopez <italic>et al.</italic> 2018</xref>), and is thus introduced as new.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Setophoma vernoniae</italic> (GenBank KJ869141.1; Identities = 445/486 (92 %), 8 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>Shiraia bambusicola</italic> (GenBank MF062656.1; Identities = 451/491 (92 %), 11 gaps (2 %)). It was identical to several unidentified sequences, e.g. GenBank GU566235.1 from the rhizosphere of <italic>Phalaris arundinacea</italic> in Czech Republic, GenBank FN394707.1 from a fungal endophyte of <italic>Holcus lanatus</italic> in Spain and GenBank MH063650.1 from surface-sterilised, asymptomatic roots of <italic>Arrhenatherum elatius</italic> in France. Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Coniothyrium quercinum</italic> (GenBank MH877842.1; Identities = 858/860 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Sclerostagonospora cycadis</italic> (GenBank MH874827.1; Identities = 858/860 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Coniothyrium ferrarisianum</italic> (GenBank MH872593.1; Identities = 858/860 (99 %), no gaps). Distant hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Exserohilum fusiforme</italic> (GenBank LT852483.1; Identities = 732/899 (81 %), 22 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Exserohilum oryzicola</italic> (GenBank LT715748.1; Identities = 717/883 (81 %), 19 gaps (2 %)), and <italic>Bipolaris maydis</italic> (GenBank XM_014222497.1; Identities = 740/918 (81 %), 17 gaps (1 %)). Very distant hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Dendryphion penicillatum</italic> (GenBank AY375376.1; Identities = 207/234 (88 %), 4 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Libertasomyces quercus</italic> (GenBank KY929197.1; Identities = 208/235 (89 %), 8 gaps (3 %)), and <italic>Alternaria alternariae</italic> (as <italic>Ulocladium alternariae</italic>, GenBank AY375370.1; Identities = 207/234 (88 %), 6 gaps (2 %)). Distant hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Sclerostagonospora ericae</italic> (GenBank KX228383.1; Identities = 467/551 (85 %), 26 gaps (4 %)), <italic>Parastagonospora avenae</italic> f. sp.<italic> avenae</italic> (as <italic>Phaeosphaeria avenaria</italic> f. sp. <italic>avenaria</italic>, GenBank AY870404.1; Identities = 468/557 (84 %), 31 gaps (5 %)), and <italic>Seltsamia ulmi</italic> (GenBank MF795918.1; Identities = 409/487 (84 %), 17 gaps (3 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pseudocercospora hakeae</italic></bold> (U. Braun &amp; Crous) U. Braun &amp; Crous, <italic>Stud. Mycol.</italic>
<bold>75</bold>: 88. 2012 (2013). <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F46">Fig. 46</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Cercostigmina protearum</italic> var. <italic>hakeae</italic> U. Braun &amp; Crous, <italic>Sydowia</italic>
<bold>46</bold>: 206. 1994.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Leaf spots</italic> amphigenous, elongated, confined by leaf veins, 2&#x2013;3 mm diam, medium brown with raised, dark brown border. <italic>Caespituli</italic> olivaceous brown, amphigenous, developing on a well-defined brown stroma up to 250 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> densely aggregated, subcylindrical, branched or not, geniculoussinuous, 3&#x2013;7-septate, medium brown, thick-walled, finely verruculose, 30&#x2013;70 &#xD7; 6&#x2013;8 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> subcylindrical, medium brown, finely verruculose, thick-walled, terminal and intercalary, proliferating percurrently and or sympodially, 12&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 5&#x2013;7 &#xB5;m; loci truncate, unthickened, not darkened, 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, subcylindrical, medium brown, finely verruculose, apex obtuse, base truncate, 2(&#x2013;2.5) &#xB5;m diam, straight to geniculous-sinuous, (1&#x2013;)3&#x2013;6(&#x2013;7)-septate, (15&#x2013;)30&#x2013;50(&#x2013;65) &#xD7; 4(&#x2013;5) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 7 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface olivaceous grey, and reverse iron-grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Fitzroy Falls, Morton National Park, on leaves of <italic>Hakea</italic> sp. (<italic>Proteaceae</italic>), 26 Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, HPC 1756 = CBS H-23798, culture CPC 32100 = CBS 144520).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Pseudocercospora hakeae</italic> (as <italic>Cercostigmina protearum</italic> var. <italic>hakeae</italic>) was described from leaves on <italic>Hakea saligna</italic> collected in the Limpopo Province of South Africa (<xref rid="R16" ref-type="bibr">Crous &amp; Braun 1994</xref>). The culture linked to this species (CBS 112226), was, however, collected on <italic>Grevillea</italic> sp. in Australia (<xref rid="R15" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 2013</xref>). The present collection provided the first culture from a <italic>Hakea</italic> sp., also collected in Australia.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pseudocercospora fuligena</italic> (GenBank GU214675.1; Identities = 533/535 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Pseudocercospora</italic>
<italic>chengtuensis</italic> (GenBank GU214672.1; Identities = 533/535 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and <italic>Pseudocercospora atromarginalis</italic> (GenBank GU214671.1; Identities = 533/535 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Pseudocercospora cydoniae</italic> (GenBank MH877505.1; Identities = 852/852 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Pseudocercospora rhamnellae</italic> (GenBank MH877382.1; Identities = 852/852 (100 %), no gaps), and <italic>Pseudocercospora ranjita</italic> (GenBank MH875340.1; Identities = 852/852 (100 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>actA</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pseudocercospora hakeae</italic> (GenBank JQ325017.1; Identities = 587/588 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Pseudocercospora cruenta</italic> (GenBank JQ325012.1; Identities = 574/590 (97 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Pseudocercospora neriicola</italic> (GenBank KJ869231.1; Identities = 573/589 (97 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pseudocercospora prunicola</italic> (GenBank MF951621.1; Identities = 851/893 (95 %), no gaps), <italic>Pseudocercospora nymphaeacea</italic> (GenBank LC199939.1; Identities = 813/860 (95 %), no gaps), and <italic>Pseudocercospora flavomarginata</italic> (GenBank MF951619.1; Identities = 841/893 (94 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pseudocercospora hakeae</italic> (GenBank GU384495.1; Identities = 314/315 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Pseudocercospora basiramifera</italic> (GenBank DQ211677.2; Identities = 458/510 (90 %), 9 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Pseudocercospora pallida</italic> (GenBank GU384469.1; Identities = 280/315 (89 %), 3 gaps (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pseudocercospora atromarginalis</italic> (GenBank KM452894.1; Identities = 226/235 (96 %), no gaps), <italic>Pseudocercospora pyracanthigena</italic> (GenBank JX902271.1; Identities = 225/235 (96 %), no gaps), and <italic>Pseudocercospora tereticornis</italic> (GenBank JX902280.1; Identities = 224/235 (95 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pseudoconiothyrium</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829339.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to its morphological similarity to the genus <italic>Coniothyrium</italic>, from which it is phylogenetically distinct.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> eustromatica, pycnidial, aggregated, globose with central opening; wall of 6&#x2013;10 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells lining inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, doliiform to ampulliform, phialidic with periclinal thickening, and at times with percurrent proliferation. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, subcylindrical to ellipsoid to subglobose, apex obtuse, base truncate to bluntly rounded, medium brown, verruculose.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>: <italic>Pseudoconiothyrium broussonetiae</italic> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pseudoconiothyrium broussonetiae</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829340. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F47">Fig. 47</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Broussonetia</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> eustromatica, pycnidial, aggregated, 250&#x2013;400 &#xB5;m diam, globose with central opening; wall of 6&#x2013;10 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells lining inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, doliiform to ampulliform, phialidic with periclinal thickening, and at times with percurrent proliferation, 5&#x2013;10 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;6 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, subcylindrical to ellipsoid to subglobose, apex obtuse, base truncate to bluntly rounded, medium brown, verruculose, (5&#x2013;) 6&#x2013;7(&#x2013;8) &#xD7; (4.5&#x2013;)5(&#x2013;6) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies spreading, with folded surface, moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 30 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface dirty white to ochreous, reverse ochreous; on PDA surface pale luteous to ochreous, reverse ochreous; on OA surface ochreous with diffuse ochreous pigment.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Italy</bold>, Firenze, Plaza della indipendenza, branch of <italic>Broussonetia papyrifera</italic> (<italic>Moraceae</italic>), 16 Feb. 2017, <italic>G. Bonari &amp; R.K. Schumacher</italic>, HPC 2009 = RKS 68 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23822, culture ex-type CPC 33570 = CBS 145036).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Pseudoconiothyrium</italic> is allied to <italic>Paraconiothyrium</italic> in the phylogenetic tree, but it is phylogenetically distinct from the latter genus. Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pseudocoleophoma typhicola</italic> (GenBank NR_154350.1; Identities = 508/563 (90 %), 13 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Coniothyrium crepinianum</italic> (GenBank MH860873.1; Identities = 507/574 (88 %), 25 gaps (4 %)), and <italic>Pseudocoleophoma polygonicola</italic> (GenBank NR_154274.1; Identities = 429/470 (91 %), 11 gaps (2 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Aquadictyospora lignicola</italic> (as <italic>Pleosporales</italic> sp. ZLL-2017a, GenBank MF948629.1; Identities = 774/789 (98 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Dictyosporium tratense</italic> (as <italic>Dictyocheirospora</italic> sp. YJ2018b, GenBank MH381776.1; Identities = 814/831 (98 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Cheiromyces inflatus</italic> (GenBank JQ267363.1; Identities = 802/819 (98 %), 1 gap (0 %)). Very distant hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Xenophoma puncteliae</italic> (GenBank KP170686.1; Identities = 265/321 (83 %), 18 gaps (5 %)) and <italic>Pseudochaetosphaeronema ginkgonis</italic> (as <italic>Pseudochaetosphaeronema</italic> sp. XYD-2016a, GenBank KU365984.1; Identities = 278/345 (81 %), 18 gaps (5 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pseudophaeophleospora phormii</italic></bold> (Naito) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829341. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F48">Fig. 48</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>:<italic> Hendersonia phormii</italic> Naito, <italic>Science Rep. Kagoshima Univ.</italic>
<bold>1</bold>: 77. 1952.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonyms</italic>: <italic>Kirramyces phormii</italic> (Naito) M.E. Palm, <italic>Mycol. Res.</italic>
<bold>100</bold>: 374. 1996.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Phaeophleospora phormii</italic> (Naito) Crous <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>S. Afr. J. Bot.</italic>
<bold>63</bold>: 115. 1997.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Leaf spots</italic> brown, elliptical to elongate, surrounded by a dark red-purple border. <italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, immersed, solitary, globose to subglobose, up to 200 &#xB5;m diam; wall of 3&#x2013;6 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis</italic>. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells lining the inner cavity. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> cylindrical to lageniform, medium brown, finely roughened, 10&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m, proliferating percurrently near apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, medium brown, verruculose, aggregating in mucoid mass, cylindrical, apex obtuse, base truncate, 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam, with marginal frill, 3(&#x2013;6)-septate, (30&#x2013;)38&#x2013;55(&#x2013;60) &#xD7; (3&#x2013;)3.5(&#x2013;4) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium, folded surface and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 7 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface grey olivaceous, reverse olivaceous grey; on PDA surface dirty white, reverse olivaceous grey; on OA surface dirty white with diffuse red pigment.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>New Zealand</bold>, Levin, Earl St, on <italic>Phormium tenax</italic>, 12 Dec. 1971, <italic>G. Laudon</italic>, PDD 39822 (<bold>neotype</bold> designated by Palm 1996); Auckland, Grey Lynn Park, on <italic>Phormium tenax</italic> (<italic>Asphodelaceae</italic>), 5 Oct. 2016, <italic>R. Thangavel</italic> T16_03297D (<bold>epitype designated here</bold> CBS H-23264, MBT385290, culture ex-epitype CPC 32742 = CBS 144606).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Pseudophaeophleospora</italic> was established by Videira <italic>et al</italic>. (2017) to accommodate a phaeophleospora-like genus occurring on <italic>Eucalyptus</italic>. The two genera are morphologically similar, and best distinguished based on their DNA sequences.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">The present collection closely matches the morphology of the neotype of <italic>Hendersonia phormii</italic>, described by <xref rid="R68" ref-type="bibr">Palm (1996)</xref>. Unfortunately, the culture used in the latter paper is no longer viable, and could thus not be deposited. The culture from the present collection is thus herewith designated as epitype, to fix the phylogenetic application of the name.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pseudophaeophleospora atkinsonii</italic> (as <italic>Phaeophleospora atkinsonii</italic>, GenBank GU214643.1; Identities = 480/505 (95 %), no gaps), <italic>Pallidocercospora acaciigena</italic> (GenBank MH862893.1; Identities = 478/520 (92 %), 5 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Pallidocercospora heimii</italic> (as <italic>Mycosphaerella heimii</italic>, GenBank GQ852745.1; Identities = 479/521 (92 %), 7 gaps (1 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Pseudophaeophleospora atkinsonii</italic> (as <italic>Phaeophleospora atkinsonii</italic>, GenBank GU214463.1; Identities = 839/849 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Pallidocercospora irregulariramosa</italic> (GenBank GU214441.1; Identities = 878/892 (98 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and <italic>Pallidocercospora holualoana</italic> (as <italic>Mycosphaerella holualoana</italic>, GenBank JF770467.1; Identities = 877/892 (98 %), 1 gap (0 %)). No <bold><italic>actA</italic></bold> sequences of <italic>Pseudophaeophleospora</italic> are available for comparison on GenBank; distant hits include <italic>Pseudocercospora udagawana</italic> (GenBank GU320527.1; Identities = 544/604 (90 %), 12 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Parapallidocercospora thailandica</italic> (as <italic>Pallidocercospora thailandica</italic>, GenBank EU514333.1; Identities = 496/535 (93 %), 7 gaps (1 %)), and<italic> Pallidocercospora heimii</italic> (GenBank KF903399.1; Identities = 487/525 (93 %), 6 gaps (1 %)). No <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequences of <italic>Pseudophaeophleospora</italic> are available for comparison on GenBank; distant hits include <italic>Pallidocercospora crystallina</italic> (GenBank MF135483.1; Identities = 376/463 (81 %), 27 gaps (5 %)), <italic>Parapallidocercospora thailandica</italic> (as <italic>Mycosphaerella thailandica</italic>, GenBank AY840477.2; Identities = 329/399 (82 %), 24 gaps (6 %)), and <italic>Neoceratosperma cyatheae</italic> (GenBank KT037504.1; Identities = 184/196 (94 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pseudorobillardaceae</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>fam. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829342.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the genus <italic>Pseudorobillarda</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> immersed, globose, unilocular, with central ostiole; wall of 3&#x2013;6 layers of thin-walled, flattened <italic>textura angularis</italic>; conidiomata giving rise to both micro- and macroconidia. <italic>Macroconidiophores</italic> lining the inner cavity, reduced to conidiogenous cells, hyaline, smooth, doliiform, phialidic with periclinal thickening and flared collarette, or proliferating percurrently when older. <italic>Paraphyses</italic> numerous, hyphae-like, intermingled among conidiophores, aseptate, flexuous. <italic>Macroconidia</italic> solitary, septate, guttulate, hyaline, smooth, apex subobtuse, tapering to a truncate base; apical appendages arising from splitting of the conidial sheath, hair-like, flexuous, unbranched, fragile, flexuous, unbranched, mostly absent. <italic>Microconidiogenous cells</italic> hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical to ampulliform, proliferating percurrently. <italic>Microconidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, hyaline, smooth, guttulate, subcylindrical, apex obtuse, base truncate; apical appendages hair-like, flexuous, unbranched, fragile, flexuous, unbranched.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type genus</italic>: <italic>Pseudorobillarda</italic> M. Morelet (1968)</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>: <italic>Pseudorobillarda phragmitis</italic> (Cunnell) M. Morelet.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Notes: <italic>Pseudorobillarda bolusanthi</italic> was recently introduced by <xref rid="R21" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. (2018b</xref>), and placed in the <italic>Pseudorobillardaceae</italic> (<italic>Dothideomycetes</italic>). The family, however, was unpublished, and is therefore formally introduced here.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pseudosigmoidea alnicola</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829346. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F49">Fig. 49</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name reflects the host genus <italic>Alnus</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of pale brown, smooth, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam hyphae, frequently forming hyphal coils, giving rise to solitary, erect conidiophores, subcylindrical, unbranched, pale brown, smooth, 0&#x2013;1-septate, 10&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> integrated, terminal, pale brown, smooth, subcylindrical, 5&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 1.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m; apex with one to several denticles-like loci, 0.5&#x2013;1 &#xD7; 1 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> obclavate, flexuous, multi-septate, pale brown, smooth-walled, guttulate, apex subobtuse, base obconically truncate, widest at first basal septum, base bluntly rounded, attached to conidiogenous cell via excentric locus which leaves a cylindrical separating cell on the side of the conidium, 1&#x2013;2 &#xD7; 1&#x2013;1.5 &#xB5;m, 80&#x2013;250 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m, apical region of conidium 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 25 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA, surface and reverse umber.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, alder wood, leaf litter of <italic>Alnus glutinosa</italic> (<italic>Betulaceae</italic>), 3 May 2017, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic>, HPC 2100 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23826, culture ex-type CPC 33776 = CBS 145034).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Pseudosigmoidea</italic> (based on <italic>P. cranei</italic>), has rhexolytic conidiogenesis with a separating cell, and long, flexuous, subcylindrical to obclavate, septate, hyaline to pale brown, smooth conidia (<xref rid="R4" ref-type="bibr">Ando &amp; Nakamura 2000</xref>). Although the genus is listed as <italic>Ascomycota</italic> &#x201C;<italic>incertae sedis</italic>&#x201D;, this study shows that it resides in the <italic>Sympoventuriaceae</italic> (<italic>Venturiales, Dothidiomycetes</italic>). <italic>Pseudosigmoidea</italic> is known from two species, <italic>P. cranei</italic> (conidia 26&#x2013;116.5 &#xD7; 1.5&#x2013;2.5 &#xB5;m, 3&#x2013;8-septate) and <italic>P. ibarakiensis</italic> (conidia 68&#x2013;133 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;8 &#xB5;m, up to 6-septate; <xref rid="R35" ref-type="bibr">Diene <italic>et al.</italic> 2013</xref>), both of which can easily be distinguished from <italic>P. alnicola</italic> based on their conidial morphology.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Troposporella fumosa</italic> (GenBank DQ351724.1; Identities = 564/585 (96 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Helicoma monilipes</italic> (GenBank DQ351723.1; Identities = 556/587 (95 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Pseudosigmoidea ibarakiensis</italic> (GenBank LC146758.1; Identities = 546/577 (95 %), 10 gaps (1 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Scolecobasidium excentricum</italic> (GenBank MH874174.1; Identities = 854/856 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Troposporella fumosa</italic> (GenBank MH874121.1; Identities = 850/856 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Sympoventuria melaleucae</italic> (GenBank NG_058520.1; Identities = 840/849 (99 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria africana</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829347. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F50">Fig. 50</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the continent of Africa where it was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Leaf spots</italic> amphigenous, circular, 2&#x2013;5 mm diam, medium brown, with thin, raised dark brown border. <italic>Ascomata</italic> pseudothecial, predominantly hypophyllous, black, immersed to erumpent, globose, 70&#x2013;100 &#xB5;m diam, with apical ostiole; wall of 2&#x2013;3 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Asci</italic> aparaphysate, fasciculate, bitunicate, subsessile, obovoid, straight to slightly curved, 8-spored, 30&#x2013;35 &#xD7; 8&#x2013;11 &#xB5;m. <italic>Ascospores</italic> bi- to triseriate, overlapping, hyaline, guttulate, thin-walled, straight to slightly curved, obovoid with obtuse ends, widest in middle of apical cell, medianly 1-septate, constricted at septum, tapering towards both ends, but more prominently towards lower end, (11&#x2013;)12&#x2013;13(&#x2013;14) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3&#x2013;3.5(&#x2013;4) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium, folded surface, and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 20&#x2013;30 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Angola</bold>, Longa River, leaf spot on unidentified host, 6 Nov. 2010, <italic>J. Roux</italic>, HPC 1697 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23816, culture ex-type CPC 33144 = CBS 144595).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Additional materials examined</italic>: <bold>Angola</bold>, Longa River, leaf spot on unidentified host, 6 Nov. 2010, <italic>J. Roux</italic>, cultures CPC 33145 = CBS 144596, CPC 33072 = CBS 144597.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria</italic> was introduced by <xref rid="R72" ref-type="bibr">Quaedvlieg <italic>et al</italic>. (2014)</xref> to accommodate a genus morphologically similar to <italic>Teratosphaeria</italic>, which lacked any known asexual morphs, and occurred primarily on <italic>Myrtaceae</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence of CPC 33072 had highest similarity to <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria perpendicularis</italic> (GenBank NR_155617.1; Identities = 485/496 (98 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria stramenticola</italic> (as <italic>Mycosphaerella stramenticola</italic>, GenBank DQ632669.1; Identities = 488/500 (98 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria gamsii</italic> (as <italic>Teratosphaeria gamsii</italic>, GenBank DQ302959.1; Identities = 481/497 (97 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). The ITS sequences of CPC 33072, 33144 and 33145 are identical. Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria perpendicularis</italic> (as <italic>Teratosphaeria perpendicularis</italic>, GenBank JN232443.1; Identities = 859/861 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria ohnowa</italic> (GenBank EU019305.2; Identities = 866/873 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria flexuosa</italic> (as <italic>Teratosphaeria flexuosa</italic>, GenBank JN232432.1; Identities = 877/885 (99 %), no gaps). The LSU sequences of CPC 33072, 33144 and 33145 are identical. Closest hits using the <bold><italic>actA</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria stramenticola</italic> (GenBank KF903530.1; Identities = 515/541 (95 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria perpendicularis</italic> (GenBank KF903491.1; Identities = 513/540 (95 %), no gaps), and <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria gamsii</italic> (GenBank KF903494.1; Identities = 510/540 (94 %), no gaps). The <italic>actA</italic> sequences of CPC 33072, 33144 and 33145 are identical. Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria perpendicularis</italic> (GenBank KF903232.1; Identities = 320/347 (92 %), 5 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria stramenticola</italic> (GenBank KF903237.1; Identities = 319/354 (90 %), 16 gaps (4 %)), and <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria gamsii</italic> (GenBank KF903229.1; Identities = 311/352 (88 %), 13 gaps (3 %)). The <italic>tef1</italic> sequences of CPC 33072, 33144 and 33145 are identical. Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria ohnowa</italic> (as <italic>Teratosphaeria ohnowa</italic>, GenBank KF442464.1; Identities = 304/338 (90 %), 6 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria gamsii</italic> (GenBank KF902933.1; Identities = 221/246 (90 %), 3 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Pseudoteratosphaeria perpendicularis</italic> (GenBank KF902936.1; Identities = 218/247 (88 %), 5 gaps (2 %)). The <italic>tub2</italic> sequences of CPC 33072 and 33145 are identical; the sequence of CPC 33144 differs at one nucleotide from the others.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Porodiplodia vitis</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829349. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F51">Fig. 51</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Vitis</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> eustromatic, uni- to multilocular, brown, globose, 150&#x2013;300 &#xB5;m, aggregated on agar, ostiolate. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> lining inner cavity, subcylindrical, hyaline, smooth, branched, 1&#x2013;3-septate, 15&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m, proliferating percurrently near apex. <italic>Paraphyses</italic> intermingled among conidiophores, hyaline, smooth, septate, subcylindrical with obtuse ends, 25&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> in short chains (&#x2013;3), fusoid-ellipsoid to subcylindrical, medium brown, finely verruculose, guttulate, thick-walled, 1-septate, apex obtuse (at times with central pore), base truncate with central pore, 2 &#xB5;m diam, (13&#x2013;)14&#x2013;16(&#x2013;19) &#xD7; (5&#x2013;)6(&#x2013;8) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 35 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface cinnamon to buff, reverse sienna; on PDA surface saffron, reverse cinnamon; on OA surface cinnamon, with diffuse cinnamon pigment.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>USA</bold>, New York, Bronx, Van Cortlandt Park, on canes of <italic>Vitis vinifera</italic> (<italic>Vitaceae</italic>), 2016, <italic>E. Crenson &amp; R.K. Schumacher</italic>, HPC 1372 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23795, culture ex-type CBS 144634 = CPC 31642).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Porodiplodia</italic> was recently established for a genus occurring on leaves of <italic>Livistona australis</italic> in Australia, characterised by having eustromatic conidiomata, and conidia occurring in short chains, with a pore at each end of its conidia (Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 2018c). <italic>Porodiplodia vitis</italic> differs from <italic>P. livistonae</italic> (conidia (14&#x2013;)15&#x2013;17(&#x2013;20) &#xD7; 5(&#x2013;6) &#x3BC;m) in having shorter, wider conidia.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Porodiplodia livistonae</italic> (GenBank MH327809.1; Identities = 533/536 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Chalara clidemiae</italic> (GenBank NR_145313.1; Identities = 528/547 (97 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and <italic>Mollisia caespiticia</italic> (GenBank KY965813.1; Identities = 506/542 (93 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Porodiplodia livistonae</italic> (GenBank MH327845.1; Identities = 859/859 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Chalara clidemiae</italic> (GenBank MH878219.1; Identities = 765/772 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Chaetochalara africana</italic> (as <italic>Chalara africana</italic>, GenBank FJ176249.1; Identities = 834/849 (98 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). No <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequences of <italic>Porodiplodia</italic> are available on GenBank for comparison; distant hits using the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Davidhawksworthia ilicicola</italic> (GenBank KU728592.1; Identities = 205/233 (88 %), 7 gaps (3 %)), <italic>Hymenoscyphus menthae</italic> (GenBank KM114512.1; Identities = 203/231 (88 %), 6 gaps (2 %)), and <italic>Fusarium napiforme</italic> (GenBank KM099398.1; Identities = 201/231 (87 %), 4 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Selenodriella fertilis</italic></bold> (Piroz. &amp; Hodges) R.F. Casta&#xF1;eda &amp; W.B. Kendr., <italic>Univ. Waterloo Biol. Ser.</italic>
<bold>33</bold>: 34. 1990. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F52">Fig. 52</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Circinotrichum fertile</italic> Piroz. &amp; Hodges, <italic>Canad. J. Bot.</italic>
<bold>51</bold>: 160. 1973.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiophores</italic> dimorphic. <italic>Microconidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells or with a supporting cell, arising directly from mycelium, hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical, tapering toward denticulate apex, 7&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3.5 &#xB5;m. <italic>Macroconidiophores</italic> erect, arising from superficial hyphae, flexuous, branched or not, base with T-cell or rhizoids, subcylindrical, 60&#x2013;140 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m, 4&#x2013;10-septate, lateral branches 0&#x2013;3-septate, 15&#x2013;60 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> pale brown, smooth, subcylindrical to elongated fusoid-ellipsoid, terminal and intercalary, with apical rachis of denticulate loci; denticles 1&#x2013;2 &#xD7; 1&#x2013;1.5 &#xB5;m, scars somewhat darkened, not thickened nor refractive, 20&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> aggregating in mucoid masses, aseptate, fusoid-ellipsoid, prominently curved, apex subobtuse, base truncate, 1 &#xB5;m diam, not thickened nor darkened, (9&#x2013;)12&#x2013;14(&#x2013;15) &#xD7; 2(&#x2013;3) &#xB5;m. <italic>Chlamydospores</italic> in chains, globose, thin-walled, hyaline, becoming pale brown and forming microsclerotia, 7&#x2013;12 &#xB5;m diam.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium, folded surface and smooth, even margin, reaching 35 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface and reverse isabelline to buff; on PDA surface and reverse olivaceous grey; on OA surface olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, Victoria, Nowa Nowa, on leaf litter of <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> sp. (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), 30 Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, HPC 1876, culture CPC 32663 = CBS 144589.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: For notes on <italic>Selenodriella</italic>, see <xref rid="R58" ref-type="bibr">Hern&#xE1;ndez-Restrepo <italic>et al</italic>. (2016)</xref>, who confirmed the occurrence of <italic>Selenodriella fertilis</italic> in Australia on <italic>Hakea baxteri</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Selenodriella fertilis</italic> (GenBank MH861691.1; Identities = 525/526 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Gyrothrix circinata</italic> (GenBank KJ476968.1; Identities = 477/483 (99 %), 5 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Selenodriella cubensis</italic> (GenBank NR_154414.1; Identities = 515/522 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Selenodriella fertilis</italic> (GenBank KP858992.1; Identities = 849/851 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Selenodriella cubensis</italic> (GenBank NG_058151.1; Identities = 844/852 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and <italic>Gyrothrix verticiclada</italic> (GenBank KC775726.1; Identities = 800/821 (97 %), 6 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Stagonospora pseudoperfecta</italic></bold> Kaz. Tanaka &amp; K. Hiray., <italic>Stud. Mycol.</italic>
<bold>82</bold>: 106. 2015. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F53">Fig. 53</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> globose, brown, 250&#x2013;300 &#xB5;m diam (with papillate neck on host tissue); wall of 2&#x2013;3 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> lining the inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, ampulliform to subcylindrical, 5&#x2013;10 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m; proliferating percurrently. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, hyaline, smooth, fusoid-ellipsoid, guttulate, 3-septate, apex obtuse, tapering from basal septum to truncate hilum, 2 um diam, (13&#x2013;)20&#x2013;22(&#x2013;250 &#xD7; (4&#x2013;)5(&#x2013;6) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with abundant, fluffy aerial mycelium covering dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface smoke grey, and reverse olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, on <italic>Typha</italic> sp. (<italic>Typhaceae</italic>), 1 Apr. 2017, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic>, RKS 85 = HPC 2026, culture CPC 33138 = CBS 144607.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Stagonospora pseudoperfecta</italic> was described from dead leaves of <italic>Typha latifolia</italic> collected in Japan (<xref rid="R86" ref-type="bibr">Tanaka <italic>et al.</italic> 2015</xref>), and this is the first record of the fungus from Europe.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence was identical to <italic>Stagonospora pseudoperfecta</italic> (GenBank NR_155768.1; Identities = 497/497 (100 %)); and related to <italic>Stagonospora trichophoricola</italic> (GenBank KY750315.1; Identities = 533/538 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>Stagonospora bicolor</italic> (as <italic>Saccharicola bicolor</italic>, GenBank KT367526.1; Identities = 530/535 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Stagonospora pseudoperfecta</italic> (GenBank NG_059399.1; Identities = 797/797 (100 %)), <italic>Stagonospora forlicesenensis</italic> (GenBank NG_059716.1; Identities = 794/797 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Stagonospora imperaticola</italic> (GenBank NG_059793.1; Identities = 793/797 (99 %), no gaps). No <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequences of <italic>Stagonospora pseudoperfecta</italic> are available for comparison on GenBank; distant hits include <italic>Helminthosporium oligosporum</italic> (GenBank KY984449.1; Identities = 304/364 (84 %), 19 gaps (5 %)), <italic>Helminthosporium tiliae</italic> (GenBank KY984456.1; Identities = 304/364 (84 %), 19 gaps (5 %)), and <italic>Corynespora leucadendri</italic> (GenBank KF253110.1; Identities = 313/381 (82 %), 22 gaps (5 %)). No <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequences of <italic>Stagonospora pseudoperfecta</italic> are available for comparison on GenBank; distant hits include <italic>Stagonospora victoriana</italic> (GenBank MG386166.1; Identities = 331/389 (85 %), 13 gaps (3 %)), <italic>Stagonospora chrysopyla</italic> (GenBank KM033943.1; Identities = 322/387 (83 %), 14 gaps (3 %)), and <italic>Stagonospora</italic> cf. <italic>paludosa</italic> (GenBank KF252737.1; Identities = 245/296 (83 %), 11 gaps (3 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Sympodiella</italic></bold> W.B. Kendr., <italic>Trans. Br. Mycol. Soc</italic>. <bold>41</bold>: 519. 1958. <bold><italic>emend</italic></bold>. Hern.-Restr. &amp; Crous</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of pale to medium brown, smooth, septate, branched hyphae. <italic>Sympodiella</italic> morph. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, medium brown, smooth, subcylindrical, straight to flexuous, unbranched, septate, sometimes proliferating percurrently (in culture). <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, subcylindrical, medium brown, polyblastic, sympodial. <italic>Conidia</italic> aseptate or septate, sometimes constricted at the septa, subcylindrical to acicular, apex obtuse, base truncate, smooth, hyaline to subhyaline. Repetophragma-like <italic>Synasexual morph</italic>. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, medium brown, smooth, subcylindrical, straight to geniculous-sinuous, unbranched, septate, proliferating percurrently. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, subcylindrical, straight or flexuous, medium brown, mono- or polyblastic, sometimes sympodial (mainly in culture). <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, septate, subcylindrical, straight, apex obtuse, sometimes with a dark cap, base truncate, with or without a minute marginal frill, smooth, pale- to medium brown, guttulate; hilum unthickened, not darkened.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>: <italic>Sympodiella acicola</italic> W.B. Kendr.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: We emend <italic>Sympodiella</italic> to include species with a repetophragma-like synasexual morph. A new species is introduced as <italic>S. quercina</italic> and additionally two new combinations are proposed and discussed below.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Sympodiella acicola</italic></bold> W.B. Kendr.,<italic> Trans. Br. Mycol. Soc</italic>. <bold>41</bold>: 519. 1958. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F54">Figs 54</xref>&#x2013;<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F55"/><xref ref-type="fig" rid="F56">56</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>UK</bold>, Cheshire, on <italic>Pinus sylvestris</italic> (<italic>Pinaceae</italic>), 1956, <italic>W.B. Kendrick</italic>, <bold>holotype</bold> IMI 69967. <bold>Netherlands</bold>, Baarn, De Vuursche, on <italic>Pinus sylvestris,</italic> 12 Apr. 1982, <italic>G.S. de Hoog</italic> (<bold>epitype</bold> designated here CBS H-1620 MBT385535, ex-epitype culture CBS 487.82).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synasexual morph</italic> repetophragma-like. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> brown, smooth, proliferating percurrently, up to 25 &#xB5;m long, 2&#x2013;3.5 &#xB5;m wide at the base. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, brown. <italic>Conidia</italic> 3&#x2013;4(&#x2013;7)-septate, subcylindrical, straight, apex obtuse, base truncate, with a minute marginal frill, smooth, pale- to medium brown, 13&#x2013;35 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Conidia in <italic>S. acicola</italic> have been considered arranged in unbranched chains (Kendrick 1958, Seifert <italic>et al.</italic> 2011). During an examination of the specimen CBS H-1620, some of these conidia resemble phragmoconidia constricted at the septa similar to those described in <italic>Wiesneriomyces</italic>, since they often remain connected together after they separate from the conidiogenous cells. In culture however (CBS 487.82), they are readily deciduous. Furthermore, in a specimen of <italic>Sympodiella acicola</italic> (CBS H-1620) the conidiophores were mixed with a repetophragma-like conidiophores described here as the synasexual morph of <italic>Sympodiella acicola</italic>. Interestingly, in culture (CBS 487.82) we observed some conidiophores with percurrent proliferations and the 1-septate conidia were more abundant than in natural substrate. This species has been reported mainly from <italic>Pinus</italic> spp. (Kendrick 1958, <xref rid="R38" ref-type="bibr">Ellis 1976</xref>).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Sympodiella alternata</italic></bold> (Tubaki &amp; Saito) Crous &amp; Hern.-Restr., <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829352. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F57">Fig. 57</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Endophragmia alternata</italic> Tubaki &amp; Saito, <italic>Trans. Brit. Mycol. Soc.</italic>
<bold>52</bold>: 477. 1969.</p>
