        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Japan</bold>, Sendai, on fallen needles of <italic>Pinus densifolia</italic> (<italic>Pinaceae</italic>), 1966, <italic>T. Sait&#xF4;</italic> (<bold>holotype</bold> IFO H-11600, ex-type culture IFO 8933 = CBS 326.69).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Note</italic>: <italic>Sympodiella alternata</italic> is only known by the repetophragmalike synasexual morph from Asia (<xref rid="R90" ref-type="bibr">Tubaki &amp; Sait&#xF4; 1969</xref>). During this study we examined the ex-type culture of <italic>Sympodiella alternata</italic> (CBS 326.69). Conidia were similar to those described in the protologue with a dark cap in the apex of the conidia, but they were slightly smaller with less septa (30&#x2013;36 &#xD7; 5&#x2013;6 &#xB5;m, 5&#x2013;8-septate vs. (37&#x2013;)40&#x2013;46(&#x2013;70) &#xD7; 5&#x2013;6(&#x2013;7) &#xB5;m, (7&#x2013;)8-septate; <xref rid="R90" ref-type="bibr">Tubaki &amp; Sait&#xF4; 1969</xref>). The conidiophores proliferate percurrently and sometimes geniculate conidiophores were observed. This species is known from <italic>Pinus densifolia</italic> from Japan (<xref rid="R90" ref-type="bibr">Tubaki &amp; Sait&#xF4; 1969</xref>) and from an unknown substrate from China (Shenoy <italic>et al.</italic> 2006).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Sympodiella goidanichii</italic></bold> (Rambelli) Crous &amp; Hern.-Restr., <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829353.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>:<italic> Ceratosporella goidanichii</italic> Rambelli, <italic>R.C. Secc. Accad. Sci. Ist. Bologna</italic>, s&#xE9;r. 6, <bold>5</bold>: 3. 1958.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonyms</italic>: <italic>Sporidesmium goidanichii</italic> (Rambelli) S. Hughes, <italic>N.Z. J. Bot</italic>. <bold>17</bold>: 162. 1979.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Repetophragma goidanichii</italic> (Rambelli) W.P. Wu, <italic>Fungal Diversity Res. Ser.</italic>
<bold>15</bold>: 80. 2005.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Italy</bold>, on cupule of <italic>Fagus sylvatica</italic> (<italic>Fagaceae</italic>), collection date unknown, <italic>A. Rambelli</italic>, ex-type culture CBS 136.58.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Note: <italic>Sympodiella goidanichii</italic> was described from <italic>Fagus sylvatica</italic> in Italy as <italic>Ceratosporella goidanichii</italic> (<xref rid="R74" ref-type="bibr">Rambelli 1958</xref>). Hughes (1979) considered <italic>Ceratosporella goidanichii</italic> and <italic>Endophragmia alternata</italic> as conspecific species and include them in <italic>Sporidesmium</italic> due to the successive proliferation of the conidiophores. During his studies the type strain of <italic>Ceratosporella goidanichhii</italic> failed to produce conidia and the observations were based on the sporulating culture of <italic>Endophragmia alternata</italic> and the descriptions given by <xref rid="R74" ref-type="bibr">Rambelli (1958)</xref> and <xref rid="R38" ref-type="bibr">Ellis (1976)</xref>. Later this species was transferred to <italic>Repetophragma</italic>, because of the percurrent proliferations of the conidiophores and the presence of euseptate conidia (Wu &amp; Zhuang 2005). In our study the ex-type strain of <italic>Ceratosporella goidanichii</italic> (CBS 136.58) remains sterile and the new combination in <italic>Sympodiella</italic> is mainly based on the phylogenetic analysis.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Sympodiella quercina</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829351. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F58">Figs 58</xref>&#x2013;<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F59"/><xref ref-type="fig" rid="F60">60</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Quercus</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of pale to medium brown, smooth, septate, branched, 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam hyphae. Sympodiella-like morph. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, medium brown, smooth, subcylindrical, straight to flexuous, unbranched, septate, 48.5&#x2013;68 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, subcylindrical, medium brown, polyblastic, sympodial, 15&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;3.5 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> septate, subcylindrical to acicular, tapering, apex obtuse, base truncate, smooth, hyaline, 30&#x2013;74 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3.5 &#xB5;m, apex 1.5&#x2013;2.5 &#xB5;m wide. Repetophragma-like synasexual morph. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, medium brown, smooth, subcylindrical, straight to geniculous-sinuous, unbranched, 2&#x2013;6-septate, 25&#x2013;90 &#xD7; 5&#x2013;6 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, subcylindrical, medium brown, 6&#x2013;17 &#xD7; 5&#x2013;6 &#xB5;m, proliferating percurrently. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, subcylindrical, apex obtuse, base truncate, medium brown (end cells frequently subhyaline), smooth, guttulate, straight, (4&#x2013;)6-septate, (40&#x2013;)47&#x2013;55(&#x2013;65) &#xD7; (5&#x2013;)6&#x2013;6.5(&#x2013;7) um; hilum unthickened, not darkened, 5&#x2013;6.5 &#xB5;m diam, with minute marginal frill.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 12 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface umber, reverse chestnut; on PDA surface umber, reverse iron-grey; on OA surface umber.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, in <italic>Pinus sylvestris</italic> forest, on fallen leaf of <italic>Quercus robur</italic> (<italic>Fagaceae</italic>), 19 Aprs. 2017, <italic>H. Schreiber &amp; R.K. Schumacher</italic>, HPC 2106 = RKS 94 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23829, culture ex-type CPC 33903 = CBS 145028).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Additional material examined</italic>: <bold>UK</bold>, Lancashire, on leaf litter of <italic>Betula</italic> sp., 17 Jan. 1968, deposited by <italic>J.C. Frankland</italic>, CBS 987.70.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: In natural substrate this species has repetophragma-like conidiophores up to 210 &#xB5;m long with percurrent proliferations and conidia measuring 32&#x2013;44 &#xD7; 5&#x2013;7 &#xB5;m, with or without a dark cap in the apex of the conidia. Next to repetophragma-like conidiophores, <italic>Sympodiella</italic> conidiophores were also found, and since the close phylogenetic relationship with <italic>Sympodiella acicola</italic> we also described the synasexual morph. In this species the <italic>Sympodiella</italic> type of conidiophores produce fragile hyaline phragmoconidia similar to those observed in <italic>Cylindrosympodium</italic> (Kendrick &amp; Casta&#xF1;eda 1990) and some species of <italic>Subulispora</italic> (Sutton 1973, Kirk 1985). Additionally, the superficial network of darkly pigmented hyphae described in <italic>S. acicola</italic> (Kendrick 1985) was also observed in <italic>S. quercina</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">An additional strain (CBS 987.70) previously identified as <italic>Repetophragma goidanichii</italic> was phylogenetically related with <italic>S. quercina</italic>. However, the conidial sizes observed in this culture are below the range observed in CPC 33903, and also have more septa (35&#x2013;50 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;7 &#xB5;m, 6&#x2013;7(&#x2013;9)-septate), the dark apical cap was only evident in some of the younger conidia, and conidiophores were not well-developed. The synasexual morph was not observed in any of the cultures of <italic>S. quercina</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Sporidesmium goidanichii</italic> (GenBank MH860019.1; Identities = 486/489 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Septonema crispulum</italic> (GenBank MH862607.1; Identities = 402/445 (90 %), 8 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Sympodiella acicola</italic> (GenBank KY853468.1; Identities = 432/488 (89 %), 18 gaps (3 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Repetophragma goidanichii</italic> (GenBank DQ408574.1; Identities = 836/848 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Sympodiella acicola</italic> (GenBank KY853530.1; Identities = 844/858 (98 %), no gaps), and <italic>Cylindrosympodium lauri</italic> (GenBank EU035414.1; Identities = 836/859 (97 %), 2 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Sympoventuria regnans</italic></bold> Crous, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>39</bold>: 425. 2017. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F61">Fig. 61</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of medium brown, smooth, septate, branched, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells, or a supporting cell. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> arising directly from hyphae, subcylindrical, medium brown, smooth, 7&#x2013;18 &#xD7; 3(&#x2013;4) &#xB5;m, with 1(&#x2013;3) terminal, flat-tipped loci, 1(&#x2013;1.5) &#xB5;m diam, thickened and darkened. <italic>Conidia</italic> pale brown, guttulate, smooth-walled, 0(&#x2013;1)-septate, fusoid-ellipsoid, occurring in chiefly unbranched acropetal chains of up to 10, (10&#x2013;)13&#x2013;16(&#x2013;18) &#xD7; (2&#x2013;)3 &#xB5;m; loci thickened and somewhat darkened, 1(&#x2013;1.5) &#xB5;m diam.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 10 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface isabelline, reverse umber; on PDA surface umber, reverse dark brick; on OA surface umber.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, 31.366346S 151.580038E, Ngulin Nature Reserve, Hell Hole Forest Rd, on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus pauciflora</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), 13 Jul. 2016, <italic>A.J. Carnegie</italic>, HPC 1454, culture CPC 31820 = CBS 144605.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Sympoventuria</italic> was introduced for a genus of ascomycetes with sympodiella-like asexual morphs occurring on <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> leaf litter in South Africa (<xref rid="R22" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2007</xref>). <italic>Sympoventuria regnans</italic> is described from leaves of <italic>E. regnans</italic> collected in La Trobe State Forest, Victoria, Australia (<xref rid="R27" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 2017</xref>), and has a similar morphology to the present collection.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Sympoventuria regnans</italic> (GenBank MG386066.1; Identities = 568/569 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Fusicladium eucalypti</italic> (GenBank HQ599600.1; Identities = 548/573 (96 %), 5 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Fusicladium eucalypticola</italic> (GenBank NR_145402.1; Identities = 516/538 (96 %), 4 gaps (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Sympoventuria regnans</italic> (GenBank NG_058523.1; Identities = 852/852 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Fusicladium eucalypticola</italic> (GenBank KX228329.1; Identities = 861/872 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and <italic>Fusicladium eucalypti</italic> (GenBank HQ599601.1; Identities = 863/877 (98 %), 3 gaps (0 %)). No <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequences of <italic>Sympoventuria</italic> are available for comparison on GenBank; distant hits include <italic>Pallidocercospora crystallina</italic> (GenBank MF135483.1; Identities = 189/201 (94 %), 3 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Parapallidocercospora thailandica</italic> (as <italic>Mycosphaerella thailandica</italic>, GenBank AY840477.2; Identities = 176/184 (96 %), no gaps), and <italic>Phyllosticta ericarum</italic> (GenBank KR025451.1; Identities = 179/189 (95 %), no gaps). Distant hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Sympoventuria regnans</italic> (GenBank MG386169.1; Identities = 328/373 (88 %), 9 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Didymocyrtis brachylaenae</italic> (GenBank MH327896.1; Identities = 837/946 (88 %), 12 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Phoma nigrificans</italic> (GenBank AY749030.1; Identities = 836/945 (88 %), 11 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Tubakia suttoniana</italic></bold> U. Braun &amp; Crous, <italic>Fungal Syst. Evol.</italic>
<bold>1</bold>: 90. 2018. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F62">Fig. 62</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">On SNA: <italic>Pycnothyria</italic> not developing. Central columella developing with aggregated brown, smooth conidiophores. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> tapering toward apex, branched or not, 0&#x2013;2-septate, 10&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> medium brown, smooth, subcylindrical with apical taper, phialidic, at times with percurrent proliferations, 10&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> aseptate, solitary, pale brown, smooth, granular, guttulate, ellipsoid, with minute truncate hilum, 1&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam, (11&#x2013;)13&#x2013;14(&#x2013;15) &#xD7; 7(&#x2013;8) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading in concentric circles, with moderate to profuse aerial mycelium, covering the dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface zones of pale olivaceous grey to olivaceous grey, reverse olivaceous grey; on PDA surface zones of olivaceous grey to smoke grey, reverse olivaceous grey; on OA surface olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>New Zealand</bold>, Auckland, Takanini, Marango PK way, on leaves of <italic>Quercus</italic> sp. (<italic>Fagaceae</italic>), 16 May 2016, <italic>R. Thangavel</italic>, CBS H-23808, culture CPC 32745 = T16_01981A = CBS 144591.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Tubakia suttoniana</italic> is known from branch and stem cankers on <italic>Quercus cerris</italic> in New Zealand (CBS 229.77; <xref rid="R10" ref-type="bibr">Braun <italic>et al</italic>. 2018</xref>), and CPC 32745 represents an additional record from that country.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence was identical to <italic>Tubakia suttoniana</italic> (GenBank MG591919.1; Identities = 605/605 (100 %)); other closest hits included <italic>Tubakia californica</italic> (GenBank MG591847.1; Identities = 602/603 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and <italic>Tubakia melnikiana</italic> (GenBank MG591893.1; Identities = 600/601 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Tubakia japonica</italic> (GenBank MG591979.1; Identities = 882/882 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Tubakia seoraksanensis</italic> (GenBank KP260501.1; Identities = 845/845 (100 %), no gaps), and <italic>Tubakia californica</italic> (GenBank MG591940.1; Identities = 844/844 (100 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Tubakia suttoniana</italic> (GenBank MG976493.1; Identities = 940/941 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Tubakia californica</italic> (GenBank MG976452.1; Identities = 933/934 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Tubakia japonica</italic> (GenBank MG976469.1; Identities = 991/993 (99 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Tubakia suttoniana</italic> (GenBank MG592108.1; Identities = 467/467 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Tubakia</italic> sp. 1 (GenBank MG592101.1; Identities = 550/562 (98 %), no gaps), and <italic>Tubakia japonica</italic> (GenBank MG592075.1; Identities = 550/562 (98 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Tubakia suttoniana</italic> (GenBank MG592201.1; Identities = 505/507 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Tubakia seoraksanensis</italic> (GenBank MG592190.1; Identities = 487/492 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and <italic>Tubakia japonica</italic> (GenBank MG592165.1; Identities = 508/515 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Turquoiseomycetales</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>ord. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829363.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Turquoiseomycetaceae</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>fam. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829461.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Turquoiseomyces</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829363.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the characteristic green-blue discolouration of the host tissue surrounding conidiomata.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> solitary to aggregated, dark brown, globose, pycnidial, opening by irregular rupture; wall of 6&#x2013;8 layers of brown <italic>textura intricata. Conidiophores</italic> lining the inner cavity, extensively branched, septate, tightly aggregated, pale green-brown, finely roughened, subcylindrical. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> ampulliform to subcylindrical, pale green-brown, finely roughened, terminal and intercalary, proliferating percurrently. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, subcylindrical, guttulate, smooth-walled, medianly 1-septate, apex swollen with mucoid cap, base somewhat tapered, truncate, reflective.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>: <italic>Turquoiseomyces eucalypti</italic> Crous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Turquoiseomyces eucalypti</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829364. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F63">Fig. 63</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> solitary to aggregated, dark brown, globose, pycnidial, opening by irregular rupture, 250&#x2013;350 &#xB5;m diam; wall of 6&#x2013;8 layers of brown <italic>textura intricata. Conidiophores</italic> lining the inner cavity, extensively branched, septate, tightly aggregated, 10&#x2013;25 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m, pale green-brown, finely roughened, subcylindrical. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> ampulliform to subcylindrical, pale green-brown, finely roughened, terminal and intercalary, 5&#x2013;10 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m, proliferating percurrently. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, subcylindrical, guttulate, smooth-walled, medianly 1-septate, apex swollen with mucoid cap, base somewhat tapered, truncate, reflective, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#xB5;m diam, straight to flexuous, (50&#x2013;) 55&#x2013;60(&#x2013;80) &#xD7; 3(&#x2013;4) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, surface folded, with sparse aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, reaching 10 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface greenish grey, reverse smoke grey; on PDA surface olivaceous grey, reverse smoke grey; on OA surface iron-grey in centre, buff in outer region.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold> New South Wales, Cobb Highway, on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus leptophylla</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), Aug. 2017, <italic>B.A. Summerell</italic>, HPC 2220 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23834, culture ex-type CPC 34399 = CBS 145126).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: This very obvious fungus was first seen on leaves where conidia were surrounded by tissue with a green-blue discolouration, which was different from the normal foliicolous coelomycetes on <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> that generally have structures with shades of brown to black. In culture, it again produced greenish grey colonies on MEA. The present collection is not known from DNA data available in GenBank, and is also distinct morphologically, representing a distinct family and order in <italic>Lecanoromycetes</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Lecanora subcarnea</italic> (GenBank AY541267.1; Identities = 313/374 (84 %), 25 gaps (6 %)), <italic>Pseudogymnoascus pannorum</italic> var.<italic> pannorum</italic> (GenBank MH866140.1; Identities = 313/374 (84 %), 27 gaps (7 %)), and <italic>Ciliciopodium hyalinum</italic> (GenBank KM231857.1; Identities = 313/374 (84 %), 27 gaps (7 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Umbilicaria torrefacta</italic> (GenBank JQ740001.1; Identities = 818/886 (92 %), 5 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Umbilicaria muehlenbergii</italic> (GenBank JQ739997.1; Identities = 814/886 (92 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Acarospora anomala</italic> (GenBank LN810758.1; Identities = 813/885 (92 %), 3 gaps (0 %)). No significant hits were obtained when the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence was used in blastn and megablast searches.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Typhicola</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829599.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the genus <italic>Typha</italic> on which it was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Ascomata</italic> gregarious along leaf veins, immersed, globose with central ostiole, somewhat papillate to erumpent, black, soft. <italic>Pseudoparaphyses</italic> numerous, hyaline, smooth, branched with anastomoses, hyphae-like. <italic>Asci</italic> 8-spored, bitunicate, fissitunicate, subcylindrical, with well-developed ocular chamber, thick-walled, short papillate. <italic>Ascospores</italic> ellipsoid, septate, straight to slightly curved, end cells conically rounded, brown, thick-walled, prominently constricted at thick septa, with mucilaginous sheath.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>:<italic> Typhicola typharum</italic> (Desm.) Crous<italic>.</italic></p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Typhicola typharum</italic></bold> (Desm.) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829600. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F64">Fig. 64</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Sphaeria scirpicola</italic> var. <italic>typharum</italic> Desm., <italic>Pl. cryptog. Fr,</italic> ed. 2, nr. 1428. 1848.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonym</italic>: <italic>Juncaceicola typharum</italic> (Desm.) Tennakoon <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Cryptog. Mycol.</italic>
<bold>37</bold>: 151. 2016.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Ascomata</italic> on dead leaves, gregarious along leaf veins, immersed, globose with central ostiole, somewhat papillate to erumpent, black, soft, 100&#x2013;150 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Pseudoparaphyses</italic> numerous, hyaline, smooth, branched with anastomoses, hyphae-like, 2&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Asci</italic> 8-spored, bitunicate, fissitunicate, subcylindrical, with well-developed ocular chamber, 2 &#xB5;m diam, thick-walled, short papillate, 80&#x2013;100 &#xD7; 20&#x2013;25 &#xB5;m. <italic>Ascospores</italic> ellipsoid, 3-septate, with central pore in septum, widest in second cell from apex, straight to slightly curved, end cells conically rounded, golden brown, thick-walled (&lt; 0.5 &#xB5;m), prominently constricted at thick septa, exospore warty, endospore smooth, finely guttulate, with mucilaginous sheath (up to 3 &#xB5;m diam), covering entire ascospore (when mounted in water), (23&#x2013;)27&#x2013;29(&#x2013;31) &#xD7; (8&#x2013;)9&#x2013;10(&#x2013;11) &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and feathery, lobate margin, reaching 45 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA and PDA surface and reverse olivaceous grey; on OA surface iron-grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>France</bold>, on leaves of <italic>Typha</italic> sp. (<italic>Typhaceae</italic>), <italic>Desm</italic>., exsiccata &#x201C;Plantes Cryptogames de France, ed. 2: no. 1428 (1848)&#x201D; (<bold>lectotype</bold> designated here in PC, MBT385534). <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, leaf of <italic>Typha</italic> sp. (<italic>Typhaceae</italic>), 1 Apr. 2017, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic>, HPC 2025 = RKS 84 (<bold>epitype</bold> designated here CBS H-23819, MBT385272, culture ex-epitype CPC 33271 = CBS 145043).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: This fungus occurs commonly in Europe, sporulates well in culture, but produced only the sexual morph in the present study. <xref rid="R87" ref-type="bibr">Tennakoon <italic>et al</italic>. (2016)</xref> introduced the genus <italic>Juncaceicola</italic> and the combination <italic>J. typharum</italic>, but could not locate any type material of <italic>Sphaeria scirpicola</italic> var. <italic>typharum</italic>, and based their new combination on CBS 296.54 (on <italic>Nardus stricta</italic>, Switzerland), which probably represents an undescribed species of <italic>Juncaceicola.</italic> Although phylogenetically distinct, there is morphologically little to choose between <italic>Typhicola</italic> and <italic>Juncaceicola</italic>, and the two genera are best distinguished based on DNA data.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Juncaceicola typharum</italic> (as <italic>Leptosphaeria typharum</italic>, GenBank AF439465.1; Identities = 507/518 (98 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Pleospora typhicola</italic> (GenBank KF636768.1; Identities = 453/486 (93 %), 12 gaps (2 %)), and <italic>Neocamarosporium goegapense</italic> (GenBank KJ869163.1; Identities = 519/587 (88 %), 26 gaps (4 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Pleospora typhicola</italic> (GenBank KF636774.1; Identities = 848/862 (98 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Camarosporidiella robiniicola</italic> (GenBank MF434266.1; Identities = 832/849 (98 %), no gaps), <italic>Camarosporium laburnicola</italic> (GenBank KY497779.1; Identities = 845/863 (98 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and <italic>Juncaceicola typharum</italic> (GenBank MH868883.1; Identities = 834/863 (97 %), 3 gaps (0 %)). Distant hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Pleospora incompta</italic> (GenBank KC584504.1; Identities = 740/867 (85 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Comoclathris compressa</italic> (GenBank KC584498.1; Identities = 736/867 (85 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Pleospora typhicola</italic> (GenBank KC584505.1; Identities = 733/865 (85 %), no gaps). Distant hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Juncaceicola typharum</italic> (as <italic>Phaeosphaeria typharum</italic>, GenBank KF253148.1; Identities = 123/131 (94 %), no gaps), <italic>Dendryphion penicillatum</italic> (GenBank AY375371.1; Identities = 261/281 (93 %), 6 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Alternaria ventricosa</italic> (GenBank KY352501.1; Identities = 272/301 (90 %), 5 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Lasiodiplodia iranensis</italic> (GenBank KU997110.1; Identities = 266/295 (90 %), 4 gaps (1 %)). Distant hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Alternaria solani</italic> (GenBank CP022033.1; Identities = 916/981 (93 %), 9 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Alternaria alternata</italic> (GenBank KJ396337.1; Identities = 905/977 (93 %), 7 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Alternaria cucumerina</italic> (GenBank HQ413318.1; Identities = 903/977 (92 %), 7 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Wojnowiciella dactylidis</italic></bold> (Wijayaw. <italic>et al.</italic>) Hern.-Restr. &amp; Crous, <italic>Sydowia</italic>
<bold>68</bold>: 221. 2016. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F65">Fig. 65</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Wojnowicia dactylidis</italic> Wijayaw. <italic>et al</italic>., <italic>Fungal Diversity</italic>
<bold>72</bold>: 144. 2015.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> erumpent, pycnidial, solitary, globose, papillate, 200&#x2013;300 &#xB5;m diam, with 1&#x2013;2 ostioles; wall of 3&#x2013;6 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Microconidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells lining the inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, doliiform to ampulliform, 4&#x2013;5 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m, phialidic, with periclinal thickening. <italic>Microconidia</italic> solitary, hyaline, smooth, guttulate, aseptate, subcylindrical, apex obtuse, base truncate, (3&#x2013;)4(&#x2013;5) &#xD7; 2 &#xB5;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margin, covering dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface isabelline, reverse isabelline to hazel, with zones of cinnamon.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>New Zealand</bold>, Auckland, Grey Lynn, Grey Lynn park, on <italic>Dypsis</italic> sp. (<italic>Arecaceae</italic>), 5 Oct. 2016, <italic>R. Thangavel</italic>, CBS H-23807, culture T16_03296B = CPC 32741 = CBS 145077.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Wojnowiciella dactylidis</italic> was described from <italic>Dactylis glomerata</italic> collected in Italy, and this is the first record from New Zealand. Unfortunately, only the microconidial morph was observed in culture.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Wojnowiciella dactylidis</italic> (GenBank LT990660.1; Identities = 572/572 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Wojnowiciella cissampeli</italic> (GenBank NR_155972.1; Identities = 568/579 (98 %), 6 gaps (1 %)), and <italic>Wojnowicia rosicola</italic> (GenBank MG828979.1; Identities = 554/568 (98 %), 8 gaps (1 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Wojnowicia rosicola</italic> (GenBank MG829091.1; Identities = 846/847 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Wojnowicia italica</italic> (GenBank KX430001.1; Identities = 846/847 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Wojnowiciella dactylidis</italic> (GenBank LT990632.1; Identities = 844/845 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tef1</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Wojnowicia italica</italic> (GenBank KX430003.1; Identities = 438/440 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Wojnowiciella dactylidis</italic> (GenBank LT990613.1; Identities = 423/425 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Wojnowiciella cissampeli</italic> (GenBank LT990616.1; Identities = 463/469 (99 %), no gaps). No <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequences of <italic>Wojnowiciella</italic> or<italic> Wojnowicia</italic> are available for comparison on GenBank; distant hits using the <italic>tub2</italic> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Fenestella fenestrata</italic> (GenBank MF795893.1; Identities = 247/280 (88 %), 7 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Didymocyrtis banksiae</italic> (GenBank KY979923.1; Identities = 251/284 (88 %), 18 gaps (6 %)), and <italic>Didymocyrtis foliaceiphila</italic> (as <italic>Diederichomyces foliaceiphila</italic>, GenBank KP170700.1; Identities = 246/280 (88 %), 8 gaps (2 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Xenodevriesiaceae</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>fam. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829462.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Xenodevriesia</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829365.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name reflects the fact that this is similar to, but distinct from the genus <italic>Devriesia</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of medium brown, smooth, septate, branched hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> dimorphic. <italic>Microconidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells on hyphae, erect, cylindrical, medium brown, smooth with truncate ends, proliferating sympodially. <italic>Macroconidiophores</italic> erect, cylindrical, straight to geniculate-sinuous, medium brown, smooth, unbranched or branched above, septate. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal or lateral on branched conidiophores, medium brown, smooth, cylindrical, proliferating sympodially; loci truncate, inconspicuous, somewhat darkened, not refractive. <italic>Conidia</italic> medium brown, smooth, guttulate, subcylindrical to narrowly obclavate, apex obtuse to truncate, base truncate, occurring in branched chains, septate; hila inconspicuous to somewhat darkened and thickened, not refractive.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>:<italic> Xenodevriesia strelitziicola</italic> (Arzanlou &amp; Crous) Crous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Xenodevriesia strelitziicola</italic></bold> (Arzanlou &amp; Crous) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829366.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Devriesia strelitziicola</italic> Arzanlou &amp; Crous, <italic>Stud. Mycol.</italic>
<bold>64</bold>: 38. 2009.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Devriesia strelitziicola</italic> was introduced by <xref rid="R23" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> (2009b</xref>) for a fungus that was devriesia-like and pseudocercospora-like in morphology, but which proved to be phylogenetically distinct from both genera. It is morphologically distinct from <italic>Devriesia</italic> in that it does not produce chlamydospores, and from <italic>Peudocercospora</italic> in that the conidial hila are somewhat darkened and thickened. Phylogenetically, it is also clearly distinct, and represents a new family in <italic>Capnodiales</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Zasmidium hakeicola</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829367. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F66">Fig. 66</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the host genus <italic>Hakea</italic> from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of smooth, pale brown, septate, branched, 2&#x2013;2.5 &#xB5;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, geniculous-flexuous, branched or not, subcylindrical, medium brown, finely verruculose, thick-walled, guttulate, multiseptate, 100&#x2013;200 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#xB5;m, arising from superficial hyphae or as a few cells of a weakly developed stroma. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, at times intercalary, subcylindrical, medium brown, finely verruculose, proliferating sympodially, 25&#x2013;50 &#xD7; 5&#x2013;7 &#xB5;m; loci prominently thickened and darkened, refractive, 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xB5;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, obclavate, apex obtuse, base obconically truncate, verruculose, medium brown, straight, (40&#x2013;)47&#x2013;55(&#x2013;65) &#xD7; 8(&#x2013;9) &#xB5;m; hilum thickened, darkened and refractive, 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m diam; conidia at times bifurcate, 3(&#x2013;5)-septate.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with sparse to moderate aerial mycelium and feathery margin, reaching 4 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA and PDA surface pale olivaceous grey to olivaceous grey, reverse olivaceous grey; on OA surface pale olivaceous grey to olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Australian Botanical Garden Mount Annan, on leaves of <italic>Hakea corymbosa</italic> (<italic>Proteaceae</italic>), 25 Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, HPC 1722 (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-23806, culture ex-type CPC 32703 = CBS 144590).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: A morphologically similar species, <italic>Zasmidium grevilleae</italic> (conidia 3&#x2013;7(&#x2013;12)-septate, (30&#x2013;)50&#x2013;65(&#x2013;80) &#xD7; (5&#x2013;)6&#x2013;7 &#x3BC;m), was described from leaves of <italic>Grevillea decurrens</italic> collected in Australia (Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2009a, Videira <italic>et al.</italic> 2017). The present collection from <italic>Hakea</italic> differs from that species in having shorter, wider conidia, with fewer septa.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Zasmidium grevilleae</italic> (GenBank NR_156522.1; Identities = 533/538 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Zasmidium proteacearum</italic> (as <italic>Verrucisporota proteacearum</italic>, GenBank FJ839635.1; Identities = 513/539 (95 %), 23 gaps (4 %)), and <italic>Zasmidium velutinum</italic> (as <italic>Periconiella velutina</italic>, GenBank EU041781.1; Identities = 492/545 (90 %), 16 gaps (2 %)). Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Zasmidium proteacearum</italic> (as <italic>Verrucisporota proteacearum</italic>, GenBank FJ839671.2; Identities = 858/860 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Zasmidium grevilleae</italic> (GenBank MH874876.1; Identities = 857/860 (99%), no gaps), and <italic>Zasmidium biverticillatum</italic> (as <italic>Ramichloridium biverticillatum</italic>, GenBank EU041853.1; Identities = 834/846 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>actA</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Zasmidium proteacearum</italic> (as <italic>Verrucisporota proteacearum</italic>, GenBank KF903478.1; Identities = 433/439 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Zasmidium citri-griseum</italic> (GenBank KF903676.1; Identities = 392/430 (91 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Parapallidocercospora thailandica</italic> (as <italic>Mycosphaerella thailandica</italic>, GenBank EU514333.1; Identities = 373/410 (91 %), 6 gaps (1 %)). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>rpb2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Zasmidium proteacearum</italic> (GenBank MF951721.1; Identities = 677/683 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Zasmidium grevilleae</italic> (GenBank MF951705.1; Identities = 662/668 (99 %), no gaps), and <italic>Zasmidium musicola</italic> (GenBank MF951717.1; Identities = 663/761 (87 %), no gaps). Closest hits using the <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Zasmidium commune</italic> (GenBank KY979928.1; Identities = 721/787 (92 %), no gaps), <italic>Pseudocercospora fijiensis</italic> (GenBank XM_007921924.1; Identities = 702/789 (89 %), no gaps), and <italic>Ramularia collo-cygni</italic> (GenBank JN003648.1; Identities = 701/789 (89 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Zygosporium pseudogibbum</italic></bold> Crous, <italic>Fungal Syst. Evol.</italic>
<bold>1</bold>: 213. 2018. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F67">Fig. 67</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, consisting of 1&#x2013;2 pale brown basal cells forming a stipe, 8&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m, giving rise to a curved, dark brown terminal vesicle, 12&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 5&#x2013;7 &#xB5;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> arranged in a whorl of 3&#x2013;4 on a terminal vesicle, hyaline, smooth, reniform, 5&#x2013;6 &#xD7; 3.5&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m. <italic>Vesicle</italic> with single apical cell, 4&#x2013;6 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#xB5;m, pale brown, cylindrical, with obtuse apex and prominent collarette. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, globose, verruculose, faintly olivaceous, (5&#x2013;)5.5(&#x2013;6) &#xB5;m diam.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium, folded surface and even, smooth margin, reaching 25 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface dirty white, reverse pale luteous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Material examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Australian Botanical Garden Mount Annan, on leaves of <italic>Macrozamia miquelii</italic> (<italic>Zamiaceae</italic>), 25 Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, HPC 1734, CBS H-23580, culture CPC 32120 = CBS 144442.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Zygosporium pseudogibbum</italic> (on <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> leaves from Malaysia; <xref rid="R24" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2018c</xref>) is closely related to <italic>Z. gibbum</italic>, a European taxon (reference isolate, FMR 13130 = CBS 137306; leaf litter Canary Islands; <xref rid="R56" ref-type="bibr">Hern&#xE1;ndez-Restrepo <italic>et al.</italic> 2017</xref>). Morphologically these taxa are very similar and they are thus best distinguished based on their DNA sequences.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search of NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the closest hits using the <bold>ITS</bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Zygosporium mycophilum</italic> (GenBank MH856563.1; Identities = 562/565 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Zygosporium pseudogibbum</italic> (GenBank NR_159072.1; Identities = 551/554 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Zygosporium masonii</italic> (GenBank MH860771.1; Identities = 527/567 (93 %), 16 gaps (2 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Closest hits using the <bold>LSU</bold> sequence are <italic>Zygosporium pseudogibbum</italic> (GenBank MH107974.1; Identities = 839/840 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Atrotorquata spartii</italic> (GenBank KP325443.1; Identities = 845/872 (97 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), and <italic>Lopadostoma fagi</italic> (GenBank KC774577.1; Identities = 829/874 (95 %), 4 gaps (0 %)). The <bold><italic>actA</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Zygosporium pseudogibbum</italic> (GenBank MH107989.1; Identities = 526/540 (97 %), no gaps); other distant hits include <italic>Nalanthamala psidii</italic> (GenBank KM231245.1; Identities = 346/369 (94 %), no gaps), <italic>Dactylonectria alcacerensis</italic> (GenBank KM231158.1; Identities = 346/369 (94 %), no gaps), and <italic>Dactylonectria novozelandica</italic> (GenBank KM231157.1; Identities = 346/369 (94 %), no gaps). The <bold><italic>tub2</italic></bold> sequence had highest similarity to <italic>Zygosporium pseudogibbum</italic> (GenBank MH108055.1; Identities = 461/475 (97 %), 1 gap (0 %)); other distant hits include <italic>Hypoxylon crocopeplum</italic> (GenBank AY951711.1; Identities = 739/798 (93 %), no gaps), <italic>Hypoxylon calileguense</italic> (GenBank KU604579.1; Identities = 739/799 (92 %), no gaps), and <italic>Dicyma funiculosa</italic> (GenBank KU684134.1; Identities = 830/937 (89 %), 11 gaps (1 %)).</p>
      </sec>
      <sec id="s3c">
        <title>Addendum: validation of names and typifications</title>
        <p content-type="specimen">During the course of this study we encountered several names that were invalid based on the International Code of nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants (see MycoBank and Index Fungorum) due to a variety of reasons. As this has led to problems with new combinations or genera and families subsequently based on these names also being rendered invalid, and thus we decided to validate these names below.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Allelochaeta falcata</italic></bold> (B. Sutton) Crous, <italic>Fungal Syst. Evol.</italic>
<bold>2</bold>: 288. 2018.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Cryptostictis falcata</italic> B. Sutton, <italic>Mycol. Pap</italic>. <bold>88</bold>: 25. 1963.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Morphological descriptions and illustrations</italic>: See <xref rid="R6" ref-type="bibr">Barber <italic>et al</italic>. (2011)</xref>, <xref rid="R20" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> (2018a</xref>).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>.<bold> Australia</bold>, Victoria, on <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> sp., 1963, <italic>collector unknown</italic> (<bold>holotype</bold> Herb IMI 59166); New South Wales, Central Tablelands, <italic>ca</italic>. 200 metres WSW of &#x2018;Coomber&#x2019; homestead, on Coomber property, <italic>ca</italic>. 8 km SW of Rylstone, S32&#xB0;50'04" E149&#xB0;56'13", alt. 600 &#xB1; 10 m, 17 Aug. 2006, <italic>R. Johnstone</italic> &amp; <italic>A.E. Orme</italic>, 734259, on <italic>Eucalyptus alligatrix</italic> (<bold>epitype</bold> designated here CBS H-20744, MBT385261, cultures ex-epitype CPC 13578 = CBS 131117).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Allelochaeta</italic> was treated by <xref rid="R20" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> (2018a</xref>). Unfortunately, the holotype specimen was incorrectly cited and thus the epitype is consequently invalid. This is corrected here.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Arthrocatena</italic></bold> Egidi &amp; Selbmann, <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829384.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonym</italic>: <italic>Arthrocatena</italic> Egidi &amp; Selbmann, <italic>Fungal Diversity</italic>
<bold>65</bold>: 159. 2014. <italic>Nom. inval</italic>., Art. 40.7 (Shenzhen).</p>

        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R59" ref-type="bibr">Isola <italic>et al</italic>. (2016)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Italy</bold>, Cagliari, isolated from little marble angels of an anonymous funerary monument in the cemetery of Bonaria (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS 139725, culture and specimen preserved as metabolically inactive).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Sodiomyces</italic></bold> A.A. Grum-Grzhim, Debets &amp; Bilanenko, <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829354.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonym</italic>: <italic>Sodiomyces</italic> Grum-Grzhim., Debets &amp; Bilanenko, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>31</bold>: 154. 2013. <italic>Nom. inval</italic>., Art. 40.1 (Shenzen).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: From the English soda and Latin <italic>mycetes</italic>, referring to the ability of filamentous fungus grow at high ambient pH and salts.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R45" ref-type="bibr">Giraldo &amp; Crous (2019)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Types species</italic>: <italic>Sodiomyces alkalinus</italic> Grum-Grzhim., Debets &amp; Bilanenko.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Sodiomyces alkalinus</italic></bold> Grum-Grzhim., Debets &amp; Bilanenko, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829355.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: From the Latin, alcalinus = alkaline.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustrations</italic>: <xref rid="R7" ref-type="bibr">Bilanenko <italic>et al.</italic> (2005)</xref> and <xref rid="R50" ref-type="bibr">Grum-Grzhimaylo <italic>et al</italic>. (2013)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Mongolia</bold>, Choibalsan area, the soda soil (pH 10.7) on the edge of Shar-Burdiyn lake, 1999, <italic>D. Sorokin</italic> (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS 110278, culture and specimen preserved as metabolically inactive), culture ex-type CBS 110278 = F11 = VKM F-3762.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Sodiomyces alcalophilus</italic></bold> (G. Okada) Giraldo L&#xF3;pez &amp; Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829356.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Acremonium alcalophilum</italic> G. Okada, <italic>Trans. Mycol. Soc. Japan</italic>
<bold>34</bold>: 173. 1993.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustrations</italic>: <xref rid="R67" ref-type="bibr">Okada <italic>et al.</italic> (1993)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Japan</bold>, Kanagawa Pref., Tsukui-gun, near Tsukui Lake, from sludge of pig faeces compost, 9 Dec. 1984, <italic>A. Yoneda</italic> (<bold>holotype</bold> TNS-F-176428, isotype CBS H-5163, ex-isotype culture CBS 114.92 = JCM 7366).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Sodiomyces magadiensis</italic></bold> S.A. Bondarenko, Grum-Grzhim., Debets &amp; Bilanenko, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829359.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonym</italic>:<italic> Sodiomyces magadii</italic> S.A. Bondarenko, <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Fungal Diversity</italic>
<bold>76</bold>: 52. 2015 (2016). <italic>Nom. inval</italic>., Art. 35.1 (Shenzhen).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the Magadi Lake in Kenya (Africa), where the fungus was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustrations</italic>: <xref rid="R51" ref-type="bibr">Grum-Grzhimaylo <italic>et al.</italic> (2016)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Kenya</bold>, soda soil (pH 11) at the edge of Magadi Lake, Jan. 2013, S. Bondarenko (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-21958, culture ex-type MAG2 = CBS 137619 = VKM F-4583).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Sodiomyces tronii</italic></bold> S.A. Bondarenko, Grum-Grzhim., Debets &amp; Bilanenko, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829361.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonym</italic>: <italic>Sodiomyces tronii</italic> S.A. Bondarenko, <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Fungal Diversity</italic>
<bold>76</bold>: 52. 2015 (2016). <italic>Nom. inval</italic>., Art. 35.1 (Shenzhen)</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the &#x2018;trona&#x2019; salt (carbonate mineral), which is abundant in Magadi Lake in Kenya (Africa), where the fungus was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustrations</italic>: <xref rid="R51" ref-type="bibr">Grum-Grzhimaylo <italic>et al.</italic> (2016)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Kenya</bold>, soda soil (pH 11) at the edge of Magadi Lake, Jan. 2013, <italic>S. Bondarenko</italic> (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS H-21957, culture ex-type MAG1 = CBS 137618 = VKM F-4582).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Although <italic>Sodiomyces alkalinus</italic> was redescribed in <xref rid="R45" ref-type="bibr">Giraldo &amp; Crous (2019)</xref>, all species in the genus are invalid. This is due to the fact that the generic name <italic>Sodiomyces</italic> was invalid because it lacked a valid type species. The genus and all species are thus validated here.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Vermiconidia</italic></bold> Egidi &amp; Onofri, <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829433. <italic>Synonym</italic>: <italic>Vermiconia</italic> Egidi &amp; Onofri, <italic>Fungal Diversity</italic>
<bold>65</bold>: 150. 2014. <italic>Nom. inval</italic>., Art. 40.7 (Shenzhen).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Morphology of conidial chains reminiscent of worms.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R36" ref-type="bibr">Egidi <italic>et al.</italic> (2014)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>: <italic>Vermiconidia foris</italic> Egidi &amp; Onofri.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Vermiconidia antarctica</italic></bold> Egidi &amp; Selbmann, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829434.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonym</italic>: <italic>Vermiconia antarctica</italic> Egidi &amp; Selbmann, <italic>Fungal Diversity</italic>
<bold>65</bold>: 152. 2014. <italic>Nom. inval</italic>., Art. 40.7 (Shenzhen).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Named after the cold continent the strain was isolated from.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R36" ref-type="bibr">Egidi <italic>et al.</italic> (2014)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Antarctica</bold>, McMurdo Dry Valleys, Battleship Promontory, from rock (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS 136107, culture and specimen preserved as metabolically inactive).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Vermiconidia calcicola</italic></bold> de Hoog &amp; Onofri, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829435.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonym</italic>: <italic>Vermiconia calcicola</italic> de Hoog &amp; Onofri, <italic>Fungal Diversity</italic>
<bold>76</bold>: 90. 2015 (2016). <italic>Nom. inval</italic>., Art. 40.7 (Shenzhen).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Named after the substrate where the ex-type strain was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R59" ref-type="bibr">Isola <italic>et al</italic>. (2016)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Italy</bold>, Cagliari, isolated from Giuseppina Ara funerary marble monument in the cemetery of Bonaria (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS 140080, culture and specimen preserved as metabolically inactive).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Vermiconidia foris</italic></bold> Egidi &amp; Onofri, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829436.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonym</italic>: <italic>Vermiconia foris</italic> Egidi &amp; Onofri, <italic>Fungal Diversity</italic>
<bold>65</bold>: 150. 2014. <italic>Nom. inval</italic>., Art. 40.7 (Shenzhen).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Morphology of propagating cultures reminiscent of extraterrestrial worms.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R36" ref-type="bibr">Egidi <italic>et al</italic>. (2014)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Italy</bold>, Monte Rosa, from rock (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS 136106, culture and specimen preserved as metabolically inactive).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Vermiconidia flagrans</italic></bold> Selbmann &amp; Isola, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB829437.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonym</italic>: <italic>Vermiconia flagrans</italic> Selbmann &amp; Isola, <italic>Fungal Diversity</italic>
<bold>65</bold>: 152. 2014. <italic>Nom. inval</italic>., Art. 40.7 (Shenzhen).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Named after the survival of high summer temperatures prevailing in its natural habitat.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R36" ref-type="bibr">Egidi <italic>et al.</italic> (2014)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Typus</italic>: <bold>Spain</bold>, Mallorca, from rock (<bold>holotype</bold> CBS 118296, culture and specimen preserved as metabolically inactive).</p>
      </sec>
    </sec>
  </body>

    <fig id="F1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <label>Fig. 1.</label>
      <caption>
        <p>Consensus phylogram (50 % majority rule) obtained from a Bayesian analysis of the <italic>Dothideomycetes</italic> alignment. Bayesian posterior probabilities (PP) &gt;0.84 are shown at the nodes and thickened lines represent nodes with PP = 1.00. The scale bar represents the expected changes per site. Families and orders are indicated with coloured blocks to the right of the tree. GenBank accession and/or culture accession numbers are indicated behind the species names. The tree was rooted to <italic>Helotium subcorticale</italic> (GenBank MH869740.1) and the novelties treated in the Taxonomy section are indicated in bold face.</p>
      </caption>
      <graphic xlink:href="fuse-2019-3-6-g001"/>
      <graphic xlink:href="fuse-2019-3-6-g001a"/>

    </fig>

Bayesian posterior probabilities (PP) &gt;0.84 are shown at the nodes and thickened lines represent nodes with PP = 1.00. The scale bar represents the expected changes per site. Families and orders are indicated with coloured blocks to the right of the tree. GenBank accession and/or culture accession numbers are indicated behind the species names. The tree was rooted to <italic>Saccharata proteae</italic> (GenBank EU552145.1) and the novelties treated in the Taxonomy section are indicated in bold face.</p>

Bayesian posterior probabilities (PP) &gt;0.84 are shown at the nodes and thickened lines represent nodes with PP = 1.00. The scale bar represents the expected changes per site. Families, orders and classes are indicated with coloured blocks to the right of the tree. GenBank accession and/or culture accession numbers are indicated behind the species names. The tree was rooted to <italic>Saccharata proteae</italic> (GenBank EU552145.1) and the novelties treated in the Taxonomy section are indicated in bold face.</p>

    <fig id="F21" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <label>Fig. 21.</label>
      <caption>
        <p>The first of five equally most parsimonious trees obtained from a phylogenetic analysis of the <italic>Hansfordia</italic> ITS alignment (20 strains including the outgroup; 477 characters analysed: 337 constant, 93 variable and parsimony-uninformative and 47 parsimony-informative). The tree was rooted to <italic>Dicyma funiculosa</italic> (GenBank NR_132072.1) and the scale bar indicates the number of changes. Bootstrap support values higher than 49 % are shown at the nodes and the species clades are highlighted with coloured boxes. Species names are indicated to the right of the tree. Strain numbers, followed by the sources between round brackets, substrate/source and country of origin are indicated for each sequence. Branches present in the strict consensus tree are thickened. The length of the most basal branch was shortened to facilitate layout. Tree statistics: TL = 159, CI = 0.975, RI = 0.986, RC = 0.961.</p>
      </caption>
      <graphic xlink:href="fuse-2019-3-6-g021"/>
    </fig>

    <fig id="F54" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <label>Fig. 54.</label>
      <caption>
        <p>RAxML phylogenetic tree obtained from a phylogenetic analysis of the <italic>Sympodiella</italic> ITS, LSU, <italic>rpb2</italic> and <italic>tef1</italic> alignment (9 strains including outgroup; 4014 characters analysed: 699 from ITS, 886 from LSU, 921 from <italic>rpb2</italic>, and 1508 from <italic>tef1</italic>). The tree was rooted to <italic>Pseudoanungitea variabilis</italic> CBS 132716 and <italic>Septonema crispulum</italic> CBS 735.96 and the scale bar indicates the number of changes. Bootstrap support values higher than 70 % and Bayesian posterior probabilities higher than 0.95 are shown at the nodes and the species clades are highlighted with coloured boxes. Species names are indicated to the right of the tree. Strain numbers are followed by the substrate/source and country of origin are indicated for each strain.</p>
      </caption>
      <graphic xlink:href="fuse-2019-3-6-g054"/>
    </fig>

            <td align="left" valign="top" rowspan="1" colspan="1">&#x2012;, DQ408574.1, &#x2012;</td>
            <td align="left" valign="top" rowspan="1" colspan="1">&#x2012;, &#x2012;, &#x2012;</td>
            <td align="left" valign="top" rowspan="1" colspan="1">DQ435078.1, &#x2012;, &#x2012;</td>
          </tr>

            <td align="left" valign="top" rowspan="1" colspan="1">

            </td>
            <td align="left" valign="top" rowspan="1" colspan="1">Italy</td>

          <label>1</label>
          <p>ATCC: American Type Culture Collection, Virginia, USA; CBS: Westerdijk Fungal Biodiversity Institute, Utrecht, The Netherlands; CPC: Culture collection of Pedro Crous, housed at CBS; dH: Culture collection of Sybren de Hoog, housed at CBS; IFO: Institute for Fermentation, Osaka, Yodogawa-ku, Osaka, Japan (collection transferred to NBRC); IMI: International Mycological Institute, CABI-Bioscience, Egham, Bakeham Lane, United Kingdom; MFLUCC: Mae Fah Luang University Culture Collection, Chiang Rai, Thailand.</p>
        </fn>
        <fn id="tfn2">
          <label>2</label>
          <p>ITS: internal transcribed spacers and intervening 5.8S nrDNA; LSU: large subunit (28S) of the nrRNA gene operon; <italic>act</italic>: partial actin gene; <italic>cmdA</italic>: partial calmodulin gene; <italic>gapdh</italic>: partial glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase gene; <italic>his3</italic>: partial histone H3 gene; <italic>rpb2</italic>: partial DNA-directed RNA polymerase II second largest subunit gene; <italic>tef1</italic>: partial translation elongation factor 1-alpha gene; <italic>tub2</italic>: partial beta-tubulin gene.</p>
