      <abstract abstract-type="executive-summary">
        <p>This study introduces two new families, one new genus, 22 new species, 10 new combinations, four epitypes, and 16 interesting new host and / or geographical records. <italic>Cylindriaceae</italic> (based on <italic>Cylindrium elongatum</italic>) is introduced as new family, with three new combinations. <italic>Xyladictyochaetaceae</italic> (based on <italic>Xyladictyochaeta lusitanica</italic>) is introduced to accommodate <italic>Xyladictyochaeta. Pseudoanungitea</italic> gen. nov. (based on<italic> P. syzygii</italic>) is described on stems of <italic>Vaccinium myrtillus</italic> (Germany). New species include: <italic>Exophiala eucalypticola</italic> on<italic> Eucalyptus obliqua</italic> leaf litter<italic>, Phyllosticta hakeicola</italic> on leaves of <italic>Hakea</italic> sp<italic>., Setophaeosphaeria citricola</italic> on leaves of <italic>Citrus australasica,</italic> and <italic>Sirastachys cyperacearum</italic> on leaves of <italic>Cyperaceae</italic> (Australia); <italic>Polyscytalum chilense</italic> on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus urophylla</italic> (Chile); <italic>Pseudoanungitea vaccinii</italic> on <italic>Vaccinium myrtillus</italic> (Germany); <italic>Teichospora quercus</italic> on branch tissue of <italic>Quercus</italic> sp. (France); <italic>Fusiconidium lycopodiellae</italic> on stems of <italic>Lycopodiella inundata, Monochaetia junipericola</italic> on twig of <italic>Juniperus communis, Myrmecridium sorbicola</italic> on branch tissues of <italic>Sorbus aucuparia, Parathyridaria philadelphi</italic> on twigs of <italic>Philadelphus coronarius,</italic> and <italic>Wettsteinina philadelphi</italic> on twigs of <italic>Philadelphus coronarius</italic> (Germany); <italic>Zygosporium pseudogibbum</italic> on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus pellita</italic> (Malaysia); <italic>Pseudoanungitea variabilis</italic> on dead wood (Spain); <italic>Alfaria acaciae</italic> on leaves of <italic>Acacia propinqua, Dictyochaeta mimusopis</italic> on leaves of <italic>Mimusops caffra,</italic> and <italic>Pseudocercospora breonadiae</italic> on leaves of <italic>Breonadia microcephala</italic> (South Africa); <italic>Colletotrichum kniphofiae</italic> on leaves of <italic>Kniphofia uvaria, Subplenodomus iridicola</italic> on <italic>Iris</italic> sp., and <italic>Trochila viburnicola</italic> on twig cankers on <italic>Viburnum</italic> sp. (UK); <italic>Polyscytalum neofecundissimum</italic> on <italic>Quercus robur</italic> leaf litter<italic>,</italic> and <italic>Roussoella euonymi</italic> on fallen branches of <italic>Euonymus europaeus</italic> (Ukraine). New combinations include: <italic>Cylindrium algarvense</italic> on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> sp. (Portugal), <italic>Cylindrium purgamentum</italic> on leaf litter (USA), <italic>Cylindrium syzygii</italic> on leaves of <italic>Syzygium</italic> sp. (Australia), <italic>Microdochium musae</italic> on leaves of <italic>Musa</italic> sp. (Malaysia), <italic>Polyscytalum eucalyptigenum</italic> on <italic>Eucalyptus grandis</italic> &#xD7; <italic>pellita</italic> (Malaysia), <italic>P. eucalyptorum</italic> on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> (Australia), <italic>P. grevilleae</italic> on leaves of <italic>Grevillea</italic> (Australia), <italic>P. nullicananum</italic> on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> (Australia), <italic>Pseudoanungitea syzygii</italic> on <italic>Syzygium cordatum</italic> leaf litter (South Africa), and <italic>Setophaeosphaeria sidae</italic> on leaves of <italic>Sida</italic> sp. (Brazil). New records include: <italic>Sphaerellopsis paraphysata</italic> on leaves of <italic>Phragmites</italic> sp., <italic>Vermiculariopsiella dichapetali</italic> on leaves of <italic>Melaleuca</italic> sp. and <italic>Eucalyptus regnans</italic>, and <italic>Xyladictyochaeta lusitanica</italic> on leaf litter of<italic> Eucalyptus</italic> sp. (Australia); <italic>Camarosporidiella mackenziei</italic> on twigs of <italic>Caragana</italic> sp. (Finland); <italic>Cyclothyriella rubronotata</italic> on twigs of <italic>Ailanthus altissima</italic>, <italic>Rhinocladiella quercus</italic> on <italic>Sorbus aucuparia</italic> branches (Germany); <italic>Cytospora viticola</italic> on stems of <italic>Vitis vinifera</italic> (Hungary); <italic>Echinocatena arthrinioides</italic> on leaves of <italic>Acacia crassicarpa</italic> (Malaysia); <italic>Varicosporellopsis aquatilis</italic> from garden soil (Netherlands); <italic>Pestalotiopsis hollandica</italic> on needles of <italic>Cupressus sempervirens</italic> (Spain), <italic>Pseudocamarosporium africanum</italic> on twigs of <italic>Erica</italic> sp. (South Africa), <italic>Pseudocamarosporium brabeji</italic> on branch of <italic>Platanus</italic> sp. (Switzerland); <italic>Neocucurbitaria cava</italic> on leaves of <italic>Quercus ilex</italic> (UK); <italic>Chaetosphaeria myriocarpa</italic> on decaying wood of <italic>Carpinus betulus, Haplograhium delicatum</italic> on decaying <italic>Carpinus betulus</italic> wood (Ukraine). Epitypes are designated for:<italic> Elsino&#xEB; mimosae</italic> on leaves of <italic>Mimosa diplotricha</italic> (Brazil), <italic>Neohendersonia kickxii</italic> on <italic>Fagus sylvatica</italic> twig bark (Italy), <italic>Caliciopsis maxima</italic> on fronds of <italic>Niphidium crassifolium</italic> (Brazil), <italic>Dictyochaeta septata</italic> on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus grandis</italic> &#xD7;<italic> urophylla</italic> (Chile), and <italic>Microdochium musae</italic> on leaves of <italic>Musa</italic> sp. (Malaysia).</p>
      </abstract>
      <kwd-group>
        <kwd>biodiversity</kwd>
        <kwd>ITS barcodes</kwd>
        <kwd>multi-gene phylogeny</kwd>
        <kwd>new taxa</kwd>
        <kwd>systematics</kwd>
        <kwd>typification</kwd>
        <kwd>36 new taxa</kwd>
      </kwd-group>
    </article-meta>
  </front>
  <body>
    <sec sec-type="intro" id="s1">
      <title>INTRODUCTION</title>
      <p>New and Interesting Fungi (NIF) is introduced as a new series of papers that will supplement other series focussed on expanding existing knowledge of fungal biodiversity and fungal conservation. Another similar series such as the Fungal Planet (<ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="www.fungalplanet.org">www.fungalplanet.org</ext-link>) aims to provide a rapid and simplified outlet for researchers to describe new fungal species as well as to highlight the environments where these fungi were isolated. The Fungal Planet series established in 2006 emphasises a holistic conservation of all life on the planet including not only plants and animals but also fungi (<xref rid="R9" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2017</xref>a, b).</p>
      <p>This new series of papers focusses not only on new fungal taxa but also on those that are generally interesting and that deserve notice. Like other series including the already mentioned Fungal Planet, the Genera of Fungi (GoF) series (<xref rid="R9" ref-type="bibr">Crous &amp; Groenewald 2017</xref>, <xref rid="R33" ref-type="bibr">Giraldo <italic>et al.</italic> 2017</xref>), the Genera of Phytopathogenic Fungi (GOPHY) series (<xref rid="R49" ref-type="bibr">Marin-Felix <italic>et al.</italic> 2017</xref>), and the Fungal Systematics and Evolution series (<xref rid="R10" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 2015a</xref>, <xref rid="R37" ref-type="bibr">Hernandez-Restrepo <italic>et al.</italic> 2016</xref>, <xref rid="R41" ref-type="bibr">Krisai-Greilhuber <italic>et al.</italic> 2017</xref>) it has become evident that there are many undescribed species of fungi and new host or geographical records for which a scientific repository is lacking. Most of these could easily never be described or catalogued, and thus being lost to science. This justified the decision to launch the new series New and Interesting Fungi (NIF). It is hoped that this series will provide an attractive vehicle for mycologists to publish single new species or to highlight the relevance of important fungi.</p>
      <p>Many known fungal species need to be recollected and epi- or neotypified in order to secure the application of old names already in use and resolve their DNA phylogeny. Subsequent to the end of the long-standing dual nomenclature for fungi (<xref rid="R35" ref-type="bibr">Hawksworth <italic>et al</italic>. 2011</xref>, <xref rid="R74" ref-type="bibr">Wingfield <italic>et al</italic>. 2012</xref>) and the connection of different morphs to a single name (<xref rid="R59" ref-type="bibr">Rossman <italic>et al</italic>. 2015</xref>, <xref rid="R57" ref-type="bibr">R&#xE9;blov&#xE1; <italic>et al.</italic> 2016</xref>), it became clear that a vehicle was required to ensure that these data could be easily and effectively published. This would be comparable to &#x201C;data release papers&#x201D; published in other fields of science and biology (<xref rid="R51" ref-type="bibr">Miller et al. 2013</xref>, <xref rid="R70" ref-type="bibr">Vu <italic>et al.</italic> 2016</xref>). The New and Interesting Fungi series will link not only asexual and sexual morphs of species, but also provide opportunities to merge morphological observations with DNA sequence data, providing a means for rapid and accurate identification. New and Interesting Fungi will appear twice each year (June and December) in the journal Fungal Systematics and Evolution (<ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="www.FUSE-journal.org">www.FUSE-journal.org</ext-link>). Mycologists and other researchers wishing to contribute to future issues in this series are encouraged to contact Pedro Crous (p.crous@westerdijkinstitute.nl) before submission to ensure that potential conflicts with activities arising from other research groups can be avoided.</p>
    </sec>
    <sec sec-type="materials|methods" id="s2">
      <title>MATERIALS AND METHODS</title>
      <sec id="s2a">
        <title>Isolates</title>
        <p>Leaves and twig samples were placed in damp chambers and incubated at room temperature for 1&#x2013;3 d. Single conidial colonies were grown from sporulating conidiomata in Petri dishes containing 2 % malt extract agar (MEA) as described earlier by <xref rid="R21" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> (1991)</xref>. Leaf and stem tissues bearing ascomata were soaked in water for approximately 2 h, after which they were attached to the bottom side of the lids of Petri dishes containing MEA. After ascospores ejected onto the MEA, germination patterns were determined after 24 h, and single ascospore or conidial cultures were established following the method described by (<xref rid="R6" ref-type="bibr">Crous 1998</xref>). Colonies were sub-cultured on 2 % potato-dextrose agar (PDA), oatmeal agar (OA), MEA (<xref rid="R14" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2009b</xref>), autoclaved pine needles on 2 % tap water agar (PNA) (<xref rid="R61" ref-type="bibr">Smith <italic>et al.</italic> 1996</xref>), or autoclaved banana leaves (BLA), and incubated at 25 &#xB0;C under continuous near-ultraviolet light to promote sporulation. Reference strains and specimens are maintained at the Westerdijk Fungal Biodiversity Institute in Utrecht, the Netherlands (CBS).</p>
      </sec>
      <sec id="s2b">
        <title>DNA extraction, amplification (PCR) and phylogeny</title>
        <p>Fungal mycelium (Supplementary Table 1) was scraped from the agar surface of cultures with a sterile scalpel and the genomic DNA was isolated using the Wizard&#xAE; Genomic DNA Purification Kit (Promega Corporation, WI, USA) following the manufacturers&#x2019; protocols. The 28S nrRNA gene (LSU) and internal transcribed spacer regions with intervening 5.8S nrRNA gene (ITS) of the nrDNA operon were sequenced for all the isolates included in this study. Other loci were sequenced for various species or genera using primers and conditions specific for those groups of fungi (see REFERENCES for details). The resulting fragments were sequenced in both directions using the respective PCR primers and the BigDye Terminator Cycle Sequencing Kit v. 3.1 (Applied Biosystems Life Technologies, Carlsbad, CA, USA); DNA sequencing amplicons were purified through Sephadex G-50 Superfine columns (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO) in MultiScreen HV plates (Millipore, Billerica, MA). Purified sequence reactions were analysed on an Applied Biosystems 3730xl DNA Analyzer (Life Technologies, Carlsbad, CA, USA). The DNA sequences were analysed and consensus sequences were computed using SeqMan Pro v. 13 (DNASTAR, Madison, WI, USA).</p>
        <p>The sequences for each gene were subjected to megablast searches (<xref rid="R77" ref-type="bibr">Zhang <italic>et al</italic>. 2000</xref>) to identify closely related sequences in the NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database. The results are provided as part of the species notes or as selected phylogenetic trees. Phylogenetic trees were generated using Bayesian analyses performed with MrBayes v. 3.2.6 (<xref rid="R58" ref-type="bibr">Ronquist <italic>et al</italic>. 2012</xref>) for the overview trees and Maximum Parsimony analyses performed with PAUP v. 4.0b10 (<xref rid="R65" ref-type="bibr">Swofford 2003</xref>) as explained in <xref rid="R3" ref-type="bibr">Braun <italic>et al</italic>. (2018)</xref> for the genus and species trees. All resulting trees were printed with Geneious v. 11.0.3 (<ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="http://www.geneious.com">http://www.geneious.com</ext-link>, <xref rid="R40" ref-type="bibr">Kearse <italic>et al.</italic> 2012</xref>) and the layout of the trees was done in Adobe Illustrator v. CC 2017. Statistical measures calculated included tree length (TL), consistency index (CI), retention index (RI) and rescaled consistency index (RC).</p>
      </sec>
      <sec id="s2c">
        <title>Morphology</title>
        <p>Slide preparations were mounted in lactic acid, Shear&#x2019;s mounting fluid or water, from colonies sporulating on MEA, PDA, PNA, BLA or OA. Sections through conidiomata were made by hand. Observations were made with a Nikon SMZ25 dissection-microscope, and with a Zeiss Axio Imager 2 light microscope using differential interference contrast (DIC) illumination and images recorded on a Nikon DS-Ri2 camera with associated software. Colony characters and pigment production were noted after 2&#x2013;4 wk of growth on MEA, PDA and OA (<xref rid="R14" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2009b</xref>) incubated at 25 &#xB0;C. Colony colours (surface and reverse) were scored using the colour charts of <xref rid="R56" ref-type="bibr">Rayner (1970)</xref>. Sequences derived in this study were deposited in GenBank (Supplementary Table 1), the alignment in TreeBASE (<ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="www.treebase.org;">www.treebase.org;</ext-link> study number S22442), and taxonomic novelties in MycoBank (<ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="www.MycoBank.org;">www.MycoBank.org;</ext-link>
<xref rid="R8" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2004</xref>).</p>
      </sec>
    </sec>
    <sec sec-type="results" id="s3">
      <title>RESULTS</title>
      <sec id="s3a">
        <title>Phylogeny</title>
        <p><italic>Dothideomycetes</italic> LSU phylogeny: The alignment contained 125 isolates and <italic>Candida broadrunensis</italic> (CBS 11838, GenBank KY106372.1) was used as outgroup. The final alignment contained a total of 808 characters used for the phylogenetic analyses, including alignment gaps. Based on the results of MrModelTest, dirichlet base frequencies and the GTR+I+G model was used for the Bayesian analysis. The Bayesian analyses generated 38 302 trees from which 28 728 were sampled after 25 % of the trees were discarded as burn-in. The posterior probability values (PP) were calculated from the 28 728 trees (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F1">Fig. 1</xref> overview <italic>Dothideomycetes</italic>; PP &gt;0.74 shown). The alignment contained a total of 345 unique site patterns.</p>
        <p><italic>Eurotiomycetes</italic> and <italic>Leotiomycetes</italic> LSU phylogeny: The alignment contained 44 isolates and <italic>Orbilia vinosa</italic> (GenBank DQ470952.1) was used as outgroup. The final alignment contained a total of 813 characters used for the phylogenetic analyses, including alignment gaps. Based on the results of MrModelTest, dirichlet base frequencies and the GTR+I+G model was used for the Bayesian analyses. The Bayesian analyses generated 9 702 trees from which 7 278 were sampled after 25 % of the trees were discarded as burn-in. The posterior probability values (PP) were calculated from the 7 278 trees (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F2">Fig. 2</xref> overview <italic>Eurotiomycetes</italic>; PP &gt;0.74 shown). The alignment contained a total of 253 unique site patterns.</p>
        <p><italic>Sordariomycetes</italic> LSU phylogeny: The alignment contained 148 isolates and <italic>Candida broadrunensis</italic> (CBS 11838, GenBank KY106372.1) was used as outgroup. The final alignment contained a total of 761 characters used for the phylogenetic analyses, including alignment gaps. Based on the results of MrModelTest, dirichlet base frequencies and the GTR+I+G model was used for the Bayesian analysis. The Bayesian analyses generated 34 702 trees from which 26 028 were sampled after 25 % of the trees were discarded as burn-in. The posterior probability values (PP) were calculated from the 26 028 trees (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F3">Fig. 3</xref> overview <italic>Sordariomycetes</italic>; first value: PP &gt;0.74 shown). The alignment contained a total of 361 unique site patterns.</p>
        <p>Species phylogenies: Specific phylogenetic analyses were run for selected species and the resulting phylogenies are discussed in the species notes where applicable. Statistics associated with those phylogenies are provided in the figure legends.</p>
      </sec>
      <sec id="s3b">
        <title>Taxonomy</title>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Alfaria acaciae</italic></bold> Crous &amp; M.J. Wingf., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824766. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F4">Fig. 4</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Acacia,</italic> the genus of the substrate from which this fungus was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> sporodochial, surrounded by setae, black with dark green to black slimy conidial masses, 80&#x2013;250 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Setae</italic> flexuous, unbranched, thick-walled, apex obtuse, dark brown, verruculose, 3&#x2013;6-septate, 100&#x2013;150 &#xD7; 5&#x2013;7 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> densely aggregated, arising from hyaline basal stroma, becoming pigmented and verruculose towards conidiogenous region, subcylindrical, 3&#x2013;5-septate, branched, 30&#x2013;55 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;2.5 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> integrated, terminal and intercalary, subcylindrical, becoming pigmented and verruculose at upper region, phialidic with periclinal thickening and flared collarette, 10&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;2.5 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, fusoid-ellipsoid, straight, apex subobtuse, base truncate, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m diam, aseptate, guttulate, granular, medium brown, smooth, (6&#x2013;)8&#x2013;10(&#x2013;12) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, reaching 50 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface dirty white to pale luteous, reverse luteous. On PDA surface dirty white, reverse pale luteous. On OA surface pale luteous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimens examined</italic>: <bold>South Africa</bold>, Western Cape Province, Stellenbosch, Helshoogte Pass, on leaves of <italic>Acacia propinqua</italic> (<italic>Fabaceae</italic>), Jul. 2012, <italic>M.J. Wingfield</italic> (holotype CBS H-23428, culture ex-type CPC 31882 = CBS 143504); <italic>ibid.</italic>, CPC 31940.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Alfaria cyperi-esculenti</italic> was originally described from <italic>Cyperus esculentus</italic> in Spain, where it causes a serious foliar disease (<xref rid="R11" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 2014</xref>). This species is currently known only from its sexual morph, which complicates a morphological comparison with the present, asexual isolate from South Africa. Although phylogenetically closely related (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F5">Fig. 5</xref>), we regard them as two distinct species (see bp differences below). Furthermore, culture characteristics also differ between the two species, with cultures of <italic>A. acaciae</italic> growing faster, and paler in colour than the ochreous / apricot cultures of <italic>A</italic>. <italic>cyperi-esculenti</italic> (<xref rid="R11" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 2014</xref>).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>A. cyperi-esculenti</italic> (GenBank KJ869143; Identities 567 / 577 (98 %), 5 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Myrothecium leucotrichum</italic> (GenBank AJ301992; Identities 566 / 578 (98 %), 7 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>A. thymi</italic> (GenBank KU845990; Identities 559 / 572 (98 %), 8 gaps (1 %)). The ITS sequences of CPC 31882 and 31940 are identical. The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>A. cyperi-esculenti</italic> (GenBank KJ869200; Identities 803 / 804 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>A. thymi</italic> (GenBank KU845999; Identities 824 / 828 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>A. caricicola</italic> (GenBank KU845992; Identities 822 / 828 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)). The highest similarities using the <italic>cmdA</italic> sequence of CPC 31882 were <italic>A. terrestris</italic> (GenBank KU845979; Identities 479 / 544 (88 %), 7 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Gregatothecium humicola</italic> (GenBank KU846285; Identities 475 / 544 (87 %), 7 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>A. ossiformis</italic> (GenBank KU845977; Identities 461 / 545 (85 %), 10 gaps (1 %)). The highest similarities using the <italic>rpb2</italic> sequence of CPC 31882 were <italic>A. putrefolia</italic> (GenBank KU846003; Identities 624 / 704 (89 %), 3 gaps (0 %)), <italic>A. ossiformis</italic> (GenBank KU846002; Identities 620 / 710 (87 %), 3 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>A. caricicola</italic> (GenBank KU846001; Identities 536 / 597 (90 %), no gaps). The <italic>rpb2</italic> sequences of CPC 31882 and 31940 were identical. The highest similarities using the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence of CPC 31882 were <italic>A. terrestris</italic> (GenBank KU846010; Identities 321 / 378 (85 %), 26 gaps (6 %)), <italic>A. caricicola</italic> (GenBank KU846008; Identities 370 / 441 (84 %), 20 gaps (4 %)) and <italic>A. ossiformis</italic> (GenBank KU846009; Identities 313 / 373 (84 %), 27 gaps (7 %)). The <italic>tef1</italic> sequences of CPC 31882 and 31940 were identical. The highest similarities using the <italic>tub2</italic> sequence of CPC 31882 were <italic>A. terrestris</italic> (GenBank KU846019; Identities 331 / 348 (95 %), 3 gaps (0 %)), <italic>A. putrefolia</italic> (GenBank KU846017; Identities 330 / 347 (95 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>A. ossiformis</italic> (GenBank KU846015; Identities 328 / 348 (94 %), 3 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Caliciopsis maxima</italic></bold> (Berk. &amp; M.A. Curtis) H&#xF6;hn., <italic>Sitzungsber Akad. Wiss. Wien</italic>, <italic>Math.-Naturwiss. Kl., Abt. 1</italic>, <bold>128</bold>: 84. 1919. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F6">Fig. 6</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Capnodium maximum</italic> Berk. &amp; M.A. Curtis, <italic>J. Linn. Soc., Bot</italic>. <bold>10</bold>(46): 391. 1868 (1869).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Stromata</italic> mostly abaxial, limited to sporangial sori of ferns, hidden from view beneath the host sporangia until black ascigerous, bristle-like stromatic columnar tubes push up and protrude from the sori, or otherwise are produced on wounded tissues, sometimes bordering entire pinnules; not associated with discoloration or necrosis of the opposite surface of the frond; rarely adaxial; starting as minute, erumpent cushions, increasing in diameter and thickness after emergence. <italic>Ascigerous columns</italic> long-stalked, prominently beaked, undergoing repeated apical proliferation; additional stromatic column material is formed in a renewed vegetative growth phase at the funnel-shaped apex of each stalk; the process is repeated as many as five times; primary column usually longer, reaching up to 1.7 mm long, all columns formed later, not exceeding 700 &#x3BC;m in length; stalk long, slender, flexuous, 35&#x2013;50 &#x3BC;m diam, covered with brown hyphae. <italic>Ascigenous swelling</italic> (locules) subterminal, ellipsoid, 125&#x2013;150 &#x3BC;m diam, 200&#x2013;350 &#x3BC;m in length, apical dehiscence, forming a reddish brown pulverulent of terminally aggregated ascospores. <italic>Asci</italic> bitunicate, evanescent, obclavate, pedicellate, straight or slightly curved, 15&#x2013;17 &#xD7; 8&#x2013;10 &#x3BC;m, 8-spored, aparaphysate, hyaline, smooth. <italic>Ascospores</italic> inordinate, overlapping, globose or subglobose, 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m diam, aseptate, eguttulate, yellowish brown, thin-walled, smooth. <italic>Spermogonium</italic> subglobose, sessile or short stipitate, papillate, often covered in pale brown hyphae, aggregated below ascomatal tubes, black, smooth. <italic>Spermatia</italic> unicellular, narrowly fusiform, 11&#x2013;24 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m, hyaline, smooth.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies on PCA slow-growing, 15&#x2013;20 mm diam after 1 mo; irregular, convex with papillate surface, edges entire, aerial mycelium sparse to absent, composed of black hyphal tufts, vinaceous buff towards periphery, pigmenting the medium with cinnamon taint; sepia in reverse; colonies sterile.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimens examined</italic>: <bold>Cuba</bold>, on fronds of <italic>Niphidium</italic> sp. (<italic>Polypodiaceae</italic>) (originally identified as <italic>Polypodium</italic> sp.), 1941, <italic>Wright</italic> (holotype CUP-029913). <bold>Brazil</bold>, Rio de Janeiro, Nova Friburgo, on fronds of <italic>Niphidium crassifolium</italic> (<italic>Polypodiaceae</italic>), 5 Nov. 2011, <italic>R.W. Barreto</italic> (epitype designated here VIC 42568, MBT373013, culture ex-epitype COAD 1983 = CPC 24674); <italic>ibid,</italic> on fronds of <italic>Microgramma squamulosa</italic> (<italic>Polypodiaceae</italic>), 10 Oct. 2013, <italic>R.W. Barreto</italic> (VIC 42602).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The epitype specimen of <italic>Caliciopsis maxima</italic> (<italic>Coryneliaceae</italic>) proposed here closely matches the morphology of the holotype and several additional collections studied by <xref rid="R29" ref-type="bibr">Fitzpatrick (1942)</xref>, including one recorded on the same host and location in Brazil (NY-02928724). On all materials, stromata were produced on sori of sporangia, or on wounded tissues, not associated with discoloration or tissue necrosis of the opposite surface of the frond. Ascigerous columns had a tendency to undergo repeated apical proliferation, a feature that differs from all other known species; ascospores are typically globose or subglobose, yellowish brown, 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m diam (<xref rid="R29" ref-type="bibr">Fitzpatrick 1942</xref>). Based on phylogenetic evidence, the genus resides in the <italic>Coryneliaceae</italic>, within the <italic>Eurotiomycetes</italic>, as recently demonstrated through molecular analysis (<xref rid="R53" ref-type="bibr">Prieto <italic>et al.</italic> 2013</xref>, <xref rid="R32" ref-type="bibr">Garrido-Benavent &amp; P&#xE9;rez-Ortega 2015</xref>, <xref rid="R75" ref-type="bibr">Wood <italic>et al.</italic> 2016</xref>). In the combined ITS-LSU analysis (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F7">Fig. 7</xref>), <italic>C. maxima</italic> clustered in a basal position, suggesting that the fungal species associated with ferns are evolutionarily basal to the evolution of their relatives, as previously demonstrated for the cercosporoid and mycosphaerella-like species occurring on ferns (<xref rid="R34" ref-type="bibr">Guatimosim <italic>et al.</italic> 2016</xref>).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Corynelia uberata</italic> (GenBank KU204606; Identities 474 / 544 (87 %), 21 gaps (3 %)), <italic>Caliciopsis pinea</italic> (GenBank KY099604; Identities 323 / 361 (89 %), 6 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>C. beckhausii</italic> (GenBank NR_132090; Identities 330 / 370 (89 %), 11 gaps (2 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>C. nigra</italic> (GenBank KP144011; Identities 771 / 825 (93 %), 5 gaps (0 %)), <italic>C. pinea</italic> (GenBank DQ678097; Identities 779 / 839 (93 %), 6 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>C. valentina</italic> (GenBank KP144013; Identities 780 / 842 (93 %), 6 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Camarosporidiella mackenziei</italic></bold> Wanas. <italic>et al</italic>., <italic>Stud. Mycol</italic>. <bold>87</bold>: 236. 2017. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F8">Fig. 8</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> separate, pycnidial, globose, 150&#x2013;200 &#x3BC;m diam, with central ostiole; wall of 2&#x2013;3 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis</italic>. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> tightly aggregated, lining the inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical to ampulliform or doliiform, proliferating percurrently at apex, 5&#x2013;8 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, hyaline, smooth, guttulate to granular, subcylindrical to ellipsoid, apex obtusely rounded, base truncate, (3&#x2013;)4&#x2013;5(&#x2013;6) &#xD7; (2&#x2013;)2.5(&#x2013;3) &#x3BC;m. <italic>Ascomata</italic> pseudothecial, intra- to subcorticolous, singly to densely crowded, tufted if fully developed, erumpent, subglobose with flattened base, later somewhat fusing at the base, ostiole central and indistinct, black, finely rough, thick, soft, basally with a few red brown, thick-walled, smooth and gnarled hyphae, 0.5&#x2013;0.75 mm diam. <italic>Peridium</italic> multi-layered, consisting of a <italic>textura angularis</italic> with red brown, thick-walled and smooth cells, inner layer hyaline, cells 10&#x2013;17 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Pseudoparaphyses</italic> numerous, longer than the asci, basally moniliform otherwise cylindrical and filiform, short celled, multi-celled, branched, with a few anastomoses, hyaline, thin-walled, smooth, septa in the upper part smooth and thin-walled, eguttulate, 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m in diam. <italic>Asci</italic> 8-spored, cylindrical, bitunicate, fissitunicate, thick-walled, apically roundish, pedicel short and furcate, inamyloid (water plus Lugol), 131&#x2013;210 &#xD7; 15&#x2013;16 &#x3BC;m, ascospores oblique uniseriate. <italic>Ascospores</italic> 8(&#x2013;10)-celled, muriform, ellipsoid, mostly straight, both parts of the spore approx. equal in size, end cells conical or roundish, wall golden brownish, thick and always smooth, median septum constricted, otherwise smooth to faintly constricted, thick-walled and reddish, one longitudinal septum per cell, end cells aseptate, plasma eguttulate, without a gelatinous sheath and appendages, examined in water, living and mature, 30&#x2013;35(&#x2013;44) &#xD7; 10&#x2013;12.5 &#x3BC;m (av. 31.4 &#xD7; 11.5).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies spreading, with fluffy, moderate to abundant aerial mycelium. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse dark mouse grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimens examined</italic>: <bold>Finland</bold>, Outokumpu, on twig of <italic>Caragana</italic> sp. (<italic>Fabaceae</italic>), 31 Dec. 2014, <italic>M. Pennanen</italic>, specimen CBS H-23430, culture CPC 25960 = CBS 144200; <italic>ibid.</italic>, CPC 25962.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Isolates CPC 25960 and CPC 25962 were treated as &#x201C;<italic>Camarosporium</italic> sp. 2&#x201D; in <xref rid="R9" ref-type="bibr">Crous &amp; Groenewald (2017)</xref>. The species was subsequently placed in the genus <italic>Camarosporidiella</italic> by <xref rid="R72" ref-type="bibr">Wanasinghe <italic>et al.</italic> (2017)</xref>, clustering within the <italic>C. mackenziei</italic> clade. The latter taxon was described from twigs of <italic>Caragana arborescens</italic> collected in Russia. Although the present collection produced only the microconidial morph in culture, the sexual morph was observed on host tissue, which is a new observation for this species.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence of CPC 25960, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>C. mackenziei</italic> (GenBank MF434159; Identities 542 / 543 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>C. melnikii</italic> (GenBank MF434162; Identities 540 / 544 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>C. caraganicola</italic> (GenBank MF434124; Identities 540 / 544 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence of CPC 25960, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>C. aborescentis</italic> (GenBank MF434203; Identities 821 / 822 (99 %), no gaps), &#x201C;<italic>Cf</italic>. <italic>Camarosporium</italic> sp. 4&#x201D; (GenBank KY929167; Identities 821 / 822 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>C. arezzoensis</italic> (GenBank KY929163; Identities 821 / 822 (99 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence of CPC 25960, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>C. mackenziei</italic> (GenBank MF434423; Identities 904 / 907 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>C. italica</italic> (GenBank MF434415; Identities 899 / 907 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>C. arborescentis</italic> (GenBank MF434380; Identities 899 / 907 (99 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Chaetosphaeria myriocarpa</italic></bold> (Fr.) C. Booth, <italic>Mycol. Pap</italic>. <bold>68</bold>: 5. 1957. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F9">Fig. 9</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Sphaeria myriocarpa</italic> Fr., <italic>Kongl. Vetensk. Acad. Hand.</italic>
<bold>267</bold>. 1817.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonym</italic>:<italic> Sphaeria myriocarpa</italic> Fr., <italic>Syst. mycol</italic>. <bold>2</bold>(2): 459. 1823.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of medium brown, verruculose, branched, septate, 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, subcylindrical, flexuous, unbranched, at times rejuvenating percurrently in apical part, 1&#x2013;5-septate, dark brown, thick-walled, roughened in lower region, 35&#x2013;100 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> integrated, terminal, medium brown, smooth, subcylindrical to obovoid, 25&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m; apex with flared collarette, 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> occurring in chains, aggregating in mucoid mass, hyaline, smooth, apex obtuse, abruptly tapering to a truncate base, creating triangular conidia, 2.5&#x2013;3 &#xD7; 2.5 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse to moderate aerial mycelium and feathery, lobate margins, reaching 25 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse iron-grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Ukraine</bold>, Ternopil region, Zalischyky district, Dniester Canyon, on decaying wood of <italic>Carpinus betulus</italic> (<italic>Betulaceae</italic>), 5 Oct. 2016, <italic>A. Akulov</italic>, specimen ex CWU (MYC) AS 6049 (dried culture CBS H-23426, culture CPC 31840 = CBS 143389).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Chaetosphaeria myriocarpa</italic> is commonly isolated from dead woody substrates in Europe, and represents a new record for Ukraine. Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Ch. myriocarpa</italic> (GenBank JF340253; Identities 483 / 490 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Ch. pygmaea</italic> (GenBank AF178545; Identities 473 / 496 (95 %), 3 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Phialophora phaeophora</italic> (GenBank AF083191; Identities 503 / 533 (94 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Ch. myriocarpa</italic> (GenBank AF178552; Identities 841 / 841 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Ch. pygmaea</italic> (GenBank AF178545; Identities 837 / 843 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Ch. preussii</italic> (GenBank AF178561; Identities 816 / 835 (98 %), no gaps). Only distant matches were obtained with the <italic>tub2</italic> sequence, e.g. with <italic>Chaetomium jodhpurense</italic> (GenBank KP336854; Identities 292 / 361 (81 %), 19 gaps (5 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Colletotrichum kniphofiae</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Denman, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824769. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F10">Fig. 10</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Kniphofia</italic>, the host genus from which it was isolated.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Asexual morph</italic> on OA (sterile on other media). <italic>Conidiomata</italic> acervular, conidiophores formed on a cushion of pale brown, angular cells, 6&#x2013;15 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Setae</italic> rarely observed in culture, brown, flexuous, verruculose, tapering to subobtuse apices, 5&#x2013;8-septate, up to 100 &#x3BC;m long. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> hyaline, septate, branched, smooth-walled, up to 60 &#x3BC;m long. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> hyaline, smooth, cylindrical, 12&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;7 &#x3BC;m, phialidic with periclinal thickening. <italic>Conidia</italic> hyaline, smooth-walled, aseptate, straight, rarely curved, prominently multi-guttulate, fusoid to subcylindrical, apex obtuse, tapering at base to truncate hilum, 2 &#x3BC;m diam, (17&#x2013;)25&#x2013;28(&#x2013;37) &#xD7; (5&#x2013;)6(&#x2013;7) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and even, lobate margins, covering dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface dirty white with patches of olivaceous grey, reverse amber with patches of olivaceous grey. On PDA surface and reverse olivaceous grey with patches of smoke grey. On OA surface olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <sc><bold>UK</bold></sc>, England, Upton Grey, on leaves of <italic>Kniphofia uvaria</italic> (<italic>Xanthorrhoeaceae</italic>), 28 Mar. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (holotype CBS H-23432, culture ex-type CPC 30166 = CBS 143496); <italic>ibid</italic>., CPC 30168.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Sexual morph not observed, but ascospores harvested from plant material, indicating that a sexual morph exists. <italic>Colletotrichum kniphofiae</italic> was isolated from dead leaves of <italic>Kniphofia</italic>, and nothing is known regarding its ecology, and no species of <italic>Colletotrichum</italic> have been described from this host. Supported by its distinct DNA phylogeny (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F11">Fig. 11</xref>), we believe this collection represents a distinct species.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence of CPC 30166, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Co. godetiae</italic> (GenBank KX756147; Identities 567 / 575 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Co. pyricola</italic> (GenBank KU963516; Identities 565 / 575 (95 %), 2 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Co. salicis</italic> (GenBank KU498278; Identities 565 / 575 (95 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). The ITS sequences of CPC 30166 and CPC 30168 are identical. The highest similarities using the LSU sequence of CPC 30166 were <italic>Co. godetiae</italic> (GenBank KU973721; Identities 837 / 839 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Co. acutatum</italic> (GenBank JN939926; Identities 837 / 839 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Co. fioriniae</italic> (GenBank JN939914; Identities 837 / 839 (99 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>actA</italic> sequence were <italic>Co. destructivum</italic> (GenBank AY157843; Identities 596 / 657 (91 %), 16 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Co. kahawae</italic> (GenBank KU579251; Identities 595 / 659 (90 %), 26 gaps (3 %)) and <italic>Co. orbiculare</italic> (GenBank AB778553; Identities 584 / 654 (89 %), 22 gaps (3 %)). The highest similarities using the <italic>chs1</italic> sequence were <italic>Co. salicis</italic> (GenBank JQ949131; Identities 245 / 252 (97 %), no gaps), <italic>Co. godetiae</italic> (GenBank KY171916; Identities 244 / 252 (97 %), no gaps) and <italic>Co. rhombiforme</italic> (GenBank JQ949118; Identities 243 / 252 (97 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>gapdh</italic> sequence were <italic>Co. pyricola</italic> (GenBank KU221341; Identities 560 / 604 (93 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Co. nymphaeae</italic> (GenBank KP339289; Identities 556 / 602 (92 %), 2 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Co. fioriniae</italic> (GenBank KF944354; Identities 542 / 589 (92 %), 9 gaps (1 %)). The highest similarities using the <italic>tub2</italic> sequence were with <italic>Co. phormii</italic> (GenBank KX069820.1; Identities 386 / 413 (93 %), 7 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Co. australe</italic> (GenBank JQ950106.1; Identities 385 / 413 (93 %), 7 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>Co. scovillei</italic> (GenBank KY475561.1; Identities 384 / 414 (93 %), 8 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Cyclothyriella rubronotata</italic></bold> (Berk. &amp; Broome) Jaklitsch &amp; Voglmayr, <italic>Stud. Mycol</italic>. <bold>85</bold>: 41. 2016. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F12">Fig. 12</xref>. <italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Melogramma rubronotatum</italic> Berk. &amp; Broome, <italic>Ann. Mag. nat. Hist. Ser.</italic> 3, <bold>3</bold>: 375. 1859.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> erumpent, globose, 200&#x2013;250 &#x3BC;m diam, with central ostiole; wall of 3&#x2013;6 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Conidiophores</italic> lining the inner cavity, reduced to conidiogenous cells or with a single supporting cell. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical to ampulliform, 6&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m; apex with prominent periclinal thickening, rarely with percurrent proliferation. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, brown, smooth, thin-walled, guttulate, subcylindrical, mostly straight, apex obtuse, base truncate, (4.5&#x2013;)5(&#x2013;6) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies spreading, flat on OA, erumpent on MEA and PDA, with moderate aerial mycelium and feathery margins, reaching 35 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface dirty white, reverse apricot, on OA surface pale violet, on PDA surface coral with flesh in outer region, reverse sienna with patches of umber.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, on twig of <italic>Ailanthus altissima</italic> (<italic>Simaroubaceae</italic>), 4 Jun. 2015, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic> (specimen CBS H-23423, culture CPC 27604 = CBS 144201).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The genus <italic>Cyclothyriella</italic> was recently introduced by <xref rid="R39" ref-type="bibr">Jaklitsch &amp; Voglmayr (2016)</xref>, who also treated the taxonomic history of this genus in detail. The asexual morph isolated in this study closely resembles that described and illustrated by <xref rid="R39" ref-type="bibr">Jaklitsch &amp; Voglmayr (2016)</xref>, who reported conidia as (2&#x2013;)4.5&#x2013;6(&#x2013;6.5) &#xD7; (2&#x2013;) 2.7&#x2013;3.5(&#x2013;4) &#x3BC;m, &#x4FF;rst hyaline, becoming medium brown with age. This fungus is common in Europe, and here we present a culture from Germany to supplement the Austrian material studied by <xref rid="R39" ref-type="bibr">Jaklitsch &amp; Voglmayr (2016)</xref>.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Cyclothyriella rubronotata</italic> (GenBank NR_147651; Identities 564 / 564 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Melanomma pulvis-pyrius</italic> (GenBank KY189979; Identities 400 / 476 (84 %), 20 gaps (4 %)) and <italic>Ascochyta medicaginicola</italic> (GenBank KX381183; Identities 359 / 419 (86 %), 10 gaps (2 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Cy. rubronotata</italic> (GenBank KX650541; Identities 833 / 833 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Thyridaria rubronotata</italic> (GenBank JX681121; Identities 833 / 833 (100 %), no gaps) and <italic>Neooccultibambusa jonesii</italic> (GenBank KY111437; Identities 781 / 812 (96 %), 2 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Cylindriaceae</italic></bold> Crous &amp; L. Lombard, <bold><italic>fam. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824770.<italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of hyaline, smooth, septate, branched, hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> aggregated in sporodochia, or solitary, erect; hyphae and basal part of conidiophores becoming pale brown, smooth, subcylindrical, erect, septate, branched. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal and intercalary, subcylindrical, hyaline, smooth, with several sympodial flat-tipped loci, unthickened, not darkened. <italic>Ramoconidia</italic> hyaline, smooth, guttulate, subcylindrical. <italic>Conidia</italic> aseptate, hyaline, smooth, arranged in long, branched chains, scars unthickened, slightly refractive.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type genus: Cylindrium</italic> Bonord.<italic>Note</italic>: The genus <italic>Cylindrium</italic>, based on <italic>C. elongatum</italic>, was regarded by <xref rid="R47" ref-type="bibr">Lombard <italic>et al</italic>. (2015)</xref> as <italic>incertae sedis</italic>, and thus <italic>Cylindriaceae</italic> is herewith introduced to accommodate this genus.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Cylindrium algarvense</italic></bold> (Cheew. &amp; Crous) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824771.<italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Polyscytalum algarvense</italic> Cheew. &amp; Crous, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>23</bold>: 73. 2009.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R5" ref-type="bibr">Cheewangkoon <italic>et al</italic>. (2009)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Portugal</bold>, Faro, Algarve, on <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> sp.         <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Note</italic>: See discussion under <italic>Polyscytalum</italic> and <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F13">Fig. 13</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Cylindrium purgamentum</italic></bold> (Crous) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824772.<italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Polyscytalum purgamentum</italic> Crous, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>37</bold>: 363. 2016.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R15" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. (2016a)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>USA</bold>, Texas, Austin, on leaf litter, Aug. 2013, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (holotype CBS H-22899, culture ex-type CPC 29580 = CBS 142114).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Note</italic>: See discussion under <italic>Polyscytalum</italic> and <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F13">Fig. 13</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Cylindrium syzygii</italic></bold> (Crous &amp; R.G. Shivas) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824773.<italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Pseudoidriella syzygii</italic> Crous &amp; R.G. Shivas, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>27</bold>: 135. 2011.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R12" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. (2011)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, Queensland, Mackay, Eungella National Park, on leaves of <italic>Syzygium</italic> sp. (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), 14 Jul. 2009, <italic>P.W. Crous &amp; K.L. Crous</italic>, (holotype CBS H-20758, cultures ex-type CPC 17233 = CBS 131307).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Note</italic>: See discussion under <italic>Polyscytalum</italic> and <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F13">Fig. 13</xref>. By placing <italic>Pseudoidriella syzygii</italic> in<italic> Cylindrium,</italic> the genus <italic>Pseudoidriella</italic> is also reduced to synonymy with <italic>Cylindrium</italic>. This suggests that the conidiomata of <italic>Cylindrium</italic> could be reduced to solitary conidiophores, as well as sporodochia, as observed in this species. Interestingly enough, an LSU sequence attributed to <italic>Tristratiperidium microsporum</italic> also clustered in this clade (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F3">Fig. 3</xref>), which completely disagrees with the morphology of this fungus. This suggests that this sequence (MFLUCC) should be reconsidered. The ITS sequence from the same culture placed <italic>Tristratiperidium microsporum</italic> with<italic> Kirstenboschia diospyri</italic> (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F13">Fig. 13</xref>).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Cytospora viticola</italic></bold> D.P. Lawr. <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Pl. Pathol.</italic>
<bold>66</bold>: 718. 2017. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F14">Fig. 14</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> (on PDA) with stromata up to 500 &#x3BC;m diam, rosette cytosporoid, subdivided by invaginations, up to four radially arranged. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> hyaline, smooth, branched, 1&#x2013;3-septate, 15&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m, immersed in a mucilaginous layer. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> phialidic with periclinal thickening and apical taper, 10&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 1.5&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> hyaline, smooth, guttulate, allantoid, aseptate, (5&#x2013;)6&#x2013;7(&#x2013;7.5) &#xD7; 1(&#x2013;1.5) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, covering dish after 1 mo at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface isabelline, reverse brown vinaceous. On PDA surface and reverse. On OA surface sepia.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Hungary</bold>, P&#xE9;cs wine region, on stems of <italic>Vitis vinifera</italic> (<italic>Vitaceae</italic>), 5 Nov. 2014, <italic>K.Z. V&#xE1;czy</italic> (specimen CBS H-23278, culture T15 / 464 = CPC 30117 = CBS 143162).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Species of <italic>Cytospora</italic> are commonly known from woody plants and generally have wide host ranges. Two <italic>Cytospora</italic> species, <italic>C. vinacea</italic> and <italic>C. viticola,</italic> causing dieback and cankers of grapevines in the USA were recently described (<xref rid="R42" ref-type="bibr">Lawrence <italic>et al</italic>. 2017</xref>). Other species known from <italic>Vitis</italic> include <italic>C. ceratosperma</italic> (CBS 397.36), as well as the European taxa <italic>C. vitis</italic> and <italic>Valsa vitis</italic>, which are insufficiently known, and for which we could not trace type material. The isolate described here was associated with cankers on grapevines in Hungary, and is similar to <italic>C. viticola</italic>.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Cy. sibiraeae</italic> (GenBank KR045651; Identities 566 / 591 (96 %), 8 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Cy. chrysosperma</italic> (GenBank KT692596; Identities 568 / 594 (96 %), 7 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>Cy. germanica</italic> (GenBank KX168596; Identities 563 / 590 (95 %), 7 gaps (1 %)). Our ITS sequence is identical to <italic>Cy. viticola</italic> (GenBank KX256239; Identities 423 / 423 (100 %), no gaps), but was not a result in the megablast search as roughly half of the first internal spacer region sequence is missing for the deposited sequences of that species. The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Valsa mali</italic> (GenBank AF362559; Identities 837 / 842 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Cy. centrivillosa</italic> (GenBank MF190068; Identities 830 / 837 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>Cy. ambiens</italic> (GenBank EU255208; Identities 772 / 779 (99 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>actA</italic> sequence were <italic>Cy. salicicola</italic> (GenBank KU982637; Identities 163 / 180 (91 %), 6 gaps (3 %)), <italic>Cy. parasitica</italic> (GenBank KT459410; Identities 190 / 212 (90 %), 10 gaps (4 %)) and <italic>Cy. cincta</italic> (GenBank KU710994; Identities 223 / 250 (89 %), 13 gaps (5 %)). The highest similarities using the <italic>rpb2</italic> sequence were<italic> Cy. berberidis</italic> (GenBank KU710948; Identities 658 / 727 (91 %), no gaps), <italic>Cy. schulzeri</italic> (GenBank KU710980; Identities 656 / 727 (90 %), no gaps) and <italic>Cy. rostrata</italic> (GenBank KU710974; Identities 656 / 727 (90 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence were <italic>Cy. viticola</italic> (GenBank KX256274; Identities 253 / 253 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Cy. mali</italic> (GenBank KU710928; Identities 359 / 422 (85 %), 24 gaps (5 %)) and <italic>Cy. sophorae</italic> (GenBank KU710941; Identities 422 / 517 (82 %), 26 gaps (5 %)). The highest similarities using the <italic>tub2</italic> sequence were <italic>V. malicola</italic> (GenBank KT934374; Identities 363 / 413 (88 %), 18 gaps (4 %)), <italic>V. sordida</italic> (GenBank KT428034; Identities 346 / 396 (87 %), 14 gaps (3 %)) and <italic>Cy. carbonacea</italic> (GenBank KP310825; Identities 343 / 395 (87 %), 16 gaps (4 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Dictyochaeta mimusopis</italic></bold> Crous &amp; M.J. Wingf., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824774. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F15">Fig. 15</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Mimusops,</italic> the host genus from which this fungus was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of branched, septate, hyaline, 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, pale brown, smooth, subcylindrical, unbranched, straight to flexuous, 1&#x2013;6-septate, 40&#x2013;150 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> monophialidic, integrated, terminal, pale brown, smooth, subcylindrical, 30&#x2013;55 &#xD7; 3(&#x2013;3.5) &#x3BC;m; with flared apical collarette, 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, hyaline, smooth, guttulate to granular, inequilateral, fusoid, outer plane convex, apex subacute, base truncate, 1&#x2013;1.5 &#x3BC;m diam, (11&#x2013;)16&#x2013;18(&#x2013;20) &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3(&#x2013;3.5) &#x3BC;m, with a single unbranched, flexuous appendage at each end, (6&#x2013;)7(&#x2013;8) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, reaching 50 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface hazel with cinnamon pigment, reverse sepia. On PDA surface cinnamon, reverse amber. On OA surface sienna with patches of olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>South Africa</bold>, Eastern Cape Province, Haga Haga, on leaves of <italic>Mimusops caffra</italic> (<italic>Sapotaceae</italic>), Dec. 2010, <italic>M.J. Wingfield</italic> (holotype CBS H-23412, culture ex-type CPC 29987 = CBS 143435).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Dictyochaeta mimusopis</italic> is closely allied to isolates in the <italic>Di. simplex</italic> complex (conidia 14&#x2013;19 &#xD7; 2.1&#x2013;2.7 &#x3BC;m; <xref rid="R38" ref-type="bibr">Hughes &amp; Kendrick 1968</xref>).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Di. simplex</italic> (GenBank EF029193; Identities 482 / 503 (96 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Di. fertilis</italic> (GenBank AF178540; Identities 469 / 491 (96 %), 5 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>Codinaea pini</italic> (GenBank NR_137943; Identities 485 / 521 (93 %), 22 gaps (4 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Di. simplex</italic> (GenBank AF178559; Identities 830 / 836 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Codinaea pini</italic> (GenBank KP004493; Identities 829 / 838 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>Rattania setulifera</italic> (GenBank HM171322; Identities 815 / 835 (98 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Dictyochaeta septata</italic></bold> (B. Sutton &amp; Hodges) Whitton <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Fungal Diversity</italic>
<bold>4</bold>: 148. 2000. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F16">Fig. 16</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Codinaea septata</italic> B. Sutton &amp; Hodges, <italic>Nova Hedwigia</italic>
<bold>26</bold>(2&#x2013;3): 520. 1975.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Synonym</italic>: <italic>Dictyochaeta septata</italic> (B. Sutton &amp; Hodges) Aramb. &amp; Cabello, <italic>Mycotaxon</italic>
<bold>34</bold>(2): 682 (1989) (nom. inval. Art 41.5, Melbourne).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of hyaline, septate, branched, smooth, 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, brown, smooth, subcylindrical, straight to flexuous, 1&#x2013;3-septate, 30&#x2013;120 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;6 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, integrated, pale brown, smooth, mono-, rarely polyphialidic, 10&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m; collarette flared, 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, hyaline, smooth, guttulate, granular, subcylindrical, falcate, ends subobtuse, (14&#x2013;)15&#x2013;19(&#x2013;20) &#xD7; 2.5(&#x2013;3) &#x3BC;m, medianly 1-septate, with a single unbranched, flexuous appendage at each end, 5&#x2013;7 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, reaching 45 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface hazel with cinnamon pigment, reverse sepia. On PDA surface cinnamon, reverse amber. On OA surface sienna with patches of olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimens examined</italic>: <bold>Brazil</bold>, Espirito Santo, Vania, on <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> sp. (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), 11 Dec. 1973, <italic>C.S. Hodges</italic> (holotype K(M) IMI 181532f). <bold>Chile</bold>, on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus grandis</italic> &#xD7; <italic>urophylla</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), Jun. 2010, <italic>M.J. Wingfield</italic> (epitype of <italic>Codinaea septata</italic> designated here CBS H-23427, MBT381137, culture ex-epitype CPC 31949 = CBS 143386).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: This collection closely resembles <italic>Codinaea septata</italic>, described from <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> leaves in Brazil with its conidia being 1(&#x2013;2)-septate, (14.5&#x2013;)17.5&#x2013;23 &#xD7; 2 &#x3BC;m, and conidiophores 30&#x2013;105 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;6 &#x3BC;m (<xref rid="R63" ref-type="bibr">Sutton &amp; Hodges 1975</xref>). Although we have in recent papers treated the genera <italic>Codinaea</italic> (setulate conidia) as distinct from <italic>Dictyochaeta</italic> (asetulate conidia) (<xref rid="R18" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2015b</xref>), it appears that they could very well represent a single genus, with preference given to the older name, <italic>Dictyochaeta</italic>.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Pseudolachnella guaviyunis</italic> (GenBank KJ834524; Identities 480 / 542 (89 %), 13 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Di. simplex</italic> (GenBank EF029193; Identities 462 / 519 (89 %), 9 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>Thozetella fabacearum</italic> (GenBank KY212754; Identities 478 / 544 (88 %), 27 gaps (4 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>T. pinicola</italic> (GenBank EU825195; Identities 810 / 837 (97 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>T. nivea</italic> (GenBank EU825200; Identities 807 / 837 (96 %), 2 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>P. fraxini</italic> (GenBank JQ889301; Identities 806 / 836 (96 %), 1 gap (0 %)). No close hits were obtained when the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence was used in a megablast search.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Echinocatena arthrinioides</italic></bold> R. Campb. &amp; B. Sutton, <italic>Trans. Brit. Mycol. Soc</italic>. <bold>69</bold>: 130. 1977. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F17">Fig. 17</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of branched, septate, pale brown, smooth, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> erect, solitary, 20&#x2013;50 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m, unbranched, straight to flexuous, pale brown, smooth, 3&#x2013;7-septate. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> in simple or branched acropetal chains, 5&#x2013;7 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m, separated by thick, dark brown, refractive septa, appearing like a separating cell, pale brown, echinulate, doliiform to cylindrical, constricted at septa, polyblastic, integrated with 5&#x2013;7 conidiogenous loci. <italic>Conidia</italic> (4&#x2013;)5&#x2013;6(&#x2013;7) &#x3BC;m diam, solitary, spherical, orange-brown, thick-walled, aseptate, echinulate.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Malaysia</bold>, on leaves of <italic>Acacia crassicarpa</italic> (<italic>Fabaceae</italic>), 1 Jul. 2015, <italic>M.J. Wingfield</italic> (specimen CBS H-23424, culture CPC 28754 = CBS 144202).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Echinocatena arthrinioides</italic> was originally described from leaf litter collected in India. This collection has conidia that are slightly larger those observed for the type collection (3.5&#x2013;4.5 &#x3BC;m; <xref rid="R4" ref-type="bibr">Campbell &amp; Sutton 1977</xref>), and DNA data would be required to fully resolve if this strain is conspecific with the type (IMI 199279).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were &#x201C;<italic>Fusicladium</italic> sp.&#x201D; from marine sponges in Panama (GenBank JN837045; Identities 524 / 530 (99 %), no gaps) and &#x201C;<italic>Sympoventuriaceae</italic> sp.&#x201D; from a human nail in Hong Kong (GenBank LC158598; Identities 448 / 452 (99 %), no gaps); the remaining matches were with the 5.8S nrRNA genes of <italic>Fusicladium</italic> species. The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Mycosisymbrium cirrhosum</italic> (GenBank KR259884; Identities 758 / 828 (92 %), 9 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Scolecobasidium cateniphorum</italic> (GenBank EU107309; Identities 758 / 829 (91 %), 11 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>Verruconis verruculosa</italic> (GenBank KF282668; Identities 757 / 829 (91 %), 11 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Elsino&#xEB; mimosae</italic></bold> Vi&#xE9;gas, <italic>Bragantia</italic>
<bold>4</bold>: 13. 1944.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R27" ref-type="bibr">Fan <italic>et al</italic>. (2017)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimens examined</italic>: <bold>Brazil</bold>, S&#xE3;o Paulo, Campinas, on <italic>Mimosa</italic> sp.
