Zagatto</italic> (holotype IAC No. 2836); <bold>Brazil</bold>, Rio de Janeiro, Itagua&#xED;, Mazomba, on <italic>Mimosa diplotricha</italic> (= <italic>Mimosa invisa</italic>), Mar. 1999, <italic>R.W. Barreto</italic> (epitype designated here MBT381423, preserved in metabolically inactive state, ex-epitype culture CBS 141878) = CPC 19478 = RWB 154. <bold>Ecuador</bold>, Coca, on <italic>Mimosa diplotricha</italic>, Nov. 2000, <italic>R.W. Barreto</italic>, specimen CBS H-22804, culture CPC 18518 = RWB 224 = CBS 141943.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The epitype was designated in <xref rid="R27" ref-type="bibr">Fan <italic>et al</italic>. (2017)</xref>, but that epitypification was not effected since the holotype was not &#x201C;explicitly&#x201D; cited (Art 9.8, Melbourne Code). We correct this situation by citing the holotype as &#x201C;IAC No. 2836&#x201D;.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Exophiala eucalypticola</italic></bold> Crous &amp; T.I. Burgess, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824775. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F18">Fig. 18</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Eucalyptus,</italic> the host genus from which it was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of pale brown, smooth, septate, branched, 2&#x2013;2.5 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> arising as lateral ends of hyphae, or reduced to conidiogenous cells, integrated on hyphae, erect, medium brown, smooth, subcylindrical, 3&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m; scars thickened and darkened, 1 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> occurring in branched chains, pale brown, smooth, 0&#x2013;1-septate, fusoid-ellipsoidal, with hila that are thickened and darkened, 1 &#x3BC;m diam, (7&#x2013;)10&#x2013;13(&#x2013;15) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3(&#x2013;4) &#x3BC;m. Synasexual morph: <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> integrated as phialidic loci on creeping hyphae, 1&#x2013;2 &#xD7; 1 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> dimorphic, with exophiala-like conidia pale brown, smooth, aseptate, ellipsoid, 4&#x2013;7 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse to moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, reaching 10 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface slimy, chestnut to black.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>:<bold><sc>A</sc>ustralia</bold>, Victoria, Melbourne, Dandenong Ranges, Silvan Reservoir Park, leaf litter of <italic>Eucalyptus obliqua</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), 1 Dec. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (holotype CBS H-23305, cultures ex-type CPC 32736 = CBS 143412).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The genera <italic>Exophiala</italic> and <italic>Rhinocladiella</italic> contain several clinically relevant species (<xref rid="R25" ref-type="bibr">de Hoog 1977</xref>). Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>R. aquaspersa</italic> (GenBank AB091214; Identities 458 / 519 (88 %), 18 gaps (3 %)), <italic>E. phaeomuriformis</italic> (GenBank KP761151; Identities 485 / 555 (87 %), 27 gaps (4 %)) and <italic>R. coryli</italic> (GenBank KX306768; Identities 518 / 594 (87 %), 25 gaps (4 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>E. xenobiotica</italic> (GenBank KC311483; Identities 831 / 862 (96 %), 7 gaps (0 %)), <italic>E. xenobiotica</italic> (GenBank FJ358246; Identities 826 / 857 (96 %), 7 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Melanoctona tectonae</italic> (GenBank KX258779; Identities 828 / 860 (96 %), 6 gaps (0 %)). The present collection is best allocated to this generic complex, and until better resolved it is best placed in <italic>Exophiala</italic>. No significant hits were obtained when the <italic>tef1</italic> and <italic>tub2</italic> sequences were used in a megablast search.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Fusiconidium lycopodiellae</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824776. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F19">Fig. 19</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Lycopodiella,</italic> the host genus from which this fungus was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of hyaline, smooth, branched, septate, 2.5&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae. <italic>Hyphopodia</italic> absent. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, subcylindrical, geniculate-sinuous, brown, smooth, 1&#x2013;2-septate, 20&#x2013;50 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, subcylindrical, brown, smooth, 10&#x2013;17 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m, proliferating sympodially, holoblastically; scars unthickened, undarkened, 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, brown, smooth, granular, subcylindrical, apex obtuse, tapering in lower cell to truncate hilum, 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m diam, (7&#x2013;)8&#x2013;9(&#x2013;11)-septate, (65&#x2013;)75&#x2013;85(&#x2013;100) &#xD7; (7&#x2013;)8(&#x2013;9) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, covering dish after 1 mo at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface ochreous, reverse amber. On PDA surface and reverse amber. On OA surface luteous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, on stems of <italic>Lycopodiella inundata</italic> (<italic>Lycopodiaceae</italic>), 25 Feb. 2016, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic> (holotype CBS H-23407, culture ex-type CPC 30371 = CBS 143437).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The present collection is reminiscent of <italic>Clasterosporium</italic>, except that it lacks hyphopodia (<xref rid="R26" ref-type="bibr">Ellis 1971</xref>). Based on LSU sequence data it is allied to <italic>Fusiconidium</italic> (<xref rid="R44" ref-type="bibr">Li <italic>et al</italic>. 2017</xref>), except that it lacks percurrent proliferation of the conidiogenous cells, and fusoid to ellipsoid conidia, and probably represents a new genus in this complex. However, due to the poor sporulation of the culture, we have tentatively named it in <italic>Fusiconidium</italic>.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Camposporium cambrense</italic> (GenBank KY853428; Identities 481 / 502 (96 %), 3 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Phragmocephala atra</italic> (GenBank KP698721; Identities 495 / 523 (95 %), 4 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Phragmocephala garethjonesii</italic> (GenBank NR_147636; Identities 493 / 523 (94 %), 3 gaps (0 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Fusiconidium mackenziei</italic> (GenBank KX611113; Identities 806 / 815 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Paradendryphiella salina</italic> (GenBank KF156156; Identities 780 / 791 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Aposphaeria corallinolutea</italic> (GenBank KU243051; Identities 804 / 817 (98 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Haplographium delicatum</italic></bold> Berk. &amp; Broome, <italic>Ann. Mag. Nat. Hist., Ser</italic>. 3,<bold> 3</bold>(17): 361. 1859. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F20">Fig. 20</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiophores</italic> erect, subcylindrical, straight to flexuous, brown, thick-walled, verruculose, base with T-cell, lacking rhizoids, 70&#x2013;160 &#xD7; 5&#x2013;6 &#x3BC;m, 5&#x2013;10-septate. Conidiophores with swollen apical cell, pale brown, giving rise to 3&#x2013;6 apical conidiogenous cells or primary branches; primary branches subcylindrical, straight to allantoid, hyaline, smooth, 5&#x2013;10 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical, straight to slightly curved, 6&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;2.5 &#x3BC;m, proliferating sympodially at apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> aggregating in mucoid mass, hyaline, smooth, guttulate, subcylindrical, straight, apex slightly swollen, obtuse, base truncate, (3&#x2013;)5&#x2013;6(&#x2013;7.5) &#xD7; 2(&#x2013;2.5) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, reaching 13 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface and reverse pale luteous. On PDA surface pale olivaceous grey, reverse ochreous. On OA surface umber, with diffuse sienna pigment.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Ukraine</bold>, Ternopil region, Zalischyky district, Dniester Canyon, on decaying wood of <italic>Carpinus betulus</italic> (<italic>Betulaceae</italic>), 5 Oct. 2016, <italic>A. Akulov</italic>, specimen ex CWU (MYC) AS 6049 (dried culture CBS H-23417, culture CPC 31844 = CBS 143493).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The genus <italic>Haplographium</italic> is based on <italic>H. delicatum</italic> described from wood collected in Britain. The present collection is phylogenetically similar to strains identified as <italic>H. catenatum</italic> and <italic>H. delicatum</italic> (<xref rid="R7" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 2009a</xref>). Because the genus <italic>Haplographium</italic> lacks a type and the species concepts are still in flux, we have identified the present collection as <italic>H</italic>. <italic>delicatum.</italic> Species of <italic>Haplographium</italic> have been linked to <italic>Dematioscypha</italic> sexual morphs (<xref rid="R55" ref-type="bibr">Raitviir 2001</xref>), but this relationship also requires further study.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>H. catenatum</italic> (GenBank FJ839620; Identities 528 / 533 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>H. delicatum</italic> (GenBank HF677177; Identities 495 / 500 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>Ciliciopodium brevipes</italic> (GenBank KM231856; Identities 401 / 451 (89 %), 10 gaps (2 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>H. catenatum</italic> (GenBank FJ839657; Identities 855 / 855 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Hyaloscypha minuta</italic> (GenBank KY769526; Identities 832 / 857 (97 %), 3 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Hy. monodictys</italic> (GenBank JN086756; Identities 808 / 833 (97 %), 3 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Microdochium musae</italic></bold> (T.Y. Lin &amp; J.M. Yen) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824777. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F21">Fig. 21</xref>.<italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Sphaerulina musae</italic> T.Y. Lin &amp; J.M. Yen, <italic>Rev. Mycol</italic>. (Paris) <bold>35</bold>: 326. 1971.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Ascomata</italic> (on OA) solitary, immersed on leaf tissue (superficial to immersed on banana leaf agar), globose, semi-papillate with central ostiole, pale brown, 200&#x2013;250 &#x3BC;m diam; wall of 6&#x2013;8 layers of pale brown <italic>textura angularis. Paraphyses</italic> intermingled among asci, hyaline smooth, septate, unbranched, constricted at septa, hyphae-like, 4&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m diam, with obtuse ends. <italic>Asci</italic> fasciculate, hyaline, unitunicate, apical mechanism staining blue in Meltzer&#x2019;s, broadly ellipsoid, straight to curved, 8-spored, stipitate, 80&#x2013;100 &#xD7; 17&#x2013;22 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Ascospores</italic> bi- to triseriate, hyaline to faintly pinkish, smooth, guttulate, obovoid, apex obtuse, tapering from middle to base, straight to curved, 3&#x2013;6-septate, at times with mucoid sheath, frequently constricted at median septum, (30&#x2013;) 32&#x2013;33(&#x2013;35) &#xD7; (6&#x2013;)7(&#x2013;8) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium, radially folded, and even margins, reaching 40 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface and reverse saffron. On PDA surface and reverse salmon. On OA surface salmon.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimens examined.</italic>
<bold>Republic of China</bold> (Taiwan), on leaves of <italic>Musa</italic> sp. (<italic>Musaceae</italic>), 1970, <italic>T. Wang</italic>, holotype missing, lectotype designated here, MBT381229 (<xref rid="R45" ref-type="bibr">Lin &amp; Yen 1971</xref>, fig. 2 D&#x2013;F). <bold>Malaysia</bold>, Sabah, on leaves of <italic>Musa</italic> sp., 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (epitype designated here, CBS H-23431, MBT381140, culture ex-epitype CPC 32689 = CBS 143500).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Additional cultures examined</italic>: <bold>Costa Rica</bold>, on <italic>Musa</italic> cv. Cavendish, May 2002, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (CBS 111018 = CPC 5380). <bold>Malaysia</bold>, on <italic>Musa</italic> leaves, 2010, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (CPC 32681), <italic>ibid.</italic> (CPC 32809). <bold>Mauritius</bold>, on <italic>Musa</italic> leaves, Jan. 2004, <italic>Y. Jaufeerally-Fakim</italic> (CPC 11234), <italic>ibid.</italic> (CPC 11240). <bold>Mexico</bold>, Chiapas, on <italic>Musa</italic> leaves, 16 Dec. 2008, <italic>M. de J. Yanez Morales</italic> (CPC 16258).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The genus <italic>Sphaerulina</italic> was treated by <xref rid="R54" ref-type="bibr">Quaedvlieg <italic>et al.</italic> (2013)</xref>, and represents a genus in the <italic>Mycosphaerellaceae</italic>, to which <italic>S. musae</italic> (<xref rid="R45" ref-type="bibr">Lin &amp; Yen 1971</xref>) is not related. &#x201C;<italic>Sphaerulina&#x201D; musae</italic> clusters among species of <italic>Microdochium</italic>, which have sexual morphs that are morphologically similar (<xref rid="R37" ref-type="bibr">Hern&#xE1;ndez-Restrepo <italic>et al.</italic> 2016</xref>), justifying this new combination.</p>
        <p><italic>Microdochium musae</italic> is commonly associated with brown necrotic areas on banana leaves, appears to be globally distributed along with its host, and is assumed to be weakly pathogenic (unpubl. data). Because the holotype could not be traced in Taiwan or Paris, the original illustration is proposed as lectotype and a neotype is designated. Colonies initially have a yeast-like appearance in culture, and single ascospores give rise to the sexual morph, suggesting that the species is homothallic.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence of CPC 32689, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Sphaerulina musae</italic> (GenBank AY293061; Identities 477 / 477 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Mi. stoveri</italic> (GenBank FJ430601; Identities 537 / 540 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Mi. colombiense</italic> (GenBank KP858999; Identities 499 / 516 (97 %), 3 gaps (0 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence of CPC 32689, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Mi. colombiense</italic> (GenBank KP858935; Identities 834 / 842 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Mi. citrinidiscum</italic> (GenBank KP858939; Identities 831 / 842 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Mi. sorghi</italic> (GenBank KP858936; Identities 831 / 842 (99 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>actA</italic> sequence of CPC 16258 were <italic>Chaetopsina fulva</italic> (GenBank KM231165; Identities 404 / 422 (96 %), no gaps), <italic>Fusarium phaseoli</italic> (GenBank KM231203; Identities 400 / 419 (95 %), no gaps) and <italic>Ch. acutispora</italic> (GenBank KM231164; Identities 401 / 421 (95 %), no gaps). The <italic>actA</italic> sequences of CPC 11234, 11240, 16258, 32681 and 32809 are identical, but differ with two nucleotides from CPC 32689. No significant hits were obtained when the <italic>cmdA</italic> sequences were used in a megablast search. The <italic>cmdA</italic> sequences of CPC 11234, 11240, 16258, 32689 and 32809 are identical, but differ one nucleotide from CPC 32681. The highest similarities using the <italic>rpb2</italic> sequence of CPC 32689 were <italic>Mi. colombiense</italic> (GenBank KP859108; Identities 740 / 782 (95 %), no gaps), <italic>Mi. majus</italic> (GenBank KP859110; Identities 675 / 780 (87 %), 4 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>M. nivale</italic> (GenBank KP859117; Identities 679 / 785 (86 %), 6 gaps (0 %)). No significant hits were obtained when the <italic>tef1</italic> and <italic>tub2</italic> sequences of CPC 32681 were used in a megablast search. The <italic>tef1</italic> sequences of CPC 11234, 11240, 16258 and 32689 are identical. The <italic>tub2</italic> sequences of CPC 11234, 11240, 32689 and 32809 are identical, but differ one nucleotide from CPC 16258.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Monochaetia junipericola</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824778. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F22">Fig. 22</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Juniperus,</italic> the host genus from which this fungus was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidioid, separate to gregarious, erumpent, ovoid, 150&#x2013;250 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> arising from central stroma, hyaline, smooth, 3&#x2013;6-septate, branched, subcylindrical, 40&#x2013;100 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal and intercalary, hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical, 10&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m, proliferating percurrently at apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> fusoid-ellipsoid, 4-septate, not constricted at septa, medium brown, finely verruculose, end cells hyaline, (22&#x2013;)25&#x2013;27(&#x2013;28) &#xD7; (5&#x2013;)6(&#x2013;7) &#x3BC;m, apical cell terminating in a single, unbranched, filiform, flexuous appendage, 10&#x2013;20 &#x3BC;m long; basal cell with single, unbranched, flexuous, excentric appendage, 2&#x2013;15 &#x3BC;m long. <italic>Conidiomata</italic> with <italic>beta conidia</italic> developing on OA, beta conidia hyaline, smooth, filiform, curved, apex obtuse, base truncate, 12&#x2013;22 &#xD7; 1.5&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and feathery, lobate margins, reaching 40 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface pale luteous, reverse luteous. On PDA surface smoke grey with patches of isabelline, reverse pale luteous. On OA surface pale luteous with patches of amber.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, on twig of <italic>Juniperus communis</italic> (<italic>Cypressaceae</italic>), 20 Apr. 2016, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic> (holotype CBS H-23408, culture ex-type CPC 30561 = CBS 143391).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <xref rid="R52" ref-type="bibr">Nag Raj (1993)</xref> defined the genus <italic>Monochaetia</italic> to accommodate taxa with acervular conidiomata and fusiform, brown, transversely septate conidia with a single cellular apical, and single cellular basal appendage (when present). <xref rid="R52" ref-type="bibr">Nag Raj (1993)</xref> also regarded <italic>Mo. juniperi</italic> as synonym of <italic>Sarcostroma foliicola</italic>, occurring on needles of <italic>Juniperus communis</italic>. Morphologically <italic>S. foliicola</italic> has fusiform, 5-septate conidia, 18&#x2013;22.5 &#xD7; 7&#x2013;8(&#x2013;9) &#x3BC;m, apical appendage 3&#x2013;8(&#x2013;9) &#x3BC;m, and basal appendage excentric, 3&#x2013;11 &#x3BC;m, thus smaller than those of <italic>M. junipericola</italic>. Phylogenetically, <italic>M. junipericola</italic> is basal to the other <italic>Monochaetia</italic> species known from ITS sequences (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F23">Fig. 23</xref>).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Mo. ilexae</italic> (GenBank NR_148179; Identities 497 / 516 (96 %), 7 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Mo. dimorphospora</italic> (GenBank LC146750; Identities 498 / 527 (94 %), 20 gaps (3 %)) and <italic>Synnemadiella eucalypti</italic> (GenBank KY173467; Identities 497 / 538 (92 %), 10 gaps (1 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Mo. ilexae</italic> (GenBank KX984152; Identities 846 / 847 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Mo. kansensis</italic> (GenBank DQ534035; Identities 832 / 833 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Mo. monochaeta</italic> (GenBank KF590148; Identities 828 / 829 (99 %), no gaps). Only distant hits were obtained using the <italic>rpb2</italic> sequence; some of these were <italic>Pestalotiopsis versicolor</italic> (GenBank DQ368654; Identities 662 / 803 (82 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), <italic>P. fici</italic> (GenBank XM_007830789; Identities 657 / 800 (82 %), no gaps) and <italic>Discosia brasiliensis</italic> (GenBank KF827475; Identities 658 / 805 (82 %), 4 gaps (0 %)). No significant hits were obtained when the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence was used in a megablast search. The best hit using the <italic>tub2</italic> sequence was with <italic>Mo. kansensis</italic> (GenBank DQ534049; Identities 356 / 407 (87 %), 3 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Myrmecridium sorbicola</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824779. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F24">Fig. 24</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Sorbus,</italic> the host genus from which this fungus was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">On OA (only medium with sporulation). <italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of hyaline, smooth, branched, septate, 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, flexuous, unbranched, brown, subcylindrical, smooth, 1&#x2013;18-septate, 50&#x2013;200 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;7 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> integrated, terminal and intercalary, 20&#x2013;65 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m, with a rachis of pimple-like denticles, 0.5&#x2013;1 &#xD7; 0.5 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, obovoid, initially hyaline, but pale brown with age, apex obtuse, hilum 1 &#x3BC;m diam, (0&#x2013;)1(&#x2013;3) septate, with mucoid sheath surrounding conidium in median region, 1&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m diam, (7&#x2013;)8&#x2013;10(&#x2013;15) &#xD7; 4(&#x2013;5) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and even, lobate margins, reaching 12 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface and reverse luteous. On PDA surface and reverse pale luteous. On OA surface pale luteous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, on branch of <italic>Sorbus aucuparia</italic> (<italic>Rosaceae</italic>), 17 Feb. 2016, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic> (holotype CBS H-23405, culture ex-type CPC 30455 = CBS 143433).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Myrmecridium</italic> was introduced by <xref rid="R2" ref-type="bibr">Arzanlou <italic>et al.</italic> (2007)</xref> for ramichloridium-like taxa having hyaline mycelium, and relatively unpigmented, pimple-like denticles, and obovoid to fusoid conidia with a wing-like gelatinous sheath. <italic>Myrmecridium sorbicola</italic> is distinct from known species based on its conidial morphology, with conidia being (0&#x2013;)1(&#x2013;3)-septate, (7&#x2013;)8&#x2013;10(&#x2013;15) &#xD7; 4(&#x2013;5) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>My. schulzeri</italic> (GenBank KF986544; Identities 447 / 513 (87 %), 14 gaps (2 %)), <italic>My. phragmitis</italic> (GenBank NR_137782; Identities 494 / 567 (87 %), 18 gaps (3 %)) and <italic>My. fluviae</italic> (GenBank KX839679; Identities 419 / 481 (87 %), 15 gaps (3 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>My. banksiae</italic> (GenBank NG_042684; Identities 813 / 842 (97 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>My. schulzeri</italic> (GenBank EU041835; Identities 812 / 842 (96 %), 2 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>My. spartii</italic> (GenBank KR611902; Identities 812 / 843 (96 %), 3 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Nematogonum ferrugineum</italic></bold> (Pers.) S. Hughes, <italic>Canad. J. Bot.</italic>
<bold>36</bold>: 789. 1958. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F25">Fig. 25</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Monilinia ferruginea</italic> Pers., <italic>Mycol. eur.</italic> (Erlanga) <bold>1</bold>: 30. 1822.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of hyaline, smooth, branched, septate, 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> dimorphic. <italic>Microconidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells on hyphae, erect, golden-brown, smooth, cylindrical, 20&#x2013;40 &#xD7; 6&#x2013;8 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Macroconidiophores</italic> erect, flexuous, subcylindrical, smooth, golden-brown, flexuous, up to 400 &#x3BC;m tall, 8&#x2013;10 &#x3BC;m diam, 2&#x2013;7-septate, unbranched, terminal conidiogenous cell clavate, but at times also intercalary (appears to be linked to rejuvenating conidiophore), 25&#x2013;100 &#xD7; 11&#x2013;15 &#x3BC;m; loci sympodial, thickened, somewhat darkened, 1&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> occurring in branched chains, obovoid to ellipsoid, thick-walled, golden-brown, smooth, granular, apex obtuse, tapering to a truncate hilum, thickened and somewhat darkened, 1&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m diam, attached via a narrow isthmus, aseptate; primary conidia 15&#x2013;21 &#xD7; 12&#x2013;14 &#x3BC;m; secondary conidia 11&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 8&#x2013;9 &#x3BC;m; tertiary conidia 7&#x2013;10 &#xD7; 6&#x2013;7 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies not growing on MEA, PDA or SNA. Colonies on OA pale luteous, flat, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and feathery, lobate margins, reaching 40 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Ukraine</bold>, Ternopil region, Zalischyky district, Dniester Canyon, on ascomata of <italic>Melogramma campylosporum</italic> on trunk of fallen <italic>Carpinus betulus</italic> (<italic>Betulaceae</italic>), 7 Oct. 2016, <italic>A. Akulov,</italic> specimen ex CWU (MYC) AS 6079 (dried culture CBS H-23418, culture CPC 31872 = CBS 144203).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <xref rid="R50" ref-type="bibr">Matsushima (1975)</xref> firstly reported an aspergillus-like synasexual morph for <italic>Nematogonum highlei</italic> (a synonym of <italic>N. ferrugineum</italic>). His description and illustrations correspond well with the conidiophores we observed in this study. <xref rid="R71" ref-type="bibr">Walker &amp; Minter (1981)</xref> studied the conidiogenesis of <italic>N. ferrugineum</italic> and cited conidia to be ellipsoid, 4&#x2013;24 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;15 &#x3BC;m, which become progressively smaller towards the tips of the chains. However, no distinction was made between primary, secondary or tertiary conidia. The general conidium dimensions observed here, 7&#x2013;21 &#xD7; 6&#x2013;15 &#x3BC;m, in the collection are different from the original species description, but correspond well with those provided by <xref rid="R50" ref-type="bibr">Matsushima (1975)</xref>, 7&#x2013;22 &#xD7; 6.5&#x2013;15 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p><italic>Nematogonum</italic> is not known from any sequence data that we were able to locate, and is listed as &#x201C;<italic>incertae sedis</italic>&#x201D; in MycoBank and Index Fungorum. In the present study, we were unable to generate an LSU sequence. However, based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Melanospora</italic> spp. (<italic>Melanosporales, Hypocreomycetidae, Sordariomycetes</italic>), of which most members are also fungicolous. <italic>Nematogonum ferrugineum</italic> is known as an obligate fungicolous fungus on species of <italic>Neonectria,</italic> but has also been found on <italic>Chaetomella, Cladosporium, Graphium, Melogramma, Tritirachium</italic> and <italic>Verticillium</italic> representatives (<xref rid="R71" ref-type="bibr">Walker &amp; Minter 1981</xref>, <xref rid="R31" ref-type="bibr">Gams <italic>et al.</italic> 2004</xref>, <xref rid="R1" ref-type="bibr">Akulov 2011</xref>).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Melanospora kurssanoviana</italic> (GenBank KP981479; Identities 500 / 549 (91 %), 12 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Me. singaporensis</italic> (GenBank LC146748; Identities 519 / 582 (89 %), 20 gaps (3 %)) and <italic>Papulaspora funabasensis</italic> (GenBank LC228646; Identities 508 / 569 (89 %), 17 gaps (2 %)). The highest similarities using the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence were <italic>My. banksiae</italic> (GenBank NG_042684; Identities 813 / 842 (97 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>My. schulzeri</italic> (GenBank EU041835; Identities 812 / 842 (96 %), 2 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>My. spartii</italic> (GenBank KR611902; Identities 812 / 843 (96 %), 3 gaps (0 %)). No significant hits were obtained when the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence was used in a megablast search. All attempts to generate an LSU sequence for this culture failed, irrespective of using fresh DNA or different primer sets.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Neocucurbitaria cava</italic></bold> (Schulzer) Valenzuela-Lopez <italic>et al</italic>., <italic>Stud. Mycol</italic>. <bold>90</bold>: 46. 2018. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F26">Fig. 26</xref>.<italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Phoma cava</italic> Schulzer, <italic>Verh. K. K. Zool.-Bot. Ges. Wien</italic>
<bold>21</bold>: 1248. 1871.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, solitary, dark brown with 1&#x2013;2 papillate ostioles, 150&#x2013;250 &#x3BC;m diam; wall of 2&#x2013;3 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Conidiophores</italic> lining the inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical, branched, 1&#x2013;4-septate, 7&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> phialidic, with periclinal thickening, hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical, apical and intercalary, 4&#x2013;7 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, hyaline, smooth, aseptate, subcylindrical, guttulate, with bluntly rounded ends, (3&#x2013;)3.5(&#x2013;4) &#xD7; 1.5 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, reaching 40 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface pale mouse grey, reverse mouse grey. On PDA surface olivaceous grey, reverse iron-grey. On OA surface iron-grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>UK</bold>, England, Bournmouth, on leaves of <italic>Quercus ilex</italic> (<italic>Fagaceae</italic>), 30 Dec. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (specimen CBS H-23414, culture CPC 32488 = CBS 143400).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The present collection is morphologically similar to that of the epitype, which was described from soil collected in Germany and has conidia that are aseptate, hyaline, smooth- and thin-walled, mostly cylindrical to slightly allantoid, 2.5&#x2013;3.5 &#xD7; 1&#x2013;1.5 &#x3BC;m, guttulate (<xref rid="R68" ref-type="bibr">Valenzuela-Lopez <italic>et al</italic>. 2018</xref>). The present study adds a new culture of <italic>N. cava</italic> from the UK.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>N. cava</italic> (GenBank JF440610; Identities 475 / 480 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>N. hakeae</italic> (GenBank KY173436; Identities 512 / 533 (96 %), 3 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Ochrocladosporium frigidarii</italic> (GenBank FJ755255; Identities 439 / 463 (95 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Ne. cava</italic> (GenBank EU754199; Identities 855 / 855 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Ne. quercina</italic> (GenBank GQ387620; Identities 848 / 855 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>Ne. unguis-hominis</italic> (GenBank GQ387621; Identities 847 / 855 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)). The highest similarities using the <italic>actA</italic> sequence were <italic>Parastagonospora nodorum</italic> (GenBank CP022855; Identities 469 / 508 (92 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Alternaria hordeicola</italic> (GenBank JQ671637; Identities 478 / 520 (92 %), 2 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Al. triticimaculans</italic> (GenBank JQ671631; Identities 478 / 520 (92 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). The highest similarities using the <italic>rpb2</italic> sequence were <italic>Ne. populi</italic> (GenBank MF795816; Identities 1035 / 1059 (98 %), no gaps),<italic> Ne. juglandicola</italic> (GenBank MF795815; Identities 1027 / 1059 (97 %), no gaps) and <italic>Ne. cisticola</italic> (GenBank MF795814; Identities 995 / 1058 (94 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>tub2</italic> sequence were <italic>Ne. populi</italic> (GenBank MF795902; Identities 500 / 515 (97 %), 2 gaps (0 %)),<italic> Ne. juglandicola</italic> (GenBank MF795901; Identities 498 / 516 (97 %), 3 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Pyrenochaeta hakeae</italic> (GenBank KY173613; Identities 500 / 534 (94 %), 10 gaps (1 %)).</p>

        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Parapleurotheciopsis caespitosa</italic></bold> (Crous <italic>et al</italic>.) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824780.</p>

        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Parathyridaria philadelphi</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824781. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F27">Fig. 27</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Philadelphus,</italic> the host genus from which this fungus was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> (on OA) separate, pycnidial, brown, globose, erumpent, 250&#x2013;300 &#x3BC;m diam, with central ostiole; wall of 6&#x2013;8 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells lining the inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, ampulliform, proliferating percurrently near phialidic apex, 4&#x2013;7 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> aseptate, solitary, subcylindrical, apex obtuse, base bluntly rounded, brown, smooth, at times slightly granular, (4&#x2013;)5(&#x2013;6) &#xD7; 2 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and even, lobate margins, reaching 45 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface pale olivaceous grey with patches of ochreous, reverse amber. On PDA surface amber, reverse chestnut. On OA surface amber with patches of sienna and vinaceous buff.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, on twigs of <italic>Philadelphus coronarius</italic> (<italic>Hydrangeaceae</italic>), 2 Apr. 2016, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic> (holotype CBS H-23409, culture ex-type CPC 30532 = CBS 143432).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The genus <italic>Parathyridaria</italic> was recently introduced by <xref rid="R39" ref-type="bibr">Jaklitsch &amp; Voglmayr (2016)</xref>. Phylogenetically (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F28">Fig. 28</xref>), <italic>Pa. philadelphi</italic> is allied to <italic>Pa. robiniae</italic>, a sexual species recently described from Italy on <italic>Robinia pseudoacacia</italic> (<xref rid="R66" ref-type="bibr">Tibpromma <italic>et al</italic>. 2017</xref>).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Pa. robiniae</italic> (GenBank KY511142; Identities 709 / 715 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Roussoella mukdahanensis</italic> (GenBank KU940129; Identities 602 / 718 (84 %), 20 gaps (2 %)) and <italic>Pa. ramulicola</italic> (GenBank NR_147657; Identities 406 / 429 (95 %), 3 gaps (0 %)).         <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pestalotiopsis hollandica</italic></bold> Maharachch. <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Stud. Mycol.</italic>
<bold>79</bold>: 164. 2014. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F29">Fig. 29</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, globose, separate, immersed to erumpent on banana leaf agar, dark brown to black, 120&#x2013;350 &#x3BC;m diam, exuding a globose, dark brown conidial mass. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> subcylindrical, branched, hyaline, smooth, 1&#x2013;2-septate, 15&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal and intercalary, subcylindrical, hyaline, smooth, 8&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3.5 &#x3BC;m; proliferating percurrently at apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, fusoid-ellipsoid, 4-septate, versicoloured, central three cells brown, of which the median cell is dark brown, guttulate, verruculose, apical and basal cells hyaline, conidia (22&#x2013;)24&#x2013;26(&#x2013;27) &#xD7; (7&#x2013;)8(&#x2013;9) &#x3BC;m, apical cell 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m long, basal cell 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m long, apical cell with three flexuous appendages, unbranched, attachment apical, 17&#x2013;25 &#x3BC;m long, basal cell with central unbranched appendage, 3&#x2013;9 &#x3BC;m long.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and feathery, lobate margins, covering dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface dirty white, reverse luteous. On PDA surface pale luteous to luteous, reverse amber. On OA surface pale luteous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Spain</bold>, Zaragoza, Carretera el Frago, on needles of <italic>Cupressus sempervirens</italic> (<italic>Cupressaceae</italic>), 7 Jan. 2016, <italic>R. Blasco</italic>, culture CPC 30399 = CBS 143436.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Phylogenetically the present collection is identical (based on ITS and LSU, and almost identical based on <italic>tub2</italic>) to <italic>Pe. hollandica</italic> (<xref rid="R48" ref-type="bibr">Maharachchikumbura <italic>et al</italic>. 2014</xref>). Morphologically, however, they are quite distinct, with <italic>Pe. hollandica</italic> having conidia that are larger, (25&#x2013;)25.5&#x2013;33(&#x2013;34) &#xD7; 8.5&#x2013;10(&#x2013;10.5) &#x3BC;m, with 1&#x2013;4 tubular apical appendages, 20&#x2013;40 &#x3BC;m long. Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the ITS sequence is identical to <italic>Pe. hollandica</italic> (CBS 265.33; GenBank NR_147555), <italic>Pe. monochaeta</italic> (CBS 144.97; GenBank NR_147554) and <italic>Pe. funerea</italic> (ML4DY; GenBank EF055197). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database, the LSU sequence is identical to <italic>Pe. monochaeta</italic> (CBS 144.97; GenBank KM116229), <italic>Pe. hollandica</italic> (CBS 265.33; GenBank KM116228) and <italic>Pe. hangzhouensis</italic> (PSHI2002Endo390; GenBank DQ657865). The highest similarities using the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence were <italic>Pe. verruculosa</italic> (GenBank JX399061; Identities 298 / 299 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Pe. hollandica</italic> (GenBank KM199481; Identities 281 / 286 (98 %), no gaps) and <italic>Pe. brassicae</italic> (GenBank KM199558; Identities 268 / 273 (98 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>tub2</italic> sequence were <italic>Pe. hollandica</italic> (GenBank KM199388; Identities 446 / 447 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Pe. italiana</italic> (GenBank KP781882; Identities 442 / 445 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Pe. monochaeta</italic> (GenBank KX642435; Identities 448 / 452 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Phyllosticta hakeicola</italic></bold> Crous &amp; T.I. Burgess, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824782. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F30">Fig. 30</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Hakea</italic>, the host genus from which it was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, solitary, globose, dark brown, 150&#x2013;250 &#x3BC;m diam, with central ostiole, 25&#x2013;40 &#x3BC;m diam; wall of 3&#x2013;8 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Conidiophores</italic> lining the inner cavity, 1&#x2013;2-septate, subcylindrical, hyaline, smooth, branched below, 20&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 6&#x2013;10 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal and intercalary, subcylindrical, hyaline, smooth, 8&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m, proliferating percurrently at apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, ellipsoid to obovoid, aseptate, smooth, hyaline, guttulate, granular, (9&#x2013;)10&#x2013;13(&#x2013;15) &#xD7; (6.5&#x2013;)7 &#x3BC;m; conidia encased in a persistent mucoid sheath, 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m diam, but with a single apical mucoid appendage, 5&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 1.5&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m, tapering to subacutely rounded apex.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat to erumpent, spreading, with sparse to moderate aerial mycelium and feathery, lobate margins, reaching 55 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse iron-grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Fitzroy Falls, on leaves of <italic>Hakea</italic> sp. (<italic>Proteaceae</italic>), 26 Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (holotype CBS H-23315, culture ex-type CPC 32041 = CBS 143492).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <xref rid="R69" ref-type="bibr">Van der Aa &amp; Vanev (2002)</xref> placed <italic>Phyllosticta hakeae</italic> in the genus <italic>Microsphaeropsis</italic>, and presently no species of <italic>Phyllosticta</italic> are known from <italic>Hakea</italic>. Phylogenetically (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F31">Fig. 31</xref>), <italic>Ph. hakeicola</italic> is closely related to <italic>Ph. telopeae</italic> (also <italic>Proteaceae</italic>; <xref rid="R13" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2000</xref>), but can be distinguished by its larger conidia, (12&#x2013;)13&#x2013;16(&#x2013;18) &#xD7; (7&#x2013;)8&#x2013;9 &#x3BC;m (<xref rid="R64" ref-type="bibr">Swart <italic>et al</italic>. 1998</xref>).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Ph. telopeae</italic> (GenBank KF206205; Identities 568 / 570 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Ph. abieticola</italic> (GenBank NR_147344; Identities 562 / 570 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Ph. ligustricola</italic> (GenBank NR_136951; Identities 609 / 626 (97 %), 4 gaps (0 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Ph. telopeae</italic> (GenBank KF766384; Identities 841 / 841 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Ph. abieticola</italic> (GenBank EU754193; Identities 852 / 854 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Ph. philoprina</italic> (GenBank DQ377878; Identities 852 / 854 (99 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>actA</italic> sequence were <italic>Ph. abieticola</italic> (GenBank KF289238; Identities 225 / 225 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Ph. telopeae</italic> (GenBank KF289255; Identities 222 / 225 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Ph. foliorum</italic> (GenBank KF289247; Identities 221 / 225 (98 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>gapdh</italic> sequence were <italic>Ph. hubeiensis</italic> (GenBank JX025029; Identities 339 / 351 (97 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Ph. cavendishii</italic> (GenBank KU716083; Identities 324 / 337 (96 %), no gaps) and <italic>Ph. citricarpa</italic> (GenBank KX280614; Identities 323 / 336 (96 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence were <italic>Ph. telopeae</italic> (GenBank KF766435; Identities 303 / 308 (98 %), no gaps), <italic>Ph. yuccae</italic> (GenBank JX227948; Identities 371 / 396 (94 %), 5 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>Ph. minima</italic> (GenBank KF766432; Identities 287 / 309 (93 %), 6 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Polyscytalum chilense</italic></bold> Crous &amp; M.J. Wingf., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824783. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F32">Fig. 32</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to Chile, the country where this fungus was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of branched, septate, brown, smooth, 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, 1&#x2013;3-septate, subcylindrical, brown, smooth, straight to geniculous-sinuous, 30&#x2013;60 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal and intercalary, subcylindrical to clavate, 7&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m; scars arranged in a rachis, prominent, thickened, darkened and refractive, 1&#x2013;1.5 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> cylindrical, pale brown, smooth, prominently guttulate, 1-septate, apex obtuse, base truncate, 1&#x2013;1.5 &#x3BC;m diam, somewhat darkened and refractive, in very long, unbranched chains, (13&#x2013;)15&#x2013;18(&#x2013;20) &#xD7; (2&#x2013;)2.5 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and feathery, lobate margins, reaching 15 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface ochreous, reverse chestnut. On PDA surface and reverse amber. On OA surface iron-grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Chile</bold>, on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus urophylla</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), Jun. 2010, <italic>M.J. Wingfield</italic> (holotype CBS H-23403, culture ex-type CPC 31946 = CBS 143387).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <xref rid="R62" ref-type="bibr">Sutton (1973)</xref> established the genus <italic>Anungitea</italic> for a genus of hyphomycetes with dark, solitary conidiophores, bearing a head of denticles with flattened conidiogenous scars that are neither thickened nor darkened, and chains of cylindrical, 1-septate subhyaline conidia. Since its introduction, several taxa have been added to the genus, and because the type <italic>A. fragilis</italic> remains phylogenetically undefined, the generic concept has widened. As seen in the present study, several of these &#x201C;<italic>Anungitea</italic>&#x201D; species cluster with <italic>Po. fecundissimum</italic>, the type species of <italic>Polyscytalum</italic>. It has become clear that the generic concepts of these two genera overlap and that several species would be better accommodated in <italic>Polyscytalum</italic> than in <italic>Anungitea</italic>. <italic>Polyscytalum</italic> has cylindrical conidia that vary from being 0&#x2013;1-septate, hyaline to pale brown, smooth, with truncate ends (those in <italic>Anungitea</italic> have obtuse ends), and the scars can be somewhat darkened and refractive, but unthickened in both genera (see <italic>Pseudoanungitea</italic> with thickened hila elsewhere in this manuscript).</p>
        <p>Phylogenetically (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F13">Fig. 13</xref>), <italic>Po. chilense</italic> is distinct from all species known from <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> (<xref rid="R9" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 2017</xref>a) and is most similar to <italic>Po</italic>. <italic>grevilleae</italic>, which has setae, and smaller conidia, (10&#x2013;)13&#x2013;16(&#x2013;22) &#xD7; (2&#x2013;)2.5&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m (<xref rid="R22" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 2016b</xref>).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Po. grevilleae</italic> (GenBank KX228252; Identities 537 / 560 (96 %), no gaps), <italic>Po. eucalyptorum</italic> (GenBank NR_132904; Identities 534 / 560 (95 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>Po. fecundissimum</italic> (GenBank EU035441; Identities 371 / 391 (95 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Po. eucalyptigena</italic> (GenBank KY173477; Identities 818 / 821 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Phlogicylindrium eucalypti</italic> (GenBank DQ923534; Identities 888 / 896 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>Po. eucalyptorum</italic> (GenBank KJ869176; Identities 878 / 886 (99 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Polyscytalum eucalyptigenum</italic></bold> (Crous &amp; M.J. Wingf.) Crous &amp; M.J. Wingf., <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824784. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F33">Fig. 33</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Anungitea eucalyptigena</italic> Crous &amp; M.J. Wingf., <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>37</bold>: 339. 2016.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R15" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. (2016a)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of brown, smooth, septate, 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> erect, solitary, subcylindrical, unbranched, brown, smooth, flexuous, 1&#x2013;3-septate, 20&#x2013;100 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> integrated, terminal, 7&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m, apex swollen with several sympodial loci, denticulate, flat-tipped, 1&#x2013;2 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;2.5 &#x3BC;m, not thickened nor darkened. <italic>Ramoconidia</italic> subcylindrical, pale brown, smooth, 0&#x2013;1-septate, 12&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> occurring in long, unbranched chains, cylindrical with truncate ends, hyaline, smooth, guttulate, medianly 1-septate, (11&#x2013;)13&#x2013;17(&#x2013;20) &#xD7; (2&#x2013;)2.5 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and feathery, lobate margins, reaching 30 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface ochreous, reverse iron-grey. On PDA surface amber, reverse brown vinaceous. On OA surface olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimens examined</italic>: <bold>Chile</bold>, on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus grandis</italic> &#xD7;<italic> uromycoides</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), Jun. 2010, <italic>M.J. Wingfield</italic> (specimen CBS H-23421, culture CPC 31878 = CBS 143388). <bold>Malaysia</bold>, Kota Kinabalu, on leaf spots of <italic>Eucalyptus grandis</italic> &#xD7; <italic>pellita</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), 30 May 2015, <italic>M.J. Wingfield</italic> (holotype CBS H-22888, culture ex-type CPC 28762 = CBS 142102).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The present collection from Chile is morphologically and phylogenetically (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F13">Fig. 13</xref>) similar to the ex-type strain of <italic>Po. eucalyptigenum</italic> from Malaysia (ramoconidia 16&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m, conidia (11&#x2013;)14&#x2013;16(&#x2013;18) &#xD7; (2&#x2013;)2.5(&#x2013;3) &#x3BC;m; <xref rid="R15" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2016a</xref>). Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Po. eucalyptigena</italic> (GenBank KY173383; Identities 570 / 571 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Po. grevilleae</italic> (GenBank KX228252; Identities 548 / 571 (96 %), 11 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>Po. eucalyptorum</italic> (GenBank NR_132904; Identities 545 / 571 (95 %), 12 gaps (2 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Po. eucalyptorum</italic> (GenBank KY173477; Identities 819 / 821 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Po. grevilleae</italic> (GenBank KX228304; Identities 824 / 831 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Phlogicylindrium eucalypti</italic> (GenBank DQ923534; Identities 835 / 844 (99 %), 1 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Polyscytalum eucalyptorum</italic></bold> (Crous &amp; R.G. Shivas) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824785.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Anungitea eucalyptorum</italic> Crous &amp; R.G. Shivas, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>32</bold>: 199. 2014.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R11" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. (2014)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, Queensland, Dave&#x2019;s Creek, S28&#xB0;12&#x2019;13.7&#x201D; E153&#xB0;12&#x2019;9.5&#x201D;, on <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>) leaf litter, 11 Jul. 2009, <italic>P.W. Crous &amp; R.G. Shivas,</italic> (holotype CBS H-21678, culture ex-type CPC 17207 = CBS 137967).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Polyscytalum grevilleae</italic></bold> (Crous &amp; Jacq. Edwards) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824786.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Anungitea grevilleae</italic> Crous &amp; Jacq. Edwards, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>36</bold>: 327. 2016.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R22" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. (2016b)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, Victoria, Royal Botanic Gardens Cranbourne, S38&#xB0;7&#x2019; 49.6&#x201D; E145&#xB0;16&#x2019;9&#x201D;, on leaves of <italic>Grevillea</italic> sp. (<italic>Proteaceae</italic>), 7 Nov. 2014, <italic>P.W. Crous &amp; J. Edwards</italic> (holotype CBS H-22591, culture ex-type CPC 25576 = CBS 141282).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Polyscytalum neofecundissimum</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Akulov, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824787. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F34">Fig. 34</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to its morphological similarity to <italic>Polyscytalum fecundissimum</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells or erect, flexuous, subcylindrical, branched, up to 100 &#x3BC;m tall, pale brown, smooth. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal and intercalary, subcylindrical, pale brown, smooth, 20&#x2013;25 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m, proliferating sympodially at apex, scars unthickened, 2&#x2013;2.5 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> occurring in chains, cylindrical with obtuse ends, hyaline, smooth, medianly 1-septate, guttulate, (12&#x2013;)14&#x2013;17(&#x2013;20) &#xD7; 2(&#x2013;3) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, surface folded, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, reaching 20 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface olivaceous grey, reverse iron-grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Ukraine</bold>, Ternopil region, Zalischyky district, Dniester Canyon, on leaf litter of <italic>Quercus robur</italic> (<italic>Fagaceae</italic>), associated with the mycelium of <italic>Cladosporium</italic> sp., 7 Oct. 2016, <italic>A. Akulov,</italic> specimen ex CWU (MYC) AS 6073 isotype (holotype CBS H-23419, culture ex-type CPC 31826 = CBS 143390).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Polyscytalum neofecundissimum</italic> is morphologically and phylogenetically (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F13">Fig. 13</xref>) similar to <italic>Po. fecundissimum</italic> (conidia 13&#x2013;18 &#xD7; 2 &#x3BC;m; <xref rid="R26" ref-type="bibr">Ellis 1971</xref>), except that it has larger conidia. Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Po. fecundissimum</italic> (GenBank EU035441; Identities 562 / 578 (97 %), no gaps), <italic>Subulispora britannica</italic> (GenBank EF029198; Identities 535 / 571 (94 %), 2 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Pseudophloeospora eucalyptorum</italic> (GenBank NR_145406; Identities 436 / 494 (88 %), 18 gaps (3 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Po. fecundissimum</italic> (GenBank EU035441; Identities 800 / 809 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Po. eucalyptigena</italic> (GenBank KY173477; Identities 812 / 823 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Po. eucalyptorum</italic> (GenBank KJ869176; Identities 831 / 843 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Polyscytalum nullicananum</italic></bold> (Crous) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824788.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Anungitea nullicana</italic> Crous, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>39</bold>: 411. 2017.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R17" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. (2017b)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Nullica State Forest, on leaf litter of <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> sp. (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), 29 Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (holotype CBS H-23297, culture ex-type CPC 32528 = CBS 143406).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pseudoanungitea</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>gen. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824789.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to its morphological similarity to <italic>Anungitea</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of branched, septate, brown, smooth, 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, septate, subcylindrical, brown, smooth, straight to flexuous. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal and intercalary, subcylindrical to clavate; scars arranged in a rachis, prominent, thickened, darkened and refractive. <italic>Conidia</italic> fusoid-ellipsoid, pale brown, smooth, prominently guttulate, 0&#x2013;1-septate, hila somewhat darkened and refractive, in short (1&#x2013;2) unbranched chains.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type species</italic>: <italic>Pseudoanungitea syzygii</italic> (Crous <italic>et al.</italic>) Crous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pseudoanungitea syzygii</italic></bold> (Crous <italic>et al</italic>.) Crous, <bold><italic>comb. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824790. <italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Anungitea syzygii</italic> Crous <italic>et al</italic>., <italic>Canad. J. Bot</italic>. <bold>73</bold>(2): 225. 1995.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Description and illustration</italic>: <xref rid="R19" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> (1995)</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>South Africa</bold>, Mpumalanga, Sabie, on leaf litter of <italic>Syzygium chordatum</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), Mar. 1993, <italic>W.J. Swart</italic> (holotype PREM 51687, culture ex-type CPC 578 = CBS 520.93).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Anungitea</italic> includes species with dark, solitary conidiophores, bearing a head of denticles with flattened conidiogenous scars that are unthickened and not darkened, and chains of cylindrical, 1-septate subhyaline conidia, with apical and basal scars (<xref rid="R62" ref-type="bibr">Sutton 1973</xref>). <italic>Anungitopsis</italic> is similar but includes taxa with indistinguishable scars arranged in a rachis. <italic>Neoanungitea</italic> is somewhat intermediate between these two genera, having a rachis, but with flat-tipped loci (<xref rid="R9" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 2017</xref>b).</p>
        <p>Because the type species of <italic>Anungitea</italic> (<italic>A. fragilis</italic>) is not presently known from culture and needs to be recollected (leaves of <italic>Abies balsamea</italic>, Manitoba, Canada), the phylogeny of <italic>Anungitea</italic> remains unresolved, and several unrelated taxa have been described in the genus. The two species treated here cluster apart from the generic clade assumed to be <italic>Anungitea s. str</italic>. They differ from <italic>Anungitea</italic> in having terminal and intercalary conidiogenous cells, and refractive, thickened scars that give rise to short conidial chains with somewhat darkened and refractive hila.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pseudoanungitea vaccinii</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824791. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F35">Fig. 35</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Vaccinium,</italic> the host genus from which this fungus was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of branched, septate, brown, smooth, 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, 0&#x2013;3-septate, subcylindrical, brown, smooth, straight to flexuous, 8&#x2013;40 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal and intercalary, subcylindrical to clavate, 5&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m; scars arranged in a rachis, prominent, thickened, darkened and refractive, 1&#x2013;1.5 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> fusoid-ellipsoid, pale brown, smooth, prominently guttulate, 0&#x2013;1-septate, apex obtuse, base truncate, 1&#x2013;1.5 &#x3BC;m diam, somewhat darkened and refractive, in short (1&#x2013;2) unbranched chains, (8&#x2013;)10&#x2013;12(&#x2013;13) &#xD7; (2&#x2013;)3(&#x2013;4) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, reaching 7 mm diam after 1 mo at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse brown vinaceous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, on stem of <italic>Vaccinium myrtillus</italic> (<italic>Ericaceae</italic>), 16 Jan. 2016, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic> (holotype CBS H-23422, culture ex-type CPC 30522 = CBS 143164).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Anungitea syzygii</italic> (GenBank KY853424; Identities 499 / 526 (95 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Tothia fuscella</italic> (GenBank JF927786; Identities 504 / 561 (90 %), 11 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>T. spartii</italic> (GenBank NR_132917; Identities 430 / 487 (88 %), 15 gaps (3 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Cylindrosympodium lauri</italic> (GenBank EU035414; Identities 840 / 855 (98 %), no gaps), <italic>Cy. variabile</italic> (GenBank KX228353; Identities 836 / 852 (98 %), no gaps) and <italic>An. syzygii</italic> (GenBank KY853484; Identities 802 / 823 (98 %), 6 gaps (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic><bold>Pseudoanungitea variabilis</bold></italic> Hern.-Restr., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824792. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F36">Fig. 36</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the variable conidial morphology.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of branched, septate, pale brown to brown, smooth, 1&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, simple, rarely branched, subcylindrical, straight to flexuous, 0&#x2013;7-septate, brown paler to the apex, smooth, 18&#x2013;100 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal and intercalary, sympodial, denticulate, subcylindrical, 8.5&#x2013;23.5 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m; denticles prominent, sometimes darkened, 1&#x2013;1.5 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> in short chains (1&#x2013;2(&#x2013;4)), two shapes <italic>a</italic>. fusoid-ellipsoid, hyaline, smooth, sometimes guttulate, 0&#x2013;1-septate, apex obtuse or truncate, base truncate, 1&#x2013;1.5 &#x3BC;m diam, somewhat darkened and refractive, 8&#x2013;14 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;2.5(&#x2013;3) &#x3BC;m; <italic>b</italic>. globose, subglobose to pyriform, hyaline, smooth, aseptate, apex obtuse, base truncated, 1&#x2013;1.5 &#x3BC;m diam, 4&#x2013;8.5 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies after 1 mo at 25 &#xB0;C, on OA reaching 6 mm, velvety, brown vinaceous, entire to lobate margin; reverse brown vinaceous. On MEA and PDA reaching 6&#x2013;12 mm, effuse becoming raised, aerial mycelium pale mouse grey, submerged mycelium black, lobate margin; reverse black.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Spain</bold>, Castilla la Mancha, Hayedo de la Tejera Negra Natural Park, on dead wood, May 2011, <italic>M. Hern&#xE1;ndez-Restrepo, J. Mena &amp; J. Guarro</italic> (holotype CBS H-23494, culture ex-type CBS 132716).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>:<italic> Pseudoanungitea variabilis</italic> is distinct from other species in the genus due to its having two conidial shapes. Some conidia are fusoid-ellipsoid resembling those of <italic>Ps. syzygii</italic> and <italic>Ps. vaccini</italic> (<xref rid="R19" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 1995</xref>, this study). However, <italic>Ps. variabilis</italic> can be distinguished by the presence of globose conidia.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Sympodiella acicola</italic> (GenBank KY853468; Identities 370 / 412 (90 %), 17 gaps (4 %)), <italic>Tothia fuscella</italic> (GenBank JF927786; Identities 469 / 528 (89 %), 13 gaps (2 %)) and <italic>T. spartii</italic> (GenBank NR_132917; Identities 399 / 448 (89 %), 10 gaps (2 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Cylindrosympodium lauri</italic> (GenBank EU035414; Identities 820 / 849 (97 %), 6 gaps (0%)), <italic>Cyl. variabile</italic> (GenBank KX228353; Identities 819 / 849 (96 %), 6 gaps (0%)) and <italic>Repetophragma goidanichii</italic> (GenBank DQ408574; Identities 802 / 836 (96 %), 9 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pseudocamarosporium africanum</italic></bold> (Damm <italic>et al.</italic>) Crous, <italic>Sydowia</italic>
<bold>67</bold>: 110. 2015. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F37">Fig. 37</xref>.<italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Paraconiothyrium africanum</italic> Damm <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>20</bold>: 15. 2008.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> separate, pycnidial, brown, erumpent, globose, 150&#x2013;200 &#x3BC;m diam, with 1&#x2013;2 ostioles, exuding a brown conidial mass; wall of 3&#x2013;4 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis</italic>. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> lining the inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, doliiform with periclinal thickening at apex, 4&#x2013;9 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;6 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, hyaline, smooth, becoming brown, finely roughened, subcylindrical, apex obtuse, at times slightly clavate, base truncate to bluntly rounded, 0&#x2013;1-septate, (6&#x2013;)7&#x2013;8(&#x2013;9) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3&#x2013;3.5(&#x2013;4) &#x3BC;m. <italic>Spermatogonia</italic> separate or in same conidioma as conidia, globose, brown, up to 150 &#x3BC;m diam, with central ostiole; wall of 3&#x2013;4 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis</italic>. <italic>Spermatophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells. <italic>Spermatogenous cells</italic> lining the inner cavity, ampulliform to doliiform, hyaline, smooth, 4&#x2013;6 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m, apex with visible periclinal thickening and minute collarette. <italic>Spermatia</italic> solitary, smooth, hyaline, subcylindrical, straight to slightly curved, apex obtuse, base truncate, 3&#x2013;5 &#xD7; 1.5 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies spreading, with sparse to moderate aerial mycelium. On MEA surface pale mouse grey, reverse greyish sepia; on PDA surface and reverse fuscous black; on OA surface mouse grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>South Africa</bold>, Western Cape Province, Franschhoek pass, twigs of <italic>Erica</italic> sp. (<italic>Ericaceae</italic>), Nov. 2014, <italic>M.J. Wingfield</italic> (specimen CBS H-23425, culture CPC 25926 = CBS 144204).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The present collection is phylogenetically identical to <italic>Pseudocamarosporium africanum</italic>. The latter taxon was originally described from branches of <italic>Prunus persica</italic> in South Africa. Morphologically, the two collections are also similar in that conidia of the ex-type strain of <italic>Ps. africana</italic> are 1-septate, rarely 3- or 4-celled, brown and thick-walled, verruculose, (4&#x2013;) 6.5&#x2013;9.5(&#x2013;12) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3&#x2013;4(&#x2013;5) &#x3BC;m (<xref rid="R23" ref-type="bibr">Damm <italic>et al</italic>. 2008</xref>).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Ps. africanum</italic> (GenBank EU295650; Identities 457 / 457 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Ps. cotinae</italic> (GenBank KY098789; Identities 475 / 477 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Pseudocamarosporium</italic> &#x201C;sp. 2&#x201D; (GenBank KY929162; Identities 475 / 477 (99 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Ps. cotinae</italic> (GenBank KY098790; Identities 835 / 835 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Pseudocamarosporium</italic> &#x201C;sp. 2&#x201D; (GenBank KY929187; Identities 835 / 835 (100 %), no gaps) and <italic>Paracamarosporium</italic> &#x201C;sp. 1&#x201D; (GenBank KY929184; Identities 835 / 835 (100 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pseudocamarosporium brabeji</italic></bold> (Marinc. <italic>et al.</italic>) Crous, <italic>Sydowia</italic>
<bold>67</bold>: 110. 2015. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F38">Fig. 38</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Camarosporium brabeji</italic> Marinc. <italic>et al</italic>., in Marincowitz <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>CBS Diversity Ser.</italic> (Utrecht) <bold>7</bold>: 90. 2008.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, superficial on PNA, solitary, globose, brown, 200&#x2013;250 &#x3BC;m diam, with central papillate ostiole up to 100 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Peridium</italic> of 3&#x2013;6 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis</italic>, thick-walled, dark brown. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> hyaline, smooth, 5&#x2013;8 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m, ampulliform to doliiform with periclinal thickening at apex. <italic>Conidia</italic> brown, ellipsoid or subcylindrical, (9&#x2013;)10&#x2013;12(&#x2013;13) &#xD7; (4&#x2013;)5(&#x2013;6) &#x3BC;m, 1&#x2013;3-transversely septate, straight or oblique, smooth to finely roughened, thick-walled.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading with moderate aerial mycelium. On MEA surface pale mouse grey, reverse greyish sepia; on PDA surface and reverse fuscous black; on OA surface honey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimens examined</italic>: <bold>Switzerland</bold>, on branch of <italic>Platanus</italic> sp. (<italic>Platanaceae</italic>), 24 Jun. 2014, <italic>O. Holdenrieder</italic> (specimen CBS H-23429, culture CPC 25002 = CBS 144205); <italic>ibid</italic>. (CPC 25004, 25843, 27400, 30973, 31482).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Pseudocamarosporium</italic> and <italic>Paracamarosporium</italic> were recently introduced to accommodate camarosporium-like taxa that reside in <italic>Didymosphaeriaceae</italic> (<xref rid="R73" ref-type="bibr">Wijayawardene <italic>et al</italic>. 2014</xref>). Both genera were also shown to include species with a coniothyrium-like morphology (<xref rid="R10" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 2015a</xref>). <italic>Pseudocamarosporium brabeji</italic> was treated as <italic>Pseudocamarosporium</italic> sp. 2. in <xref rid="R9" ref-type="bibr">Crous &amp; Groenewald (2017)</xref>.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Ps. tilicola</italic> (GenBank KJ747050; Identities 555 / 555 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Ps. brabeji</italic> (GenBank EU552105; Identities 578 / 579 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), and <italic>Ps. lonicerae</italic> (GenBank KJ747047; Identities 571 / 572 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Ps. cotinae</italic> (GenBank KY098790; Identities 882 / 882 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Paracamarosporium</italic> &#x201C;sp. 1&#x201D; (GenBank KY929184; Identities 882 / 882 (100 %), no gaps) and <italic>Pa. fagi</italic> (GenBank KY929183; Identities 882 / 882 (100 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Pseudocercospora breonadiae</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Jol. Roux, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824793. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F39">Fig. 39</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Breonadia,</italic> the host genus from which this fungus was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">Sporulation on the underside of leaves; lesions indistinct, pale to medium brown zones, containing several fungi, with <italic>Pseudocercospora breonadiae</italic> being intermixed with a <italic>Zasmidium</italic> sp., with superficial brown verruculose hyphae, and dark brown, verruculose, solitary, erect to flexuous conidiophores, giving rise to dark brown, verruculose obclavate conidia with thickened, darkened hila. <italic>Mycelium</italic> superficial on host surface, pale brown, smooth, branched, septate, 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, arising from superficial hyphae, pale brown, smooth, erect, geniculate-sinuous, subcylindrical, 0&#x2013;3-septate, 10&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> integrated, terminal, pale brown, smooth, subcylindrical with several terminal sympodial loci, flat-tipped, not thickened nor darkened, 1&#x2013;1.5 &#x3BC;m diam, 7&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, pale brown, smooth, guttulate, mostly gently curved, narrowly obclavate, apex subobtuse, base obconically truncate, 1&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m diam, 5&#x2013;6(&#x2013;8)-septate, (30&#x2013;)50&#x2013;80(&#x2013;100) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3(&#x2013;3.5) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, surface folded with moderate aerial mycelium and even, lobate margins, reaching 20 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface grey olivaceous, reverse iron-grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>South Africa</bold>, Limpopo Province, Wolkberg, on leaves of <italic>Breonadia microcephala</italic> (<italic>Rubiaceae</italic>), Jan. 2010, <italic>J. Roux</italic> (holotype CBS H-23413, culture ex-type CPC 30153 = CBS 143489).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: No species of <italic>Pseudocercospora</italic> have been described from <italic>Breonadia microcephala</italic>. The closest allied species to <italic>Ps. breonadiae</italic> was <italic>Ps. planaltinensis</italic>, which was described from leaves of a <italic>Chamaecrista</italic> sp. in Brazil (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F40">Fig. 40</xref>). However, it is morphologically distinct, having cylindrical to obclavate conidia, 1&#x2013;8-septate, 49&#x2013;129 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m (<xref rid="R60" ref-type="bibr">Silva <italic>et al</italic>. 2016</xref>).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Ps. planaltinensis</italic> (GenBank KT290137; Identities 503 / 505 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Ps. fuligena</italic> (GenBank GU214675; Identities 539 / 543 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>Ps. chengtuensis</italic> (GenBank GU214672; Identities 539 / 543 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Ps. dingleyae</italic> (GenBank KX286997; Identities 840 / 841 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Ps. proiphydis</italic> (GenBank KM055434; Identities 840 / 841 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Ps. airliensis</italic> (GenBank KM055433; Identities 840 / 841 (99 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>actA</italic> sequence were <italic>Ps. paraguayensis</italic> (GenBank KF903444; Identities 507 / 521 (97 %), no gaps), <italic>Ps. piricola</italic> (GenBank KY048162; Identities 562 / 578 (97 %), no gaps) and <italic>Ps. flavomarginata</italic> (GenBank JX902134; Identities 522 / 537 (97 %), no gaps).
