The highest similarities using the <italic>rpb2</italic> sequence were <italic>Ps. neriicola</italic> (GenBank KX462647; Identities 681 / 686 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Ps. crispans</italic> (GenBank KX462623; Identities 674 / 686 (98 %), no gaps) and <italic>Ps. fukuokaensis</italic> (GenBank KX462632; Identities 672 / 686 (98 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence were <italic>Ps. basiramifera</italic> (GenBank DQ211677; Identities 464 / 518 (90 %), 13 gaps (2 %)), <italic>Ps. parapseudarthriae</italic> (GenBank KJ869238; Identities 457 / 511 (89 %), 6 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>Ps. jahnii</italic> (GenBank KM393284; Identities 449 / 509 (88 %), 8 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Rhinocladiella quercus</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <italic>Sydowia</italic>
<bold>68</bold>: 219. 2016. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F41">Fig. 41</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of pale brown, smooth, branched, septate, 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> trimorphic. <italic>Microconidiophores</italic> exophiala-like, reduced to conidiogenous loci on hyphae, phialidic hyphal pegs solitary, 1&#x2013;2 &#xD7; 1 &#x3BC;m, giving rise to a mucoid conidial mass. <italic>Macroconidiophores</italic> ramichloridium-like, cylindrical, erect, medium brown, smooth, 1&#x2013;2-septate, unbranched, straight, 20&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal, medium brown, smooth, developing a rachis of pimple-like denticles, 0.5 &#x3BC;m diam, refractive, 11&#x2013;25 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, hyaline, smooth, ellipsoid to cylindrical, straight to slightly curved, (3&#x2013;)4(&#x2013;5) &#xD7; 1.5&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m. Cladophialophora-like morph developing at hyphal ends, with cells becoming swollen, ellipsoid, aseptate, and prominently constricted at septa, in branched chains, 4&#x2013;7 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and even, lobate margins, reaching 20 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA, surface and reverse olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, on branch of <italic>Sorbus aucuparia</italic> (<italic>Rosaceae</italic>), 17 Feb. 2016, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic> (specimen CBS H-23406, culture CPC 30459 = CBS 143495).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Rhinocladiella quercus</italic> was recently described from twigs of <italic>Quercus robur</italic> collected near Berlin in Germany (<xref rid="R37" ref-type="bibr">Hern&#xE1;ndez-Restrepo <italic>et al.</italic> 2016</xref>). The morphology of the present collection on <italic>Sorbus aucuparia</italic> closely matches that of the type.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>R. quercus</italic> (GenBank KX306769; Identities 633 / 642 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Capronia</italic> sp. (GenBank AF050240; Identities 613 / 617 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>Cladophialophora</italic> sp. (GenBank JX494354; Identities 621 / 634 (98 %), 3 gaps (0 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>R. quercus</italic> (GenBank KX306794; Identities 792 / 792 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Capronia</italic> sp. (GenBank JN941378; Identities 799 / 801 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Ca. fungicola</italic> (GenBank FJ358224; Identities 768 / 801 (96 %), 3 gaps (0 %)). No significant hits were obtained when the <italic>tef1</italic> and <italic>tub2</italic> sequences were used in a megablast search.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Roussoella euonymi</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Akulov, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824794. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F42">Fig. 42</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Euonymus,</italic> the host genus from which this fungus was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> erumpent, globose, brown, pycnidial, 150&#x2013;300 &#x3BC;m diam, with central ostiole, exuding a black conidial mass. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells, lining the inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, ampulliform to doliiform, proliferating percurrently at apex, 5&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 5&#x2013;7 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, ellipsoid, guttulate, aseptate, apex obtuse, base 2 &#x3BC;m diam, bluntly rounded, thick-walled, becoming warty, golden-brown to red-brown, (6&#x2013;)7(&#x2013;8) &#xD7; (4&#x2013;)5&#x2013;6 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and even, lobate margins, reaching 60 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface olivaceous grey with patches of pale olivaceous grey, reverse pale olivaceous grey. On PDA surface olivaceous grey, reverse iron-grey. On OA surface iron-grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Ukraine</bold>, Ternopil region, Zalischyky district, Dniester Canyon, on fallen branches of <italic>Euonymus europaeus</italic> (<italic>Celastraceae</italic>), 14 Oct. 2016, <italic>A. Akulov</italic>, specimen ex CWU (MYC) AS 6061 isotype (holotype CBS H-23420, culture ex-type CPC 31963 = CBS 143426).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Based on the LSU sequence, <italic>Roussoella euonymi</italic> is accommodated in the <italic>Roussoellaceae</italic>, being similar to other asexual species such as <italic>Ro. solani</italic> and <italic>Ro. mexicana</italic> (<xref rid="R18" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 2015b</xref>, c). Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were numerous unidentified &#x201C;<italic>Pleosporales</italic> sp.&#x201D; sequences (e.g. GenBank HM116753; Identities 542 / 561 (97 %), 1 gap (0 %)), with the closest known species being <italic>Ro. neopustulans</italic> (GenBank KJ474833; Identities 441 / 474 (93 %), 5 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>Ro. pustulans</italic> (GenBank KJ474830; Identities 442 / 478 (92 %), 4 gaps (0 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Ro. mukdahanensis</italic> (GenBank KU863118; Identities 837 / 847 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Arthopyrenia salicis</italic> (GenBank LN907499; Identities 843 / 854 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Ro. neopustulans</italic> (GenBank KU863119; Identities 839 / 850 (99 %), no gaps). Only distant hits were obtained using the <italic>actA</italic> sequence; some of these were <italic>Stagonosporopsis cucurbitacearum</italic> (GenBank KX246908; Identities 459 / 509 (90 %), 10 gaps (1 %)), <italic>S. citrulli</italic> (GenBank KX246907; Identities 459 / 509 (90 %), 10 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>S. caricae</italic> (GenBank KX246909; Identities 458 / 509 (90 %), 10 gaps (1 %)). Only distant hits were obtained using the <italic>rpb2</italic> sequence; for example with <italic>Torula herbarum</italic> (GenBank KF443393; Identities 582 / 735 (79 %), 6 gaps (0 %)). No significant hits were obtained with the <italic>tub2</italic> sequence.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Setophaeosphaeria citricola</italic></bold> Crous &amp; M.J. Wingf., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824795. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F43">Fig. 43</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Citrus,</italic> the host genus from which this fungus was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Ascomata</italic> on twigs immersed, black, 150&#x2013;250 &#x3BC;m diam, globose, opening via a central ostiole that could with age become an irregular rupture in ascomatal wall; wall of 2&#x2013;3 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Asci</italic> bitunicate, sessile, subcylindrical to narrowly ellipsoid, apical chamber 1&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m diam, stipitate, 50&#x2013;70 &#xD7; 11&#x2013;15 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Ascospores</italic> multiseriate, hyaline, thin-walled, smooth, aseptate, fusoid-ellipsoidal, widest in upper third, apex subobtusely rounded, base obtuse, (16&#x2013;)19&#x2013;20(&#x2013;22) &#xD7; (4.5&#x2013;)5(&#x2013;6) &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, 150&#x2013;250 &#x3BC;m diam, aggregated, globose, pale brown with dark brown central ostiole, 20&#x2013;30 &#x3BC;m diam, ostiole surrounded by brown, thick-walled, verruculose, septate hyphae, up to 100 &#x3BC;m long, 4&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m diam at base, apex obtuse. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells lining the inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, ampulliform to doliiform, 5&#x2013;7 &#xD7; 5&#x2013;6 &#x3BC;m, phialidic with prominent periclinal thickening. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, hyaline, smooth, aseptate, multiguttulate and granular, fusoid-ellipsoid, straight to irregularly twisted, apex obtuse, base truncate, 2 &#x3BC;m diam, (10&#x2013;)12&#x2013;14(&#x2013;17) &#xD7; 3&#x2013;3.5(&#x2013;4) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and even, lobate margins, reaching 45 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface pale mouse grey to mouse grey, reverse mouse grey. On PDA surface olivaceous grey, reverse mouse grey. On OA surface olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Mount Annan Botanical Garden, on leaves of <italic>Citrus australasica</italic> (<italic>Rutaceae</italic>), 25 Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (holotype CBS H-23271, culture ex-type CPC 32083 = CBS 143179).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Coniothyrium sidae</italic> was recently described from a <italic>Sida</italic> sp. collected in Brazil (<xref rid="R54" ref-type="bibr">Quaedvlieg <italic>et al</italic>. 2013</xref>). Although the ITS is identical (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="F44">Fig. 44</xref>), the morphology is very different, with the sexual morph having hyaline, aseptate ascospores, those of <italic>Con. sidae</italic> being brown, (3&#x2013;)5-septate, (18&#x2013;)20&#x2013;24(&#x2013;26) &#xD7; (4&#x2013;)5(&#x2013;5.5) &#x3BC;m, and conidia being smaller, fusoid-ellipsoidal, straight to slightly curved, (9&#x2013;)10&#x2013;12(&#x2013;13) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3 &#x3BC;m. Conidia of <italic>S. citri</italic>, described from <italic>Citrus</italic> in Italy, are smaller than those of <italic>S. citricola</italic>, 3.5&#x2013;5 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m (<xref rid="R9" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al.</italic> 2017</xref>b).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Con. sidae</italic> (GenBank KF251149; Identities 518 / 520 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Phaeosphaeria setosa</italic> (GenBank AF439500; Identities 472 / 476 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>S. hemerocallidis</italic> (GenBank KJ869161; Identities 503 / 521 (97 %), 10 gaps (1 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Con. sidae</italic> (GenBank KF251653; Identities 835 / 836 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>S. badalingensis</italic> (GenBank KJ869219; Identities 828 / 832 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Leptosphaeria rubefaciens</italic> (GenBank JF740311; Identities 843 / 854 (99 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>rpb2</italic> sequence were<italic> Pyrenochaeta unguis-hominis</italic> (GenBank LT717682; Identities 715 / 847 (84 %), no gaps), <italic>Py. cava</italic> (GenBank LT717681; Identities 705 / 847 (83 %), no gaps) and <italic>Py. hakeae</italic> (GenBank KY173593; Identities 705 / 847 (83 %), no gaps). The best hit with the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence was with <italic>Con. sidae</italic> (GenBank KF253109; Identities 439 / 500 (88 %), 21 gaps (4 %)) while the <italic>tub2</italic> sequence was less than 87 % identical to species of <italic>Pyrenochaeta</italic>, <italic>Neocucurbitaria</italic> and <italic>Cucurbitaria</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Setophaeosphaeria sidae</italic></bold> (Quaedvl. <italic>et al.</italic>) Crous,<italic><bold>comb. nov.</bold></italic> MycoBank MB824796.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Basionym</italic>: <italic>Coniothyrium sidae</italic> Quaedvl. <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Stud. Mycol.</italic>
<bold>75</bold>: 374. 2013.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Brazil</bold>, Rio de Janeiro, Nova Friburgo, Riograndina, along roadside on <italic>Sida</italic> sp. (<italic>Malvaceae</italic>), 24 Feb. 2008, <italic>R.W. Barreto</italic> (holotype CBS H-21315, culture ex-type CPC 19602 = RWB 866 = CBS 135108).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Sirastachys cyperacearum</italic></bold> Crous &amp; T.I. Burgess, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824797. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F45">Fig. 45</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Cyperaceae</italic>, the substrate from which this fungus was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiophores</italic> macro- and mononematous, single or in groups of 2&#x2013;3, thin-walled, smooth, unbranched, erect, straight to flexuous, 3&#x2013;4-septate, stipe 70&#x2013;90 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m, bearing 5&#x2013;10 conidiogenous cells. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> phialidic, clavate to subclavate, hyaline (to faintly greenish), smooth, 10&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m, with collarettes. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, ellipsoid, thick-walled, dark brown, guttulate, verrucose, (5&#x2013;)6&#x2013;7(&#x2013;8) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3 &#x3BC;m, with rounded ends.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse to moderate aerial mycelium and even, lobate margins, reaching 25 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface olivaceous grey, reverse olivaceous grey to smoke grey. On PDA surface olivaceous grey, reverse smoke grey. On OA surface iron-grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Fitzroy Falls, on leaves of <italic>Cyperaceae</italic>, 26 Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (holotype CBS H-23308, culture ex-type CPC 32087 = CBS 143444).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The genus <italic>Sirastachys</italic>, based on <italic>Si. phaeospora</italic>, was recently established by <xref rid="R46" ref-type="bibr">Lombard <italic>et al</italic>. (2016)</xref>. Phylogenetically the present collection is closely related to <italic>Si</italic>. <italic>phaeospora,</italic> but distinct in that the latter has smaller conidia, 4&#x2013;5 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m, and shorter conidiophores (40&#x2013;65 &#x3BC;m long) (<xref rid="R46" ref-type="bibr">Lombard <italic>et al</italic>. 2016</xref>).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Si. phaeospora</italic> (GenBank KU846667; Identities 581 / 588 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Si. pandanicola</italic> (GenBank KU846664; Identities 555 / 563 (99 %), 3 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Stachybotrys parvispora</italic> (GenBank JN093263; Identities 543 / 552 (98 %), 2 gaps (0 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Si. phyllophila</italic> (GenBank KU846784; Identities 822 / 827 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Si. pandanicola</italic> (GenBank KU846777; Identities 820 / 827 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>Si. phaeospora</italic> (GenBank KU846779; Identities 817 / 827 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Sphaerellopsis paraphysata</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Alfenas, <italic>IMA Fungus</italic>
<bold>5</bold>: 411. 2014. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F46">Fig. 46</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> eustromatic, pycnidioid, 200&#x2013;300 &#x3BC;m diam, immersed to erumpent, dark brown, multilocular, ostiolate, ostioles 30&#x2013;40 &#x3BC;m diam; wall of 4&#x2013;6 layers of medium brown <italic>textura angularis. Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells, or 1&#x2013;2-septate, hyaline, smooth, ampulliform to subcylindrical, unbranched, 7&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical to ampulliform with percurrent proliferation at apex, 7&#x2013;13 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, hyaline, smooth, guttulate, medianly 1-septate, constricted or not, ellipsoid with mucoid polar appendages, (12&#x2013;)14&#x2013;17(&#x2013;18) &#xD7; (4&#x2013;)4.5&#x2013;5.5(&#x2013;6) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and feathery margin, reaching 15 mm diam after 2 wk. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Sussex Inlet, on leaves of <italic>Phragmites</italic> sp. (<italic>Poaceae</italic>), 27 Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, CBS 143579 = CPC 32406.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Sphaerellopsis paraphysata</italic> was recently described on a rust on <italic>Pennisetum</italic> sp. collected in Brazil (<xref rid="R67" ref-type="bibr">Trakunyingcharoen <italic>et al.</italic> 2014</xref>), and this is the first record of this hyperparasite from Australia.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Sphaerellopsis paraphysata</italic> (GenBank NR_137956; Identities 554 / 561 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Eudarluca caricis</italic> (GenBank KP170655; Identities 426 / 475 (90 %), 7 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>Subplenodomus drobnjacensis</italic> (GenBank MG131867; Identities 426 / 481 (89 %), 14 gaps (2 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Sphaerellopsis paraphysata</italic> (GenBank KP170729; Identities 840 / 841 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Plenodomus congestus</italic> (GenBank JF740278; Identities 846 / 855 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)) and <italic>Con. telephii</italic> (GenBank LN907332; Identities 847 / 857 (99 %), 1 gap (0 %)). The highest similarities using the <italic>rpb2</italic> sequence were <italic>Leptosphaeria biglobosa</italic> (GenBank FO905662; Identities 680 / 868 (78 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Curvularia affinis</italic> (GenBank HG779159; Identities 674 / 871 (77 %), 15 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>Plenodomus enteroleucus</italic> (GenBank KY064042; Identities 603 / 770 (78 %), 8 gaps (1 %)). The highest similarity using the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence was <italic>Sp. paraphysata</italic> (GenBank KP170685; Identities 496 / 505 (98 %), 4 gaps (0 %)). The highest similarity using the <italic>tub2</italic> sequence was <italic>Sp. paraphysata</italic> (GenBank KP170710; Identities 300 / 304 (99 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Subplenodomus iridicola</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Denman, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824798. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F47">Fig. 47</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the fact that the fungus is found on <italic>Iris</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Leaf spots</italic> pale brown with blackish margins, amphigenous, elongated, subcircular, 4&#x2013;7 mm diam, up to 4 cm long. <italic>Ascomata</italic> immersed, globose, dark brown, 150&#x2013;250 &#x3BC;m diam, with central ostiole, 20&#x2013;30 &#x3BC;m diam; wall of 4&#x2013;6 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis</italic>. <italic>Pseudoparaphyses</italic> intermingled among asci, subcylindrical, hyaline, smooth, hyphae-like, 2&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Asci</italic> 8-spored, fasciculate, stipitate, bitunicate, narrowly ellipsoid, ocular chamber 1.5&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m diam, 80&#x2013;100 &#xD7; 10&#x2013;15 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Ascospores</italic> multiseriate, fusoid-ellipsoid, pale brown, guttulate, finely roughened, constricted at median septum, developing 1(&#x2013;4) additional septa in both cells, at times first cell above median septum slightly swollen, (19&#x2013;)21&#x2013;25(&#x2013;27) &#xD7; (5&#x2013;)6(&#x2013;7) &#x3BC;m. Germinating ascospores become distorted, up to 8 &#x3BC;m diam, with germ tubes via terminal or intercalary cells. <italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, globose, pale brown, 100&#x2013;200 &#x3BC;m diam, with central papillate ostiole, 20&#x2013;30 &#x3BC;m diam; wall of 4&#x2013;6 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells lining inner cavity, doliiform, hyaline, smooth, phialidic with periclinal thickening, 4&#x2013;7 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;6 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aseptate, hyaline, smooth, guttulate, subcylindrical to narrowly ellipsoid, apex obtuse, base truncate, (4&#x2013;)5&#x2013;6(&#x2013;7) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, reaching 50 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface ochreous, reverse amber. On PDA surface and reverse isabelline. On OA surface rosy buff with patches of isabelline and cinnamon.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>UK</bold>, England, Upton Grey, on <italic>Iris</italic> sp. (<italic>Iridaceae</italic>), 28 Mar. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (holotype CBS H-23415, culture ex-type CPC 30162 = CBS 143395).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Subplenodomus</italic> was established by de Gruyter <italic>et al.</italic> (2013) for <italic>Su. violicola</italic>. Phylogenetically <italic>Su. iridicola</italic> is closely related to <italic>Su. galicola</italic>, but distinct in that the latter (described from a dead stem of <italic>Galium</italic> sp. collected in Italy) has larger ascospores [30&#x2013;40 &#xD7; 6&#x2013;9 &#x3BC;m, (3&#x2013;)4-septate] and asci (66&#x2013;120 &#xD7; 12&#x2013;17 &#x3BC;m) (<xref rid="R66" ref-type="bibr">Tibpromma <italic>et al</italic>. 2017</xref>).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Alloleptosphaeria italica</italic> (GenBank KT454722; Identities 428 / 458 (93 %), 6 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Subplenodomus galicola</italic> (GenBank KY554204; Identities 505 / 576 (88 %), 23 gaps (3 %)) and <italic>Leptosphaeria rubefaciens</italic> (GenBank KT804116; Identities 448 / 495 (91 %), 12 gaps (2 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Su. galicola</italic> (GenBank KY554199; Identities 848 / 854 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Su. violicola</italic> (GenBank GU238156; Identities XXX / 848 / 854 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Plenodomus deqinensis</italic> (GenBank KY064031; Identities 843 / 849 (99 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Teichospora quercus</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824799. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F48">Fig. 48</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Quercus,</italic> the host genus from which this fungus was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Ascomata</italic> solitary to gregarious, semi-immersed, becoming erumpent, dark brown, uniloculate, globose with papillate ostiole, 200&#x2013;350 &#x3BC;m diam; peridium thick-walled, multi-layered, of <italic>textura angularis</italic>, brown, becoming hyaline inwards. <italic>Asci</italic> 8-spored, bitunicate, fissitunicate, cylindrical-clavate, short-stipitate, rounded at apex, with ocular chamber, 60&#x2013;110 &#xD7; 10&#x2013;15 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Ascospores</italic> tri- to multiseriate, hyaline, fusiform or ellipsoid-fusoid, straight, widest just above median septum, (1&#x2013;)3-septate, but becoming golden brown, with mucoid sheath (up to 2.5 &#x3BC;m diam), (19&#x2013;)20&#x2013;22(&#x2013;25) &#xD7; (4&#x2013;)5(&#x2013;6) &#x3BC;m. <italic>Pseudoparaphyses</italic> longer than asci, filiform, cells cylindrical, branched, hyaline, thin-walled, smooth, 2&#x2013;2.5 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidiomata</italic> globose to subglobose, 150&#x2013;300 &#x3BC;m diam, with central ostiole, sessile on foot of brown stroma; wall of 6&#x2013;8 layers of pale brown <italic>textura angularis</italic>, becoming hyaline towards inside. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> subcylindrical, hyaline, smooth, branched at base, 10&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal and intercalary, hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical, phialidic with prominent percurrent proliferation, 5&#x2013;10 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, ellipsoid, hyaline, smooth, guttulate, apex obtuse, base truncate, 1.5&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m diam, (4&#x2013;)5(&#x2013;6) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3 &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, reaching 30 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface smoke grey in centre, olivaceous grey in outer zone, reverse olivaceous grey. On PDA surface pale olivaceous grey, reverse smoke grey with diffuse sienna pigment. On OA surface pale olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>France</bold>, Cl&#xE9;ron, on stroma of pyrenomycete, on branch of <italic>Quercus</italic> sp. (<italic>Fagaceae</italic>), 15 Nov. 2015, <italic>G. Moyne</italic> (holotype CBS H-23404, culture ex-type CPC 30009 = CBS 143396).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The genus <italic>Teichospora</italic> was treated in detail by <xref rid="R39" ref-type="bibr">Jaklitsch &amp; Voglmayr (2016)</xref> and includes several generic synonyms. Although the present collection was initially assumed to represent a new genus, it clusters phylogenetically with other species of <italic>Teichospora</italic>. It is, however, morphologically distinct, in that the ascospores remain hyaline, and are surrounded by a mucoid sheath, and are only 1(&#x2013;3) transversely septate. The asexual morph, however, is phoma-like, which again resembles those of <italic>Teichospora</italic>. Nevertheless, if additional gene loci eventually show this clade to represent more than one genus, <italic>T. quercus</italic> will most likely be placed in a separate genus.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>T. rubriostiolata</italic> (GenBank KU601590; Identities 562 / 589 (95 %), 4 gaps (0 %)), <italic>T. melanommoides</italic> (GenBank KU601585; Identities 561 / 590 (95 %), 7 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>T. acaciae</italic> (GenBank NR_138410; Identities 559 / 591 (95 %), 8 gaps (1 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>T. parva</italic> (GenBank GU385195; Identities 851 / 854 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>T. acaciae</italic> (GenBank KR611898; Identities 800 / 810 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>T. melanommoides</italic> (GenBank KU601585; Identities 841 / 852 (99 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>rpb2</italic> sequence were <italic>T. rubriostiolata</italic> (GenBank KU601596; Identities 745 / 829 (90 %), no gaps), <italic>T. trabicola</italic> (GenBank KU601600; Identities 732 / 830 (88 %), no gaps) and <italic>Melanomma radicans</italic> (GenBank AY485625; Identities 701 / 826 (85 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence were <italic>T. trabicola</italic> (GenBank KU601603; Identities 410 / 477 (86 %), 25 gaps (5 %)), <italic>T. rubriostiolata</italic> (GenBank KU601608; Identities 404 / 471 (86 %), 16 gaps (3 %)) and <italic>T. melanommoides</italic> (GenBank KU601610; Identities 399 / 466 (86 %), 9 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Trochila viburnicola</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Denman, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824800. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F49">Fig. 49</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to the fact that the fungus occurs (<italic>icola</italic> = dweller) on stems of <italic>Viburnum</italic>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> pale brown, globose, somewhat flattened, 120&#x2013;250 &#x3BC;m diam, opening by irregular rupture, becoming acervular; wall of 3&#x2013;6 layers of pale brown <italic>textura angularis</italic>. <italic>Macroconidiophores</italic> lining inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical, branched, 1&#x2013;7-septate, 10&#x2013;40 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;6 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Macroconidiogenous cells</italic> integrated, terminal and intercalary, hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical to doliiform, 5&#x2013;13 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m, with semi-flared collarette, 1&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m tall, proliferating percurrently. <italic>Macroconidia</italic> solitary, hyaline, smooth, guttulate, aseptate, subcylindrical, straight, apex obtuse, base truncate, 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m diam with prominent marginal frill, (5&#x2013;)6&#x2013;7 &#xD7; (3&#x2013;)4 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Microconidiophores</italic> similar in morphology to <italic>macroconidiophores</italic>, 8&#x2013;20 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Microconidiogenous cells</italic> terminal and intercalary, subcylindrical to ampulliform, 4&#x2013;7 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m, proliferating percurrently. <italic>Microconidia</italic> similar to macroconidia but smaller, 3&#x2013;4 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;2.5 &#x3BC;m, with minute marginal frill.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, surface folded, with sparse aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, reaching 50 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface pale luteous to ochreous, reverse ochreous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>UK</bold>, England, Upton Grey, on twig cankers of <italic>Viburnum</italic> sp. (<italic>Adoxaceae</italic>), 28 Mar. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (holotype CBS H-23416, culture ex-type CPC 30254 = CBS 144206).</p>
        <p><italic>Notes</italic>: The genus <italic>Sirophoma</italic> is known from <italic>Viburnum</italic>, but is distinct from the present collection in that it has pycnidial conidiomata with central ostioles, long flexuous conidiophores, and globose to pyriform conidia. Based on DNA sequence similarity, the present asexual collection is similar to sequences of the sexual morph <italic>Trochila</italic> (<italic>Dermateaceae</italic>). <italic>Trochila</italic> has been linked to cryptocline-like asexual morphs, and hence it is tentatively placed in this genus. A species of <italic>Trochila</italic> known from <italic>Viburnum</italic> is <italic>T. tini</italic>, but as this species is not known from culture and only the sexual morph is known, a comparison is impossible.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Crumenulopsis sororia</italic> (GenBank KY941133; Identities 437 / 487 (90 %), 7 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Cenangiopsis quercicola</italic> (GenBank LT158425; Identities 506 / 552 (92 %), 4 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Vestigium trifidum</italic> (GenBank NR_121556; Identities 502 / 551 (91 %), 3 gaps (0 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Vestigium trifidum</italic> (GenBank KC407777; Identities 833 / 860 (97 %), 3 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Fabrella tsugae</italic> (GenBank AF356694; Identities 798 / 824 (97 %), 2 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Trochila laurocerasi</italic> (GenBank KX090835; Identities 812 / 839 (97 %), no gaps). The highest similarities using the <italic>rpb2</italic> sequence were <italic>Hyalopeziza nectrioides</italic> (GenBank JN086836; Identities 551 / 689 (80 %), 6 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Chlorencoelia torta</italic> (GenBank JN086854; Identities 618 / 777 (80 %), 6 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Loramyces macrosporus</italic> (GenBank JN086838; Identities 533 / 671 (79 %), 7 gaps (1 %)). Only distant hits to <italic>Cucurbitaria</italic> and <italic>Trichoderma</italic> were obtained when the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence was used in a megablast search.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Varicosporellopsis aquatilis</italic></bold> Lechat &amp; J. Fourn., <italic>Ascomycete.org</italic>
<bold>8</bold>(3): 87. 2016. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F50">Fig. 50</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen">On SNA: <italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of hyaline, branched, septate, smooth, 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae, lacking chlamydospores, and frequently forming hyphal coils. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, branched at base, 0&#x2013;2-septate, or reduced to conidiogenous cells; branched conidiophores consist of a basal stipe, 15&#x2013;30 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m, giving rise to 1&#x2013;3 lateral branches, 0&#x2013;1-septate, or conidiogenous cells, 40&#x2013;100 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> subcylindrical with slight apical taper, hyaline, smooth, 35&#x2013;60 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m, apex phialidic with minute cylindrical collarette, 1&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m tall, giving rise to clusters of slimy conidia. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, hyaline, smooth, granular to guttulate, ellipsoid, aseptate, straight to curved, apex subobtuse, base tapered to a truncate hilum, 1&#x2013;1.5 &#x3BC;m diam, (6&#x2013;)11&#x2013;13(&#x2013;15) &#xD7; (3&#x2013;)4(&#x2013;4.5) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, aerial mycelium sparse, surface folded, with smooth, lobate margins, reaching 15&#x2013;25 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface dirty white to pale luteous, reverse luteous to pale luteous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>The Netherlands</bold>, Culemborg, from garden soil, Feb. 2017, <italic>H. van Warenburg</italic>, culture JW75003 = CBS 143509.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Morphologically <italic>Varicosporellopsis aquatilis</italic> resembles <italic>Acremonium curvulum</italic> in having curved, fusoid-ellipsoid conidia with truncate hila. However, it can be distinguished in that it lacks chlamydospores, and has much larger conidia than <italic>A. curvulum</italic> (4&#x2013;6.7 &#xD7; 1.4&#x2013;2.1 &#x3BC;m; <xref rid="R30" ref-type="bibr">Gams 1971</xref>), from which it is also phylogenetically distinct. Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>V. aquatilis</italic> (GenBank KU233187; Identities 524 / 530 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Fusarium merismoides</italic> var.<italic> violaceum</italic> (GenBank EU860060; Identities 842 / 906 (93 %), 27 gaps (2 %)) and <italic>Thyronectria asturiensis</italic> (GenBank KJ570690; Identities 854 / 919 (93 %), 25 gaps (2 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>V. aquatilis</italic> (GenBank KU233189; Identities 835 / 836 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Paracremonium variiforme</italic> (GenBank KU746739; Identities 823 / 836 (98 %), no gaps) and <italic>Pa. contagium</italic> (GenBank KP012631; Identities 790 / 804 (98 %), no gaps). Only distant hits were obtained using the <italic>actA</italic> sequence; some of these were <italic>Verticillium dahliae</italic> (GenBank CP010981; Identities 874 / 973 (90 %), 15 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Fusarium oxysporum</italic> f. sp. <italic>dianthi</italic> (GenBank LT841228; Identities 870 / 977 (89 %), 17 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>Fusarium graminearum</italic> (GenBank HG970335; Identities 872 / 979 (89 %), 21 gaps (2 %)). The highest similarities using the <italic>tub2</italic> sequence were <italic>Pa. inflatum</italic> (GenBank KM232101; Identities 528 / 583 (91 %), 9 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Pa. contagium</italic> (GenBank KM232103; Identities 532 / 599 (89 %), 9 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>Pa. pembeum</italic> (GenBank KU053055; Identities 438 / 500 (88 %), 9 gaps (1 %)).</p>
        <p><italic>Varicosporellopsis aquatilis</italic> was recently described from submerged wood collected in freshwater in southwestern France. The acremonium-like asexual morph is morphologically similar, but its conidia are somewhat smaller, 6&#x2013;11 &#xD7; 2.8&#x2013;3.2 &#x3BC;m (<xref rid="R43" ref-type="bibr">Lechat &amp; Fournier 2016</xref>).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Vermiculariopsiella dichapetali</italic></bold> Crous, <italic>Persoonia</italic>
<bold>32</bold>: 213. 2014. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F51">Fig. 51</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> sporodochial, on SNA erumpent, crystalline, up to 500 &#x3BC;m diam, with brown, erect setae distributed throughout conidioma, thick-walled, flexuous, finely roughened, 180&#x2013;500 &#xD7; 4&#x2013;10 &#x3BC;m, 6&#x2013;20-septate, with obtuse ends. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> aggregated in stroma, subcylindrical, 2&#x2013;4-septate, branched below, 35&#x2013;70 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> phialidic, terminal, cylindrical with curved apex, pale brown, smooth to finely roughened, 12&#x2013;26 &#xD7; 2.5&#x2013;3 &#x3BC;m, apex 1.5&#x2013;2 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, hyaline, smooth, guttulate, aseptate, straight to slightly curved, inequilateral, outer plane convex, apex subobtusely rounded, with truncate hilum, excentric, 1 &#x3BC;m diam, (14&#x2013;)16&#x2013;19(&#x2013;21) &#xD7; 2.5(&#x2013;3) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, with sparse aerial mycelium and even, lobate margins, covering the dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA, PDA and OA surface and reverse pale luteous to ochreous.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimens examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Barron Grounds Nature Reserve, on leaves of <italic>Melaleuca</italic> sp. (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), 26 Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (culture CPC 32057 = CBS 143424); Victoria, La Trobe State Forest, on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus regnans</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), 30 Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic> (CBS H-23312, culture CPC 32544 = CBS 143440).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: <italic>Vermiculariopsiella dichapetali</italic> was described from leaves of <italic>Dichapetalum rhodesicum</italic> collected in Botswana (<xref rid="R11" ref-type="bibr">Crous <italic>et al</italic>. 2014</xref>), and these are the first records from Australia. Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Ve. dichapetali</italic> (GenBank KX306771; Identities 532 / 534 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Ve.immersa</italic> (GenBank KY853476; Identities 532 / 534 (99 %), 2 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Ve. acaciae</italic> (GenBank NR_145253; Identities 520 / 536 (97 %), 7 gaps (1 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Ve. dichapetali</italic> (GenBank KX306796; Identities 716 / 716 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Ve. acaciae</italic> (GenBank KX228314; Identities 837 / 839 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Ve. immersa</italic> (GenBank KJ476961; Identities 822 / 827 (99 %), 4 gaps (0 %)). Only distant hits were obtained using the <italic>actA</italic> sequence of CPC 32544; some of these were <italic>Xenogliocladiopsis eucalyptorum</italic> (GenBank KM231140; Identities 390 / 418 (93 %), no gaps), <italic>Allantonectria miltina</italic> (GenBank KM231247; Identities 388 / 418 (93 %), no gaps) and <italic>X. cypellocarpa</italic> (GenBank KM231141; Identities 388 / 418 (93 %), no gaps).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Wettsteinina philadelphi</italic></bold> Crous &amp; R.K. Schumach., <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824801. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F52">Fig. 52</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to <italic>Philadelphus,</italic> the host genus from which this fungus was collected.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiomata</italic> pycnidial, solitary to aggregated, globose, 250&#x2013;350 &#x3BC;m diam, with central ostiole; wall of 6&#x2013;8 layers of brown <italic>textura angularis. Conidiophores</italic> reduced to conidiogenous cells lining inner cavity, hyaline, smooth, subcylindrical to ampulliform, 10&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m, with numerous, prominent percurrent proliferations in apical region. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, medium brown, finely roughened, guttulate, fusoid-ellipsoid, apex obtuse, tapering prominently in lower third to truncate hilum, 1&#x2013;1.5 &#x3BC;m diam; with (2&#x2013;)3(&#x2013;5) transverse eusepta, and 1&#x2013;3 muriform or vertical septa, (11&#x2013;)15&#x2013;20(&#x2013;23) &#xD7; (5&#x2013;)6&#x2013;7(&#x2013;8) &#x3BC;m.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies erumpent, spreading, with moderate to abundant aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, covering the dish after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface and reverse smoke grey. On PDA surface and reverse olivaceous grey. On OA surface olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Germany</bold>, near Berlin, on twigs of <italic>Philadelphus coronarius</italic> (<italic>Hydrangeaceae</italic>), 2 Apr. 2016, <italic>R.K. Schumacher</italic> (holotype CBS H-23410, culture ex-type CPC 30534 = CBS 143392).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The present camarosporium-like collection is described in the genus <italic>Wettsteinina</italic>, although this genus is primarily known from its sexual morphs (<xref rid="R76" ref-type="bibr">Zhang <italic>et al.</italic> 2012</xref>), with one reference to a possible stagonospora-like asexual morph (<xref rid="R28" ref-type="bibr">Farr &amp; Rossman 2018</xref>).</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Alpinaria rhododendri</italic> (GenBank NR_147686; Identities 505 / 534 (95 %), 10 gaps (1 %)), <italic>Herpotrichia juniperi</italic> (GenBank JX981496; Identities 443 / 472 (94 %), 7 gaps (1 %)) and <italic>He. pinetorum</italic> (GenBank KP966102; Identities 442 / 471 (94 %), 8 gaps (1 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Melanomma pulvis-pyrius</italic> (GenBank LC203344; Identities 847 / 853 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Trematosphaeria pertusa</italic> (GenBank DQ678072; Identities 847 / 853 (99 %), no gaps) and <italic>Wettsteinina macrotheca</italic> (GenBank AY849969; Identities 838 / 844 (99 %), no gaps). Only distant similarity to <italic>He. juniperi</italic> sequences were obtained with the <italic>tef1</italic> sequence.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Xyladictyochaetaceae</italic></bold> Crous &amp; Hern.-Restr., <bold><italic>fam. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824802.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of medium brown, smooth, septate, branched, hyphae, forming globose, intercalary, brown, smooth, chlamydospore-like structures. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> erect, brown, smooth, subcylindrical, flexuous, multiseptate. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal and intercalary, polyphialidic; phialidic opening lacking flared collarettes. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aggregating in slimy mass, hyaline, smooth, fusoid-ellipsoid, slightly curved, apex subacute, base truncate, medianly 1-septate; each end with flexuous, unbranched appendage.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Type genus</italic>: <italic>Xyladictyochaeta</italic> Hern.-Restr. <italic>et al.</italic></p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Xyladictyochaeta lusitanica</italic></bold> Hern.-Restr. <italic>et al.</italic>, <italic>Stud. Mycol.</italic>
<bold>86</bold>: 94. 2017. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F53">Fig. 53</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Mycelium</italic> consisting of medium brown, smooth, septate, branched, 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m diam hyphae, that form globose, intercalary, brown, smooth, chlamydospore-like structures, 5&#x2013;6 &#x3BC;m diam. <italic>Conidiophores</italic> erect, brown, smooth, subcylindrical, flexuous, multiseptate, 60&#x2013;150 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;5 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> terminal and intercalary, polyphialidic, 2&#x2013;6 &#xD7; 2&#x2013;2.5 &#x3BC;m; phialidic opening 1 &#x3BC;m diam, lacking flared collarettes. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, aggregating in slimy mass, hyaline, smooth, fusoid-ellipsoid, slightly curved, apex subacute, base truncate, 1 &#x3BC;m diam, medianly 1-septate, (10&#x2013;) 11&#x2013;12(&#x2013;13) &#xD7; (2.5&#x2013;)3 &#x3BC;m; each end with flexuous, unbranched appendage, apex central, base excentric, 3&#x2013;7 &#x3BC;m diam.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, surface folded, with sparse to moderate aerial mycelium and feathery, lobate margins, reaching 20 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA and PDA surface and reverse amber. On OA surface olivaceous grey.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimens examined</italic>: <bold>Australia</bold>, New South Wales, Nullica State Forest, on <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> sp. (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>) leaf litter, 29 Nov. 2016, <italic>P.W. Crous</italic>, (CBS H-23291, culture CPC 32324 = CBS 143502); <italic>ibid</italic>. (CPC 32526).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: The genus <italic>Xyladictyochaeta</italic>, based on <italic>Xy. lusitanica</italic>, was recently described from <italic>Eucalyptus</italic> leaves collected in Portugal (<xref rid="R36" ref-type="bibr">Hern&#xE1;ndez-Restrepo <italic>et al</italic>. 2017</xref>), and this is the first record of this fungus from Australia. <italic>Xyladictyochaeta</italic> represents an undescribed family in <italic>Xylariales</italic>, and <italic>Xyladictyochaetaceae</italic> is introduced to accommodate it. Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Xy. lusitanica</italic> (GenBank KY853479; Identities 571 / 573 (99 %), no gaps), <italic>Anungitea eucalyptigena</italic> (GenBank KY173383; Identities 517 / 578 (89 %), 16 gaps (2 %)) and <italic>Beltraniopsis neolitseae</italic> (GenBank NR_148072; Identities 521 / 583 (89 %), 19 gaps (3 %)). The ITS sequences of CPC 32324 and 32526 differs with three nucleotides (morphologically they are similar, except for prominent differences in conidiophore length). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Xy. lusitanica</italic> (GenBank KY853543; Identities 801 / 801 (100 %), no gaps), <italic>Phlogicylindrium eucalypti</italic> (GenBank DQ923534; Identities 822 / 844 (97 %), no gaps) and <italic>Phl. mokarei</italic> (GenBank KY173521; Identities 796 / 818 (97 %), no gaps). The LSU sequences of CPC 32324 and CPC 32526 are identical. No significant matches were obtained using the <italic>tef1</italic> sequences and the <italic>tef1</italic> sequences of CPC 32324 and CPC 32526 differ with one nucleotide and a single CA-repeat. No significant matches were obtained using the <italic>tub2</italic> sequence and the <italic>tub2</italic> sequences of CPC 32324 and CPC 32526 are 99 % identical (806 / 813, 1 gap).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><bold><italic>Zygosporium pseudogibbum</italic></bold> Crous, <bold><italic>sp. nov.</italic></bold> MycoBank MB824803. <xref ref-type="fig" rid="F54">Fig. 54</xref>.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Etymology</italic>: Name refers to its morphological similarity to<italic> Zygosporium gibbum.</italic></p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Conidiophores</italic> solitary, erect, consisting of 1&#x2013;2 pale brown basal cells forming a stipe, 7&#x2013;15 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m, giving rise to a curved, dark brown terminal vesicle, 11&#x2013;12 &#xD7; 6&#x2013;8 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Conidiogenous cells</italic> arranged in a whorl of 3&#x2013;4 on a terminal vesicle, hyaline, smooth, reniform, 4&#x2013;6 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m. <italic>Vesicle</italic> with single apical cell, 4&#x2013;5 &#xD7; 3&#x2013;4 &#x3BC;m, pale brown, cylindrical, with obtuse apex and prominent collarette. <italic>Conidia</italic> solitary, globose, verruculose, faintly olivaceous, 6(&#x2013;7) &#x3BC;m diam.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Culture characteristics</italic>: Colonies flat, spreading, surface folded, with sparse to moderate aerial mycelium and smooth, lobate margins, reaching 50 mm diam after 2 wk at 25 &#xB0;C. On MEA surface buff to dirty white, reverse luteous. On PDA surface buff to dirty white, reverse saffron. On OA surface buff to dirty white.</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Specimen examined</italic>: <bold>Malaysia</bold>, Sabah, on leaves of <italic>Eucalyptus pellita</italic> (<italic>Myrtaceae</italic>), Mar. 2016, <italic>M.J. Wingfield</italic> (holotype CBS H-23411, culture ex-type CPC 30421 = CBS 143503).</p>
        <p content-type="specimen"><italic>Notes</italic>: Morphologically, the present collection matches the description of <italic>Z. gibbum</italic>, a European taxon (reference isolate, FMR 13130 = CBS 137306; leaf litter Canary Islands; <xref rid="R36" ref-type="bibr">Hernandez-Restrepo <italic>et al</italic>. 2017</xref>), which has a wide host range and wide geographical distribution (<xref rid="R26" ref-type="bibr">Ellis 1971</xref>). Phylogenetically, however, it clusters sister to this species, and thus a new taxon is introduced to accommodate it. The vesicle gives rise to a single apical cell that appears to be a conidiogenous cell, but could play a different role entirely (moisture droplet, insect dispersal). Active spore dispersal was observed on host tissue, and it could be that conidia on this cell can actively discharge.</p>
        <p>Based on a megablast search using the ITS sequence, the closest matches in NCBI&#x2019;s GenBank nucleotide database were <italic>Z. gibbum</italic> (GenBank KY853482; Identities 481 / 504 (95 %), 1 gap (0 %)), <italic>Podosordaria muli</italic> (GenBank JX156377; Identities 462 / 499 (93 %), 14 gaps (2 %)) and <italic>Poronia australiensis</italic> (GenBank KP012826; Identities 384 / 434 (88 %), 21 gaps (4 %)). The highest similarities using the LSU sequence were <italic>Z. gibbum</italic> (GenBank KY853546; Identities 739 / 757 (98 %), 6 gaps (0 %)), <italic>Atrotorquata spartii</italic> (GenBank KP325443; Identities 818 / 846 (97 %), 2 gaps (0 %)) and <italic>Circinotrichum cycadis</italic> (GenBank KJ869178; Identities 804 / 849 (95 %), 6 gaps (0 %)). Only distant hits were obtained using the <italic>actA</italic> sequence; some of these were <italic>Penicillifer pulcher</italic> (GenBank KM231107; Identities 390 / 418 (93 %), no gaps), <italic>Neonectria neomacrospora</italic> (GenBank KM231143; Identities 389 / 418 (93 %), no gaps) and <italic>Cylindrodendrum album</italic> (GenBank KM231152; Identities 387 / 418 (93 %), no gaps). No significant hits were obtained when the <italic>tub2</italic> sequence was used.</p>
      </sec>
    </sec>
  </body>

        <mixed-citation publication-type="journal"><person-group person-group-type="author"><name><surname>Crous</surname><given-names>PW</given-names></name><name><surname>Summerell</surname><given-names>BA</given-names></name><name><surname>Taylor</surname><given-names>JE</given-names></name><etal/></person-group> (<year>2000</year>). <article-title>Fungi occurring on <italic>Proteaceae</italic> in Australia: selected foliicolous species</article-title>. <source>Australasian Plant Pathology</source>

      <ref id="R14">

      <label>Fig. 1.</label>
      <caption>
        <p>Consensus phylogram (50 % majority rule) resulting from a Bayesian analysis of the <italic>Dothideomycetes</italic> LSU sequence alignment. Bayesian posterior probabilities (PP) &gt; 0.74 are shown at the nodes and the scale bar represents the expected changes per site. Families and orders are indicated with coloured blocks to the right of the tree. GenBank accession or culture collection numbers are indicated behind the species names. The tree was rooted to <italic>Candida broadrunensis</italic> (GenBank KY106372.1) and the novelties treated in this study for which LSU sequence data were available are indicated in bold face.</p>
      </caption>
      <graphic xlink:href="fuse-2018-1-8-g001a"/>
      <graphic xlink:href="fuse-2018-1-8-g001b"/>
    </fig>

Bayesian posterior probabilities (PP) &gt; 0.74 are shown at the nodes and the scale bar represents the expected changes per site. Families, orders and classes are indicated with coloured blocks to the right of the tree. GenBank accession or culture collection numbers are indicated behind the species names. The tree was rooted to <italic>Orbilia vinosa</italic> (GenBank DQ470952.1) and the novelties treated in this study for which LSU sequence data were available are indicated in bold face.</p>

    <fig id="F5" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <label>Fig. 5.</label>
      <caption>
        <p>Single most parsimonious tree obtained from a phylogenetic analysis of the <italic>Alfaria</italic> ITS alignment (12 strains including the outgroup; 538 characters analysed: 306 constant, 46 variable and parsimony-uninformative and 186 parsimony-informative). The tree was rooted to <italic>Stachybotrys chlorohalonata</italic> (GenBank KU846744.1) and the scale bar indicates the number of changes. Bootstrap support values higher than 49 % are shown at the nodes and novelties are highlighted with a coloured box and bold text. Species names are indicated to the right of the tree, or before the culture collection and GenBank accession numbers. A superscript T denotes strains with a type status. Tree statistics: TL = 130, CI = 0.900, RI = 0.892, RC = 0.803.</p>
      </caption>
      <graphic xlink:href="fuse-2018-1-8-g005"/>
    </fig>

      <label>Fig. 6.</label>
      <caption>
        <p><italic>Caliciopsis maxima</italic> (CPC 24674, VIC 42568). <bold>A.</bold> Habitat where the fungus and host (<italic>Niphidium crassifolium</italic>) was found &#x2013; note growth of fern as an epiphyte on trunk of araucaria. <bold>B&#x2013;D.</bold> Detail of fern sporangia colonized by the fungus.<bold> E&#x2013;F.</bold> Detail of the ascospores aggregate formed by ascospores release. <bold>G</bold>. Squashed terminal portion of the ascomata, note the pulvurulent reddish-brown mass of ascospores. <bold>H.</bold> Detail of the percurrent proliferation of the ascoma. <bold>I.</bold> Vertical section of the upper portion of an ascoma. <bold>J.</bold> Spermogonium at the base of columnar ascomata. <bold>K.</bold> Vertical section of spermogonium, containing spermatia. <bold>L.</bold> Asci. <bold>M.</bold> Ascospores. <bold>N.</bold> Culture on PCA.     <fig id="F7" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <label>Fig. 7.</label>
      <caption>
        <p>Consensus phylogram (50 % majority rule) resulting from a Bayesian analysis of the combined ITS and LSU alignment of <italic>Caliciopsis</italic> species. Bayesian posterior probabilities are indicated at the nodes and the scale bar represents the expected changes per site. The tree was rooted to <italic>Spiromastix tentaculata</italic> (culture CBS 184.92) and the novelty treated in this study is highlighted with a coloured box and bold text. A superscript T denotes strains with a type status. GenBank accession and/or culture collection numbers are indicated behind the species names. Orders are indicated to the very right of the tree. The more basal branches were halved to facilitate easier layout. The ITS partition had 198 unique site patterns and the LSU partition had 139 unique site patterns out of the included 548 and 853 characters respectively.</p>
      </caption>
      <graphic xlink:href="fuse-2018-1-8-g007"/>
    </fig>

    <fig id="F11" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <label>Fig. 11.</label>
      <caption>
        <p>The first of three equally most parsimonious trees obtained from a phylogenetic analysis of the combined <italic>actA</italic>, <italic>chs-1</italic>, <italic>gapdh</italic> and ITS alignment representing <italic>Colletotrichum</italic> species (20 strains including the outgroup; 1 301 characters analysed: 1 038 constant, 106 variable and parsimony-uninformative and 157 parsimony-informative). The tree was rooted to <italic>Colletotrichum orchidophilum</italic> (culture CBS 632.80) and the scale bar indicates the number of changes. Bootstrap support values higher than 49 % are shown at the nodes and novelties are highlighted with a coloured box and bold text. Species names are indicated to the right of the tree and GenBank accession numbers are indicated behind the culture collection numbers. A superscript T denotes strains with a type status and branches present in the strict consensus tree are thickened. Tree statistics: TL = 366, CI = 0.839, RI = 0.904, RC = 0.758.</p>

    <fig id="F13" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <label>Fig. 13.</label>
      <caption>
        <p>The first of 72 equally most parsimonious trees obtained from a phylogenetic analysis of the ITS alignment representing the genera <italic>Cylindrium</italic>, <italic>Parapleurotheciopsis</italic>, <italic>Phlogicylindrium</italic> and <italic>Polyscytalum</italic> (34 strains including the outgroup; 538 characters analysed: 309 constant, 49 variable and parsimony-uninformative and 180 parsimony-informative). The tree was rooted to <italic>Arthrinium phragmites</italic> (GenBank KF144909.1) and the scale bar indicates the number of changes. Bootstrap support values higher than 49 % are shown at the nodes and novelties are highlighted with a coloured box and bold text. Species names are indicated to the right of the tree, or before the culture collection and GenBank accession numbers. Genera are indicated to the very right of the tree. A superscript T denotes strains with a type status and branches present in the strict consensus tree are thickened. The most basal branch was shortened three times to facilitate easier layout. Tree statistics: TL = 634, CI = 0.565, RI = 0.777, RC = 0.439.</p>
      </caption>
      <graphic xlink:href="fuse-2018-1-8-g013"/>
    </fig>
    <fig id="F14" orientation="portrait" position="float">
      <label>Fig. 14.</label>
      <caption>
        <p><italic>Cytospora viticola</italic> (CBS 143162). <bold>A.</bold> Colony on PNA. <bold>B.</bold> Colony on OA. <bold>C, D.</bold> Conidiogenous cells. <bold>E.</bold> Conidia. Scale bars = 10 &#x3BC;m.</p>

      <label>Fig. 23.</label>
      <caption>
        <p>The first of eight equally most parsimonious trees obtained from a phylogenetic analysis of the <italic>Monochaetia</italic> ITS alignment (16 strains including the outgroup; 524 characters analysed: 373 constant, 29 variable and parsimony-uninformative and 122 parsimony-informative). The tree was rooted to <italic>Neopestalotiopsis surinamensis</italic> (GenBank JX556232.1) and the scale bar indicates the number of changes. Bootstrap support values higher than 49 % are shown at the nodes and novelties are highlighted with a coloured box and bold text. Species names are indicated to the right of the tree, or before the culture collection and GenBank accession numbers. A superscript T denotes strains with a type status and branches present in the strict consensus tree are thickened. Tree statistics: TL = 238, CI = 0.782, RI = 0.899, RC = 0.702.</p>
      </caption>

        <aff id="a1"><label>1</label><institution>Non-self recognition in fungi, Institut de Biochimie et de G&#xE9;n&#xE9;tique Cellulaire, UMR 5095, CNRS - Universit&#xE9; de Bordeaux</institution>, 1 rue Camille Saint Saens, 33077 Bordeaux cedex, <country>France</country></aff>
